That fight pitted the GOP establishment backing George Bush against the more conservative and populist-oriented factions led by Jack Kemp and Pat Robertson. Durant, a national co-chairman for Kemp, helped lead the ``Anybody But Bush'' drive of Kemp and Robertson supporters that eventually lost. Some Bush backers held a grudge against Durant, but that has faded as he's campaigned hard to win support in all three camps, his campaign says. Schuette campaign director Douglas McAuliffe said his campaign has done its best to forget about 1988 and unite the party. ``Bill Schuette has been saying this over and over: There's a new level of maturity in the Michigan Republican Party. They haven't won a U.S. Senate race since 1972 and they're tired of losing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 43-Year-Old Pitcher Wins 300th Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that not all 300-game winners besides Gaylord Perry are in Hall of Fame, only those eligible. PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Ryan, who ...'; A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Nolan Ryan won his 300th game Tuesday night, pitching the Texas Rangers to an 11-3 victory over the Brewers and adding to the legend of the man who's still throwing fastballs at age 43. Ryan, who is the game's all-time strikeout leader and has a record six no-hitters, became the 20th major leaguer to get 300 victories. Except for spitballer Gaylord Perry, every pitcher to win that many games has been elected to the Hall of Fame after becoming eligible five years after retirement. Ryan, who has won 11 games and lost four this season, allowed six hits in 7 2-3 innings. He struck out eight, increasing his career total to 5,219, walked two and threw 146 pitches. It was not the overpowering, classic Ryan, but it counted. And it also served to bring baseball's focus back to the field, one day after New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner was disciplined. In fact, commissioner Fay Vincent stayed away from County Stadium, perhaps not wanting to steal attention from Ryan. The crowd of 51,533, largest of the season in Milwaukee, included 15 of Ryan's family and friends and Rangers owner George Bush, son of the president. They gave a standing ovation when he walked to the dugout before the game and loudly cheered him throughout the evening. Flash bulbs popped all during the night and ``300'' signs dotted the ballpark. At Ryan's home field in Texas, there were 7,828 people in the stands to watch the game on the scoreboard at Arlington Stadium, and fans across the country tuned in the game on TV. With Texas leading 5-1 in the eighth, two errors by second baseman Julio Franco and two singles led to two unearned runs, sabotaging Ryan's chance to finish with the complete game he wanted so much. Brad Arnsberg relieved, preserving a 5-3 lead and the win for Ryan.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Events in Liberia and Trinidad Show Gadhafi Unchanged
DOC.TEXT: Although he is more discreet nowadays, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi is still promoting revolutionary movements around the world _ as recent events in both Liberia and Trinidad demonstrate, U.S. officials and private analysts say. ``I don't think they (the Libyans) have been less active, they've been less conspicuous,'' said Robert Kuppermann, a terrorism specialist at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies. Charles Lichenstein, a distinguished fellow at the Heritage Foundation, also a Washington think tank, said Gadhafi is more prudent than he was during the early 1980s but otherwise hasn't changed much. He is still ``one of the great security threats that we have to contend with,'' Lichenstein said. A State Department official, asking not to be identified, said the Trinidad government rejected a request months ago for the import of ``medical supplies'' from Libya, suspecting that the shipment actually consisted of weapons. Over the past several days, Gadhafi's long reach has been demonstrated by the bloody upheavals under way in both Liberia and Trinidad _ two countries where rebel leaders have acknowledged receiving assistance from the North African leader. The Bush administration has sought to minimize the extent of Gadhafi's involvement in the two countries. Officials described Charles Taylor, a Liberian rebel leader and Gadhafi ally, as an opportunist with no particular philosophical underpinning. He appears to have sought out Gadhafi for help because he had nowhere else to turn, they said. As for the revolt in Trinidad, the State Department has said that although Gadhafi has provided training to the insurgents, there is no indication of a direct Libyan involvement in the seizure last Friday night of Trinidad's prime minister and dozens of other officials. Why Liberia and Trinidad? Lichenstein suggested that Liberia is an attractive target for Gadhafi because of the large array of U.S. military and communications facilities in the West African country. He added that in the event of a rebel success in Trinidad, Gadhafi could use that country as a ``launching pad'' for destabilizing other Caribbean countries. Gadhafi seems less of a preoccupation for the United States now than he was in 1986 after U.S. authorities concluded that he was behind the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque frequented by Americans. A U.S. Army sergeant was killed in the incident. President Reagan retaliated by ordering U.S. jet fighters to bomb Tripoli and Benghazi. Apparently chastened, Gadhafi virtually disappeared for an extended period but he eventually ``shook it off,'' Lichenstein said. Lichenstein said Gadhafi, nurtured by oil revenues, is continuing to support dozens of other rebel organizations, particularly radical Palestinian groups. ``His hand is still involved in various groups we don't know about,'' Lichenstein said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Proposal for Airline Child Safety Seats
DOC.TEXT: Infants and toddlers would be required to sit in child safety seats on airline flights under legislation heading to the Senate floor. The measure, approved Tuesday by the Commerce Committee, would order the Federal Aviation Administration to require the seats on domestic airline flights. It would be left to the FAA to decide a height and weight limit for children needing the seats. The committee approved the bill on a voice vote and sent it to the full Senate. No date has been scheduled for its consideration. ``This is a great step forward for this bill. We cannot continue to treat our youngest airline passengers like second-class citizens when it comes to airline safety,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., who sponsored the legislation. Currently, infants under 2 can fly free by traveling on the laps of a parent or guardian. All of the major airlines permit infants to travel in safety seats, which are attached to a regular airline seat, and generally charge a reduced fare comparable to that for children between ages 2 and 12. Unticketed infants usually can use a vacant seat at no cost. The airlines' Air Transport Association, airline unions and consumer groups have advocated mandatory safety restraints, generally for children under age 2. The legislation stemmed from the death of a 23-month-old child in a crash-landing of an airliner last year at Sioux City, Iowa. The accident killed 112 people. Three other children under age 2 were injured. A similar proposal by Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, is pending in the House. The National Transportation Safety Board has recommended that approved safety seats be required for children under 40 inches in height or weighing less than 40 pounds. The FAA has said it would consider mandatory restraints but has proposed a regulation only to require that airlines allow child seats on board if passengers want to use them _ the practice already followed by the industry. The FAA, in testimony before a House panel in mid-July, said requiring child seats would end up costing more lives than it would save. It estimated that the expense of buying tickets for infants would cause more families to travel by automobile and lead to increased numbers of traffic deaths and injuries. The Senate bill also calls for the United States to seek a similar child safety seat requirement for international flights from the International Civil Aviation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Seeks to Reassure Congress on Nuclear Waste Site
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department says it's putting some of the best scientific minds to work on the problem, but a senator compares the effort to three witches chanting over a bubbling caldron. The subject: highly radioactive wastes that have been stored for decades at the Hanford nuclear weapons facility in Washington state. There is increasing concern some of the tanks might explode and no one seems to know exactly what chemicals are inside _ or what years of radiation have done to them. ``The Hanford tanks present a serious situation, if not an imminent hazard,'' cautions the Energy Department's Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety. John Ahearne, a physicist and the panel's chairman, told a Senate hearing Tuesday that he's not ready to accept Energy Department officials' assurances that the dangers of an explosion are low. ``There's too much uncertainty,'' he said. ``There is an urgent need to determine what is in the tanks.'' For decades highly radioactive wastes were poured into underground tanks on the Hanford atomic weapons reservation, a 560-square-mile complex in south-central Washington where plutonium was processed for years for the nation's weapons program. ``We're trying to find out what's in the existing tanks,'' Leo Duffy, the Energy Department official in charge of cleanup activities at atomic waste sites, told the senators. He said some of the best scientists were trying to close ``a huge gap'' in information. Nevertheless, Duffy called the situation under control. But several senators were not as certain. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, likened it to ``trying to manage a potential bomb'' without knowing exactly what you're dealing with. And Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., calling for a more scientific approach, said the effort to date reminded him of ``three witches with a bubbling caldron, saying `bubble, bubble, toil and trouble.' They're stirring it and don't seem to know what's in there.'' Last March the Energy Department for the first time disclosed that it was worried about a chemical explosion in some of the tanks. There was concern that secondary chemical reactions might burst the tanks and release large amounts of radioactive materials. That concern was expressed even more strongly by the advisory board headed by Ahearne in a letter July 23 to Energy Secretary James Watkins. The letter was made public by Glenn's committee Tuesday. ``The technical basis for the analysis from which the (Hanford) operator draws comfort about the safety of the tanks is weak, considering the potential consequences,'' the advisory panel said. ``Each successive review of the Hanford tanks indicates that the situation is a little worse.'' Plant operators and senior DOE officials have ``only sketchy information on conditions in the tanks'' with no clear knowledge of the chemical reactions going on in the tanks and unreliable temperature sensors, the panel continued. ``There is an urgent need to determine what is in the tanks, what are the risks and what actions should be taken to ameliorate the hazards,'' the letter said. An accident involving similarly stored wastes in the Soviet Union in 1957 released huge amounts of radiation and contaminated an area covering hundreds of square miles, forcing the evacuation of 10,000 people. To this day, children are not allowed near the areas that were heavily contaminated, and agricultural crops from the region are not allowed to be sold elsewhere, officials said. But Duffy said the Soviet site is not the same as the Hanford plant. Highly radioactive wastes also are stored in tanks at the Savannah River weapons plant near Aiken, S.C., and at a plant near West Valley, N.Y., but those tanks contain different chemicals and do not pose the same risks as the tanks at Hanford, officials have said.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Chairman Sounds Alarm on Shrinking Reserves in Bank Fund
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Amid growing congressional furor over the cost of the savings and loan bailout, a top federal regulator is sounding an alarm over shrinking reserves in the fund backing commercial bank deposits. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday that ``it would not be unreasonable'' to predict a $2 billion loss in the bank fund this year. Meanwhile, at the Capitol, the House voted 424-4 Tuesday to toughen criminal penalties for rip-offs by savings and loan officials and to create a special prosecutor and a national commission on the S&L debacle. Seidman said the bank fund lost $851 million in 1989 and $4.24 billion in 1988 as bank failures soared to post-Depression highs. Nevertheless, Seidman said the fund, which is maintained through an insurance premium paid by banks, should be able to pay for any foreseeable bank failures without help from taxpayers. ``At this point, (looking at) the banks we can actually count on failing, we believe we have the resources to handle them, but that still would put us in a very much stressed position,'' he said. The 1989 and 1988 losses reduced insurance backing $2.5 trillion in deposits at the nation's 12,500 banks to 70 cents per $100 of deposits, ``the lowest point in modern history,'' Seidman said. With another loss this year, coverage could slip to 50 cents or 60 cents per $100, less than half the agency's target of $1.25 per $100, he said. Seidman's comments were his most pessimistic yet concerning the bank fund. Only two months ago, he said the fund could post a small profit absent major bank failures in 1990. Seidman indicated the FDIC board may consider an emergency hike in insurance premiums paid by banks. Those premiums, as provided by last year's savings and loan bill, are already increasing, from 8.3 cents per $100 of deposits in 1989 to 12 cents this year and 15 cents next year. However, the board has the power to raise them as high as 22.5 cents next year. Each 1 cent increase brings the fund about $250 million. ``Our board will be monitoring this very carefully and obviously that is an action they will be looking at,'' he said. Seidman said his revised assessment of the insurance fund was based on a general deterioration of the value of commercial real estate held by banks, not on any new projection of a major bank failure. So far this year, 113 banks have failed. Last year, 207 banks failed or required federal assistance to stay open, down slightly from a post-Depression record of 221 in 1988. ``Very frankly we have probably the weakest real estate markets overall that we've had for quite a few years,'' he said, adding that the weakness has spread from regional pockets in the Southwest and New England to include most areas of the country. However, Kenneth Guenther of the Independent Bankers Association of America, a trade group, said Seidman's reassessment indicates ``there are shoals under the water'' and the agency is planning for a major bank failure. ``I wonder where the big bank hits are going to come from. ... Are some of the major Texas deals going sour?'' Guenther said. The legislation that passed the House would increase the maximum prison terms _ up to life in prison for the worst offenders _ and boost fines that could be levied against individuals and institutions convicted of savings and loan crimes. It would also create new felony categories to close loopholes for those who conceal assets from the government or who try to obstruct government inquiries into financial institutions, and give the government new authority to go after the assets of failed S&Ls. The bill would authorize adding $153 million to the federal government's law enforcement efforts, and create a ``special counsel'' within the Justice Department to oversee a new Financial Institutions Fraud Unit. Banking Committee Chairman Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, one of the few to vote against the measure, said proponents hoped the measure would ``fool the American people'' that the crisis was being solved. The Senate passed its version of a savings and loan crackdown as part of an overall crime bill. The two chambers must reconcile their differences before a bill can be sent to the president.

DOC.HEAD: Did Pesticide Attack Stop Locusts, or Just Weather?
DOC.TEXT: Five years after a plague of locusts hit Africa, a congressional report says it's still unclear whether the plague was stopped by a four-year, $275 million international pesticide attack or just by the weather. A 130-page report released Tuesday by Congress' Office of Technology Assessment failed to resolve whether the weather, or the massive pesticide effort, should get credit for stopping the plague. In 1985, locusts and grasshoppers attacked 23 countries from Portugal to Tanzania, and from Iran to the Atlantic. In 1988, Hurricane Gilbert blew fragments of locust swarms to the Yucatan coast of Mexico, though apparently they did little damage there. ``Some claim this is the first time a desert locust plague has been stopped in its tracks and that the control program deserves full credit ... They seem to be right,'' the report said. ``Yet, others contend that the weather contributed more than control to the insects' decline ... They also seem to be right.'' Of the 46 governments and 12 international organizations that joined in the attack, the United States contributed the largest amount, giving nearly $59 million from the Agency for International Development. Andrew Natsios, who heads the agency's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, said the control program was a success, though he acknowledged weather may have had something to do with the fading of the threat. He called the report self-contradictory. ``None of the people on the survey ever went to Africa,'' he said. The report praised the agency for coordinating efforts of other U.S. agencies, international donors and African officials. But it suggested that too much pesticide was used _ about 3.4 million gallons _ and that there ought to be more research on how to use the pests' own habits against them. So far, scientists have not found ways to do that.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Studying Wider Impact Of North Decision
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is concerned that Oliver North's victory before an appeals court could have a wider impact affecting other cases involving defendants who testify under a similar promise of immunity. Officials are reviewing the decision, which held that the trial judge did not take proper steps to determine if North's congressional testimony influenced his trial, said Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian. The department does not have a direct interest in the North case because the former White House aide was prosecuted by independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh. In a 2-1 decision last month, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington ordered a ``witness-by-witness'' and review of the evidence presented at North's trial to determine if it was ``tainted'' by references to the testimony the former White House aide gave under a limited grant of immunity from prosecution. That ``use immunity'' barred Walsh from using any of North's testimony or information derived from it to prosecute the former Marine lieutenant colonel. Eramian said Justice Department prosecutors were concerned about the case's impact in a limited number of cases in which a defendant is prosecuted after testifying before Congress amidst widespread publicity. Justice Department officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the decision could have more widespread applications, as in case where courts or grand juries grant ``use immunity.'' The procedural requirements set down by the court could be impossible for prosecutors to meet, the officials said. Eramian stressed that the department was not necessarily considering participating in any appeal that Walsh might undertake. But if Walsh appeals the decision, the Justice Department could file a brief stating its legal position. Walsh has more than a month to decide whether to appeal the ruling to the full appellate court or ask the Supreme Court to review the issue. North's week-long appearance on Capitol Hill in 1987 received widespread television and newspaper coverage, which his lawyers contend affected the memories of witnesses in the case. The former National Security Council aide was placed on probation and ordered to perform 1,500 hours of community service for his three felony convictions. Some legal experts say the decision by two appellate judges appointed by President Reagan radically extended a 1972 Supreme Court decision that prohibits prosecutors from introducing a defendant's compelled testimony as evidence. ``What they did in this case was to virtually change use immunity into transactional immunity,'' under which the government agrees not to prosecute someone in return for their cooperation, said G. Robert Blakey, a Notre Dame law professor who drafted the 1970 use immunity statute. The court, in effect, created a rule that ``once anything was disseminated as widely as North's testimony, it necessarily affected the trial,'' Blakey said. ``There was nothing particularly unusual about the North testimony that it would irretrievably taint anybody who read it.'' The two circuit judges who joined in the ruling, Laurence H. Silberman, and David Sentelle, were both appointed by Reagan and are generally regarded as members of the court's conservative wing. Patricia Wald, the appellate court's chief judge and the dissenter in the North case, was appointed by President Carter. ``The two majority judges simply let North off,'' Blakey said. ``If that sort of solicitude was paid to criminal defendants generally, we wouldn't be talking about Reagan judges.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Urges Congress to Hold Down Clean Air Costs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's top economic adviser says no matter what additional clean air controls are approved by Congress it will be expensive to the economy and result in job losses for some workers. Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, urged Senate and House negotiators to hold down the cost of compromise clean air legislation and reiterated that Bush opposes any bill that is substantially more expensive than the $20 billion a year proposals he made last year. ``The president is not prepared to see American firms, workers and consumers overcharged or to see economic growth slowed needlessly,'' Boskin said in a letter to Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich. Dingell, who heads the House negotiating team trying to work out a compromise clean air bill with the Senate, had asked for an economic assessment of the air pollution controls being considered on Capitol Hill. House and Senate staff members, meanwhile, met most of Tuesday and were expected to continue discussions through the week as the two chambers work out differences in clean air bills approved earlier this year. A compromise bill is unlikely to emerge from conference before late September. In his letter to Dingell, Boskin belittled suggestions that most of the additional costs to the economy of tougher air pollution controls could be offset by savings elsewhere. Instead, he said, the tighter controls will result in reduced productivity and hamper U.S. industry's ability to compete with foreign industries. Environmentalists, congressional supporters of tough new pollution controls as well as some senior officials of the Environmental Protection Agency have argued that the substantial costs imposed on industry by the new clean air requirements would be offset by reduced health care spending and growth in new industries spawned by the need for pollution controls. EPA Administrator William Reilly has been among those who have argued that while some industries may suffer from the new requirements, other businesses dealing in pollution control activities may prosper and provide new jobs as well as new exports. ``The assertion ... that expanded clean air programs would on balance create jobs, increase productivity and make the U.S. economy more competitive in world markets are at best wishful thinking,'' Boskin wrote. A spokesman for Reilly said the EPA chief agrees with Boskin's analysis. ``Reilly and Boskin are eye to eye on this,'' said EPA spokesman Dave Cohen. Boskin said the administration proposal to Congress would have added about $20 billion a year in new pollution control costs to the economy by the time all the new requirements go into effect in the year 2005. He said the bills approved by both the House and Senate would cost $25 billion, somewhat higher than previous administration estimates for the Senate bill of $21.5 billion. There was no explanation for the difference. But Boskin said if the most costly features of both the House and Senate bills are kept in a final bill the cost could increase to $35 billion a year. President Bush has threatened to veto any clean air legislation he considers too costly or a threat to economic growth. But Boskin said that Bush all along has known that tougher air pollution controls will be costly. ``He is fully aware that any environmentally strong clean air bill will reduce real income growth and cause some temporary unemployment. ... The president believes that our nation is able and should be willing to pay a reasonable price to clean its air.''

DOC.HEAD: America Heading Toward Record-Breaking Murder Toll, Panel Says
With PM-Murders-States
DOC.TEXT: America is heading toward a record-breaking murder toll this year as a result of increasing quantities of assault weapons and drying up supplies of cocaine, according to a Senate committee. ``We are in the midst of a growing epidemic of homicide,'' Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said Tuesday in releasing the committee's grisly forecast. The report predicted that there would be 23,220 murders across the nation this year, about 2,000 more than the figure for 1989 and ahead of the previous record of 23,040, which was set in 1980. America's murder rate of 10.5 per 100,000 people makes it ``the most murderous industrialized nation'' in the world, the panel said. In Great Britain, the rate is 0.8 per 100,000; in Japan, 1.0; in West Germany, 1.2. The report said the upsurge can partially be traced to dwindling supplies of cocaine in major cities that have escalated the drug wars. In addition, the report pinned increased murders on a growing arsenal of assault rifles it called ``the weapons of choice for drug dealers and the weapons of doom for law enforcement personnel.'' The National Rifle Association, however, scoffed at that statement. ``Every study done by law enforcement agencies, including the FBI, the New York Police Department and the Florida Assault Weapons Commission, demonstrates the minuscule involvement of such weapons in criminal violence,'' said NRA federal liaison David Conover. The Judiciary Committee also cited a fresh wave of jobless, crime-prone teen-agers as a reason for the increase in killings. The committee said ``cocaine prices are up and purity levels are down. ``This means supplies are scarce. And that, in turn, means that drug dealers are going to be fighting for their turf and customers. ``The more they fight, the higher the death toll, a tragic consequence of winning the `war on drugs.''' The report said that since 1985, ``a new crop of 18- to 24 year-olds with all of their attendant violence has become an abnormally large segment of the population.'' The nation's murder total fell 18 percent from 1980 to 1985 but has risen 22 percent since then. Dr. Lynn Richardson, associate chief of emergency services at New York's Harlem Hospital Center, told lawmakers of a young woman rushed in several weeks ago. The right side of her head had been blown away by a rifle in an apparent drug shootout. She said doctors saved a 6{-month fetus and that the child is clinging to life. Philadelphia Police Commissioner Willie L. Williams said 35 percent of his city's killings last year were related to drugs. ``We now have drug dealers who shoot it out with semiautomatic weapons on our streets, murdering innocent children,'' Williams added. Professor James A. Fox of the College of Criminal Justice at Northeastern University in Boston said crime might get worse as unemployment and pregnancy among youths now just becoming teen-agers rises as well. ``In fact, the forecasting model developed 15 years ago indicates a resurgence in violence in the 1990s,'' Fox said. ``The worst may be yet to come.'' Drawing on FBI figures, the committee said California led the nation in murders last year with 3,158. The panel projected violent deaths this year in the nation's most-populous state at 3,442, a 9 percent increase. The largest percentage increase projected by the committee was in Idaho, which had 26 murders last year. The panel projected a 50 percent increase to 39 this year. The greatest percentage decrease predicted was 67 percent in both New Hampshire and North Dakota. New Hampshire had 36 murders last year; the forecast is for 12 this year. North Dakota had four murders last year, the lowest in the nation; the projection is for one this year.

DOC.HEAD: Debate Over Damages in Civil Rights Bill Intensifies
DOC.TEXT: Women's groups are fighting moves to cap job discrimination damages allowed under a major civil rights bill, while the White House supports such a plan as a way to head off a ``bonanza'' for trial lawyers. ``Women are at risk of being sacrificed once again on the altar of business interests,'' Patricia Ireland, vice president of the National Organization for Women, told a news conference Tuesday. The debate over job discrimination damages for women, members of religious minorities and the physically handicapped intensified as the House prepared to debate the civil rights bill. The measure, similar to a bill already passed by the Senate, appears likely to come to the House floor later this week. The Bush administration says the bill would lead to the use of hiring quotas and has been threatening a presidential veto unless it is changed. Major provisions range from a ban on harassment in the workplace to barriers to reopening court-approved fair-hiring agreements. The bill provides for open-ended damages for women who are victims of intentional discrimination, such as sexual harassment or refusal to hire based on gender. Critics say it will encourage discrimination suits because lawyers will be hungry to share in sizeable damages awards. Opponents are hoping to insert limits on damages when the bill comes to the House floor. Women's groups and bill sponsors dislike the idea of limits because a 1981 law allows open-ended damages for racial bias in the workplace. They envision cases in which black women _ alleging racial discrimination _ could collect more than white women in lawsuits against the same employer. ``While we strongly support the elimination of discrimination in the workplace, it is impossible for us to condone secondary status based on gender, religion or physical ability,'' said Joan Bronk, president of the National Council of Jewish Women. ``It is totally unacceptable to write into law, for the first time so clearly and consciously, that sex discrimination on the job is someone less offensive than race discrimination,'' Ireland said. There has been speculation, however, that support for the measure among conservative southern Democrats could wither if a cap on damages is not added at some point before the measure is sent to President Bush's desk. At the White House, deputy press secretary Alixe Glen praised a measure sponsored by Rep. John J. LaFalce, D-N.Y. The proposal would allow compensatory payments of up to $100,000 in discrimination cases in which the court felt it were necessary to deter the employer from persisting in bias. The plan would also soften provisions that would make it easier for those filing discrimination suits to win cases based on statistics. Glen said the LaFalce plan ``represents a bipartisan consensus in the House'' that would lessen the likelihood of quota hiring and ``constrains the potential litigation bonanza for trial lawyers by limiting damages to appropriate cases.'' ``We hope and expect the Democratic leadership to allow a vote on the LaFalce substitute,'' said Ms. Glen, who acknowledged the LaFalce amendment was similar to a plan defeated in the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Rock 'n' roller John Cougar Mellencamp plays a country singer in his first movie, being filmed in his native Indiana. ``Souvenirs,'' which also stars Mariel Hemingway, Claude Akins and Kay Lenz, is based on a story by Mellencamp. Larry McMurtry, whose credits include ``The Last Picture Show'' and ``Terms of Endearment,'' wrote the screenplay. Mellencamp plays a country singer who returns to Indiana to celebrate his grandfather's birthday. Once back, the singer is confronted by family issues he neglected during his climb to fame, Mellencamp manager Harry Sandler and publicist Kathy Schenker said. Mellencamp's hits include ``Jack and Diane,'' ``Pink Houses'' ``Small Town'' and ``Hurts So Good.''

Roger Craig, the San Francisco 49ers running back who posed in his underwear and then only a towel for Macy's ads, says the strip show is over. ``My wife says no more. It's time to concentrate on football,'' the football player said Monday at training camp. But Craig will remain in the public eye. The 205-pound athlete has made a workout video, ``Turn it Up a Notch,'' that will be released in August. He also will appear in the movie ``Dark Obsession,'' which comes out this fall. Craig has modeled for six years but didn't draw much attention until this summer when he posed in Calvin Klein underwear. Macy's made a poster of the ad at the request of fans. In another ad, he wore only a towel.

``Pretty Woman? Pretty Low.'' That's what the 4-by-5-inch advertisement in today's Variety says to Julia Roberts. The ad in the show business publication was placed after Ms. Roberts called Abbeville, S.C., ``horribly racist'' and a ``living hell'' in the Aug. 9 issue of Rolling Stone. The Oscar-nominated actress was here in May filming ``Sleeping With the Enemy,'' which has yet to be released. She stars with Richard Gere in the box office hit ``Pretty Woman.'' More than 100 residents contributed money for the $467 ad signed by Proud Citizens of Upstate South Carolina. ``Are there racists here?'' says the ad. ``Perhaps some, as there are throughout the world. But they do not define us. ... Our area may not offer the glamour of Hollywood, but this is our home. And we love it.''

Joan Lunden says she is not leaving ``Good Morning America,'' getting a divorce or even having an alien's baby. Lunden told viewers of ABC's morning show all this Tuesday after she said National Enquirer reporters were asking her colleagues if she seems troubled lately. ``It was a pre-emptive strike,'' she said afterward. ``I told them I could either do that or just be a wimp and sit back and let them make up whatever they want and print it.'' Ian Calder, editor of the tabloid in Lantana, Fla., said the queries about Lunden concerned problems her husband, a TV producer, has had with lawsuits over production bills for ``Everyday,'' a syndicated program on which Lunden is host. ``As far as I know, this was just something we were checking out and we've no plans to run a story,'' Calder said.

Cornerback Lewis Billups of the Cincinnati Bengals was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $1,000 for pointing a gun at two undercover police officers in January. Common Pleas Judge Ralph Winkler on Tuesday sentenced the 25-year-old football player for menacing and improper handling of a firearm while in a vehicle. Billups had pleaded guilty to the misdemeanors. Because of a sentencing backlog, Billups probably won't begin serving his sentence until January or February, Winkler said. Two police officers said Billups pointed a pistol at them Jan. 4, then led them on a chase into Kentucky, where Billups lives.

Grammy winner Harry Nilsson, who sang the theme ``Everybody's Talkin''' from the Academy Award-winning film ``Midnight Cowboy,'' has been charged with drunken driving. Nilsson, 49, was stopped July 6, and tests showed his blood-alcohol level at .23 or .24 percent, three times the legal limit of .08, Deputy District Attorney Elden Fox said. Nilsson won the 1972 Grammy for best male pop vocal performance for ``Without You.''

DOC.HEAD: Housing Bill Under Veto Threat
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The House is completing work on a comprehensive housing bill that is under a veto threat because it disregards a presidential demand for higher down payments on mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration. The legislation, expected to pass today, must be reconciled with a different Senate version that includes the tougher administration down payment requirements. President Bush threatened to veto any bill that would not keep the FHA insurance fund solvent at a time of escalating defaults. Even before the House voted overwhelmingly Tuesday night to require roughly the same cash down payments as under current law, Bush warned that such a requirement would be unacceptable. The FHA language was the main focus of debate Tuesday night, but it is only a portion of legislation that would authorize about $28 billion for the government's housing and home ownership programs for fiscal 1991. The comprehensive legislation would establish new programs to help first-time home buyers, permit low-income Americans receiving public housing assistance to own their homes, and encourage production of new rental housing. Both the administration and House members agreed to an annual fee to be charged home buyers in order to keep the FHA insurance fund solvent _ with the administration's proposed charge slightly smaller. But the House plan, adopted 418-2, also requires the lower down payment requirements. It was sponsored by Reps. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., and Thomas Ridge, R-Pa. The administration maintains that Americans qualifying for FHA mortgages should pay more up front than under current regulations because those who put up more cash will be less likely to default. Vento and Ridge argued the administration's down payment requirements would make it impossible for thousands of Americans to buy a home. The FHA payments at settlement would vary with the price of the house. Under the Vento-Ridge language, Americans buying a $65,000 home would pay up-front charges of $4,115. The administration would require payments of $4,939 on the same house. The higher cost proposed by the administration would result from a requirement that buyers pay two-thirds of the closing cost at settlement. The Vento-Ridge language would allow the closing costs to be financed through monthly mortgage payments. The FHA changes were a reaction to an analysis by the Price Waterhouse accounting firm, which said the insurance fund is currently solvent, but is losing money at an alarmingly fast rate. The administration contends the savings and loan crisis has demonstrated the dangers of allowing an undercapitalized federal insurance program to operate on an unsound basis. Supporters of the Vento-Ridge provision said the administration plan would exclude up to 100,000 potential home buyers. The administration has maintained that no more than 35,000 people would be shut out. Voting against Vento-Ridge were Reps. Thomas Petri, R-Wis. and Jim Cooper, D-Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Borscht Belt Resort Facing Liquidation
DOC.TEXT: Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club, the Borscht Belt retreat that launched Eddie Fisher's career and helped Jack Dempsey develop his punch, will soon be little more than a summer memory. The Catskills hotel, which entertained 100,000 guests a year in its heyday in the 1940s and '50s, probably will be sold off piecemeal to end years of financial trouble, said Barbara Balliber-Strauss, its bankruptcy trustee. The 812-acre resort in the town of Liberty has been empty since 1986, when it was closed for a $30 million renovation and expansion project that never was completed. Before air conditioning and convenient air travel, a getaway for hot, tired New Yorkers meant a two-hour drive to the Catskill Mountains. But like many resort areas close to big cities, the Catskills faded as other parts of the world became more accessible and an extended summer siesta became unfashionable. Grossinger's went into a slide with other hotels in the region. Joe Risitano, 60, who has vacationed in the Catskills since 1948, was hired as a security guard at Grossinger's and said he spent Tuesday turning away people curious to see the hotel. ``A lot of people are saying their grandparents stayed here and always talked about it,'' he said. ``Now they want to see it. It's nostalgia, you know.'' Fisher, who made his debut at Grossinger's 41 years ago and was discovered there _ as legend has it _ by Eddie Cantor, returned to help kick off the facelift in 1986, which was halted in 1989. More than a dozen contractors filed liens of more than $8.7 million against the owners, contending they had not been paid. The owners, a group of New York City investors, had bought the resort from the Grossinger family in 1985. The financial trouble is a far cry from the heydy of Grossinger's and other resorts in the Catskills, known as the Borscht Belt for the Jewish crowd that vacationed there and the Jewish singers and comics who entertained them. Grossinger's had it all _ a 27-hole golf course, ski slope, indoor and outdoor pools and tennis courts, post office, shopping arcade, two kosher kitchens and a 1,500-seat dining room. Dempsey, Rocky Marciano, Ken Norton and Michael Spinks trained there. Lucille Ball performed at the resort's two nightclubs. Joel Grey and Leslie Uggams advanced their careers at Grossinger's. Mamie Eisenhower was one of many political figures who regularly vacationed at the 600-room resort, famous for its all-you-can-eat meals three times a day, including a breakfast menu that included seven styles of herring. The resort was opened in 1914 by Austrian immigrants, Selig and Mahlke Grossinger. Losing money, the family sold it for $9 million in 1985 to Grossinger's Associates, an unrelated group of investors. Last December, the owners filed for protection from creditors in U.S. Bankruptcy Court under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Balliber-Strauss said the hotel and its contents likely will be liquidated under Chapter 7. ``What we plan to do is meet with lenders in order to determine the best approach to take,'' Balliber-Strauss said. In his ``The Glory and the Dream,'' William Manchester listed the first ``Singles Only'' weekend held at Grossinger's among the greater events of 1962, followed by John Glenn's spaceflight and the Cuban missile crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Baker's Visit Tame In Annals of US-Mongolia Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Many Mongolians use only one name.
DOC.TEXT: In the annals of U.S.-Mongolia relations, Secretary of State James A. Baker III's visit starting Thursday will rank as relatively tame. American adverturer-businessmen were running car services between the Chinese border and Ulan Bator, then called Urga, as early as 1916, and were embroiled in smuggling, kidnappings and shootouts. Their Cadillacs and Dodges were the first cars in this landlocked Central Asian nation, whose very name for many Americans epitomizes things remote, exotic and dangerous. The first official U.S. envoy came in 1920 from Beijing to evaluate a plea from Mongolian princes for help in ousting their Chinese overlords. But when Mongolian revolutionaries made their move in 1921, it was the Soviet Red Army that helped, starting a seven-decade alliance that sealed off Mongolia from the West more effectively than geography. One brief contact came in July 1944, the Communist Party newspaper Unen recently reported, when U.S. Vice President Henry Wallace stopped in Ulan Bator while traveling between China and the Soviet city of Irkutsk. The United States and Soviet Union were World War II allies, and Mongolian soldiers also were fighting the Japanese. Unen said reporters were keen for their first look at an American. But ``he was very ordinary,'' the paper said. ``He emerged without any hat, dressed in a very light suit and without any tie.'' Wallace, who like Baker stayed three days, met with then-dictator Marshal Horloogiyn Choybalsan, visited museums, took in a play and met Mongolian horsemen, whom he surprised with his knowledge of racehorses. Another contact came in the early 1960s, after the United States stopped blocking Mongolian entry into the United Nations. Mongolia invited U.S. Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas to visit, and he gave lectures on the U.S. legal system. American hunters began arriving in 1967, starting up what has become a multimillion-dollar safari industry for Mongolia. Negotiations on establishing diplomatic relations failed, however, both in the early 1960s and in the late 1970s. Finally, as the Cold War thawed, relations were established in 1987. The United States sent its first resident ambassador in June, even as the Soviet Union continued pulling its troops out. A complete Soviet troop withdrawal is scheduled for 1992. But Americans are still relatively rare in Ulan Bator, which bears a heavy Soviet stamp in its architecture, food and consumer goods. The Cadillacs and Dodges are long gone, replaced by official fleets of boxy black Berras from the Soviet Union. Ordinary Mongolians said they were surprised to hear of Baker's visit. Many people in Washington were, too; despite its location between China and the Soviet Union, Mongolia is not key to American strategic planning. One motive appears to be Baker's interest in hunting. He will spend two days on a private hunting and fishing expedition in the Gobi Desert. U.S. officials say Baker also will sign a consular agreement and an agreement to send Peace Corps volunteers. They are expected to start teaching English next year. The two sides also are negotiating a general trade agreement. Mongolia is seeking most-favored-nation trade status from the United States, which would entitle it to the lowest tariffs on its exports. Total trade between the countries last year was $1.6 million. Baker also will meet with Mongolia's Communist leaders and representatives of new opposition parties that contended in the country's first free elections Sunday. Nyamdoo, the Mongolian ambassador to Washington, said Baker did not confirm his trip until the opposition dropped its threat to boycott the elections. The State Department said the visit ``serves to demonstrate our support for Mongolia's peaceful democratic reform process.'' It is a subtle slap at neighboring China, with whom the Washington has halted most high-level visits since the Chinese army attacked pro-democracy protesters in Beijing in June 1989. It would have been natural for Baker to stop in Beijing, which is a main gateway to Mongolia. Opposition activists say they hope to learn from the U.S. democratic system. They want U.S. investment and development aid to reduce Mongolia's dependence on the Soviets. The Mongolian government also wants trade, investment and technology. ``Mongolia is ready to get anything he can give to us,'' Deputy Foreign Minister Choinhor said jokingly Monday. American businessmen are slowly starting contacts. The New York-based textile company Amicale Industries recently started a joint venture in Mongolia to process camel hair. Exploration Associates of Houston is searching for oil, and Ringling Brothers' circus has signed up Mongolian circus acts. Mongolian vodka is expected to appear in U.S. stores next year. One measure of Mongolian interest in the United States came when a group of scholars founded the Mongolia-U.S. Association in May. Gonchigdorj, a founding member, said 500 people showed up for the first meeting.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Campaign Finance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the major issues in campaign finance legislation before the Senate:

Democrats want to set voluntary limits on how much Senate candidates can spend in primary and general elections. Overall, the ceilings would range from just under $2 million for a candidate from a small state to $10.3 million in California. Candidates could exceed the general election caps by 25 percent with contributions of $100 or less from in-state voters. Republicans oppose absolute ceilings, saying they inhibit the ability of challengers to raise enough money to overcome incumbents. They offer ``flexible'' ceilings that would exempt money from in-state donors and out-of-state contributions of $250 or less.

Democrats offer a variety of incentives to encourage candidates to abide by voluntary spending limits. They would offer Senate candidates a total of $20 million in government vouchers every two-year election cycle to help pay for certain TV and radio ads. Republicans offer no public financing proposals.

Democrats would retain the current $1,000 limit that an individual can contribute for each primary and general election. The $25,000 annual limit on what an individual can give to all candidates and party committees would be raised to $30,000. Republicans would halve the $1,000 ceiling on individual contributions from non-state residents. But they would exempt gifts to national and state party committees from the ceiling, allowing individuals to give up to $340,000 a year.

Both parties have agreed to a proposal by President Bush to ban corporate, union and trade association political action committees. They doubt the ban could be extended to ideological PACs, keyed to issues such as abortion or gun control, because of constitutional questions.

Democrats would put new limits on spending by state party organizations for voter registration, education and turnout activities. Republicans have no fixed ceiling on such spending. But they would require state parties to subject a third of such expenses to federal limits on contributions.

Democrats would limit a candidate's contributions to his own campaign to $250,000 and bar candidates from repaying the money with contributions received after an election. Republicans would do the same. They also would let the opponents of candidates who use more than $250,000 of their own money raise contributions of up to $5,000 from individuals, up from $1,000 otherwise.=
DOC.HEAD: MAIL
DOC.TEXT: Democrats would use public funds to subsidize three-fourths of the cost of first-class campaign mail, up to a certain limit. Republicans would forbid members of Congress from using their franking privilege for mass mailings during an election year.
Both parties would require broadcasters to make their best advertising slots available to candidates 45 days before a primary and 60 days before a general election, at lower-than standard rates.
