DOC.BYLINE: City Opera Season Opens With ``Marriage of Figaro'' ^By DANIEL J. WAKIN
DOC.TEXT: Opening night at the New York City Opera revealed many of the reasons why sometimes it's worth going there rather than to the nation's leading opera house next door. It's not too often that the neighboring Metropolitan Opera engages a cast of relatively unknown American singers to render a well-acted, appealing performance without the distractions of star turns. The City Opera did it Tuesday with ``The Marriage of Figaro'' _ not sublime Mozart and not a transcendent musical experience, but yet a satisfying theatrical one. City Opera had to cancel much of its last season because of a strike, settled early this year. And Tuesday's was its first performance under new director Christopher Keene. The singers responded well to each other and the action was completely in harmony with the notes, conducted by Scott Bergeson. There was some heaviness in moving passages and the singers at times seemed to produce blocks of notes rather than lines, but generally Bergeson kept things moving. The ensembles _ really the glories of ``Figaro'' _ were well-balanced. Intonation problems surfaced occasionally in the orchestra. The sets and costumes of Carl Toms were straightforwardly 18th century, spare and unencumbered by Rococco ornament, but warm with wood paneling and ochre colors. John Copley's direction of this 1977-production was completely engaging, but most engaging of all was Maureen O'Flynn's Susanna. She showed that a small voice spinning focused lines with dramatic feeling conveyed through the notes is better than any prima donna display. ``Figaro'' is really a work about love and all its handmaidens: jealousy, lust, marital fidelity, ardor and trust. O'Flynn, with agility, displayed all of these. Her interplay with Dean Peterson's Figaro was completely convincing. O'Flynn was full of charming touches: the saucy curtsy when the Count discovers it is her, not a lover, in his wife's closet, her prompting of Figaro when the Count questions him about a letter, her demure (feigned) acquiescence to the Count's advances. Peterson was a fine match for the pert O'Flynn _ tall, athletic, graceful and able to move quick from smiling cockiness to bewilderment as his fortunes changed moment to moment in the battle of wits with the Count. Peterson sang well, but his voice had a gruff quality that's not really suited to Figaro's character. It is perfect for Masetto, the rough peasant hot-head in ``Don Giovanni.'' He showed great aplomb in the opening scene when a mannikin holding the Count's cloak and wig fell over. He picked it up, put back the dummy's head and even gave it a pat, all the while continuing his part unfazed. William Stone was a fine Count Almaviva, a character much like Don Giovanni confined to his house (and servants). He brought the fierceness necessary to make us believe the fear of his jealousy by the Countess, sung by Renee Fleming. Fleming, who's won a good many awards and seems to be on her way, evoked a mixed reaction. Her voice is creamy and she too is no wig-carrying manikin as an actress. Her third act aria ``Dove sono'' had a breathtaking soft section. But at times, particularly in the ``Porgi, amor'' cavatina that opens Act II, Fleming tended to eat words and add so much expression to each note that the melody's sense of direction was lost. She also had to zero in a few times on the right pitch, though her entrance in ``Porgi, amor'' was perfect. The only real disappointment of the night was Cynthia Rose in the pants role of Cherubino, the hopeless adolescent wooer of older women. She blared out loud notes and struck only false ones in her stage business, often smiling inappropriately, capering awkwardly and showing none of the sensuality this role needs. John Calvin West made his debut as Dr. Bartolo and bellowed a little in his ``Vendetta'' aria, but was an amusing presence. Even more so was the dried up, quavering Don Basilio of Jerold Siena, down to his sagging left sock.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Trafficking Trial of Sacramento Man Begins
DOC.TEXT: The trial began today of the first American to be charged under Malaysia's strict drug laws, which carry a mandatory death sentence for those convicted of drug trafficking. Kerry Lane Wiley, 38, of Sacramento, Calif., is being tried on charges he had 16.85 ounces of marijuana in his possession in November. Under Malaysian law, sale need not be proven for trafficking. Mere possession of 100 grams or more of marijuana or 100 grams of heroin is deemed to be trafficking. Customs officials said Wiley, a lecturer in computers at a college in Hawaii, entered Malaysia from Bangkok and was staying at a friend's house when police raided it and found the drugs among Wiley's belongings. Police said they were tipped off about the drugs. Since 1975, when Parliament allowed the death penalty for drug trafficking, 340 people have been sentenced to death. Of these, 112 have been hanged, including about 30 foreigners. Wiley is the first American charged under the tough laws. At today's proceedings, Judge Shaik Daud Ismail granted defense counsel Mohamad Shafee Abdullah's request that Wiley's trial be conducted in English. Malaysia recently made the native Malay language the official language of the court system, replacing English. Malaysia is a former British colony that won independence in 1957. The court agreed to dispense with the new policy since it said Wiley would not be able to understand the trial. The trial is scheduled to run until Aug. 11, then resume again Aug. 20. Those charged with drug trafficking do not qualify for bail, and Wiley has been confined to Kuala Lumpur's Pudu Prison.

DOC.HEAD: Army: Israeli Patrol Boat Kills Two In Guerrilla Raft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD details from Lebanese police, witnesses, LEADS with 6 grafs. Picks up 4th pvs, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli navy patrol boat attacked and sank a rubber guerrilla boat off southern Lebanon early today, killing the two men aboard, the army command said. It said in a communique that a Dvora patrol boat opened fire on the boat after identifying it as hostile. The army said no one on the Israeli boat was injured. The affiliation of the slain guerrillas was not immediately known. A Lebanese police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said an Israeli gunboat and a helicopter gunship spotted the motorized rubber dinghy north of the Lebanese port city of Tyre at about 4 a.m. Witnesses watched the 30-minute clash from rooftops and the city's coast. One witness, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``The gunboat and helicopter exchanged fire with the guerrillas in the dinghy. The dinghy was zigzaging at high speed in an effort to escape the Israeli fire. ``Suddenly, the dinghy blew up. There was a circle of fire in the sea for five minutes.'' It was the first seaborne attempt to infiltrate into Israel since June. On June 23, a Dvora patrol boat ran down a speedboat heading toward the Israeli border settlement of Rosh Haniqra and killed the two guerrillas aboard, who were armed with rocket-propelled grenades and automatic rifles. Responsibility for that attack was claimed by a fundamentalist faction of Lebanese Sunni Moslems, traditional PLO allies in Lebanon. On the Jewish holiday of Shavuot in May, powerboats carrying heavily armed Palestinians from Abul Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front outran slower Dvora patrols and landed near a crowded beach before four Arabs were killed and seven captured.

DOC.HEAD: Cargo Ship in Danger of Sinking Off Cape Cod
DOC.TEXT: A Greek cargo ship caught off Cape Cod in Hurricane Bertha was in danger of sinking early today, the Coast Guard said. The Corazon, with a crew of 27, lost part of its bow and its midsection buckled, causing one end to lift up, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Lionel Bryant. The ship was about 340 miles east-southeast of Cape Cod, he said. The 593-foot vessel loaded with concrete was buffeted by 80 mph winds and 20- to 25-foot seas, Bryant said. Bertha was about 60 miles from the ship and ``headed right toward them,'' Bryan said. The hurricane was expected to reach the ship by noon. ``The keel is broken at midship and waves are crashing over the middle,'' Bryant said. ``That's lifting the stern out of the water.'' Bryant said a Coast Guard cutter headed for the Corazon to help. A Liberian merchant ship was about two miles from the Corazon and a Coast Guard aircraft circled above, but a rescue was not immediately attempted, Bryant said. ``Any type of rescue could be quite hazardous,'' Bryant said. The cargo ship was headed for New York when it reported trouble Tuesday afternoon, Bryant said. It was unclear whether the damage to the ship was caused by the storm, he said.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Issues Smog-Cutting Proposals; Bans on Driving Contemplated
DOC.TEXT: Motorists in car-crazy Southern California would have to leave their wheels at home every other day under proposals offered by the Environmental Protection Agency for cleaning up the nation's dirtiest air. The plan offered Tuesday is aimed at cutting ozone _ a major component of smog _ by 86 percent by early next century. It is a backup to a clean-air plan approved in 1989 by the South Coast Air Quality Management District. The EPA plan would take effect only if state and regional governments in the district's area fail to reduce smog significantly. The EPA proposals were prompted by a lawsuit filed by environmentalists in 1982. ``We have been very concerned that the local district has been backsliding,'' said Jan Chatten-Brown, president of the Coalition for Clean Air. ``This plan will send a clear message ... if the district won't do the job, the EPA will step in.'' The EPA guidelines include a proposal for no-drive days if other methods fail to reduce ozone. Such a plan would use odd or even numbers on license plates to assign alternate driving days for the area's 12 million motorists. ``It is in the spirit of presenting all possibilities that we are presenting the no-drive day. ... It is not one we are endorsing,'' said Daniel W. McGovern, EPA Western regional administrative director. ``State and local authorities have been engaged in an extraordinary effort to address this problem themselves, which we all hope will render a federal plan as unnecessary.'' Other features of the EPA plan include reduction of emissions by 6 percent a year from pollution sources such as household products, industrial solvents and pesticides; extending pollution control standards to construction equipment, pleasure boats and off-road vehicles, and a requirement that new motor vehicles are 85 percent to 90 percent cleaner than current vehicles. The current three-step AQMD plan affects everything from lawn mowers to refineries, at an estimated cost of $2.62 billion a year. But later steps of that plan include the use of technology not yet developed, making its effectiveness a guessing game. In 1988, the most recent year available, Los Angeles exceeded the national standard for ozone 150 times, compared with 20 times for New York and Chicago. The federal plan takes longer to achieve goals set by the regional agency. The AQMD plan calls for reducing current ozone averages by 86 percent in 2007; the EPA by 2010.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I felt in the past that the committee would never get the message. The world's changing and even Armed Services can change'' _ Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., after the traditionally pro-Pentagon panel approved by a 40-12 margin a bill that makes deep cuts in defense spending.

``The initiative, if it's passed, threatens to change Alaska into something radically different from what it is today'' _ Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper, who opposes a measure to legalize casino gambling in his state.

``The coverage thus far never shows you this. All you get is what is in the mind of the writer. And we want our coverage to let the viewer decide, with both sides presented'' _ John VanScoyoc, managing editor of a public TV station in Boston that showed Robert Mapplethorpe's most sexually explicit photos in advance of today's opening of the exhibit.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall, Dollar At Five-Month Low
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key indicator erased its morning gains and fell back today, while the dollar closed at the lowest level against the Japanese yen in five months. The dollar ended at 146.65 yen, down 0.85 yen from Tuesday's 147.50-yen finish. It opened lower at 146.00 yen and ranged between 145.60 yen and 146.65 yen. The dollar has lost 4.1 yen from last Friday and is at its lowest since its 146.47-yen close on February 23. Dealers said the dollar, which also was sold in New York over the narrowing interest rate gap between Japan and the United States, fell below the 146-yen level when institutional investors dumped the dollar as soon as Tokyo's morning session started. ``Under the current situation with little difference in (both country's) interest rates, there's no reason to buy the currency (dollar),'' said a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. Lower interest rates tend to make a country's currency less attractive to foreign investors. But the currency soon rose and ended higher than the opening because ``there was a greater than expected demand for the dollar below the 146-yen line,'' said Yutaka Hayashi, a dealer with the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. About $13.55 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from Tuesday's $12.97 billion. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average shed 197.67 points, or 0.64 percent, ending the day at 30,837.99. The index rose 592.71 points on Tuesday, breaking its fall over the last seven consecutive days. The Nikkei was up 236.20 points at the end of morning trading because of confidence from stability in the bond market, traders said. It then fell back in the afternoon mainly because of arbitrage selling for profit-taking before Aug. 9, the final day of trading of August options, they said. ``The market is still very weak, and any news can easily affect trading, and (negative news) can discourage market players' buying interest so easily,'' said Masaki Wakabayashi, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. He said traders were pessimistic about upcoming statistics on the performance of the U.S. manufacturing industry. The index had lost 2,176.03 points, or 6.58 percent, between July 20 and July 30. Trading was thin with first section volume estimated at 430 million shares, up from Tuesday's 380 million. In bond dealing, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 7.505 percent at 4 p.m. from Tuesday's 7.535-percent close. The price stood at 85.61 points, up from 85.47 points.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Shot Dead In West Belfast
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic man was shot to death by two gunmen as he stood talking with friends outside his home in Belfast, police said today. Police headquarters in Belfast said the attackers were believed to be Protestant extremists. It said the shooting occurred Tuesday night in the Catholic stronghold Springfield Road area. The victim was identified a John Judge, a 34-year-old father of three. Police said they were treating the attack as sectarian. They said the gunmen arrived on the scene in a taxi, which was later found to have been hijacked. The gunmen escaped after the attack and the vehicle was later discovered abandoned near the staunchly Protestant Shankill Road area of Belfast.

DOC.HEAD: Waitress: Pilot Consumed 17 Drinks Night Before Flight
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines pilot on trial with two crewmates on charges of flying while intoxicated was an alcoholic who had 17 rum and Cokes the night before the flight, attorneys and witnesses say. The two other crew members shared seven pitchers of beer, a waitress said Tuesday, the opening day of their trial in federal court. She said the captain, Norman Lyle Prouse, fell on the floor before leaving the bar. The three had gone to the restaurant and bar to take the chill off their icy cockpit relationship, attorneys said. They had worked together less than a week. William Mauzy, representing 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, said Kirchner played the peacemaker between Prouse and flight engineer Joseph Balzer. Prouse had been critical of Balzer's performance, Mauzy said. Kirchner ``felt there was something lacking in the three of them getting along,'' Mauzy said. ``He tried to smooth over the situation.'' Shortly before 4 p.m. on March 7, the three met for drinks, according to testimony. They flew the next day about 6 a.m. from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis-St. Paul. Waitress Kathryn Litch testified that the bar poured about 17 rum and Diet Cokes for Prouse and seven pitchers of beer for Balzer and Kirchner. About half the beer in the last pitcher remained when Balzer and Kirchner left, she said. Ms. Litch testified Kirchner and Balzer left about 10:30 p.m. Prouse left later, after falling on the floor, she said. All three pilots had blood-alcohol levels higher than .04 percent, the FAA limit, according to test results admitted as evidence. Prouse had the highest reading, .131 percent. Prouse's attorney, Peter Wold, said in his opening statement that Prouse is an alcoholic and thus has a high tolerance for alcohol. The pilot had no trouble flying the Boeing 727 with 91 passengers, his lawyer said. The pilots were arrested when the plane landed in the Twin Cities by officials who had been tipped about their drinking. All three were fired, and the Federal Aviation Administration revoked their licenses. Les Stenerson, a lumber salesman, testified he anonymously tipped the FAA about the pilots' drinking after seeing them in the bar. FAA safety inspector Verle Addison testified he met the pilots at the departure gate in Fargo. He said the pilots were late, smelled of alcohol and had bloodshot eyes. Prouse, from Conyers, Ga.; Kirchner, from Highland Ranch, Colo., and Balzer, from Antioch, Tenn., are charged with operating the aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. The offense carries up to 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: British Rocker Wails Tune From Witness Stand
DOC.TEXT: The lead singer for Judas Priest says the heavy metal group once recorded a phrase backwards but didn't bury subliminal messages promoting suicide in an album blamed for the deaths of two young fans. Rob Halford was the first of four band members to testify in a lawsuit brought by the parents of the two fans. ``There are no subliminals of any nature'' on the 1978 album ``Stained Glass,'' he said Tuesday. Halford testified he recorded a backward phrase in the song ``Love Bites'' on the British band's album ``Defenders of the Faith'' in the mid-1980s. Halford said he recorded the phrase ``in the dead of the night, love bites'' backwards and played it simultaneously with the same words recorded forwards. He said the backward version sounded like garbled speech. District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead, who is hearing the case against the band and CBS Records without a jury, asked Halford why he did it. ``When you're composing songs, you're always looking for new ideas, new sounds ... just as an artist would add another piece of paint to a canvas,'' Halford said. He said it was the only time he could recall deliberately using the technique on any of the group's 14 albums. Halford earlier gave a 10-second a cappella demonstration of his vocal style, using ``Better by You, Better Than Me,'' a song the families claim contains subliminal messages that led their sons to shoot themselves in a suicide pact. Halford sang, ``Better by you better than me; You can tell her what I want it to be,'' accenting the end of each line with a huff of breath. The families of Raymond Belknap and James Vance claim those lines contain the subliminal message ``do it.'' The youths shot themselves in a deserted church playground in 1985. Belknap, 18, died immediately. Vance, then 20, blew away the bottom half of his face. He died in 1988 of complications from his injuries and the various medications. The band and CBS Records deny any hidden messages exist. They contend the supposed ``do it'' sounds are an exhalation of breath and a combination of drums, guitars and vocals.

DOC.HEAD: Government To Allow Competing Parties
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquim Chissano has announced that, for the first time in Mozambique's history, opposition parties will be allowed to compete for power. The move, reported Tuesday by the national news agency AIM, was considered a major concession that could help end the nation's 13-year-old civil war. The conflict has claimed about 100,000 lives, most of them civilians. ``For those who want to form parties, as long as they obey the law, as long as they behave peacefully, we have no right to prevent them from doing so,'' AIM quoted Chissano quoted as saying. Chissano said the political bureau of the ruling FRELIMO party had voted unanimously to adopt a multiparty system and that it should be in place for parliamentary and presidential elections next year. FRELIMO has ruled Mozambique as the sole legal political party since independence from Portugal in 1975. The party was Marxist, but has undergone reforms in recent years and officially dropped its Marxist label last year. Rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance began their insurgency in 1977, and the war has made this southeast African nation one of the poorest countries in the world. Almost half of Mozambique's 15 million people require food aid. More than 1 million people have been displaced, and the annual per capita income is under $200. The rebels, known by their Portuguese acronym, RENAMO, demand a multiparty system and free elections. The government and rebels held their first direct talks three weeks ago in Rome. No major breakthroughs emerged, but more talks are considered likely. Asked if RENAMO could become a legal political party, Chissano said, ``I don't imagine that RENAMO will have any difficulty in fulfilling the criteria. ``RENAMO knows the country, they have people in all the provinces and districts. They have the possibility of creating a base, though how big it would be, I don't know.'' The rebels have no clear political program. They have devastated the country with hit-and-run attacks and have been accused of widespread civilian atrocities by the U.S. State Department and others. The government controls the major cities, but the rebels are active throughout the country in rural areas. No government acknowledges supporting the rebels, although South Africa openly backed them before signing a 1984 mutual non-aggression pact with Mozambique. Mozambique still receives most of its military help from the Soviet Union. But the government has developed close ties with the United States and other Western countries in recent years. Britain helps train the army and the United States is the leading donor of food aid.

Michel Guy, a former minister of culture and director of the annual Fall Festival in Paris, died Monday after a long illness. He was 63. Guy was culture minister from 1974 to 1976 under President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. He founded the Fall Festival in 1972 and served as its director every year except during his stint in the Cabinet. In 1985, he launched a campaign against the 90-foot glass pyramid in front of the Louvre, saying it turn the museum into a ``cultural drugstore.''

Morley Richard Kare, founder of an institute that studied the senses of taste and smell, died at his home Monday of stomach cancer. He was 68. Kare founded the Monell Center at the University of Pennsylvania in 1968. He was its director and president and a professor of physiology from 1968 until his death. Kare's research focused on the relationship of taste to nutrition.

Mary Abigail McCarthy, a professor at Yale Law School and the daughter of former Sen. Eugene McCarthy of Minnesota, died of pancreatic cancer Saturday at age 41. Ms. McCarthy, active in the civil rights and anti-war movements during the 1960s, skipped a semester at Radcliffe College in 1968 to campaign for her father, who was running for president. McCarthy, 74, said his daughter dedicated her career to public-interest law, first as a public defender in Washington, and later at Yale, where she specialized in legal services for juveniles, the disabled, inmates, immigrants and the poor.

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Son Collects Mom's Nuggets of Wisdom
DOC.TEXT: Robert Popovich is one son who listened to his mother. Popovich passes his mother's advice on to clients as a corporate consultant and has even put her nuggets of wisdom in a book due out later this year. ``I'm a product of Dorothy. I'm taking her efforts and teachings and spreading them around,'' he said. Popovich, 46, called the book ``Mother Always Said, Robert ... A Mother's 10 Commandments to Personal and Business Success.'' ``I never knew he would quote me,'' Mrs. Popovich said. ``I guess it sinks in. What parents say is very important.'' From Mrs. Popovich: _ If you give respect, you will get it back. If you give love, you will get it back. _ Intellect is measured by the questions that you ask, not the statements that you make. _ Run to adversity, not away from it. Popovich said his company, Popovich & Associates, serves Fortune 500 companies in the United States and clients in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Guerrillas Crush Base of Iranian-Backed Fighters
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's guerrillas crushed the main base of an Iranian-backed breakaway Palestinian faction outside this port city today, then clashed with its fighters in a nearby refugee camp. Police said at least six guerrillas were killed and 30 wounded. The fighting, beginning with a 90-minute lightning assault on the base, was part of a Fatah crackdown on followers of renegade Maj. Jamal Suleiman. It spread to Ein el-Hilweh, the largest Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon, after Arafat's guerrillas crushed Suleiman's main base in Jabal al-Haleeb, or the milk mountain, on the camp's eastern edge. Suleiman, 35, and about 30 of 150 fighters escaped the attack on the milk mountain base and took refuge at the Nour, or light, mosque in Ein el-Hilweh, where they were joined by other Sunni Moslem fundamentalist Palestinians. Col. Wajih Abu Ali, commander of the Palestine Liberation Organization's military police in the Sidon region, said the fundamentalists fired on Fatah forces from the mosque and a nearby alley that is their stronghold in the camp. He said Sheik Hisham Shreidi, a cleric connected with the fundamentalist Hamas movement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza, was supporting Suleiman in the fight against mainstream Fatah. Witnesses in Ein el-Hilweh said Shreidi and a dozen other bearded clergymen were using the mosque's louspeakers to blare calls for jihad, or holy war, against Arafat. Arafat's men, according to Col. Abu Ali, were ``responding to the shooting.'' One witness, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a fierce clash was under way with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenade launchers. ``It's a sensitive situation,'' Abu Ali said. ``Fatah cannot easily attack a mosque to evict them. Other anti-Arafat groups might suppport them too. The situation in the camp is very tense.'' However, he said, by finishing off Suleiman's base at Jabal al-Haleeb, Fatah ``eliminated a major threat to its rear guard in the area.'' Suleiman, who heads Ein el-Hilweh's Martyrs Battalion, has sided with the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, in its confrontation with the Syrian-backed Amal militia that broke out July 16. Both militias are comprised of Shiite Moslems, Lebanon's dominant sect. At least 186 people have been killed and 560 wounded in the current round of Amal-Hezbollah clashes for control of southern Lebanon's Iqlim al-Tuffah, or apple province, southeast of Ein el-Hilweh. Fatah guerrillas joined forces with Amal against Hezbollah because they fear a fundamentalist expansion would threaten PLO bases in Ein el-Hilweh and the nearby Mieh Mieh camp on the outskirts of Sidon. Sidon, provincial capital of southern Lebanon, is 10 miles northwest of Iqlim al-Tuffah. Suleiman, who has been getting support from Hezbollah and the Sunni Moslem Islamic Grouping extremist faction for the past year, fired 40 rockets on Fatah's positions in Iqlim al-Tuffah on Monday, wounding at least seven guerrillas, PLO sources said. They said Fatah guerrillas launched their three-pronged attack with grenades and machine guns against Suleiman behind heavy artillery fire, circling his 50-man garrison in Jabal al-Haleeb. Arafat has at least 5,000 hard-core fighters in the Sidon region. Representatives of the Red Cross, Amal, Hezbollah and a 1,000-strong PLO disengagement force deployed in the apple province met behind closed doors at the headquarters of Sidon's militia leader, Mustafa Saad, to try to enforce a cease-fire, originally called for Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Social Security Puts Temporary Hold On Travel For Appeals Hearings
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration will schedule no more hearings for disability benefit appeals in September if they involve travel or other outside expenses. However, an agency spokesman said Tuesday the decision does not affect thousands of hearings already scheduled and does not mean additional hearings cannot be booked. Philip Gambino said the hold on additional travel or outside expenses is temporary and happens annually as the agency approaches the end of its fiscal year in September, Gambino said. He denied a report published in the today's editions of the New York Times, saying the agency had ``suspended'' hearings in September because of the year-end financial crunch. ``We haven't canceled any hearings,'' he said. ``We're still going to do hearings during September,'' Gambino said. ``I can't even tell you if we're going to do less in September than we are in August.'' He estimated that the agency holds some 20,000 hearings a month at more 200 locations around the country for people who are appealing decisions that deny or reduce the Social Security disability benefits they receive.
DOC.HEAD: Government Pumps $200 Million More into Student Loan Guarantee
DOC.TEXT: Agency

The government-sponsored Student Loan Marketing Association says it is injecting $200 million into a troubled student loan guarantee agency. The loan to the Higher Education Assistance Fund, HEAF, buys time for government officials who are trying to arrange a takeover to avoid a default by the fund. The association, known as Sallie Mae, had advanced the fund $200 million previously. HEAF, based in Overland Park, Kan., is the largest of 47 state or private non-profit agencies guaranteeing student loans. A week ago, it disclosed that it was in danger of defaulting on its claims. Officials from the Education Department and the Office of Management and Budget have been trying to avoid that by arranging for another guarantee agency or Sallie Mae to take over HEAF. They had said they hoped to resolve HEAF's problems this week, but Etta Fielek, a spokeswoman for the Education Department, said Tuesday the new loan will carry HEAF into the 1991 fiscal year starting Oct. 1
DOC.HEAD: Committee Recommends Approval of Hepatitis Treatment
DOC.TEXT: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee has unanimously recommended approval of interferon alpha as the first treatment shown to be effective against hepatitis C. Interferon alpha, a substance produced naturally in the body that can be made in large amounts by genetic engineering, has already been approved for treatment of hairy-cell leukemia, Kaposi's sarcoma and genital warts. The drug does not cure hepatitis C, also known as non-A, non-B hepatitis and is not universally effective, but studies have shown that it can alleviate some effects of the disease. FDA spokeswoman Faye Peterson said the advisory panel's recommendation Tuesday included a suggestion for long-term followup of hepatitis patients who receive the drug after it receives formal approval. The advisory panel also recommended against FDA approval of granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor, or GM-CSF, one of a new family of complex proteins that regulate production of blood cells. GM-CSF is critical in the production of white blood cells.
DOC.HEAD: September Start Date Set for Databank of Bad Doctors and Dentists
DOC.TEXT: A computerized databank of actions taken against incompetent physicians and dentists will start operating Sept. 1. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said Tuesday that the National Practitioner Databank is intended to prevent physicians and dentists who have been disciplined from moving to another state and setting up new practices without detection. The databank will store reports of malpractice actions, licensure disciplinary actions by state medical and dental boards and actions by professional societies, hospitals and other health care entities after a formal peer review process. The reports must be made beginning Sept. 1. Actions taken before then do not have to be reported. Hospitals will be required to check the databank when a physician or dentist applies to join the medical staff or receive clinical privileges, Sullivan said. Also, hospitals will be required to check the databank every two years concerning physicians and dentists on their medical staffs or those who have clinical privileges. State licensing boards also will have access to the information, and individual physicians, dentists and other health care professionals will be able to see their own records. Attorneys representing a physician or dentist may have access under limited conditions. Some have been critical of the data bank because members of the public will not have access to the information and retroactive reporting will not be required.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Refuses to Indict Officer in Shooting; Second Panel Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 20th graf pvs, `But teen-agers ...' to ADD that police found starter pistol.
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury refused to indict a white policeman who fatally shot a black teen-ager in the back, but New Jersey's attorney general said the probe was tainted by autopsy errors and a new panel will be convened. The slaying of Phillip Pannell Jr., 16, on April 10 touched off a night of rioting in Teaneck, a New York City suburb once called a model integrated community. After word of the grand jury action spread on Tuesday, officers with riot sticks in hand milled around the Teaneck police station, but the evening passed without incident. The grand jury refused to indict Officer Gary Spath, 29, who faced charges of manslaughter and improperly using deadly force. Attorney General Robert Del Tufo said a serious mistake in Pannell's autopsy by Medical Examiner Lawrence J. Denson ``led to an incorrect conclusion concerning the possible actions of Mr. Pannell at the time he was shot.'' ``The mistake permeated and distorted the investigation and the grand jury presentation. The medical examiner has admitted his error,'' Del Tufo said. The attorney refused to answer questions and left the news conference. Robert Galantucci, Spath's lawyer, accused Gov. Jim Florio and Del Tufo of ``attempting to buy an indictment'' and said the call for a new panel was unscrupulous. ``They shouldn't be playing politics with the grand jury system,'' he said. The victim's father said he was disappointed but hopeful. ``This is a sad day. It's three and a half months since my son was shot in the back for no reason,'' Pannell said. But he said he had a message for the youth of Teaneck: ``Chill out.'' ``I'm willing to give America another chance for justice,'' he said. ``I feel justice will be served.'' Late Tuesday, community leaders counseled Teaneck youths gathering behind the police station not to resort to violence. ``Try to be calm, talk it out over the next few days,'' said Ted Wells of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He urged the gathering to trust the judicial process, calling the empaneling of a second grand jury an extraordinary step. ``If there was a scam they'd give no indictment, shut up and bite the bullet,'' he said. A key question before the panel was whether Pannell had raised his hands in the air and pleaded with police not to shoot, as some witnesses said, or whether he twice stopped and turned in a threatening way toward the officers. Officials close to the case say one crucial question is whether Pannell was frisked by Officer Wayne Blanco moments before he was shot, according to The Record of Hackensack. Blanco said he frisked the teen-ager and warned Spath about a gun he felt in Pannell's jacket, according to the newspaper. But teen-agers with Pannell said there was no frisking before the youngster ran, and the man whose telephone call alerted police about a youth with a gun said he backed the youths' accounts when he testified before the grand jury, the paper said. Police said they recovered from Pannell's clothing a chrome-plated athletic starter pistol that had been modified to fire live ammunition. ``We've been praying for the Pannell family all along and will continue to pray for the Pannell family,'' Spath said at a news conference. Black leaders had demanded that a special prosecutor handle the case, but instead it was transferred from Bergen County to a state grand jury sitting in the state capital, and a deputy attorney general handled the case.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Delegation Departs Jiddah As Talks Apparently Deadlocked
DOC.TEXT: Reconciliation talks between Iraq and Kuwait in their dispute over oil, borders and money apparently collapsed today and the Iraqi delegation left for Baghdad, sources said. Senior officials from the two Persian Gulf nations failed to hold a scheduled second round of talks despite intensive behind-the-scenes efforts by host Saudi Arabia, the sources said. Iraq maintained a hard-line on the two-week-old disagreement, they said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The sources said Saudi King Fahd was expected to try to arrange a meeting between President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, in an attempt to break the impasse. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and other Arab leaders also were trying to defuse the tension and bring the two sides back together. The most important issue on the table in Jiddah is the dispute over the countries' joint border, which has been undemarcated since Kuwait won independence in 1961. Iraq accuses Kuwait of encroaching upon the frontier and building oil installations, military posts and farms. It has in the past few weeks moved an estimated 100,000 troops and hundreds of tanks on the Kuwaiti border. Iraq is demanding that Kuwait compensate it for $2.4 billion worth of oil drilled from a border oilfield it claims. Iraq also insists that Kuwait write off loans of billions of dollars Kuwait made to it during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Iraq's had also complained about an oil glut that cost it $14 billion being caused by overproduction on the part of Kuwait and United Arab Emirates. But that dispute appeared to have been settled by firm pledges of discipline by the two countries at last week's Geneva meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. On Tuesday, Kuwait had sent Crown Prince and Deputy Premier Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah and Iraq its No. 2 leader, Izzat Ibrahim, to Jiddah. The Saudi monarch succeeded in getting the two leaders to kiss and embrace. Sheik Saad and Ibrahim, along with their delegations, met for two hours in the presence of the Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah and separately. They were feted at a dinner banquet by the Saudi monarch and had been set to resume their peace parley this morning.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Regains Lost Ground
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed against European currencies this morning but dropped against the Japanese yen. Spot gold prices regained some of the ground lost in Tuesday's trading in New York. In Tokyo, the dollar sank to its lowest level since February 23. It closed at 146.65 yen, down 0.85 yen from Tuesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 146.12 yen. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday: _1.5889 German marks, up from 1.5875 _1.3514 Swiss francs, up from 1.3475 _5.3315 French francs, up from 5.3210 _1.7905 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7880 _1,163.25 Italian lire, up from 1,162.00 _1.1511 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1523 In London, one British pound cost $1.8572, down from late Tuesday's $1.8595. Dealers in Tokyo said institutional investors, noting the narrowing gap between U.S. and Japanese interest rates, began dumping dollars as soon as the Tokyo market opened and the U.S. unit fell below 146 yen. Once that happened, ``there was a greater than expected demand for the dollar below the 146-yen line,'' said Yutaka Hayashi, a dealer with the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Several analysts believe the dollar will sink as low as 140 yen this summer, and perhaps dip below 1.5620 Deutsche marks, the lowest level since World War II. ``There is not a lot of reason why the market should start buying the dollar,'' said Jim O'Neil, international economist at Swiss Bank Corp in London. The dollar's weakness in the foreign exchanges is helping support gold prices, although dealers are debating whether gold has sufficient support to move convincingly into a technical chart resistance area between $373.00 and $375.00 an ounce. Gold rebounded this morning from an earlier retreat in New York, where it was quoted at $370.20 bid late Tuesday. In London, gold was quoted at $371.10 per ounce at the morning fixing, compared to $372.05 a troy ounce late Tuesday. The Zurich market was closed for a national holiday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $2.04 per ounce to close at $371.46 per ounce. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid price of $4.83 a troy ounce, down from $4.85.

DOC.HEAD: Cloudy Skies East of Mississippi
DOC.TEXT: Cloudy skies covered much of the eastern third of the nation early today, while the remainder of the country had mostly dry weather. Showers fell early today in northern New Mexico, and scattered rain and thunderstorms were likely across much of the South and Texas. Today's forecast called for unseasonably cool temperatures in the Northeast and Great Lakes region, with highs in the 70s. Skies were mostly cloudy east of the Mississippi this morning after showers and thundershowers in the South on Tuesday caused flooding in Odessa, Texas, and tree damage in Tupelo, Miss. Rain continued into the evening, falling across the Rockies and from Delaware across eastern New York into New England. Thunderstorms were expected in the Dakotas, Montana, Utah and Colorado. Sunshine and mild weather were forecast for the West coast, but temperatures were to soar into the 100s in Arizona. The nation's high for Tuesday was 115 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., and Bullhead City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Leaders To Allow Foreign Investment
DOC.TEXT: In yet another move to end years of isolation as an orthodox Communist state, Albania has announced its intention to permit joint ventures and other forms of foreign investment. The presidium of the People's Assembly, or Parliament, also approved a decree granting limited rights to stage public demonstrations and proposed setting up a special commission to consider constitutional changes. The presidium's decisions were reported Tuesday by the state news agency ATA in a dispatch monitored in Vienna. It did not elaborate on the constitutional questions. The moves come just weeks after about 5,000 Albanians flooded embassies in Tirana, the capital, and received permission to leave their homeland. Many of the refugees complained of bleak economic prospects as well as the lack of political freedom. Albania is Europe's poorest country and last hard-line Communist state. The new economic reforms apparently are designed to help alleviate the country's economic backwardness and provide technical know-how. The decree on foreign investments stated that ``foreign embassies, firms or individuals or Albanians residing abroad can make investments or carry out related economic activities.'' While the official announcement did not specifically mention joint ventures, it said that ``enterprises with participation of foreign capital can carry out their economic activity in various sectors of the economy.'' ATA said the aim of such enterprises is ``the modernization of existing projects or the setting up of new projects with advanced technology.'' It said joint ventures could help in extracting and processing raw materials, increasing exports and decreasing dependence on imports, producing more consumer goods and creating new jobs. Most contracts would require government approval, ATA said. The presidium's decree ``on meetings, gatherings and manifestations'' would grant Albanians only limited freedom of assembly. The decree, as reported by ATA, apparently would continue to ban most anti-government demonstrations, including protests similar to those at embassies earlier this month. Such gatherings where ``appeals against the constitutional order are launched, where calls are made for committing ... violations of the law, where violations of relations with other countries are aimed at, are banned,'' the ATA report said.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Said They Were Unaware of Guilty Plea by S&L Buyer
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to restore dropped word ``when''.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators say they were unaware that one of an Arizona insurance executive's corporations had pleaded guilty to a felony when they allowed him to buy 15 savings and loan associations. The sale of what now is known as Bluebonnet Savings Bank of Dallas was underwritten by taxpayers to the tune of at least $1.85 billion and perhaps $3 billion, congressional investigators say. Bluebonnet now is among the nation's most profitable savings institutions. The sale of the faltering S&Ls to James M. Fail, who has insurance operations in 47 states, was approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in December 1988, a few days before a lucrative tax break for S&L investors was to expire. ``While I certainly had misgivings about Mr. Fail's background, he did not, to my knowledge at that time, fail to qualify'' to purchase the S&Ls, George M. Barclay, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee Tuesday. Barclay said he was aware that in 1976, Fail has entered into a plea bargain that resulted in dismissal of a fraud indictment in Alabama. The law says an indictment within the past 10 years should serve as ``a presumptive disqualifier'' to own an S&L. Barclay said he did not know, however, that Fail at the same time had pleaded guilty to a felony fraud indictment on behalf of a corporation he controlled. That plea, amounting to a conviction, could have disqualified him. ``Had I understood on Dec. 22, 1988, the facts as I believe them to be today, I certainly would have objected to Mr. Fail's acquisition of Bluebonnet,'' Barclay testified. Critics in Congress are citing Bluebonnet as the worst example of the S&L mess, which now is conceded to be the biggest financial scandal in the nation's history. M. Danny Wall, who at the time of the sale headed the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, defended the choice of Fail as a buyer. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, chairman of the antitrust subcommittee, said that if the rival group had been allowed to buy Bluebonnet, it would have saved taxpayers $97 million. ``That's not true at all,'' Wall said. If the two bids were compared on the same basis, ``the final terms of the (Bluebonnet) negotiations were significantly better'' than those offered by rival bidders, he said. Fail put up $1,000 cash to make the purchase and borrowed the remainder of the required $70 million capital contribution, including $10 million that was paid several weeks later than had been agreed. Metzenbaum has questioned the role in the Bluebonnet affair played by Robert J. Thompson, who was a congressional liaison for then-Vice President Bush. Thompson refused to answer a subpoena to testify Tuesday, and Metzenbaum said he will ask the full Judiciary Committee to compel Thompson to comply. ``We believe that Mr. Thompson made good use of ... (his) access at key junctures in the (Bluebonnet) acquisition process,'' Metzenbaum said. Thompson's lawyer, Stanley Brand, told reporters outside the subcommittee hearing room that Thompson did nothing wrong and scrupulously followed federal regulations in acting on behalf of Fail. The New York Times reported in today's editions that Thompson was able to review a 1989 draft report by the inspector general of the bank board that found Fail should have been precluded from buying the Texas thrifts. The newspaper said Thompson's lobbying firm helped regulators prepare a response to the report. Thompson said in an interview in The Washington Post on Tuesday that in exchange for helping Fail, he was paid a lobbying fee, given a $150,000 loan and promised 2 percent of profits from Bluebonnet. Metzenbaum said that percentage could be worth tens of millions of dollars. Thompson contends the subcommittee has no jurisdiction over banking matters and accused the panel of systematically turning over his private documents to the Times. Wall, who was the top regulator of S&Ls, denied any impropriety and said he had met with Thompson only three times _ never to discuss Bluebonnet.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Toddler's Death Can't Cope With Society, Mother Says
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murdering his 2-year-old stepson after dunking him headfirst in a toilet for breaking potty training ``doesn't know what the world's about,'' his mother says. A jury that convicted Thomas Coe on Monday of murder and child abuse was to return today to decide whether to recommend death in the electric chair or a life sentence. Circuit Judge Randall McDonald was to make the final decision on Coe's sentence. Prosecutors requested the death penalty for Coe in Bradley McGee's slaying July 27, 1989. A life sentence would mean 25 years in prison with no possibility of parole. Coe testified that he was ``irate,'' ``steamed'' and ``out of control'' when he plunged Bradley in a toilet as punishment for soiling his pants. Bradley died the next day of massive injuries. Mary Rae Coe Anders, Coe's mother, said he should be sent to prison because he can't cope with the pressures of life on the outside. ``He feels he can't cope with society and we've even talked about the fact that he's better off where he is,'' he said. ``He can't cope. He doesn't know what the world's about.'' Bradley's death came two months after he was ordered returned from foster care to his mother and stepfather. Coe said he never meant to harm the child, but the state argued the death was the culmination of weeks of torture. Medical experts testified that Bradley's body was covered with bruises up to two weeks old. Coe's wife, Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in her son's death and is serving a 30-year prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet, US Envoys Begin Talks Seeking Accord on Afghan War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze presenting Baker with list of areas of possible economic cooperation, fishing on Lake Baikal. Picks up 16th pvs, `Aside from ...' ^By ANDREW KATELL
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III tried today to build on fast-moving developments in Afghanistan to end the bloodiest conflict dividing the superpowers. The diplomats began two days of talks whose centerpiece was expected to be Afghanistan's 12-year-old civil war, which has claimed more than 1.5 million lives and left the country in ruins. ``We will be able to help solve the Afghanistan question,'' Shevardnadze told reporters before his first meeting with Baker, in an official guest house in this eastern Siberian city. He did not elaborate. He also said he and Baker would complete plans for a third summit between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, who are to meet in Moscow by year's end. Shevardnadze said he and Baker would try to set a date. Bush and Gorbachev last met in June in Washington. A Soviet source close to the talks said that during their four-hour initial meeting, Shevardnadze gave Baker a 15-page outline of areas in which the Soviet Union and the United States could cooperate economically. It mentioned capital investment, elimination of double taxation and joint work on ecology, space research and medicine, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The document was in response to Baker's July 18 offer at a meeting with Shevardnadze in Paris of U.S. technical advice to help the Soviets salvage their failing economy. With democratic changes sweeping Eastern Europe and disputes over German reunification largely settled, Washington and Moscow are eager to end regional conflicts in Asia, such as those in Cambodia and Afghanistan. The Afghan war is costing the superpowers billions of dollars in weapons and economic aid. Baker arrived in Irkutsk early today from Singapore and goes to Mongolia on Thursday. The Soviets invited him to the Siberian wilderness of cedar, birch and pine trees to reciprocate for Shevardnadze's trip to Wyoming last fall. The two envoys sampled nature after hopping aboard a white and blue hydrofoil later today for a 43-mile cruise along the tree-lined Angara River to a fishing lodge near Lake Baikal, which contains one-sixth of the world's fresh water. From the log cabin, set in the forest, they boarded a small boat to go fishing before sitting down for dinner and a second round of talks. Shevardnadze and Baker are believed to be working on a formula for a cease-fire in Afghanistan and an interim government to rule the country. The Soviet-supported Afghan president, Najibullah, has been unable to bring the U.S.-backed rebels fighting his government to the bargaining table and Washington has been pressing for him to step down. Najibullah flew to Moscow on Sunday for what Soviet officials said was medical care, but Shevardnadze told reporters today he was vacationing in a location other than Moscow. He would not say where. The Soviet source said it was a ``pure coincidence'' that Najibullah's visit coincided with the Baker-Shevardnadze talks and expressed confidence he would return to Afghanistan as president. The source said Najibullah was likely to meet during his visit with Gorbachev, who began a vacation this week on Russia's Crimean Peninsula. Aside from wanting to reduce tensions, both superpowers are trying to end the Afghan war for economic reasons. The Soviet Union is anxious to reduce foreign aid so it can put more resources into solving a domestic economic crisis that is keeping food and consumer goods off store shelves, fueling a budget deficit and crumbling the country's infrastructure. The $300 million a month the Kremlin reportedly spends to maintain the Najibullah government is a likely target. The United States would like to trim its budget, and the Senate Intelligence Committee has voted to cut secret aid for the Afghan rebels from $300 million to $200 million a year. Soviet troops fought Moslem guerrillas in Afghanistan for nine years after a 1978 coup that installed a Communist government. Moscow withdrew the last of its soldiers in February 1989 under a U.N.-brokered peace agreement, but the war continues and is at a stalemate. Baker told reporters he and Shevardnadze also would discuss a treaty to reduce strategic nuclear weapons and cuts in conventional arms. Both sides are trying to agree on the nuclear treaty so Bush and Gorbachev can sign it at their Moscow summit.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, De Klerk Discuss Communist Role in Talks on Reforms
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela said he and President F.W. de Klerk had a cordial meeting today to discuss the Communist Party's representation in talks with the government. Mandela said he would comment later on Communist Party leader Joe Slovo's standing as an ANC delegate in talks that are to begin Monday. At a meeting last week, de Klerk suggested to Mandela that Slovo be dropped from the ANC negotiating team because of police allegations that the Communist Party was plotting a secret revolt. Since that meeting and today's, questions have been raised about the accuracy of the police information given to de Klerk. Mandela and other ANC leaders believe significant progress could be made at next week's talks with the government on ending guerrilla activity, returning exiles and freeing prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes. Mandela and Slovo have denied any plot existed for a secret revolt, and they appeared together at a Communist Party rally on Sunday. The ANC and the Communist Party are longtime allies because of their common opposition to apartheid. The two groups share several top officials. Police have backed off their contention that Slovo was at a meeting at which Communist Party members allegedly discussed continuing the armed revolt while a new constitution is negotiated. The Communist Party released a transcript of the meeting which does not match the one police leaked to newspapers. Scores of ANC and Communist Party guerrillas have been detained without charge in the past few weeks, including Mac Maharaj, a member of the ANC executive committee who returned to South Africa in June under de Klerk's promise of indemnity from prosecution. Police contend the indemnity for past actions does not exempt ANC leaders from prosecution for crimes they may commit while in the country for negotiations. Police say guerrillas are continuing to cross the border illegally, store weapons, and plan and train for military actions. ANC leaders have given conflicting statements on guerrilla activity but have generally noted that there is no cease-fire with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Kenyan Lawyer Says Government Held Him in Psychiatric Wing
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer charged with sedition and freed on bond accused the government today of ``extreme cruelty'' for holding him and others similarly charged incommunicado in a prison psychiatric wing. Gitobu Imanyara, who edits a monthly magazine often critical of the government, was charged with sedition Thursday and released Tuesday on $8,700 bond. The charge stems from the most recent issue of The Nairobi Law Monthly, which was devoted entirely to multiparty politics, law and democracy. President Daniel arap Moi and other government leaders vehemently have rejected calls for multiparty democracy in Kenya, claiming more than one party could lead to tribal-based political groups and even warfare between the country's approximately 40 ethnic groups. Imanyara and two other lawyers were picked up in early July in a wave of arrests that netted Kenya's most vocal proponents of political change, including two former Cabinet ministers and the son of Keya's first vice president. The three were held for 20 days without charge before being released on July 25. But Imanyara was immediately arrested again and charged with sedition the following day. Imanyara said that during his six days in jail, he was held incommunicado in the psychiatric wing of Kamiti prison on Nairobi's outskirts. He said he found others similarly charged also being held there, including a Presbyterian minister, the Rev. Lawford Ndege Imunde, who was sentenced in March to six years imprisonment for having been found with allegdly seditious entries in his desk diary. Imanyara, who was imprisoned from 1982 to 1985 after defending 120 air force officers charged in a coup attempt, described the conditions a Kamiti as ``extreme cruelty.'' He said he and the others were kept in solitary confinment and never allowed to leave their unlighted cells. He said toilet paper and tooth brushes were not provided, and a single chamber pot per prisoner was supposed to serve as wash basin and toilet. Imanyara said they were given two blankets and fed cornmeal mush for breakfast and beans at night. ``The conditions are about 20 times worse than detention,'' he said. ``I am really concerned about the people in that place.'' He said that in addition to Imunde, the others he found in the psychiatric wing were former detainees George Anyona, Edward Oyugi and Isaiah Ngotho Kariuki, and a rural ruling party official, Augustine Gathangu. They also were arrested in the government crackdown and were charged last week with sedition. Attorneys for Anyona, Oyugi, Kariuki and Gathangu charged at a bail hearing Tuesday that their clients had been tortured. The judge refused to set bail and adjourned the hearing until Aug. 7 to give the government time to respond.

DOC.HEAD: Pedestrian Struck, Killed by Police Cruiser
DOC.TEXT: A small crowd threw several rocks and bottles toward television crews after a police cruiser struck and killed a man who stepped into its path, police said. The officer was chasing a ``traffic violator'' when the accident occurred shortly before 10 p.m. Tuesday in the impoverished Liberty City neighborhood, said Metro-Dade police spokeswoman Miriam Royle. The cruiser was traveling at normal speed with its emergency lights off when the unidentified man stepped into the road and was killed instantly, Royle said. The police officer, whose name was not released, was treated and released at a nearby hospital. The cruiser's windshield was smashed by the man's body. Police brought in more than a dozen additional units and blocked off the road after more than 100 people gathered at the scene. Officers calmed down the crowd, which dwindled after 11:30 p.m., and made no arrests.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Bodies Found in Hotel Destroyed in Quake
DOC.TEXT: Filipino miners recovered nine bodies today from the ruins of a luxury hotel, and doctors said at least one of them apparently lived for a week after a massive earthquake destroyed the building July 16. More than 45 people, including 30 guests, remain unaccounted for in the rubble of the Hyatt Terraces Hotel, said Gus Baloy, a hotel official. The U.S. Embassy said 12 of those missing at the Hyatt were Americans of Filipino descent. In Manila, Jose de Jesus, the government official in charge of relief and rescue operations in Baguio, said there were 1,500 families living in evacuation centers in the resort. Baguio, 130 miles north of Manila, was one of the cities hit hardest by the quake. It registered 7.7 on the Richter scale and killed more than 1,600 people. In Baguio, at least 400 people died. Foreign rescue teams abandoned hope of finding survivors in Baguio more than a week ago, but local miners and volunteers stepped up their search after the discovery Friday of two people alive in the ruins of the Hyatt. On Monday, another person was found alive in the hotel. The nine victims found today were all hotel employees. A doctor, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said one of them may have lived for a week after the quake. He said the body, that of a woman, bore no life-threatening injuries. Mining engineer Alex Santiago said miners' hopes were raised after Pedrito Dy, 27, a hotel cook and part-time gym instructor, was rescued Monday. Dy said he survived 14 days under the rubble by drinking rainwater and his own urine. Two days earlier, miners alerted by cries of ``Help us!'' rescued Luisa Mallorca, 20, and security guard Arnel Calabia, 26. The three are recovering in hospitals. Santiago said miners will continue searching the rubble. They have recovered 40 bodies from the Hyatt. Pablo Binwag, another miner, said he believes there are still survivors to be found. ``As long as those people trapped inside believe and have faith in God, they will survive,'' he said. The official death toll from the quake is 1,653. Another 1,000 people are missing and presumed dead, and 3,000 were seriously injured. About 110,000 people were left homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Finds Pilot, Airport Error, Led to Crash
DOC.TEXT: Pilot error and lack of routine guidance from air traffic controllers led to the 1988 crash of an Indian Airlines plane that killed all but two of the 135 people on board, an inquiry published today said. Press Trust of India quoted the report from the government-appointed inquiry as saying there was no structural or mechanical failure involved in the crash of the 17-year-old jet. The Boeing 737, on a flight from Bombay to the western state of Gujarat, crashed in fog while approaching the airport. The report, which was submitted to the Civil Aviation Ministry in January 1989, was published today in keeping with the government's decision to make public reports on air accidents, the press agency said. The inquiry report charged authorities at Ahmedabad airport with failing to provide proper navigational aids and meteorological information to the aircraft. At the time of the accident, news reports said that approach lights at the airport were unserviceable and there was no proper firefighting services. The report also attributed the crash to pilot error, but did not give details. The report did, however, say co-pilot Deepak Nagpal was ``not experienced enough to effectively assist'' the pilot. Both Nagpal and the pilot were killed. Indian Airlines operates an average of 240 flights per day. It flies to 73 Indian cities and nine neighboring countries.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Second Republic to Disobey Decree to Turn in Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The republic of Georgia followed neighboring Armenia today in at least temporarily rejecting a presidential order to confiscate weapons from illegal groups. The Tass news agency quoted Communist Party chief Givi Gumbaridze as saying the decree would not be implemented before the republic's parliament resumes work Aug. 17. Lawmakers in Armenia voted Monday night to defy President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order that illegal groups throughout the Soviet Union turn in their weapons and disband, the Armenian National Movement said. The order was issued July 25 and gave groups 15 days to comply. The Soviet interior minister, Vadim A. Bakatin, said military force might be used if necessary to restore law and order when the 15 days are up. A spokesman for the Armenian parliament, Ovanes Muradian, said the parliament decided the decree ``contradicts the natural right of the Armenian people for self-defense.'' The decree was Gorbachev's latest attempt to control ethnic unrest in the southern Caucasus and Central Asian republics. The violence has killed more than 400 people in the last two years and caused widespread damage.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Links Four East German Government Ministers to Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper today linked four ministers in East Germany's coalition government to the now-defunct secret police. The Bonn-based newspaper Die Welt did not name the four officials but said they were suspected of having been ``informal or full-time employees of the Ministry for State Security'' _ the secret police. It said two of the ministers were from Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's Christian Democratic Union and one each from the Social Democrats and the Liberal faction in Parliament. The newspaper, without citing sources, said the information was discovered in background checks of all 400 members of Parliament and eight government ministers. It said de Maiziere was not implicated. Over the weekend, two newspapers reported that 24 members of de Maiziere's party in Parliament had once worked for the secret police, called the Stasi. The East Berlin Der Morgen newspaper said it based its information on a letter reportedly sent to the 24 by a party leader, Guenther Krause, who asked them not to take on any ``important political mandate'' in a future all-German Parliament. Krause has denied there was such a letter. The Christian Democrats are the largest party in East Germany and govern in a large coalition. Their Western counterpart, West Germany's Christian Democrats, are the leading party in Bonn. The parties plan to merge before the planned December elections and are expected to fare strongly in the balloting.

DOC.HEAD: Kin of Former Mexican President Found Guilty in DEA Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS to fix summary line.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government's drive to avenge the torture-slaying of drug agent Enrique Camarena scored another victory with the conviction of the brother-in-law of a former Mexican president. Ruben Zuno Arce, 59, was found guilty Tuesday of racketeering, kidnapping and conspiracy in the 1985 slaying and could receive life in prison at sentencing Sept. 18. Two co-defendants were convicted earlier in the federal court trial. The jury was to return today to continue deliberating the fate of a fourth defendant. Zuno, a Guadalajara businessman, was not charged with murder. Prosecutors portrayed him as a man with ties to drug barons seeking revenge for U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration raids in Mexico that cost them $5 billion in profits. The Camarena case has strained relations between the United States and Mexico because of U.S. allegations of complicity between Mexican officials and drug dealers. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the slaying. Twenty-two people have been charged in the United States. In a 1988 trial in Los Angeles, three defendants were convicted for their part in the case. Zuno is one of the most prominent defendants convicted so far. Prosecutors claimed he wielded enormous political clout because of his sister's marriage to Luis Echeverria, president of Mexico from 1970 to 1976. Two paid government informants who were former Mexican policemen testified against Zuno. One told of seeing him at a meeting in which drug traffickers discussed the need to kidnap a drug agent. Zuno's lawyers said he merely had the bad luck to sell his Guadalajara home to drug lord Rafael Caro Quintero, who used it as Camarena's torture chamber. The 31-year-old Camarena was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street in 1985. Testimony and a gruesome tape recording showed the agent was interrogated and tortured before being slain.

DOC.HEAD: 29 Treated For Injuries in Train Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE casualties and interview with those aboard the trains, background on other train crashes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two British Rail passenger trains collided today when an arriving train was switched to the wrong platform, and 29 people were taken to a hospital for treatment. The driver of one train was the most seriously injured. He suffered leg, head and back injuries and was trapped in his crushed cab for more than two hours. He was given four units of blood as firemen struggled to cut him free. ``He was conscious throughout, talking to staff and lucid,'' said Peter Taylor, the ambulance incident officer. A Berkshire Royal Hospital spokesman confirmed that 29 injured people had been received there, and 15 had been discharged by mid-afternoon. Thames Valley police said an unknown number of other passenger were less seriously injured and not taken to the hospital. A preliminary police report had said that a total of 34 people were injured in the crash. Four doctors and 11 ambulances went to the scene of the crash which British Rail said was reported at 9:24 a.m. at the station 35 miles west of London. A British Rail spokesman said a three-car train from Tonbridge, traveling at 20 mph hit the Reading to London-Waterloo train, which was about to depart. Knowles Mitchell, British Rail Western Region public affairs manager, said the railway was investigating why the Tonbridge train was switched to the wrong platform. British Rail said there were 100 to 150 passengers on the Tonbridge train, but offered no estimate of the number aboard the Waterloo train. ``Everyone was thrown forward, and we were all just sitting there, wondering what had happened,'' said Debra Whitehead, a passenger on the Tonbridge train. ``I was in the third carriage from the front, but there was no panic, just confusion. Bernadette Currie said she had just stood up, preparing to leave the train, when she was ``jolted forward and hit the wood of the sliding door. Some of my teeth were knocked out.'' In July 1989, two British rail workers were killed when two trains carrying track maintenance workers collided in west London. In March 1989, five died and 94 were injured when two passenger trains collided near Purley station on London's southern outskirts. On Dec. 12, 1988, there were 35 deaths and more than 100 other people were injured in a three-train collision during the morning rush hour at Clapham Junction in south London. That crash was blamed on faulty wiring in a signal.

DOC.HEAD: Save The Children to Become First American Charity to Return to Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen years after the last U.S. troops pulled out of Vietnam, Save the Children hopes to become the first American service organization to return to the Southeast Asian country. The Westport-based international child assistance agency reached agreement last month with the government of Vietnam's poorest province, Thanh Hoa, to start a long-term program aimed at increasing food production, improving education and curbing malnutrition. ``It's a special opportunity,'' Joy Carol, director of the organization's Asia Pacific programs, said Tuesday. ``We were working in Vietnam from 1963 to 1975. Now we are returning because we know the need is so great there.'' Carol also called the program, which is scheduled to begin in November, a ``project of reconciliation and healing.'' The program, which has the endorsement of the Vietnamese Mission to the United Nations and the Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation, is a pilot project which, if successful, may be extended to other areas of Vietnam.
