DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Flat in June
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending was flat in June after two consecutive monthly declines, the government said today in a report pointing to further evidence of weakness in the building industry. The Commerce Department reported that residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $447.5 billion. But it also said the declines in April and May were not as severe as first reported. The April decline was revised from 2.2 percent to 1.9 percent and the May drop was changed from 0.4 percent to 0.3 percent. Spending had risen 0.4 percent in March. Despite the recent weakness, construction spending in June was 3.7 percent above that of the same month in 1989, when it totaled $431.6 billion. Spending in January and February posted large gains which analysts attributed to unseasonably warm weather that prompted some builders to steal activity scheduled for later in the year. In addition, high interest rates and tighter lending requirements have held back construction projects in some areas. The industry weakness was suggested in the Labor Department's recent report showing a loss of 14,000 construction jobs in June on top of a 179,000 decline during the three previous months. Residential spending declined 2.2 percent to $196.1 billion at an annual rate after falling an identical 2.2 percent the previous month. Single-family spending was off 3.5 percent to $111.3 billion at an annual rate following a 4.0 percent decline in May. Apartment construction was unchanged at $30.8 billion after rising 1.5 percent the previous month. Non-residential spending jumped 3.9 percent to $107.1 billion after falling 0.9 percent in May. Leading the increase was a 10.2 percent gain in spending on office buildings. The often-volatile government sector edged down 0.1 percent to $108.4 billion after advancing 3.8 percent in May.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest Alleged Rape of Two Nuns in India
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Christians, led by white-robed nuns, marched to Prime Minister V.P. Singh's house today to protest the alleged rape of two nuns last month. India's 10,000 Christian-run private schools and colleges closed to protest the alleged rapes on July 13 at a Roman Catholic convent in a small town in the northern Uttar Pradesh state. Seven nuns holding hands led the demonstrators who chanted, ``We want justice!'' as they marched the two miles from India Gate, a British-built war memorial, to Singh's house. Police estimated that 15,000 people took part in the protest. That would make it the largest demonstration outside the prime minister's residence since Singh took office in December. ``We want assurances that what has happened will not happen again. We want protection for every single woman,'' Shruti Sinha, 19, said in a speech at the rally. Miss Sinha is a student at a college attached to the convent. The alleged rapes at St. Mary's Convent at Gajraula, 75 miles east of New Delhi, triggered widespread criticism of the state police. Christians organizations accused the police of ``inaction'' and a ``callous attitude'' toward the victims. The Sunday Observer newspaper said it was the first time since 1948 that a nun had been raped in India. Convent authorities allege that three men broke into the Roman Catholic convent, slipped into the nuns' quarters through a ventilator and ransacked several rooms. The convent authorities say the men then raped two nuns and stole $7,000. Two men have been arrested in connection with the reported crimes, but no date has been set for the trial. The two men admitted to stealing the money, but have denied raping the women. Protest organizers said many non-Christian social organizations, women's groups and a Sikh political party attended the rally. A 13-member delegation from the rally also gave a memorandum to Singh. The demonstrators then sat on the road near his home singing protest songs and waving placards that read ``Rape is a stain on the soul of a woman.'' There are about 23 million Christians, including 13 million Roman Catholics, living in India, a nation of 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Government Troops Stage Counterattack, Recapture Parts of Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with pope's appeal, RESTORE title on first reference to Doe. Pickup 13th, `In Tuesday's...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

A day after hundreds of refugees were massacred in a church sanctuary, government troops staged a surprise counterattack and recaptured parts of the city center from rebels in heavy fighting. One area touched by the intense combat Tuesday was the diplomatic enclave. At the height of the fighting, bullets ricocheted off several U.S. Embassy buildings, but no one was hurt, Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said in Washington. ``None of the combatants have targeted our people,'' he said. The United States said it was considering calling for a U.N. peacekeeping force to intervene in the West African nation's 7-month-old tribal war. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said there were no plans to evacuate the 400 Americans remaining in Liberia. A U.S. naval flotilla has been offshore for weeks in case evacuation is required. President Samuel Doe, who rebels accuse of corruption and suppression of opposition, made his first public statement since rebels reached the city's suburbs more than a month ago. Doe reiterated he does not intend to surrender. He said he would ``fight until the last soldiers in the Liberian army die.'' He spoke from the fortified Israeli-built presidential mansion, under siege by rebel forces led by Prince Johnson. The battles came a day after up to 600 civilian refugees were killed in a suburban St. Peter's Lutheran church compound. Witnesses said government troops, who used cutlasses and bayonets in addition to bullets, were to blame Doe said rebels dressed as soldiers were responsible for the massacre. ``I do not want to believe that the armed forces of Liberia would just walk into a church and kill innocent people,'' he said Tuesday in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. The victims were members of the Gio and Mano tribes, from which the rebels get most of their support. Soldiers accused of the massacre were said by witnesses to belong to Doe's Krahn tribe. In Rome, Pope John Paul II today decried the massacres of civilians in Liberia and appealed for an end to the ``fratricidal struggle'' in the African nation. The appeal was the pope's third since the fighting escalated. In Tuesday's government attack, about 500 soldiers emerged from Barclay Training Center, the main barracks in the capital, and took scattered rebel troops by surprise, witnesses said. Doe's soldiers advanced behind their sole remaining tank toward two strategic bridges leading from downtown Monrovia north to Bushrod Island, site of the capital's port and launching point of the rebel invasion of the city. In seesaw battles with rebels led by Johnson, government forces recaptured the finance and defense ministries and fought their way through the main shopping district. The counterattack led to heavy fighting in the embassy enclave of Mamba Point, which the rebels took Monday. Overall control of the area remained unclear. Two bullets landed in the garden of the French Embassy, which backs onto the Atlantic Ocean and neighbors the U.S. Embassy. No one was hurt. A high-rise building in the city center suspected of being a rebel observation point was set afire with a salvo from the government's multibarrel rocket-launcher, witnesses reported. The streets of downtown, filled for several days with civilians searching for food, suddenly emptied. Shops, offices and ministries remained closed. Most of Monrovia's 500,000 inhabitants have been without food, running water or electricity since last month. Doe said he was ``not prepared to hand Liberia over to criminals.'' This apparently referred to embezzlement charges against another rebel leader, Charles Taylor, who fled Liberia after he was accused of stealing $1 million from state coffers while he headed the government procurement agency. Government troops have kept Taylor's forces at bay just outside the city to the east. About 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the war, which began when the rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast in December. Doe has admitted his troops attacked refugees at the U.N. compound on May 30, killing an unarmed security guard and abducting 30 people who were later killed. The United Nations withdrew its personnel in protest. St. Peter's remained inaccessible to most foreign reporters and doctors on Tuesday. Volunteer nurses tending to the nearly 100 wounded at the church were hampered by lack of equipment and vehicles, diplomats said. The European humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders said government troops fired on doctors who rushed to aid the massacre victims. In a communique, the group said its team performed more than 30 operations despite threats against the doctors' lives by soldiers. Witnesses who managed to penetrate government lines said the soldiers again attacked civilian refugees Monday at the nearby J.J. Roberts Memorial School, killing at least four people. Relief workers and diplomats for weeks have expressed fears of such attacks on the city's 15 refugee centers and embassies sheltering people who fear tribal reprisals from both government troops and rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Coal Mine Explosion Kills Three
DOC.TEXT: Dynamite exploded while being transported inside a coal mine, killing three men and injuring two others and hurling a 5-ton mine vehicle 60 feet, officials said. ``She always wished he didn't have to work in the mines, that he could find a better job,'' Penny Simpson said of her cousin Willette, whose husband, Robert Cox, was one of those killed. Mrs. Cox, 20, has three small children. Investigators have not determined how much dynamite was being carried in the coal-hauling scoop on the front of the mine vehicle or how it was detonated. ``One stick would have killed them, and we're talking cases,'' Knox County Coroner Jerry Garland said. The explosion occurred Tuesday about 500 feet underground in Big Mama Coal Co.'s Mine No. 1 in Granny Rose Hollow about 10 miles southwest of Barbourville in southeastern Kentucky. A preliminary investigation indicated the explosives might not have been transported in the correct containers, said Willard Stanley, commissioner of the state Department of Mines and Minerals. The explosion blew the half-inch-thick steel scoop to bits and hurled the 5-ton vehicle more than 60 feet down the shaft, said Leroy Gross, district supervisor for the department. The mine was a non-union operation working a coal seam 24 inches thick, said Kathy Snyder, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration. The mine had received seven citations since it opened in mid-March, according to a spokesman for the federal agency. The agency said none of the seven citations involved handling of explosives or ventilation. State mine-safety records show the mine had recurrent problems controlling loose coal and coal dust _ which is explosive in certain conditions _ and supporting the mine roof properly. The company, owned by Robert Hembree of Barbourville, reported one mining fatality in 1987, its only death in the last five years, state records show. Eight men have died in mining accidents in Kentucky so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Activist Says He's Ready to End Own Life
DOC.TEXT: A man who claims to have helped eight fellow AIDS patients commit suicide says he has made arrangements to take his own life rather than face the most agonizing stages of the disease. ``I have people in my life who will help me end my life if I get too uncomfortable,'' David Lewis said in an interview Tuesday after his release from St. Paul's Hospital. He spent two weeks in the hospital with an AIDS-related illness. ``I'm terrified. I am not interested at all in getting Alzheimer's or AIDS dementia. If I get that far, I have instructed several people to say, `That's it, no more medication.''' The 38-year-old director of the Vancouver Persons With AIDS Society says he has been diagnosed as having lymphoma and toxoplasmosis in his brain, ``and it doesn't speak well for the future.'' ``They won't say how long I've got, but I've worked with people with AIDS for years and I know it's a couple of months _ if you're lucky,'' he said. Lewis recently announced that he had helped eight people suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome to commit suicide by getting them fatal doses of prescription drugs. In an interview at the time, he described euthanasia _ the termination of life when a person is terminally ill and wants to die _ as ``dignified, compassionate and respectful.''

DOC.HEAD: Sudan to Ask U.N. for More Relief for Government-Held Areas
DOC.TEXT: Sudan will ask the United Nations to give more relief supplies to government-held areas in the embattled south and less to rebel-controlled regions, a cabinet minister said today. Peter Orat, minister of relief and displaced people, was quoted by the government-owned al-Inkaz al-Watany newspaper as saying that a U.N. team of experts would survey areas in western and southern Sudan next week to verify government claims that displaced inhabitants have returned home. The government has claimed that some rebel-held areas had been recaptured by government forces leading to the repatriation of refugees to those areas. Orat said a previous agreement with the United Nations set the ratio of relief distribution at 33 percent for rebel-held areas and 67 percent to government-controlled areas. He said the government will ask the United Nations to change those ratios to reflect the repatriation of the refugees. Also today, the military government freed 18 trade unionists who were in custody on suspicion of instigating strikes, the official Sudan News Agency reported. SUNA said the releases were ``a good gesture from the revolution and a move to allow them to open a new page.'' Sudan's powerful trade and professional unions played an important role in overthrowing President Gaafar Nimeiri in 1985. They were active in Sudanese politics until Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir dissolved the unions shortly after taking power in a military coup in June 1989. After coming to power, el-Bashir's government arrested scores of unionists and made strikes illegal. The rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army took up arms against the government in 1983, demanding greater autonomy and economic reforms in southern Sudan. The fighting created famines that killed hundreds of thousands of civilians. In 1989, a U.N.-coordinated relief operation dubbed Operation Lifeline Sudan was successful in averting a repeat of the 1988 starvation which U.N. officials said killed 260,000 people. The U.N. operation has continued in 1990 at a smaller scale, and is facing political and logistical problems from the government and the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Leaders Question Chemical Weapons Incineration
DOC.TEXT: South Pacific nations today criticized a U.S. plan to burn chemical weapons on a remote Pacific atoll and said they would not allow the region to become ``the toxic waste disposal center of the world.'' But the communique, issued by the 15-nation South Pacific Forum at the end of a two-day meeting, stopped short of condemning the United States. The chemical weapons, which were stockpiled in West Germany and elsewhere, are to be destroyed at an incinerator now being tested on the Johnson Atoll. The United States has agreed to move its entire stockpile of chemical weapons out of West Germany by the end of the year. Also to be destroyed are 1,200 tons of weapons already on Johnston Atoll, which are so badly corroded by sea air they cannot be moved. In addition, a leaking stockpile of about 100 U.S. mustard-gas rounds dating from World War II recently was found in the Solomon Islands. Despite assurances from Washington, the Pacific leaders said they ``remained concerned by the substantial potential risks to the environment'' of the incineration of the chemical weapons. Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia argued in favor of the plan, saying scientific evidence indicated the incineration was safe. He said the project was in the interests of worldwide disarmament. The communique called for the incinerator to stop operating when the current project is completed. The Pacific leaders, whose governments represent about 25 million people, will discuss the issue Friday with a U.S. delegation. Also on hand for discussions will be representatives of Canada, China, Britain, Japan and France. On a related matter, many Pacific leaders also strongly object to French nuclear testing in Polynesia.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Want New Dialogue With Israel on Mideast
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze has invited his Israeli counterpart, David Levy, to talks on resolving the Middle East conflict, an Israeli official said today. The official from Israel's Foreign Ministry, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said Shevardnadze's invitation was given verbally by the leading Soviet consular delegate in Israel, Alexei Chestakov. The Soviet Union severed diplomatic relations with Israeli following the 1967 Middle East war but has been gradually improving ties since stationing consular representatives in Tel Aviv three years ago. A Shevardnadze-Levy meeting would not be the first between the Soviet foreign minister and a high-ranking Israeli official. Shevardnadze met last year with former Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, like Levy a member of the right-wing Likud bloc, and also met with former Science Minister Ezer Weizman, a leading dove in the left-leaning Labor Party. Chestakov told Levy in a meeting Tuesday that Shevardnadze believes the Soviet Union should ``give high priority to doing something immediate to lessen tensions in the Middle East,'' the Foreign Ministry official said. No date was set for the meeting, but it was likely the two would meet in New York City in September, when foreign ministers customarily attend the opening sessions of the U.N. General Assembly. Repeated efforts by the United States to initiate talks between Israel and representatives of the Palestinians have repeatedly stalled. Israel has refused to meet with members of the PLO, which Palestinians, who have been waging an uprising in the occupied territories, say is their sole representative. The Soviet Union is the key military supplier of Syria, Israel's most implacable foe in the Middle East. In the meeting with Chestakov, Levy urged the Soviets to quickly resume full diplomatic ties with Israel. The lack of such ties ``legitimizes the Arab hostile position toward Israel,'' Levy was quoted as saying. The Soviet Union has refused to resume diplomatic ties until Israel moves toward making peace with Palestinians. The Moroccan-born Levy, 52, holds the No. 2 spot in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. He took office when Shamir's coalition was installed on June 11. His August trip to Washington will be his first as foreign minister.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Army Celebrates 63rd Anniversary
LaserPhoto BEJ1
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese army celebrated its 63rd anniversary today with little fanfare but with renewed calls for strengthening the political and moral fiber of the nation's fighting force. Last year a media barrage surrounded the Aug. 1 anniversary designed to repair the army's image after the military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in Beijing. But this year, the even got little publicity. Tiananmen Square, closed last year for a military awards ceremony, was open today and filled with tourists. Neither the square nor adjoining Chang'an Avenue were decorated for Army Day. The Communist Party People's Daily carried a speech by party chief Jiang Zemin on its front page, but there were no red headlines, a tradition on major holidays. In the days prior to Aug. 1, speeches and newspaper commentaries emphasized that the army is subordinate to the Communist Party and that political education must be strengthened. Jiang told the nation in a televised speech Tuesday night that ``the basic factor in strengthening army construction is to persist in the party's absolute leadership over the army.'' ``Only by upholding the party's leadership can the army maintain its proletariat nature ... And maintain its correct political direction,'' he said. Jiang urged soldiers to ``enthusiastically study Marxist-Leninist theory, vigorously improve the quality of their ideolgocial thought ... And strengthen (their) ability to resist bourgeois liberalization and other corrosive, decadent influences.'' Bourgeois liberalization refers to Western ideas. Marshal Nie Rongzhen, one of the last surviving of China's 10 marshals, said in an interview published earlier this week that ``political integrity'' was just as important as ability in selecting officers. Alluding to a well-known saying by revolutionary leader Mao Tse-tung that power comes from the barrel of a gun, Nie said: ``The barrels of guns are very important (but) even more important is whose hand the barrels of guns are in.'' His words were echoed in a commentary in the army newspaper, the PLA Daily, which called on educational facilities, particularly military academies, to ``firmly place moral (or political) education in the number one position.'' ``Whether army school graduates are politically up to standard is in direct relation to who has control of the barrel of the gun,'' the unsigned commentary said.

DOC.HEAD: House Speaker Denounces Murder of British MP
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas Foley today denounced the Irish Republican Army for the murder of British Parliament member Ian Gow and said the bombing would not stifle political efforts to make peace. ``The clear and despicable purpose of this callous act was intimidation through terror,'' Foley said in an unusual speech on the House floor. Traditionally, House speakers do not take to the floor to speak about non-legislative matters. ``Reconciliation and necessary economic change cannot be purchased with the gun and the bomb,'' he said. Gow, a Conservative and a close friend of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, was killed Monday when a bomb detonated in his car at his home. Gow was an outspoken foe of the IRA. ``The IRA's guns and bombs have not brought independence for Northern Ireland, nor will they. They haven't brought jobs or the elimination of sectarian discrimination, nor will they. What they have bought, in the years since British troops were sent to Northern Ireland in 1972, is the deaths of many more civilian bystanders than of soldiers or policemen,'' Foley said. ``The IRA pretend to be the protector of the Catholic minority, but the IRA is responsible for the deaths of many more Catholics than protestants _ in fact, many more deaths than can be attributed to the British forces or the police.'' Neither, Foley added, will violence deter ``open discourse and the pursuit of peaceful political agreement among freely elected governments and legislatures.'' He expressed ``strong solidarity with our sister House in Westminster in its time of duress and sorrow,'' and concluded by urging that ``whatever the governments of Ireland and of the United Kingdom may resolve with respect to Northern Ireland, they do so without any reference, and in common defiance, to the terror tactics of the IRA.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Company Got $368,000 From Cashiers Who Confessed to Theft
DOC.TEXT: A convenience store chain, some of whose employees say they were forced to sign false admissions of theft, collected $368,000 from cashiers who confessed, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today. The newspaper said it obtained internal documents from Cumberland Farms Inc. that say the company obtained confessions from 57 percent of the 2,600 cashiers it questioned about theft during a six-month period. In recent weeks, the Inquirer has reported that 154 Cumberland Farms cashiers said they were falsely accused of stealing money and goods, then coerced to make restitution. The latest report was based on documents reporting on the performance of 15 ``loss prevention'' specialists at Cumberland Farms. They covered the first six months of 1986. The reports had been sent to the company's president at the time, Demetrios B. Haseotes, by James M. Mumma, director of loss prevention, and also went to the loss-prevention specialists, the newspaper said. Twelve former Cumberland Farms cashiers claimed in a 1986 lawsuit that the company had a longstanding policy to recover legitimate inventory losses by obtaining false confessions from employees. The lawsuit is awaiting trial in U.S. District Court in Camden, N.J. Foster G. Macrides, vice president for human resources, has said the Canton, Mass.-based convenience store and petroleum distribution company ``categorically denies'' the allegations in the lawsuit. He has said he could not comment on the other claims raised in recent Inquirer articles. He declined to comment on the documents disclosed today by the newspaper. Cumberland Farms has 1,100 stores and more than 9,000 employees in New England, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and Florida. It was listed by Forbes magazine last December as the nation's 35th largest privately held U.S. company with an estimated $3 billion in revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Three American Drug Agents Charged with Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with DEA denying chargess, confirming agents have left the Philippines and will not return to face trial. No pickup. ^By ROBERT H. REID
DOC.TEXT: The military filed murder charges today against three American drug agents and 13 Filipino policemen in the slaying of three soldiers killed during an alleged drug bust last month. Officials in Washington said today that the charges against the three American agents ``have no merit,'' that the men have been removed from the Philippines, and that they will not return to stand trial. The charges were filed with the provincial prosecutor against Philip Needham, Andrew Fenrich and Jake Fernandez, agents of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, according to Brig. Gen. Gerardo Flores, chief of staff of the Philippine Constabulary. Flores said 10 of the 16 were charged before a military court. Under Philippine law, prosecutors decide whether to indict those charged by police. The U.S. Embassy said the three Americans have left the country and ``have no immediate plans to return.'' Needham was assigned to the DEA office in Bangkok, Thailand, and the others were posted in Manila. In Bangkok, Needham said he had no comment on the incident and referred all further inquiries to the Drug Enforcement Administration in Washington. ``These charges have no merit,'' DEA Administrator Terrence Burke said in a statement issued in Washington today. DEA spokesman Joe Keefe, who confirmed the three agents have left the Philippines, said in Washington that the men didn't even use their firearms on the day the shooting incident occurred. ``We would like to emphasize that the DEA agents were working at the request of the Philippines government in cooperation with the National Bureau of Investigation,'' he said. ``We're cooperating with the Philippine government on this situation,'' Keefe said, but he added that there are no plans to return the three DEA agents to the Philippines to face the murder charges. The charges stem from a July 10 incident in which Col. Rolando de Guzman, deputy chief of the Northern Luzon Command; his intelligence officer, Maj. Frank Calanog; and another soldier were slain in what police said was a shootout during a drug bust. According to the National Bureau of Investigation, de Guzman and the others tried to sell $10 million worth of heroin to Needham, who was posing as a buyer. Shooting broke out when the three resisted arrest, the bureau claims. But Flores said his investigation showed the three were slain ``under the control'' of police and ``could not have fired their weapons.'' Brig. Gen. Virgilio David, chief of the military's Narcotics Command, called the slayings ``cold-blooded murder.'' ``The high values in law enforcement are taken into consideration and to prevent crimes,'' Flores said. ``We arrest suspects, not kill them.'' Embassy officials have not given a detailed account of what they believe transpired. Ten of the Filipinos ordered arrested are members of the Manila police department detailed to the National Bureau of Investigation during the case. They include Capt. Reynaldo Jaylo, cited by President Corazon Aquino last month as one of the country's outstanding police officers. The three others are assigned to the National Bureau of Investigation and include Epimaco Velasco, assistant to Bureau Director Alfredo Lim. When Lim announced the shootout last month, he told reporters that an American, later identified as Needham, ``escaped.'' The next day, however, the Philippine Daily Inquirer quoted unidentified military sources as saying Needham was a DEA agent from Bangkok. Military sources said on condition of anonymity that senior officers suspect the killing was a plot by the CIA to drive a wedge between the military and the police and encourage a coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino. The U.S. Embassy for years has denied repeated speculation that Washington was secretly supporting coup plots to force the Philippines into extending the lease on the six U.S. military bases. The lease expires next year. Senior officers, speaking on condition of anonymity, expressed outrage that National Bureau of Investigation agents had ``murdered'' their comrades ``on orders of the Americans.'' Mrs. Aquino has faced six coup attempts since she took office in 1986 after a ``People power'' revolt that ousted longtime dictator Ferdinand Marcos. The DEA says the Philippines is a transshipment point for heroin and a new form of methamphetamine called ``ice,'' and a main source of marijuana.
