DOC.HEAD: Democrats Laud, Republicans Rap Defense Bill That Cuts SDI, Stealth
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on the House Armed Services Committee today hailed their $283 billion defense bill for reflecting the ``new threat, the new challenges'' with deep budget cuts in the Strategic Defense Initiative and a halt to the stealth bomber program. ``I think it's a combination of the changes in the Soviet threat and the changes in the budget deficit,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the panel, said of the bill that was approved by the committee overwhelmingly, 40-12. Acknowledging the end of the Cold War, the legislation makes wholesale reductions in several major strategic programs and for the first time ever kills a major weapons system _ the B-2 bomber, Aspin said. The committee realized that ``you've got to take something out and one candidate with the lowest priority was the B-2,'' the chairman told reporters at a news conference. The Air Force's chief of staff, Gen. Michael Dugan, predicted that in the end Congress will not kill the B-2, saying in an interview on Fox television today that ``thoughtful men and women ... will come to the conclusion that if you want peace, you have to prepare for war.'' But Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said that the bill ``very much fits the new threat, the new challenges.'' Some Republicans gave the legislation low marks on Tuesday. ``It stinks,'' said Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the committee. ``I voted against it and I will strongly urge the president to veto it.'' The legislation, which the full House will consider in early September, slashes $24 billion from Bush's proposal of $307 billion in military spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. It also marks a drop from this year's $305 billion defense. The Senate is expected to take up its $289 billion version of the defense bill later this week. Among major provisions of the House bill is an end to the radar-evading, B-2 stealth bomber at the 15 planes currently in development, a cut of $2.9 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, elimination of all money for two land-based nuclear missile systems and a cut of 129,500 military personnel. President Bush had called for two stealth aircraft in fiscal 1991, $4.7 billion for SDI, commonly known as Star Wars; more than $2 billion for the MX and Midgetman missiles and a troop reduction of 38,000. While chopping money from strategic programs, the panel rejected Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's second attempt in two years to kill the V-22 Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft that has widespread support in Congress. The Armed Services Committee added $403 million for the Marine Corps' hybrid plane, which is manufactured in Texas and Pennsylvania. ``If you like to smell the pork, you'd love this bill,'' Dickinson quipped. Although support for the B-2 bomber remains in the Senate, the panel dealt a serious blow to Bush's plan to build a 75-plane fleet. At nearly $865 million apiece, the aircraft are the costliest planes ever built. On Monday, the panel's procurement subcommittee eliminated funds for the bomber in the new fiscal year, thus cutting off purchases after the first 15. The full committee voted 34-20 Tuesday to reject an amendment by Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., to reverse the subcommittee's action. ``People were surprised the Berlin Wall fell down,'' said Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, co-sponsor of legislation to cancel the B-2 program. ``It's surprising the Armed Services panel killed a major weapons program.'' Nine Republicans voted to terminate the stealth bomber, Kasich said. Bush had sought $4.6 billion in the budget for two of the bat-winged planes next year and advanced procurement of parts for six more in the following year. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in its version of the defense bill approved earlier this month, adopted the administration's request. On another major strategic system, Bush had called for $2.1 billion for the multiple-warhead MX missile and for moving the missiles from fixed underground silos to railroad cars. He also sought $202 million in research money for the single-warhead Midgetman. The House committee eliminated all that money and, instead, created a $600 million pot for developing the next generation of intercontinental missiles. The panel also called on Bush to report to the panel in 90 days on which new missile the administration wants _ a mobile MX or the new Midgetman _ and end the long-running debate over which project to back. The committee also approved: _One of two Seawolf attack submarines Bush had sought; five destroyers at a cost of $3.6 billion and $1.2 billion for the 18th Trident missile-launching submarine. _A ban on spending any money to move the 401st Tactical Fighter Wing from Torrejon de Ardoz, Spain, to Crotone, Italy, or any other location overseas. The provision touched off a lengthy debate in the committee, with Republicans criticizing the amendment as detrimental to the U.S. position in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. _Postponing full-scale development of the Advanced Tactical Fighter, delaying the Scout Attack Helicopter project and restricting the C-17 transport plane program until Cheney can certify the first flight.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Free Europe Starts Broadcasting From Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: Radio Free Europe began broadcasting directly from Prague on Wednesday after 40 years of transmitting news to Czechoslovakia from abroad. ``For the first time in history, RFE is broadcasting directly from within a country about that country instead of from abroad,'' said Pavel Pechacek, director of Czechoslovak broadcasting for Radio Free Europe. For 40 years, RFE broadcasts were jammed in Czechoslovakia and the rest of Eastern Europe to prevent the flow of uncensored information about the Soviet bloc and news from the West. ``The fact that we are now able to transmit over Czechoslovak radio is really the best proof of the progress and development which has taken place in this country in the short period of eight months,'' Pechacek said. He was referring to the period following the peaceful revolution last fall that toppled the Communist regime in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Commemorates 1944 Uprising Against Nazis
DOC.TEXT: More than 3,000 people joined the president and prime minister Wednesday in a wreath-laying ceremony commemorating the outbreak of the Warsaw uprising against the Nazis in World War II. President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki laid a wreath of red and white carnations at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier to honor the 63-day struggle of the underground Home Army to free Poland's capital from German occupation. More than 20,000 Home Army soldiers and about 225,000 civilians were killed in the uprising before the insurgents surrendered. The leaders of the uprising hoped for assistance from the Soviet Army, which was approaching Warsaw from the east during the summer of 1944. But the Soviets stopped at the eastern bank of the Vistula River, within sight of Warsaw, until January 1945. Warsaw residents commemorate the insurgents each August by laying flowers and wreaths and lighting candles at monuments and graves around the city.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Killed, 18 Hurt In Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A bus en route from Morocco to Paris skidded and crashed on a highway, killing nine people on board and injuring 18, police said Wednesday. The French-owned bus crashed Tuesday as it was heading to take a ferry across the Strait of Gibraltar. Police said those killed were Moroccans living in France. No details were given about the circumstances of the accident. Seven of the injured were reported seriously hurt.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Accuses Libya, Sudan of Planning Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday accused Libya and Sudan of assembling an army of dissidents and mercenaries to launch a ``total war'' against Chad. Neither Libya nor Sudan issued any immediate response to the allegations. A large-scale offensive would be mounted from the Sudanese province of Darfur, according to an official communique drafted at an emergency meeting of the Cabinet and the ruling party's top leaders. The invasion force consists of ``hundreds and hundreds of mercenaries'' recruited from Sudan, Mali and Mauritania, as well as Chadian rebels, the communique alleged. It said the attackers would be backed by Soviet- and Brazilian-made armored vehicles driven or airlifted from Libya. The communique accused Libya of trying to torpedo talks aimed at resolving longstanding differences between the neighboring countries. Libya and Chad have been feuding since 1973 over a section of territory along their border called the Aouzou Strip. In 1984, Libyan troops and Chadian rebels took control of much of northern Chad. They were defeated by government forces in 1987. A one-year accord proposing efforts to find a peaceful settlement expires Aug. 31, and delegations from the two countries are to meet in Algeria in two weeks for what has been described as ``last chance'' negotiations. By issuing the communique, Chadian officials appeared to be suggesting they had little hope for a negotiated settlement. Sudan's military government has acknowledged that fighting between Chadian government forces and rebels in Darfur has spread into Sudanese territory.

DOC.HEAD: Provinces Ration Drinking Water as Warm Weather Continues
DOC.TEXT: Two of Belgium's nine provinces have rationed water, and a third asked the public to limit the use of tap water as hot, dry weather continued to affect water supplies, officials said Wednesday. Limburg joined West Flanders on Wednesday in barring the use of tap water for watering gardens, washing cars and filling private swimming pools. Antwerp, also faced with a shortage of tap water, urged the public to use water sparingly. The three provinces are in northern Belgium. Forecasters predicted more weather in the 90s for the rest of the week. There has not been a heavy rainfall in nearly a month.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Urged to Cut Water Use in Dry Spell
DOC.TEXT: Don't wash the car. Turn off the fountain. Turn off that tap while brushing your teeth. The almost 12 million residents of Tokyo were urged Wednesday to make a further cut in their use of water because a hot, dry summer has left reservoirs at only 35 percent of capacity. Tokyo residents were urged a month ago to cut water use by 5 percent and now are being asked to cut back by a total of 10 percent. Industrial users were urged to reduce their water consumption by 15 percent. Tadao Sahoda, a spokesman for the Tokyo Waterworks Bureau, said water pressure would be cut by up to 10 percent at night starting Friday. Sahoda said rainfall in upper reaches of the Tone River, which provides most of Tokyo's water, was 40 percent to 60 percent below the level for this time last year.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Killed in Building Collapse
DOC.TEXT: A shopping center under construction collapsed Wednesday in western India, crushing to death at least 15 people and injuring 11, United News of India reported. The news agency said several more people were feared trapped under the rubble in Neemuch. The town is in Madhya Pradesh state, 310 miles southwest of New Delhi. The shopping center was half completed, UNI said.

DOC.HEAD: Good News for Italian Prostitutes: No New Taxes
DOC.TEXT: As far as the tax man is concerned, the oldest profession in the world does not exist in Italy. That was the government's explanation in Parliament on Wednesday of why prostitutes are not taxed. ``Tax authorities cannot be bound by problems of a moral character,'' said Stefano De Luca, undersecretary of finance. De Luca explained that prostitution is not a recognized profession on tax forms and therefore is not subject to either income or sale taxes. He was responding to a question from deputy Filippo Berselli, who demanded to know why the government, always eager for new revenue, was ignoring prostitutes' earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Consortium to Salvage Sunken Soviet Sub
DOC.TEXT: A Dutch consortium will salvage a Soviet nuclear submarine that sank off Norway in April 1989, the official Tass news agency reported. ``The Dutch plan is realistic, well-substantiated technically, and economically sound,'' Tass on Tuesday quoted the deputy minister of shipbuilding, Leonid Rezunov, as telling the Pravitelstvenny Vestnik newspaper. The Soviet navy submarine Komsmolets, carrying nuclear-tipped torpedoes, sank in nearly one mile of water after a fire broke out on board. Forty-two Soviet seamen died in the accident. Tass said the accident did not cause any radiation problems in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Yeltsin to Work Out Joint Economic Program
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his main political rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, have formed a joint committee to revamp the Soviet economy, in a sign that Gorbachev is willing to move faster toward market reforms. The 12-member committee, which held its first meeting Wednesday, brought together moderate reformers loyal to Gorbachev and more radical reformers supporting Yeltsin, the president of the huge Russian republic who recently quit Gorbachev's Communist Party. A Western diplomat termed the move ``rather important'' because the national government was in danger of falling far behind economic changes introduced in Russia, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. ``If they don't do something like this, they are going to be left behind,'' the diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Russia is going to move ahead fast.'' More rapid reform of the Soviet economy also could increase the chances for obtaining Western aid, which Gorbachev says is necessary to reform the economy. Gorbachev's top economic adviser, Nikolai Y. Petrakov, said in an interview that the decision to form the committee was ``the most important information of 1990'' in Soviet domestic politics. He said Gorbachev and Yeltsin signed the agreement Saturday after several days of talks. The economists appointed to it will develop a common economic policy for the nation. Petrakov said it was too early to say what they might recommend, but their work should be done by Sept. 1, when the national and Russian parliaments reconvene. Economic reforms will be of top priority at the sessions. The committee includes such proponents of reform as Petrakov, Deputy Premier Leonid A. Abalkin, Presidential Council member Stanislav Shatalin, economist and writer Nikolai Shmelev, Yeltsin deputy Grigory Yavlinsky and Russian Finance Minister Boris Fyodorov. The Interfax news service identifed Yavlinsky as the author of Yeltsin's ``500 Days'' economic program to move Russia to a market economy. Over Gorbachev's objections, Yeltsin was elected in May to head Russia, which contains three-fourths of the Soviet Union's land and more than half its people. Since then, he has slowly outlined plans to overhaul the republic's economy. He has shown tolerance toward private property and in recent weeks indicated he intends to radically reform land ownership and seize control of banking. That brought a sharp response from Gorbachev, who on Sunday urged Soviet republics not to try to break away from the central money and banking system. Gorbachev and his premier, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, have moved more slowly on the economy and are facing sharp criticism for its failures. Yeltsin and other reformers have urged Ryzhkov to resign. Yeltsin also quit the Communist Party last month, starting an exodus of leading reformers. The independent Postfactum news service reported that Gorbachev and Yeltsin froze Ryzhkov out of their agreement and that the premier refused to sign it for several days. A January-June economic report released Sunday indicated the Soviet economy continued to deteriorate in the first half of the year. The gross national product _ the value of retail prices of all goods and services produced _ dropped 1 percent. Labor productivity dropped 1.5 percent. The Postfactum news service reported that the committee will not recommend immediate price increases, which is something Ryzhkov recommended. Under his proposal, bread prices would have increased in stages beginning July 1, but the national parliament rejected the idea. It told the government to return with a better plan in the fall. Yeltsin also opposed the plan, saying it would hit Soviet consumers too hard. A top Russian republic official, deputy parliamentary chairman Boris Isayev, told a briefing Tuesday that a special parliamentary session of the Russian republic would be called in late October to reform farm policy. The government intends to submit measures that would allow farmers to own land for life, to inherit it, and buy and sell it, Tass quoted Isayev as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Thirteen Bodies Pulled From Quake Rubble
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen bodies were recovered Wednesday from the rubble of a hotel that collapsed in an earthquake July 16, and a doctor said one of the victims may have lived a week before dying in the debris. More than 40 people, including 30 guests, remain unaccounted for at the Hyatt Terraces Hotel, one of nearly 30 buildings that collapsed in Baguio during the earthquake. The quake killed more than 1,600 people throughout Luzon island and left more than 110,000 homeless. About 1,000 people remain missing. The U.S. Embassy said 12 of those missing at the Hyatt are Americans of Filipino origin. Gus Baloy, a hotel employee, said the 13 bodies were recovered during a seven-hour period beginning Wednesday morning. All were employees of the hotel, he said. A doctor who spoke on condition of anonymity said that based on an examination of the body, it appeared one of the victims may have lived for a week after the earthquake. He said the body, that of a woman, bore no life-threatening injuries. Hopes of finding more survivors were raised after Pedrito Dy, 27, a hotel cook and part-time gym instructor, was rescued Monday from the ruins of the Hyatt. Dy survived 14 days under the rubble by drinking rainwater and his own urine. Two other hotel employees _ a man and a woman _ were rescued Friday after being trapped for 11 days. All three are recovering in hospitals. Foreign rescue teams in Baguio abandoned the search for survivors more than a week ago, but Filipino rescuers, mostly miners, have continued. ``As long as those people trapped inside believe and have faith in God, they will survive,'' said miner Pablo Binwag. ``The search will continue.'' Baguio, a mountain resort, was one of the cities hit hardest by the quake, which registered 7.7 on the Richter scale. Jose de Jesus, the government official in charge of relief and rescue in Baguio, said there were still 1,500 families living in evacuation centers in the city. He said emergency measures were needed to help them recover. With tourism in the resort at a ``zero level,'' de Jesus said business will stop and many people will become jobless. ``This is something that we need to address immediately,'' he said. ``We need to have some kind of emergency employment for these people in Baguio.''

DOC.HEAD: Press Freedom Law Takes Effect in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The first press freedom law went into effect in the Soviet Union Wednesday, guaranteeing broad rights for journalists and potential publishers. The law, unanimously approved by the Supreme Soviet legislature in June after months of debate, promises: ``The press and other mass media are free,'' and ``censorship of the mass media is forbidden.'' Censorship by the Communist Party, the government and a special censorship agency kept the Soviet news media under tight control before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. Political pressure on the media began to lighten under Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, but until now they still lacked legal protection from interference. Technically, freedom of the press was guaranteed by a declaration in the Soviet Constitution, but the new law is the first to spell out detailed guarantees of press freedoms. Soviet journalists' new freedoms include the right to attend meetings and be present at the scene of disasters, the right to refuse to prepare reports that are against a journalist's convictions and the right to hold interviews with officials. They now can withdraw their byline if the contents of a story are distorted by editing. To establish a new publication or news organization, the new law says Soviets need only provide their name, address, frequency of publication, circulation figures and source of financing. All publications will be permitted except those calling for the violent overthrow of the government, promoting racial or religious intolerance, or publishing propaganda for war, violence or cruelty. But a bigger barrier is the shortage of newsprint and its increasing costs. Distribution of paper and printing plants will remain part of the state economy. ``The law goes into effect at a time when there is an acute shortage of newsprint and printing services,'' Tass reported Wednesday. ``Just when subscriptions are to be received, the U.S.S.R. Ministry of Communications announced the establishment of higher tariffs for the delivery of printing matter to subscribers. As a result, the price of most newspapers and magazines will at least double, wiping out many publications.''
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

July 28 The Register-Guard, Eugene, Ore., on the income gap: Resentment of the rich is a recurrent theme of American politics. It has fueled populist sentiment that rises angrily and then lies dormant for a while. A new wave of such feeling may be sweeping toward the electoral beach today. The reason is that during the 1980s in the United States, the rich got considerably richer, the poor got poorer, and the majority in the middle treaded water. A report confirming that common impression was issued ... by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, based on data released by the Congressional Budget Office. ... (T)he center concluded, ``the combined incomes of the richest 2.5 million Americans now nearly equal the combined incomes of the 100 million Americans with the lowest incomes.'' These developments have powerful implications for public policy and politics. The clearest example of the former is the capital gains tax cut advocated by the Bush administration. The center says the data show clearly that the rich gained the most from the tax cuts approved during the Reagan years. And it calculates that 94 percent of the benefit from the proposed capital gains tax cut would go to the richest 20 percent of Americans, making the gap between the rich and the not-rich wider than ever. ... (T)he facts of national income disparity cannot be glossed. They represent a disturbing problem that needs to be addressed by all parties and factions, not disguised or ignored.

July 25 Philadelphia Daily News, on military spending: It's hard not to laugh at the Pentagon's idiocy. Consider the $999.20 pair of pliers Pratt and Whitney managed to foist on the blue-suited dopes of the Air Force. Paying almost a grand for a pair of pliers, after all, is something Curly, Larry and Moe might do with their inheritance. When Pratt and Whitney explains, ``They're multipurpose; not only do they put the clips on but they take them off,'' it goes somewhere Pee-Wee Herman's imagination could not follow. It's funny, that is, until you realize who's been had, until you realize that Pratt and Whitney set the price just 80 cents under the $1,000 limit that would have required the Air Force to buy the damn thing from the people who actually made it, instead of a greedy middleman. Take away that big score motive, and the Air Force might have shlepped down to Sears and bought it for $2.49 and gotten a lifetime warranty to boot. You paid the difference. Funny, huh?

July 26 The Parkersburg (W.Va.) News on the congressional mailing privileges: One of the worst abuses of office regularly perpetrated on Capitol Hill is the use of taxpayer-supported ``free'' congressional mailing privileges to send de facto campaign brochures to constituents. Among the worst offenders are freshman members of the House, who use the franking privilege to put their names (and usually their pictures) before the voters. This helps them build name recognition, which is crucial to any election effort, but is especially important to those seeking reelection. An informal study by The Washington Post found that members of the House are urging some inventive ways to get around the few restrictions on franked mail. Members are limited to three mass-mailed newsletters, but there is no limit on the number of notices for meetings that may be sent out, nor is there any limit on mailings of less than 500 pieces. Well (surprise, surprise), freshman House members (and many of their more senior brethren as well) have found an easy way around that one. Hold lots of meetings. Meetings that just happen to take place during the six months prior to elections. And, by all means, don't rely on the local media to publicize these purely nonpolitical meetings with constituents. No siree. Better tell them about it by postcard. Several times. ``At a cost of about 13 cents per piece of bulk mail, each mass-mailed town meeting notice newsletter to 225,000 households in an average congressional district would cost the taxpayers $29,250,'' the Post notes. No wonder the House has a 98 percent reelection rate. When an incumbent sends out three or four mass mailings a year, he is taking a de facto $100,000-plus campaign contribution straight from taxpayers, many of whom would not give him a dime if openly solicited. It is difficult, if not impossible, for any challenger to overcome the bottomless and unprincipled pockets of incumbents who abuse their mailing privileges.

July 31 Long Beach (Calif.) Press Telegram on the Louisiana abortion law veto: Anti-abortionists in Louisiana are helping to shape the future of international family planning more directly than you might ever imagine. In France, the maker of the abortion pill RU-486 admits that drug's distribution has been slowed by fears of American opinion. The result is that RU-486, which has the promise of saving hundreds of thousands of women's lives each year, has been kept away from countries desperate to have it. In Louisiana, Gov. Buddy Roemer ... vetoed two excessively restrictive anti-abortion bills passed by the state Legislature this year. The first, long since gone, permitted abortion only to save the mother's life. The second expanded abortion to victims of incest and aggravated rape, as long as the crime was reported to police and medical attention was sought within seven days. Such cruel and unusual conditions prompted Roemer's second veto. In such a process, an erroneous message is sent around the world _ that most Americans are rabidly opposed to abortion. Indeed the German conglomerate that owns the French pharmaceutical firm that makes RU-486 is so afraid of an American boycott that it has relegated international control of RU-486 to the World Health Organization. ... The feeble sensitivities of European industrialists no doubt give pleasure to many anti-abortionists. Yet when 200,000 women worldwide die for lack of a reliable, low-cost, low-risk abortion procedure, the efforts to make RU-486 unavailable are in themselves inhumane.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
Eds: Top 18 grafs new with White House briefing, quotes from Gingrich and moves up reference to Democrats; picks up 8th graf pvs, `We're not ...; edits to trim.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised today to turn up the political heat on Democrats unless they produce a deficit-reduction plan by the end of the week, Republican lawmakers said. However, the White House said Bush was not imposing any deadlines and expected that budget talks would intensify in September when Congress returns from its summer recess. Congressional Democrats gave no indication they were ready to offer a budget proposal. Noting that Republicans have been hit with tough criticism for their package, House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta said, ``We didn't pledge that every time the Republicans slit their wrists that we would slit ours.'' The Republican plan calls for increasing taxes on alcohol and limiting tax deductions on state and local taxes. Bush discusssed the budget impasse over coffee and donuts this morning with about 150 Republican members of the House and Senate. Bush vowed to veto spending bills and force Congress to live with a sequester, or deep automatic cuts, if the lawmakers fail to come to terms on a plan to slash $500 billion from the deficit over the next five years, GOP leaders said. GOP lawmakers left the session declaring that Bush was getting ready to go on the offensive unless the Democrats offer their own version of a deficit-reduction plan within 48 hours. House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich said, ``The first phase of the summit has collapsed.'' Indeed, it appeared unlikely that serious bargaining would happen before September, when the vacationing Bush and Congress both return to Washington. Gingrich said Bush indicated he was willing to stay in Washington to get a budget agreement, even though he is under pressure from his wife to join her at their Kennebunkport retreat. Gingrich quoted Bush as saying, ``You know, Barbara's up at Kennebunkport with two dogs, one of them sick, and with six grandkids and she needs me.'' White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said Bush, in his meeting with Republicans, said, ``We have been dealing with the Democrats in good faith and we have a plan we are prepared to share with them when they present theirs. They have not yet done so.'' In contrast with GOP lawmakers' predictions that Bush would get tough with the Democrats, Popadiuk said merely that it was ``obvious that we are frustrated by this process, that there's very little progress and, of course the American people (can) judge for themselves on this issue. ``I can expect the president to speak out but in what degree or in what shape, form or manner, I do not know,'' Popadiuk said. Lawmakers said Bush told them he wants a budget plan from Democrats by Friday. If that doesn't happen, said House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich, ``I think he may start getting tough in August. ... I think the White House has been far more patient than I would be.'' White House deputy press secretary Alixe Glen said, ``You can assume that when the GOP lawmakers go home they won't be shy about the foot-dragging we've seen by the Democrats about finding a credible solution to the budget deficit.'' ``We're not going anyplace until (the Democrats) get some numbers on the table,'' said House Minority Leader Bob Michel of Illinois. Bush is ``certainly not going to keep his trap shut all during August.'' ``I think that the first phase of the summit has collapsed,'' said Gingrich. Congressional Democrats, while not flatly ruling out that they would present a budget proposal before the August recess, gave no indication they would do so. Instead, they said the goal now was to work out a schedule with the administration for reaching a deficit-reduction pact in September. ``Getting involved in partisan recriminations isn't going to help that process,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. Bush and the Republicans held out hopes of reviving the budget negotiations in early September after Congress returns from its summer vacation. But unless the Democrats put a plan on the table by Friday, there will be no agreement before Congress takes its recess next week, they said. ``The president said he hoped the Democrats would submit a plan by Friday,'' said Gingrich. But if they don't, then ``obviously any agreement to not talk in public has no meaning,'' he said. ``He hopes to bring everybody back in early September and have serious negotiations,'' said Gingrich. But ``he'll veto spending bills across the board if they're above his spending request. He will sustain a sequester until Congress passes a five-year agreement and not let the Congress get out of sequester.'' The White House previously has estimated that without a budget agreement, the Gramm-Rudman law could inflict automatic cuts of $100 billion or more on many federal programs in October. About 150 of the 176 House Republicans and 45 GOP senators attended the strategy session with Bush over coffee at the White House, participants said. Michel said, ``He's a very kind, gentle individual, but, brother, he's got fire in his belly over ... the summit negotiations, where we're getting nowhere and he takes all the brunt of the criticism.'' Republicans have been furious with Democrats for not offering a deficit-reduction plan at the 12-week-old budget talks. The bargaining is aimed at shrinking a budget shortfall expected to reach $169 billion next year, not including the $100 billion cost of rescuing failed savings and loans. Details of a Bush administration plan surfaced last week containing $54 billion in spending cuts and new taxes for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. It included higher alcohol levies and a limit to the deductibility of state and local income taxes, proposals that drew widespread criticism, including from the GOP. Some Republicans criticized White House chief of staff John Sununu and White House budget chief Richard Darman last week for not keeping them informed about the administration's ideas about cutting the deficit. Democrats have not even tried to put their own budget plan together in recent private meetings among themselves, according to participants. Instead, they and administration officials are trying to hammer out a schedule for completing a pact when lawmakers return to the capital in September. Budget talks will continue intermittently during the August break, Democrats have said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: themselves inhumane.
DOC.TEXT: July 27 The Asbury Park Press, Neptune, N.J., on David Souter: Reporters, lobbyists and the staff of the Senate Judiciary Committee are furiously combing through musty files while David Hackett Souter, a 50-year-old bachelor who lives on his family's New Hampshire farm, meets informally with Republican senators on the committee. Souter is being touted as a wise choice to become as associate justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, primarily because he has not left an easily discernible paper trail on the controversial issues _ chiefly abortion rights _ the high court must confront. No one can predict what ... Souter would do in all instances as a justice. Senators and presidents know that members of the high court often take surprising turns of thought after they are confirmed for life. But the senators should attempt to discover what kind of jurist Souter is. Let's hope the confirmation hearings are probing and thoughtful.

July 26 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on Barney Frank: The House Ethics Committee has voted to reprimand Rep. Barney Frank, D- Mass., for his dealings with a prostitute named Stephen Gobie. This strikes us as the appropriate punishment for ... Frank. ... The fact that ... Frank's relationship with ... Gobie was a private matter and did not involve his duties as a member of Congress, suggests to us that a reprimand is sufficient discipline under the circumstances. ... Frank's political future now rests where it belongs: With his constituents. The voters of the Fourth Congressional District of Massachusetts know all they need to know about the Gobie affair, and may cast their ballots accordingly. In our view, it is not the proper function of the House to judge members on their personal lives _ unless, of course, those personal lives interfere with public responsibilities. ... Frank's transgressions were not criminal ... nor did they involve his duties as a congressman.

July 29 Grand Forks (N.D.) Herald on the federal farm bill: Farm country politicians have been wringing their hands all week about the fate of the farm bill. What if the president were to veto it? A farm bill veto would not be such a bad thing. Certainly it is better than five more years of confused and haphazard farm policy. Certainly it is better than international confrontation about agricultural trade. And certainly it is better than more bellyaching about the high cost of farm programs. A presidential veto only means that the current farm bill would be extended for a year. Congress could use that extension to begin a realistic overhaul of farm programs.

July 27 Hannibal (Mo.) Courier-Post on the federal farm bill: The (farm) bill is vital to farmers and to the Midwest economy which is so reliant on agriculture. That's why it is imperative that the Senate maintain its perspective and not allow the bill to get bogged down in unrelated or superfluous amendments. It is now time for an end to additional amendments. We applaud the Senate for its long hours of work on the farm bill. We only hope that senators don't lose sight of the importance of the bill in the fog of lengthy debate.

July 30 Chicago Tribune on children's TV: Last week the House of Representatives voted to protect children from the dangerous effects of unwholesome television. No, it didn't outlaw live coverage of the House of Representatives, part of what Mark Twain once called the only distinctly native American criminal class. Instead it placed new burdens on broadcasters, who are accused of neglecting the interests of children. The House, which would never presume to tell Dr. Seuss what to write, nevertheless feels perfectly justified in trying to dictate what children's TV programmers should offer. Members have detected the smell of commerce and their nostrils are offended. Their remedy is a limit of 10{ minutes of commercials per half hour on weekends and 12 minutes on weekdays, and a new requirement that the Federal Communications Commission consider the amount and type of kids' programs when it rules on the renewal of broadcasters' licenses. ... President Reagan killed a similar bill shortly before leaving office. If the latest version gets through the Senate, President Bush should do the same. ... If there is a problem, it lies well within the authority of parents. Those who prefer more elevating fare than ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' can direct their kids to plenty of options: watching ``Sesame Street'' and ``Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' picking up a Disney feature at the video store or curling up with a good book. They don't need the interference of Congress.

July 30 San Antonio Light on Roseanne Barr: Of baseball games it's often said that the opera ain't over until the fat lady sings. But Roseanne Barr, by her own admission, is no opera singer. ``They didn't hire me because I am Beverly Sills,'' the rotund actress-comedienne noted after her tuneless rendition of ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' before a San Diego Padres home game touched off a national uproar. ... Simmer down, folks. Barr's unfortunate experience with Francis Scott Key's ode to Old Glory was no national disgrace, but it did call attention to an often-overlooked problem: Our national anthem is unsingable
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Dentist Looks to Bucking Bull for Thrills
DOC.TEXT: When dentist Lance Lindenmuth doesn't have his hand in someone's mouth, he thinks it's fun to be thrown from the back of a 2,000-pound bucking bull, or from a mechanical bull in his backyard. He also skydives. ``I'm the type of person that sees a lot of action in life,'' said Lindenmuth, 29. ``If you haven't experienced life, if you haven't gotten into it and done some things, you really haven't lived,'' he said. He took up bullriding a few months ago just for the thrill of it. He's ridden 11 bulls so far, and has yet to stay on the required eight seconds. ``I've heard it takes 50 bulls before you get the hang of it.'' He's competing against guys who started riding calves when they were 6, but Lindenmuth is ready for the challenge. ``I figure I'm very capable physically, and mentally I'm very tough. It takes a desire, and if you have a desire you can accomplish what you want in life.'' Dentistry will remain his vocation and rodeo a committed sideline. ``It's intense and it's physical and it's very fun,'' Lindenmuth said.

DOC.HEAD: Mapplethorpe Photo Exhibit Draws Boston Protests For and Against
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 4-7 with color from scene. Picks up 4th graf pvs., `Meanwhile, a ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX4
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of supporters and a handful of protesters greeted patrons arriving today for the opening of an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe photographs that incensed Sen. Jesse Helms and got a museum director arrested in Cincinnati. The crowd of about 150 people, largely made up of those supporting the show, was orderly, and no incidents were reported. An estimated 200 visitors were lined up outside less than an hour after the museum opened its doors, said Denise Spencer, a marketing assistant at the Institute for Contemporary Art, which is showing the exhibit. The small museum is allowing just 75 people at a time to view the exhibit. ``These people are trying to force their morality on the rest of us,'' said Jim Edgerley, of the conservative American Freedom Coalition, as he stood among a crowd of demonstrators, patrons, police and reporters on the museum steps. As Edgerley spoke, two men stood in front of him locked in a deep, passionate kiss. ``See, this is the kind of behavior this is promoting,'' Edgerley said. Others praised the show. ``I'd read a lot about it and I was curious. I went to see what was objectionable, but I didn't find it objectionable. I thought it was interesting,'' said 70-year-old Eleanor Bleakie. Meanwhile, a public television station that had broadcast the most sexually explicit, homoerotic photographs from the so-called ``X Portfolio'' on its newscast Tuesday night said this morning that it got about 100 calls in reaction to the newscast, most of them supportive. But several people said they were swearing off public television forever, a station official said. Producers of WGBH's 10 p.m. newscast said they aired the ``X Portfolio'' pictures Tuesday to let viewers decide for themselves how they feel about them. ``The coverage thus far never shows you this. All you get is what is in the mind of the writer. And we want our coverage to let the viewer decide, with both sides presented,'' said John VanScoyoc, the station's managing editor. The photos have stirred a national debate over federal funding of work deemed offensive. The station, which like other public TV outlets receives federal funding, devoted 24 minutes of the half-hour newscast to the exhibit and the outcry over its explicit homosexual and sadomasochistic images. Despite efforts by protesters to have the photos banned, support for the show has been strong in Boston, once known as a city of bluenoses for banning books and movies. A Mapplethorpe supporter was arrested Tuesday after disrupting the news conference of a coalition opposed to the showing. Artists and playwrights gave speeches in support of the exhibit, and marches and rallies were planned for today. First Amendment Common Sense, a coalition opposed to the exhibit, pressed public officials to halt it as obscene. ``We're calling for a revival of common sense,'' said an opponent, Evelyn Dubel. ``We're concerned about the well-being of our neighbors, especially our children.'' David Ross, director of the art institute, said he was proud to have the show of 124 photographs taken by Mapplethorpe from 1969 until shortly before he died of AIDS last year in Boston at age 42. ``What we have to fear is the suppression of these ideas. We're talking about art,'' Ross said. ``This is not a pornography exhibit. ... This show is a celebration of beauty.'' Alan Foster, WGBH news director, said the station received at least 63 calls within 15 minutes of the program's conclusion. The line was attached to an answering machine, and it was not immediately known how callers felt, he said. Twenty callers dialed the newsroom directly. ``Those have been universally positive,'' Foster said. ``One guy said, `Brilliant show, terrific journalism.''' Mary Catherine Kilday, enforcement chief of the Federal Communications Commission in Washington, said the agency does not monitor TV or radio programming and has no authority to enforce indecency complaints after 8 p.m. A Mapplethorpe exhibit scheduled in June 1989 at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was canceled after Helms, the arch-conservative Republican from North Carolina, branded the work obscene. Helms' objections prompted Congress to limit National Endowment for the Arts grants. Before those limits, the Mapplethorpe tour had received about $30,000 from the NEA, about 10 percent of the cost. A showing in Cincinnati led to obscenity charges against the director of The Contemporary Arts Center, but a federal judge barred police from confiscating photos from the exhibit. The show in Boston was expected to draw at least 50,000 people. It runs through Oct. 4.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: burn it.
DOC.TEXT: July 25 NRC Handelsblad, Rotterdam, Netherlands, on David Souter: The nine judges of the American Supreme Court are the final guardians of morals, habits and the spirit of the time of the American nation. Every time when one of them drops out due to old age, illness or death, a president will grab his chance to extend his political signature with an appointment. ... What would (President) Bush do? Nervousness about this was big because on the one hand the candidacy of a judge is sort of a president's confession of faith towards the ideologically tinted part of the supporters. On the other hand, the relations aren't such that one could become a lot wiser on this terrain of polarisation. ... From a moral point of view the nation finds itself in a foggy zone. The pre-eminent litmus test is the abortion issue. ... With the departure of a (Supreme Court justice) ... and the inevitable discussion about a new candidate the embarrassment about this litmus test was threatening to escalate. Therefore the fearful question that many had: What would Bush do? The ... president has done something genial, at least that is what it looks like now. With the candidacy of (David) Souter he has pushed forward a judge who is generally known as very capable and possessing great integrity and who, after 20 years of legal practice, has not left a trace from which something could be deducted. The bachelor from New Hampshire has no political or ideological past and that, for the time being, contents all parties. ... But up to now the choice of Souter is a find. His knowledge is not doubted and the power of his nomination lies in the continuous question: Who is Souter?

July 25 Il Messagero, Rome, on American policy in Southeast Asia: The changes in the (U.S.) Vietnamese policy represent an important political and psychological development for the United States. American liberals had long been ready to leave the Vietnam war behind, while conservatives have maintained a more intransigent position. Even now, some of them criticize practical George Bush for having hidden a change in his Vietnamese strategy behind a change in tactics vis-a-vis Cambodia. He is going beyond pure ``containment'' in Southeast Asia, as he has already done in Europe, and rightly so.

July 30 The Times, London, on the attempted coup in Trinidad and Tobago: The seizure of the prime minister and other members of the government of Trinidad and Tobago by a violent fringe group of black Moslem radicals underlines the chronic vulnerability of very small states to extremist movements. Small communities are easily ignited by strange sparks. ... The calm response of the Trinidadian military, political and religious establishments to the militants' blackmail is a tribute to the maturity of the country's democratic institutions. ... The unpopularity of the government led by Arthur Robinson, only 30 months after winning a landslide victory with the promise of rescuing the country's tottering economy, is such that the rebels' demand for his resignation and for elections within 90 days may be so widely supported as to be irresistible. ... The economic woes would have been more readily borne had the government kept an important part of its bargain with the electorate: the promise to eliminate Trinidad's endemic corruption in public life.

July 30 Bangkok (Thailand) Post on aid to terrorism given by the former Eastern European governments: Hollywood, novelists and even the right-wing propagandists, it turns out, were right all along. For the past 40 years, the Soviets and their satellite states in Eastern Europe aided terrorism, hatched outlandish plots to expand power, and routinely pitted families and neighbors against each other to maintain secret police files. Since the fall of the communist dictatorships in Europe last year, files have been uncovered with tales of intrigue so outlandish and devious a fiction writer would have been hard pressed to imagine them. The new regime in Czechoslovakia has discovered its communist predecessor was the world's major illegal supplier of the most powerful and difficult-to-detect explosive, Semtex. In effect, the former Czech leaders helped blow up several planes in terrorist attacks which killed hundreds. Hungary, Czechoslovakia and East Germany not only provided a safe haven for the infamous Carlos, but showered the notorious terrorist with luxuries, including call girls. ... What next? Will details emerge from Bulgaria providing the long-suspected assassination attempts on the Pope? Will proof come from Romania that Nicolae Ceausescu and his clique did indeed help narcotics dealing by North Korean diplomats? ... The supreme power of the former dictatorships of Eastern Europe proved irresistible to the men who held it. Whether the power warped the men or vice versa hardly matters. As story after story from Eastern Europe proves, total power corrupts totally. Convinced by their own constant propaganda of the infallibility of the ``dictator of the proletariat,'' the old men who ran Eastern Europe for so long proved as politically perverted by power as any Latin American tinhorn despot.

July 27 Le Figaro, Paris, on the Iraq-Kuwait dispute: Apparently Iraq, which has an enormous need for money, wants each (OPEC member) to respect its production quota. But is this sufficient reason to mass 30,000 armed men in the southern sector of the country? Or is this a good opportunity seized by Saddam Hussein to establish himself as the zealous defender of the oil producing states' interests, and at the same time as the policeman of the Gulf, even while American warships cruise nearby in maneuvers with those of the Emirates? Oil, the stake in other previous conflicts, could soon be the pretext for a new source of tension in this already very complicated region.

July 26 El Mercurio, Santiago, Chile, on Cubans seeking asylum at embassies in Havana: The stubborness with which Fidel Castro rows against the current of ``perestroika'' is worsening living conditions in Cuba and encourages people to seek political asylum to leave their country. It is useless for Castro to insult the asylum-seekers, calling them ``bums with fat criminal records,'' because, as the tyrant gets more annoyed, the population shows a greater desire of emigrating. ... The first seven asylum seekers picked the Czechoslovak embassy, creating for Castro a serious problem with his former allies. Others entered the Spanish embassy, and Foreign Minister Francisco Hernandez Ordonez of Spain has said, ``There is a situation of nervousness in Havana, resulting from the isolation of Cuba from the international community, and from its extremely serious economic situation.''
End Editorial Rdp

DOC.HEAD: Queen Mother's Visit To London's East End Recalls Britain at War
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The woman who brought a queen's comfort to the bomb-shattered East End during World War II returned to the rebuilt district Wednesday to celebrate her 90th birthday. Nearly 50 years after the German blitz, the presence of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother rekindled warm memories of a bitter time. During the war years, the then-Queen Elizabeth picked her way through the rubble in high heels and the pastel dresses she still favors today, offering words of ecouragement to East Enders. They still remember. ``She really did cheer us up. People were down in their depths at the time,'' said Myrtle Lester, who as an 11-year-old spent long hours in a damp backyard bomb shelter. The visit to the East End was a sentimental high point in four months of parades and pageants leading up to the birthday on Saturday of the ``Queen Mum,'' as she is fondly known. She arrived in the riverside district aboard the royal yacht Britannia, wearing a light blue dress and matching hat with a wispy veil, a string of pearls and a beaming smile. Elderly East Enders mingled with youngsters waving Union Jacks who turned out to greet her. Alice Poyser, 69, said she remembered well the wartime visits of the queen and King George VI. ``We were pleased to see her. It felt like a mother talking to us,'' she said. Mrs. Poyser said her family was bombed out of three successive homes. Several people in the crowd recalled the queen's words after Buckingham Palace was hit by a bomb: ``I'm glad we've been bombed. It makes me feel I can look the East End in the face.'' During the war, Prime Minister Winston Churchill advised her to go to Canada for safety. She ignored him, and took lessons at Buckingham Palace on how to use a rifle. Her daughters _ Elizabeth, now the queen, and Princess Margaret _ stayed at Windsor Castle, 21 miles west of London, during the conflict. The East End's shattered docks and factories have been replaced by a huge redevelopment project that has brought new homes, shops and offices. The Queen Mother unveiled a plaque honoring 76 people killed by a bomb and revisited the shelters underneath All Saints' Church, itself a bombing casualty in 1945. She also saw some of those she met during wartime. Wednesday night, she was to be guest of honor at a birthday dinner on the Britannia given by the queen and Prince Philip, followed by fireworks over the Tower of London. The Queen Mother was born Aug. 4, 1900. Lady Elizabeth Angela Marguerite Bowes-Lyon was the ninth child of the Earl and Countess of Strathmore, whose family home was Glamis Castle in Scotland. In 1923 she married the Duke of York, second of four surviving sons of King George V. She became queen, quite unexpectedly, when the duke's elder brother, Edward, abdicated in 1936 to marry American divorcee Wallis Warfield Simpson. Biographers say the Queen Mother never recovered from her husband's early death from lung cancer in 1952. She still refers to him as ``the king'' and declines public appearances on the anniversaries of his birth, marriage and death. Despite her age, the Queen Mother is still one of the most active royals. Only the queen and Princess Anne make more public appearances.

DOC.HEAD: Cargo Ship in Distress Off Cape Cod
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with latest information on rescue, 6 missing, details of seaman's death, crew total 29 sted 27. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Crew members abandoned a Greek cargo ship battered off Cape Cod by Hurricane Bertha today. At least one seaman died and six were unaccounted for as other merchant ships rushed to help, the Coast Guard said. Eighteen crew members were rescued from a lifeboat and a life raft after four or more hours in heavy seas. Three were in a lifeboat and one was still in the water this morning, said Coast Guard Coast Guard Lt. j.g. Rodney Gadsden. Soviet, Hong Kong and Norwegian fishing and merchant ships joined efforts to pluck the sailors from 10- to 15-foot seas. An Air Force communications plane was directing their efforts and a Coast Guard ship was en route. The 593-foot Greek-registered freighter Corazon, with a crew of 29, lost part of its bow and its midsection buckled, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Lionel Bryant. The ship was about 340 miles east-southeast of Cape Cod, he said. Crew members abandoned ship at 4:20 a.m., Coast Guard Petty Officer Anthony L. Whitehead said, and by midmorning the Corazon's bow was submerged and its stern was standing clear of the water. ``You can see the screw,'' Whitehead said. One crew member apparently fell into the water as the crew members boarded the lifeboat and life raft, Whitehead said. That sailor was pulled from the water by the Russian trawler Vympel shortly after 7 a.m. but was dead. At about 8 a.m., the Vympel attempted to rescue what had been reported to be 12 sailors aboard the life raft. But the raft was pulled into the trawler's screw and rudder area, and six or seven sailors were pitched into the ocean, Coast Guard spokesmen said. The five remaining aboard the life raft were later pulled to safety by the Russian merchant ship Leonid Leonidov, Gadsden said. Two more life rafts were put out, and three people were seen, apparently in one of them, he said. Another was seen in the water and a total of six were missing, Gadsden said. More precise accounting was unavailable, he said. The Leonid Leonidov also took aboard the 13 crew members on the lifeboat, rescuing them at 8:30 a.m., Whitehead said. The Hong Kong vessel, Nova Europa, was assisting, and the Norwegian vessel, Hual Angelita, was standing by, Gadsden said. Of all the survivors rescued by 10:30 a.m., 17 were in good condition and one was hurt, with unknown injuries, Whitehead said. At the height of the storm the ship was buffeted by 80 mph wind and 20- to 25-foot seas, Bryant said. The Corazon was carrying cement from Greece to New York.

DOC.HEAD: Marshall High School Students Will Experience World
DOC.TEXT: Students at Marshall High School will learn their geography this year, or else _ or else they might have trouble finding their classroom. Each classroom has been transformed into a country, using paint and decor reflecting the culture of the assigned country. And buildings at the school in southeastern Portland now represent continents. ``I'm going to force the staff and kids to find their way round geographically,'' principal Colin Karr-Morse said. Teachers will post daily news articles and other country facts. Country flags and products will also be on display. Karr-Morse said the idea came after the results of a Gallup poll released last year showed that U.S. residents between the ages of 18 and 24 could only identify seven of 16 countries on the globe. People in the same age group from countries such as Mexico, Italy, Canada, Japan and Sweden all scored higher. Gail Ludwig, geographer in residence at the National Geographic Society, said she has never heard of another school using the Marshall concept.

DOC.HEAD: Zhelev Elected First Non-Communist President In Decades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with election of former interior minister as vice president. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Although the..'
DOC.TEXT: Zhelyu Zhelev, who led the democratic opposition in June's free elections, became president today, the first non-Communist to gain any leading post in the Balkan country in more than 40 years. Zhelev's election by Parliament ended almost a month of political stalemate following the resignation July 6 of President Petar Mladenov, a member of the ruling former Communist party, now known as the Socialists. Mladenov stepped down after it was confirmed he had called for the use of tanks against anti-government demonstrators last December. Zhelev, 55, was a compromise candidate backed by all parties _ including Socialist leaders _ after five unsuccessful attempts to get a president elected by the 400-member parliament. Zhelev won 284 of the 389 votes cast today. In a surprise move, he immediately made a proposed former Socialist Interior Minister Atanas Semerdzhiev as vice president. Deputies greeted the suggestion with applause and voted overwhelmingly for Semerdzhiev in a show of hands. Only two deputies opposed the choice, while seven abstained. Semerdzhiev had resigned as Interior Minister last week when a furor erupted over the proposed parliamentary appearance of Todor Zhivkov, the Stalinist leader ousted last fall after 35 years in power. Zhelev triumphed in the presidential race after none of the three original candidates proved able to secure the two-thirds majority needed to win election in Parliament. Although the Socialists won June's free elections with 211 parliamentary seats, their incumbent premier, Andrei Lukanov, repeatedly has said he does not want to head a one-party government. Spreading street protests against the Socialists since the elections also have made clear that the ruling party's support is dwindling rapidly, necessitating some sort of cooperation with the opposition Union of Democratic Forces. Zhelev led the UDF in the June elections, in which the 16-party coalition won 144 parliamentary seats. Before today's vote, both Zhelev and Lukanov indicated that the Socialists and opposition are willing to work together to ease Bulgaria's social tensions and rapidly deepening economic crisis. Answering questions from the floor, Zhelev said he wants to see Bulgaria make a ``peaceful evolution to democracy with the direct participation of the political opposition.'' While he did not directly retract previous opposition rejection of participation in a Lukanov-led coalition government, he stressed the most important task of any president is now to work for the creation of ''a strong, active and competent government.'' Observers in Sofia took the remark as a sign the opposition is no longer excluding participation in government with the Socialists. For his part, Lukanov said his party had agreed to Zhelev's candidacy as president in the interests of national welfare and noted this marked the effective end to one-party monopoly of power in Bulgaria. The Balkan nation was dominated by the Communists since just after World War II, when the Communists executed, imprisoned and repressed their political opponents.

DOC.HEAD: Group Recruiting Female Students To Fight Restrictive Abortion Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tamar is cq in final graf
DOC.TEXT: A major women's rights organization announced Wednesday a drive to enlist 1 million young women on college and high school campuses to fight restrictive state abortion laws, particularly those requiring parental consent. The Feminist Majority's ``Becky Bell Campaign,'' named for a 17-year-old Indianapolis girl who died in 1988 from complications suffered in a back-alley abortion, will be concentrated in Indiana, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Ohio, California, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island, sponsors said. The parents of the dead girl, Bill and Karen Bell, endorsed the project in an emotional appearance at a news conference with Eleanor Smeal, president of the Feminist Majority. ``Our daughter died because she happened to live in the wrong state ... she died because of a parental consent law that I had never even heard of,'' said the father, a 47-year-old office products salesman in Indianapolis. As the parents explained it, their daughter, who normally shared her problems freely with them, was afraid to tell them about her pregnancy for fear of disappointing them. And she heard from friends that the Indiana courts rarely granted an exception to the parental consent requirement, so, in desperation, she went to an unqualified practitioner. ``When Becky died, I died with her,'' said Karen Bell. ``Becky didn't want an abortion. But she wanted to save dad and I the shame of knowing she had fallen in love, had sex and became pregnant. This could happen to anybody. Kids are going to do these things.... Now all I have is the graveyard.'' ``Don't you think we wanted to know Becky was in trouble, that we wanted to help her?'' asked the father. ``But Becky confided to her friends `I can't tell Mom and Dad _ I love them too much.' Our hope is that in speaking out we can spare other families the nightmare we now live. These laws are punitive. They are deadly.'' The campaign will feature the distribution of memorial bracelets carrying the names of Becky Bell or Rosie Jimenez, a 27-year-old McAllen, Texas woman said by the Feminist Majority to be the first to die as a consequence of the Hyde Amendment, named for Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., which bars Medicaid abortion funding for poor women. Jimenez died Oct. 3, 1977, the same year the Hyde Amendment was passed. Smeal, formerly head of the National Organization for Women, said the campaign will move this fall into Oregon, Michigan and Texas, where parental consent laws are pending. In all states, she said, the drive will focus on voter registration and get-out-the-vote projects in behalf of sympathetic state legislators. It also will promote bringing the European abortion pill, RU-486, to the United States. The Feminist Majority is not a membership organization but currently has more than 50,000 contributors and more than 100,000 active supporters, according to press secretary Tamar Raphael.

DOC.HEAD: So Far, 1990 An Average Year for Earthquakes
DOC.TEXT: So far, 1990 is just an average year for earthquakes, the government said Wednesday, although the Iranian quake in June was the deadliest in 14 years. The U.S. Geological Survey said the death toll in Iran, estimated at 50,000 or more, is the highest since a 1976 quake in China killed more than 250,000 people. Overall, there were 34 significant quakes in the first six months of 1990. That would be close to normal, since there are, on average, 60 significant quakes in a typical year, the agency said. A significant quake is defined as one reaching 6.5 or higher on the Richter scale or a lesser temblor causing significant casualties or damage. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released in an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one whole number, say from 5.5 to 6.5, indicates a tenfold increase in ground motion. The quake that struck Iran measured 7.7 on the scale, according to Waverly Person, chief of the agency's National Earthquake Information Service in Golden, Colo. That was the same magnitude as the deadly quake that hit the Philippines on July 16. The death toll in that quake is still being calculated. On Feb. 8, a quake measured at 6.6 injured at least 15 people in the Philippines; 1 died there in a quake on March 26, and a tremor on June 14 killed 4 people. Only one significant quake was recorded in the United States from January through June, a magnitude 5.5 tremor that injured 38 people and caused $10 million in damage in Southern California on Feb. 28. After Iran, the next deadliest quake in the first half of 1990 was a magnitude 6.4 tremor in Peru on May 30, which claimed 135 lives. On April 26, 126 people were killed in a quake in China that measured 6.9 on the Richter scale. A tremor measured at 7.2 occurred May 20 in southern Sudan. Because of the remoteness of the area, casualty figures have not been confirmed. Survey officials said that is believed to be the strongest quake ever recorded in that country. There were nine deaths reported in a May 30 quake in Romania. Two people died in a May 5 quake in Italy. No injuries were reported, but buildings were damaged, when a quake shook parts of southern England on April 2. Overall, Person estimated that there are probably several million earthquakes annually, most so small they are unnoticed.

DOC.HEAD: Contractor Pleads Guilty in Naval Academy Corruption
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that Dunton is NOT a retired Navy captain; Picks up 4th graf pvs., `He admitted ...
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities are investigating corruption and bribery at the U.S. Naval Academy, where a contractor has admitted handing out more than $20,000 in illegal gratuities. Carroll R. Dunton pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court on Tuesday to charges that he gave bribes and illegal gratuities to a Navy public works officer and an Annapolis Housing Authority official. Dunton, 65, is a general contractor in Annapolis, where the Naval Academy is located. He admitted giving $20,307 worth of gratutities, including cash and household appliances, to James Weston, who was the Naval Academy's public works officer from July 1985 until his retirement in October 1989. In return, Dunton allegedly received $3.7 million in Navy contracts. Weston, reached by telephone at his home in Nevada, declined to comment on the allegation. He has not been charged. Dunton also pleaded guilty to one count of giving $13,351 worth of plumbing work to Arthur Strissel Jr., who was the executive director of the Annapolis Housing Authority. In return for the bribe to Strissel, Weston awarded Dunton's company a $559,330 contract to install gas meters at Annapolis housing projects, according to Assistant U.S. Attorney Jane F. Barret. Dunton made a profit of $249,568 on the contract, which was financed with U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development funds, prosecutors said. Strissel is serving a 10-year prison term on unrelated racketeering and bribery convictions. Academy spokesman Noel Milan confirmed that the FBI and Naval Investigative Services began an investigation in March 1989 into procurement irregularities during Weston's tenure at the academy. ``The academy is cooperating fully in the probe,'' Milan said. Dunton, the owner of Dunton Contracting Inc., faces a maximum sentence of 12 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if found guilty. Sentencing was set for Oct. 26.

DOC.HEAD: Aircraft Carrying 30 People Crashes in Azerbaijan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with plane crashing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A small airliner carrying 30 people from Armenia to the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh crashed in Azerbaijan today, Soviet media reported. No casualty report was immediately available. The accident occurred in an area blanketed by dense fog, but the cause of the crash was not known. The wreckage of the Aeroflot Yakovlev-40 was found in the Agdam region of Azerbaijan, just east of Nagorno-Karabakh and its capital, Stepanakert, said the Interfax news agency, quoting a report to the Armenian parliament. The area is not on the plane's route from the Armenian capital, Yerevan, to Stepanakert, but it could have been circling to enter its landing pattern. Air controllers lost contact with the plane this morning as it entered airspace controlled by Stepanakert, Tass quoted the Soviet state Committee for Air Safety as saying. Stepanakert is 120 miles east of Yerevan. Armenia and Azerbaijan are locked in a bitter dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, a remote, mountainous area of Azerbaijan populated largely by Armenians. Hundreds of people have died in ethnic clashes in the past two years, and thousands of Armenians have organized into armed paramilitary units. In this volatile atmosphere, accidental deaths have spawned unfounded rumors of sabotage. For example, an explosion in a bus station in Azerbaijan caused by leaking natural gas was reported widely as the result of a terrorist bomb. The Armenian parliament formed a five-person commission to investigate the catastrophe, Interfax said. The search for the plane was hampered by thick fog, the Civil Aviation Ministry in Moscow told Tass. Civilian helicopters from Azerbaijan were being used in the search, the news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Economic Indicators Post No Change in June
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge failed to budge in June, the Commerce Department said Wednesday in a report analysts said portended a listless economy in the months ahead. The department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, was unchanged for the second month this year. It had risen in March and May and fallen in February and April. Many economists had expected a small increase in June. If the index were to fall for three straight months, it could signal a forthcoming recession. ``This meandering is consistent with what is happening in the economy,'' said economist Darryl Delano of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., ``It all nets out to basically nothing.'' David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, agreed. ``Basically, what we've seen over this year is small increases, small decreases, with everything averaging around zero,'' Berson said. ``The economy is going to continue in its slow-growth path.'' But other analysts such as David Jones, an economist with the New York securities dealer Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., expressed deeper concern. ``What we have got is an economy that is slowly sinking into possibly a mild recession by either late this year or early next,'' Jones contended. The Bush administration predicted earlier this month the nation's economy would grow 2 percent this year. But the growth rate as measured by the gross national product was just 1.7 percent in the first quarter and 1.2 percent in the second, meaning the economy would have to expand at an annual rate of 2.9 percent during the second half of the year to meet the administration's prediction. Few economists expect that amount of growth. Indeed, the National Association of Purchasing Management released its latest survey on Wednesday showing the manufacturing economy slumped in July for the first time in three months. And the Commerce Department, in another report Wednesday, said construction spending in June was flat after falling during the previous two months. Both the building and manufacturing sectors have borne the brunt of high interest rates as the Federal Reserve attempted to stem inflation by slowing the economy. ``The June leading indicators report dashes almost all hope that the economy will pick up steam later this year,'' said Richard W. Rahn, chief economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``The weak industrial sector will get even weaker by year's end as manufacturers' new orders fall and growth in unfilled orders wanes,'' Rahn added. ``It would take only a mild amount of order cancellations to stop growth in industrial production and turn a weak economy into recession.'' Both manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and unfilled orders were among the negative statistics in the June report. Others were a decline in the money supply, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence, a decrease in orders for new plants and equipment and an increase in weekly unemployment claims. The consumer confidence index also was negative in May, leading some analysts to fear consumers were retrenching. Consumers account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. However, Commerce eased these fears Monday when it reported that personal consumption jumped 1.0 percent in June, suggesting consumers would keep the weak economy alive. Nevertheless, only four of June's leading indicators were positive: an increase in the price of raw materials, higher stock prices, an increase in building permits and slower business delivery times. The length of the average workweek was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 146.0 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and up 1.4 percent from its level a year ago.
