DOC.HEAD: Report: Handwriting Expert Says Saddam Needs Psychiatric Help
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Mossad spy agency ordered an analysis of Saddam Hussein's handwriting and got back a recommendation that the Iraqi president needed psychiatric care, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The report in the daily Yediot Ahronot said the graphologist who examined Saddam's handwriting several months ago did not know the identity of his subject. The report gave no further details of the handwriting analysis. Israeli officials routinely refuse to comment on activities of the Mossad. The newspaper said the results of the handwriting analysis were shown to Israeli leaders to help them ``assess the degree of severity and importance that should be attributed to Saddam's threats and declarations.'' In April, Saddam threatened to respond with binary chemical weapons if Israel staged a nuclear attack on an Arab country. The newspaper quoted the handwriting expert's report as saying the subject ``should be hospitalized immediately.'' ``He is a hasty decision maker, and has a tendency for radical mood swings, is ready to take extreme decisions and carry them out, has violent tendencies and is dangerous to his environment,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes to Ban Honoraria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 8, In 1989, with background.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted today to ban outside speaking fees, a custom Sen. Robert C. Byrd said puts lawmakers ``at the level of used car salesmen'' in the public's esteem. The 77-23 vote on an amendment by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., attached the honoraria ban to a campaign finance reform bill. The ban would take effect next January. At present, senators are allowed to accept up to $27,337 a year in honoraria. ``When a significant part of our salaries comes from hustling, and that's what it amounts to, we denigrate ourselves,'' Dodd said. ``As public servants, our salaries should come from the public alone.'' The House voted last year to give up honoraria effective Jan. 1, 1991, but also boosted the salaries of its members from $98,400 to $124,000 then. Reluctant to vote themselves a 25 percent pay boost, the Senate had skirted the honoraria issue up until today. ``The scandals of the past two years have put a black mark on public service and raised public cynicism to an all-time high,'' Byrd said, citing $9 million in honoraria senators have accepted over the past decade. ``We're about at the level of used car salesmen'' in the public's esteem. The Senate voted last week to denounce Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., for violating several ethics standards, including skirting the limits on honoraria in a book-publishing deal. Six other senators are under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for alleged actions involving savings and loan institutions and Department of Housing and Urban Development programs. Dodd's amendment won the support of 53 of the Senate's 55 Democrats and 24 of it 45 Republicans. In 1989, senators accepted nearly $3 million in honoraria and kept more than $2.1 milion, with the balance donated to charity, according to their financial disclosure forms. Dodd, the sponsor of the ban, reported accepting $15,000 in 1989. GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, one of the largest recipients of honoraria, said he agreed with Dodd on the need to eliminate senators' honoraria income but not on the strategy of doing it without a pay raise. ``In January, House members will be getting paid about $22,000 more than senators ... and we could be getting about $22,000 less for years to come,'' he said. Dole said he had considered trying to amend Dodd's measure to include a raise that would return Senate and House salaries to parity but acknowledged he lacked the votes to win its passage this close to the November election. Despite the vote, several lawmakers doubted that the honoraria ban will be enacted because of its attachment to what Republicans claim has become a highly Democratic partisan campaign finance reform bill. Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told him Wednesday morning that President Bush would veto the current version with its Democratic-proposed ceilings on how much candidates can spend in an election. Byrd said members of the Senate, himself among them, have supplemented their salaries with a total of more than $9 million in honoraria from special interest groups over the past decade.

He said it would be hypocritical for the Senate to ``leave the back door open'' for its members to supplement their $98,400 salaries with up to $27,300 in speaking fees while claiming to remove special interest money from campaigns. ``The pay system that has evolved _ with the public paying the bulk of a senator's salary and a handful of interest groups picking up the rest _ is untenable,'' Dodd said. ``Our salaries should come from the public alone.'' Meanwhile, outnumbered Republicans are complaining that it is only their traditional sources of political money that are being singled out for ``reform'' in the bill to clean up the way elections are financed. ``All of the bipartisanship has completely broken down,'' Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., said after losing a 49-49 tie vote on his measure to make candidates turn surpluses in their campaign accounts over to the government instead of keeping them for use in future elections. On largely party-line votes Tuesday, Democrats defeated amendments to strip unions of their tax-exempt status if they engage in politics and to allow union members to demand refunds of any dues spent on elections or lobbying. Republicans claimed the votes demonstrate that the Democrats' campaign finance reform bill and its spending ceilings is a ``partisan charade'' that will assure a veto by President Bush. Democrats contended they did their compromising last week, agreeing to Bush's proposal to abolish labor, corporate and trade association political action committees in an effort to get Republicans to accept some form of aggregate lid on how much candidates can spend. The population-based Democratic spending ceilings would range from $2 million for Senate candidates in small states to slightly over $10 million in the largest one, California.

DOC.HEAD: Gov. Wilder Addresses National Urban League
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder told fellow black leaders today that they are role models for a struggling generation. ``There has never been placed any greater responsibility on any groups of people anywhere in the history of the world than that which is presently placed on this generation of black people,'' Wilder said at a National Urban League conference. Wilder cited statistics that one-fourth of all black American males between ages 18 and 25 are in prison or on parole. He said the public school dropout rate is diminishing the workforce and future leadership prospects. Youngsters also face the problems of drug abuse, infant mortality and teen-age pregnancies. But nonetheless, Wilder said, he remains optimistic. The governor said conference members must instill black children with the attitude: ``I was not delivered into this world in defeat.'' ``We must insist upon excellence in education and a willingness to prepare our youngsters: not only to make passing grades, but to be acceptable to institutions of higher learning at graduate levels,'' he said. The nation's first black elected governor recalled that when he decided to run for the state Senate, he was told, ``That hasn't been done.'' Then, 16 years later, he wanted to become lieutenant governor, and was told, ``You've got to understand, this is Virginia.'' He ignored the nay-sayers. ``The Declaration of Independence was written by a Virginian,'' said Wilder. And when it endowed citizens with ``certain inalienable rights, I knew it meant me.'' Now, Wilder said, when boys and girls visit the governor's office, he tells them: ``Why don't you sit in my chair a while?''

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Sells Holdings Per Promise to Senate
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has sold his interests in a number of companies as promised at his Senate confirmation early last year, financial disclosure reports showed Wednesday. The sales included stocks in RJR Nabisco, Philip Morris, IBM, Caterpillar, 3M, ConAgra, Emhart, Upjohn and several others, as part of Yeutter's pledge to avoid conflicts of interest or appearances of conflict. David L. Spradlin of the Agriculture Department's personnel office said Yeutter had filed the annual disclosure on May 5, but it was returned for additional information and clarification. Yeutter joined the Reagan administration in 1985 as U.S. trade representative. Previously he was head of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and had extensive business and farming interests, as well as careers in law and economics. President Bush named him as secretary of agriculture with an eye on 1990 farm legislation and to help in agricultural negotiations during the current trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The company interests sold by Yeutter made up a fraction of the total assets listed in his financial statement. No exact figures were listed in the disclosure forms, but Yeutter's assets totaled more than $800,000 and possibly much more. Selling prices of the stocks sold varied from $15,000 to $50,000 in the case of ConAgra and Philip Morris, for example, to $5,000 to $15,000 for Caterpillar and Upjohn. Chief among his assets are two farms shared with other family members. One of 2,000 acres in Dawson County, Neb., was valued at ``over $250,000'' in the report. The other, 200 acres, is in Lancaster County, Neb., and was also listed among Yeutter's assets at ``over $250,000.'' Yeutter reported a 1989 salary as secretary of agriculture at $107,300. Outside income was indicated at more than his federal salary, including at least $55,000 from the two Nebraska farms, $15,000-plus from a condominium in Keystone, Colo., and $40,000 or more from other investments. Liabilities, mostly mortgages, were put at between approximately $830,000 and $1.35 million. Under gifts, reimbursements and gratuities, Yeutter listed a $150 silver dish from John MacGregor, the United Kingdom's agriculture minister; a $150 miniature clock from Gerhard Weiser of West Germany; and a $130 silver plate from Galal Abu El Dahak, Egypt's trade minister. A reviewer's comment said all gifts were ``under the threshold'' allowed for such gifts and that Yeutter could keep them. Free honorary membership in the Army-Navy Club, valued at $250, and $456 in air fare for Mrs. Yeutter provided by the American Enterprise Institute to participate in a world economic forum also was allowed.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Acquits Man of Murder After 2-year-old Burrito Found in Pocket
DOC.TEXT: A man charged with murder was acquitted by a jury persuaded in part by the discovery of a 2-year-old burrito in the defendant's jacket pocket. The burrito was hurriedly introduced as evidence at the trial's close to support Edward Vasquez' alibi that he was buying the burrito at a canteen truck when security guard Israel Martinez was shot to death in 1988. Vasquez was freed after his arrest on $10,000 bail but his jacket was seized as evidence and held in police custody until the trial. Then Vasquez, 23, put it on to display it for the jury and told his attorney it felt ``like there was something heavy in the right pocket.'' The jury had already begun deliberations last week when defense attorney Jay Jaffe asked to re-examine the jacket and discovered the foil-wrapped burrito. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg allowed Jaffe to reopen his final arguments, citing the new evidence. ``He didn't shoot the security guard, and this proves it,'' Jaffe told jurors as he unwrapped the well-preserved burrito. Jurors acquitted Vasquez on Tuesday. They said they had been split 8-4 for acquittal before the burrito defense came into play. Vasquez insisted he was across a parking lot when Martinez, 42, was killed in a September 1988 gun battle at the California State University Los Angeles campus. ``I'm just happy that the jury saw through what never should have been a prosecution. He endured a nightmare for two years just because he was at the wrong place at the wrong time,'' said Jaffe.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
Laserphoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope says he wrote about his life to beat his kids to the job. ``Look what happened to Bing Crosby, Bette Davis, Joan Crawford,'' he quipped at a bookstore here Tuesday while signing copies of his autobiography, ``Don't Shoot, It's Only Me.'' Hope, 87, wrote the book with Melville Shavelson, one of his comedy writers since 1938. The legendary comedian says he does not worry about death. I've died many times _ in Philadelphia, Jersey City, you name it. I generally don't feel anything until noon, then it's time for my nap.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Magic Johnson helped Michigan State University win a college basketball title 11 years ago. Now, he would like to help run the school. Michigan Democratic Party officials suggested Johnson run for a seat on the board of trustees for the East Lansing school. Johnson, who led the Los Angeles Lakers to five National Basketball Assocaiton championships, said in a statement Tuesday that he was ``very interested.'' Johnson, 30, would return next week to his hometown of Lansing to re-establish residency and register to vote, said Joel Ferguson, a Democratic Party activist. To run for the board, Johnson must be a resident for at least 30 days and be nominated by the Democratic Party at its state convention Sept. 8-9 in Flint. Gov. James Blanchard hopes Johnson's candidacy would attract voters to the polls for the Nov. 6 election, in which Blanchard is seeking his third term.

Sonny Crockett shot bad guys by the score on ``Miami Vice.'' Don Johnson, who portrayed the hip undercover TV cop, says it's harder to shoot par amid scores of fans. More than a thousand fans swarmed the Country Club of Jackson on Tuesday for a glimpse of the actor, who played in a pro-celebrity golf tournament to benefit a local hospital. Organizers credited him with doubling the size of the gallery to about 3,000. Pro golfer Kenny Perry, who was paired with Johnson, basked happily in the actor's reflected glory. ``I didn't realize I had this many fans in Jackson,'' said Perry.

Actor Emilio Estevez agrees the movie western ``Young Guns,'' dismissed by critics as a Brat Pack-on-horseback charade, was a career misstep. So why the sequel ``Young Guns 2'' opening this week? ``I have been a fan of the western movies since I was a little kid and I did `Young Guns' in the hope that it would help bring back the western,'' Estevez, 27, said in an interview this week. ``John Fusco wrote a magnificent script, but then it was turned into what I call Hollywood's first heavy-metal western. It was just an excuse for a personality piece featuring all these young actors, and I was very disappointed.'' Fusco also wrote the script for the sequel, but this time there's a different director and a bigger scope, Estevez said. ``This one has a wide-screen look with a big, glorious musical score, and the most accurate depiction of Billy the Kid of any film ever made on him,'' he said. ``Young Guns 2'' is the 43rd movie about the legendary gunman.

Former comedian Dick Gregory has told a federal court he can't afford to repay an old friend $105,000 because he has other debts totaling more than $1 million. U.S. District Judge Edward Harrington ordered Gregory to submit a financial affidavit by Friday. Gregory, 58, of Plymouth, borrowed $40,000 in 1979 from Frank Nicholas II. Nicholas sued Gregory in 1987 to recover the loan plus interest, bringing the debt to $105,000. Nicholas urged the court to find Gregory in contempt. However, Gregory said in court Monday that he can't repay the debt because he also owes more than $1.2 million to the Internal Revenue Service, American Express, banks and other creditors.

DOC.HEAD: Five European Countries Expand Regional Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Five European countries, meeting for the first time as a new regional alliance, agreed Wednesday to step up political and economic cooperation to promote stability on the changing continent. The leaders of Italy, Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary and Yugoslavia reached a wide range of accords aimed at strengthening democracy and spurring economic development in eastern and central Europe. The agreements came at the first summit of the so-called Pentagonal Initiative, a regional alliance founded in Budapest in November 1989. All the delegations except Italy's were led by heads of government. The host country was represented by Deputy Premier Claudio Martelli because Premier Giulio Andreotti was forced to stay in Rome to ensure passage of a bill in the Chamber of Deputies. The leaders said the initiative should play a vital role in consolidating the political upheavals that have swept away Communist regimes across Eastern Europe, including in Hungary and Czechoslovakia. ``Shifting from ideological rivalry to the implementation of joint programs in the economic field and other sectors will be the most effective way of avoiding any temptation to revert to the past,'' they said in a joint declaration. The leaders said the new Europe should be based on parliamentary and pluralistic democracy and a free market economy. ``The choice is no longer the continuation of the classic game of balances but the construction of new forms of collaboration and integration,'' Martelli said in a speech. ``In a period of such tumultuous change, it is necessary to strengthen dialogue and reciprocal consultation.'' Officials said the alliance could help bring East European countries closer to the European Community and act as a possible counterweight to the political and economic strength of a unified Germany. The bulk of the accords involved projects for improving transportation links between the countries. The leaders agreed to establish four main road corridors and six railway lines and to expand air and maritime networks. It is not yet known, however, where the funds for these projects will come. Among the observers at the summit were officials of the World Bank and the European Investment Bank. Other agreements were reached in the fields of telecommunications, the environment, small- and medium-size enterprises, scientific and technical research, culture, tourism and information. A point of contention appeared to be the question of admitting Poland to the group. At a news conference, Hungarian Premier Jozsef Antall said he supported the idea of including Poland. Martelli, however, said no such request has been made and there were no immediate plans to expand the alliance. Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitsky said he proposed that the group study the possibility of abolishing nuclear power, as his country has done. ``This must be accepted by the majority,'' he said. ``It can't be implemented in a fortnight.'' The leaders also took up the question of minorities, a potentially explosive issue in several countries, especially Yugoslavia. No specific decisions were made, although Hungary will chair a technical committee studying the problem.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Say IRS Losing Fight to Collect Overdue Taxes
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is losing its battle against overdue taxes, which are growing faster than tax collections, government auditors said Wednesday. ``Each year IRS falls farther and farther behind in its efforts to reduce the accounts-receivable balance,'' Paul L. Posner, associate director of the General Accounting Office, told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. Unless the problem is reduced, he said, it ``could have a serious negative impact on voluntary taxpayer compliance.'' Accounts receivable _ which the IRS estimates grew from $30 billion in 1984 to $66 billion last year _ represent taxes that have been assessed but not paid, such as when a taxpayer files a return but fails to remit what is owed. The IRS says 13 million couples, individuals and businesses are involved. The IRS, the GAO and other experts agree that accounts receivable may be exaggerated by as much as 50 percent. Accounts receivable are the total of unpaid income, payroll and other taxes due over the last six years, generally the legal maximum the IRS can go back to in collecting taxes. Over the last six years, Posner said, accounts receivable ``grew three times faster than collections of delinquent taxes and twice as fast as total net tax receipts.'' He said it is especially disturbing that the average age of accounts is getting older, meaning the debts are less likely to be collected. ``This rapid, out-of-control growth in unpaid taxes threatens to overwhelm the IRS and is absolutely unacceptable at a time when the administration and Congress are grappling with painful revenue and spending choices,'' said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the committee. Accounts receivable are different from the ``tax gap,'' which is the difference in income taxes that are collected and what would be collected if individuals and businesses correctly reported their income and deductions. The gap is expected to be about $100 billion this year alone. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. acknowledged that accounts receivable are a worrisome problem but said the agency is making progress. For example, he said, the IRS this year is collecting $472,000 in delinquencies for each staff member in the collections division, up from $388,000 two years ago. The division is expected to collect $26.5 billion this year, compared with $23.3 billion in 1988. Goldberg said there has been a slow but steady increase in accounts the IRS believes will never be collected because of death, bankruptcy or inability to locate the debtor. That $27 billion is in addition to the $66 billion. Goldberg said there will be dramatic reductions in accounts receivables only when IRS's 30-year-old computer system is modernized; when the agency's budget is stabilized so that staffer hiring and training can be improved, and when tax laws are simplified. President Bush's budget for the IRS for next year would allow hiring 1,050 new collection personnel. ``This represents the growth we can prudently manage and absorb during 1991. No more, no less,'' he said. Goldberg said that in February, the IRS had nearly 800,000 accounts totaling $1.8 billion that could not be worked because of lack of personnel. That shortage was a result of a two-year hiring freeze that was imposed on the IRS, he said. John Pepping, an IRS collections officer in the Laguna Niguel, Calif., district, said the personnel shortage there is so severe that as a rule no account under $50,000 is sent to the field for collection. He testified on behalf of the National Treasury Employees Union, which represents most IRS workers. Robert M. Tobias, president of the union, urged Congress to boost the IRS budget sufficiently to hire 5,000 new collectors over the next three years. That would boost collections by $6.1 billion over five years, he said.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Fighters Clash with Pro-Iranian Palestinians, 15 Killed
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's guerrillas attacked the main base of a pro-Iranian Palestinian faction Wednesday and then clashed with its fighters barricaded inside a mosque in a refugee camp. Fifteen people were killed and 95 wounded in clashes between the two Palestinian forces. The confrontations were an offshoot of a three-week battle between Iranian-backed fundamentalists and their more secular rivals for control of Iqlim al-Tuffah, or Apple Province, which is next to the border strip Israel occupies in south Lebanon. The inter-Palestinian fighting rekindled the battles between the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia in the Apple Province. Police said three combatants were killed and 10 wounded in that fighting, raising the overall toll in the three-week battle to 189 dead and 570 injured. The inter-Palestinian fighting started when guerrillas from Arafat's Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization launched an assault on the main base of Maj. Jamal Suleiman, a Fatah renegade. Fatah fighters have fought alongside the Amal militiamen, while Suleiman supports Hezbollah. On Monday, Suleiman's fighters fired 40 rockets at Fatah positions in the Apple Province, wounding at least seven guerrillas, PLO officials said. The inter-Palestinian fighting spread to the Ein el-Hilweh refuge camp after Arafat's guerrillas crushed Suleiman's base in Jabal al-Haleeb, or the Milk Mountain, on the camp's eastern edge. Suleiman and about 30 of his 150 followers escaped the first attack and barricaded themselves inside the Nour mosque in Ein el-Hilweh. Other Moslem fundamentalist Palestinians soon joined them there. Col. Wajih Abu Ali, commander of the PLO's military police in the Sidon region, where the camp is located, said the fundamentalists opened fire at Fatah forces from the mosque and a nearby alley. Arafat's men ringed the mosque and were ``responding to the shooting,'' Abu Ali said. Witnesses in Ein el-Hilweh said about a dozen clergymen were using the mosque's loudspeakers to blare calls for a jihad, or holy war, against Arafat. ``It's a sensitive situation. Fatah cannot easily attack a mosque to evict them. Other anti-Arafat groups might suppport them too. The situation in the camp is very tense,'' Abu Ali said. At nightfall, guerrillas from terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal's Fatah Revolutionary Council joined Suleiman's fighters around the mosque and mounted a counterattack on Milk Mountain, police said. ``They have managed to recapture many of their positions in the mountain,'' the police spokesman said. Arafat has at least 5,000 hardcore fighters in the Sidon region. Also Wednesday, police said intermittent exchanges of machine gun and rocket-propelled grenade fire between Amal and Hezbollah fighters in the Apple Province prevented rescuers from the International Committee of the Red Cross from evacuating dozens of decomposing bodies.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Rules Hinder Experimental AIDs Treatments
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to develop drugs for AIDS-related diseases are hindered by federal rules which bar hospital insurance coverage for people receiving novel treatments, the government's chief AIDS researcher said Wednesday. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and other witnesses told a House Government Operations subcommittee that the lack of public and private insurance for hospital care in clinical trials prevents thousands of people from receiving potentially life-prolonging treatment. Insurers, including the public Medicare and Medicaid programs, do not regularly reimburse for treatments that are considered to be experimental. A person with an AIDS-related infection who does not receive experimental treatment would be reimbursed, according to Fauci and others. Both AIDS research and the health-care reimbursement programs fall under the jurisdiction of the Department of Health and Human Services. AIDS and the particularly virulent ``opportunistic infections'' that follow it strike largely at people least able to afford hospital care, witnesses said. The infections strike all organs, including the eyes, lungs and intestines, and, along with tumors, cause most AIDS deaths. AIDS weakens the body's ability to resist ordinary bacteria, fungi, parasites and viruses. Fauci told the subcommittee on human resources and intergovernmental relations that he has brought up the gap in biweekly meetings of the interagency HIV Leadership Group. The response within the department is that ``they were very sympathetic with the difficulties this is posing for us in the conduct of our trials, but a solution is not readily at hand,'' Fauci said. He said the problem is an unwillingness to spend more money on reimbursements that are already stretching the government for non-experimental hospitalizations. ``We do not agree from the biomedical, research and health care delivery standpoint with that philosophy,'' said Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases at the National Institutes of Health. Hospitalization is required for AIDS patients with opportunistic infections because the infection is usually acute and patients must be monitored around the clock, said Dr. Fred R. Sattler of the University of Southern California's School of Medicine. The hearing was called to examine the status of research into drugs used to prevent or treat opportunistic infections, and the priority given by the NIH to research into those drugs rather than an overall cure for AIDS. The institutes have recently indicated they would spend a larger share on the drugs against opportunistic infections. And on Tuesday evening, the NIH announced it would give $2.8 million to six teams of scientists for research on such drugs.

DOC.HEAD: US Sending Rice To Liberia
DOC.TEXT: The United States will provide 30,000 bags of rice to help feed victims of the civil war in Liberia, the State Department said Wednesday. Catholic Relief Services will use commercial channels to sell the rice at a subsidized price to enable poor Liberians to buy it, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. The proceeds will be used for relief-related activities. The United States also is providing 29,200 metric tons of rice to Liberian refugees in Cote D'Ivoire, Sierra Leone, and Guinea, and to displaced persons in Liberia. Thus far, 15,000 metric tons of rice have been delivered. The remaining 14,200 metric tons have been shipped, Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Bertha Bears Down on Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with 1 dead, six missing from damaged cargo ship, movement of hurricane. Picks up 5th graf pvs., `Little change ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mariners were securing their vessels in Halifax, Nova Scotia, today as Hurricane Bertha continued on an expected collision course with Canada's maritime provinces. Crew members aboard the damaged Greek cargo ship Corazon, caught in the hurricane 340 miles off Cape Cod, abandoned ship early today. At least one seaman died and six were missing early today. Eighteen crew members were rescued from a lifeboat and a life raft after four or more hours in heavy seas. Three were in a lifeboat and one was still in the water this morning, said Coast Guard Coast Guard Lt. j.g. Rodney Gadsden. At noon, Bertha was centered near latitude 41.8 north and longitude 62.0 west, or about 185 miles south southwest of Sable Island, Nova Scotia. The hurricane was moving northeast at about 12 mph, with top sustained winds near 75 mph. Little change in strength or direction was expected through Thursday morning, according to forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The government of Canada has issued a heavy rainfall and wind warning for the eastern Canadian maritime provinces, and tropical storm force winds of at least 39 mph were beginning to reach land early today, forecasters said. Rough waters attributed to the hurricane created havoc Tuesday with swimmers in Florida, where one man drowned and nearly 200 had to be rescued from Volusia County waters, according to chief lifeguard, Tom Rennick. Nelson Lejune, 59, drowned trying to rescue his 18-year-old foster son, Robert Perry, at New Smyrna Beach, about 15 miles south of Daytona Beach. Perry survived.

DOC.HEAD: Television Academy To Announce Emmy Nominees
DOC.TEXT: Because it's a cartoon, ``The Simpsons'' is not allowed to compete for an Emmy in the category of outstanding comedy series. But Nancy Cartwright can be nominated for lead actress in a comedy series for providing the voice of animated Bart Simpson. How can a female be nominated for playing an imaginary boy? This is television. Anything is possible, if you understand the rules of the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. Actress Dana Delany of ``China Beach'' and actor Louis Gossett Jr. will help announce this year's primetime Emmy nominees during a news conference Thursday morning. Because ``The Simpsons'' is animated, it must compete in the category of ``outstanding animated program of one hour or less,'' said John Leverence, the academy's award director. There are no categories for actors and actresses who provide the voices for animated primetime shows, Leverence said. As a result, Julie Kavner, whose gravelly voice doubles as mom Marge Simpson, could be nominated for outstanding lead actress in a comedy series, as could Cartwright. Daniel Castellaneta, the grumbling voice of baldheaded dad Homer Simpson, could be nominated as lead actor in a comedy series. The phenomenally successful Simpsons are likely to be part of a Fox Broadcasting Co. nomination list that could also include ``In Living Color,'' a black, saucier version of ``Saturday Night Live'' that has received rave reviews. The now-retired ``Tracey Ullman Show,'' which won Fox its first Emmy, may also be on the list for outstanding variety series. In the category of outstanding comedy series, Emmy favorites are ``Cheers'' and ``The Golden Girls'' on NBC, ``The Wonder Years'' on ABC, and ``Murphy Brown'' and ``Designing Women'' on CBS. Roseanne Barr and her top-rated ABC comedy series ``Roseanne'' will likely be snubbed again this year, the actress and network sources said. Cult hit ``Twin Peaks'' on ABC is favored for a nomination for best drama series. Past ABC Emmy winners ``China Beach'' and ``thirtysomething,'' as well as ``In the Heat of the Night'' on NBC, also are favored. ``Twin Peaks'' lead actors Kyle MacLachlan and Michael Ontkean, as coffee- and pie-loving law enforcement officers, may get nominated, as may female stars Piper Laurie, Peggy Lipton and Joan Chen. Emmy winner Patricia Wettig's portrayal of a young mother suffering from ovarian cancer on ``thirtysomething'' may nab her another nomination. Delany of ``China Beach,'' who won last year for outstanding lead actress in a drama series, also could get another nod this year. In the movies and miniseries categories, favorite choices are ``Small Sacrifices'' starring Farrah Fawcett on ABC, ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' on ABC, ``Murder in Mississippi'' on NBC and ``Phantom of the Opera'' on NBC. The NBC movie about the murders of three young civil rights' workers in Mississippi also could get nominations for stars Blair Underwood and Tom Hulce. The winners will be selected Aug. 26-27 by panels of directors, actors and writers who vote only in their professional categories. The 42nd annual primetime Emmy awards ceremony will be broadcast live on Fox on Sunday, Sept. 16.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0647 to fix date
DOC.TEXT: Eds: Members who used AM-Indigent Organs, sent under a Milwaukee dateline July 19 as a0583, may wish to use the following.

The Associated Press reported July 19 that Milwaukee County Supervisor T. Anthony Zielinski had proposed selling the organs of dead welfare recipients whether or not they had granted permission. More specifically, Zielinski's proposal would have required the county to sell the organs of welfare recipients who do not state their preference prior to their death. Zielinski has since retracted the proposal and apologized.

DOC.HEAD: Some Tornado Victims Receiving Bills From Ambulance Services
DOC.TEXT: Some victims of the tornadoes that devastated Petersburg in June feel insults have been added to their injuries after receiving bills up to $200 for ambulance services. ``It just hasn't set right with some of the people,'' said the Rev. Jeffrey Stratton, Petersburg's volunteer coordinator. More than a dozen people have received the bills, Stratton said. ``What I have told the people is that an ambulance service is still a business,'' Stratton said. ``Although I doubt if that (billing) was the first thing on their minds, it still cost them money.'' Jess Roberts, director of Alexander Ambulance Services in Evansville, said 23 ambulances from throughout southern Indiana helped with disaster relief following the tornadoes June 2 that killed seven residents. Roberts said Alexander billed four tornado victims and later regretted it. The company sent letters on July 17 to people who had received the bills advising that no collection would be attempted because the service was voluntary. ``We had discussed it but decided it was just a cost of doing business,'' he said Tuesday. It cost Alexander $6,000 to $7,000 to send five ambulances, two wheelchair vans and 20 workers to Petersburg, Roberts said. Much of the equipment was used to transport 99 residents of the Petersburg Health Care Center to other area nursing homes. Other ambulance services said they planned to bill patients that had been transported. Janet Hunt, director of the Pike County Emergency Medical Services, said six people would be billed, but all were covered by insurance. Rick Shephard, director of Ziemer-Bassemier Ambulance Service in Evansville, said he planned to bill the insurance companies of two people transported.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Say They've Had Trouble Getting Credit
DOC.TEXT: One out of every five businesses seeking credit in the last six months had trouble borrowing funds, according to a survey released Wednesday by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``The credit crunch on business is more serious and more widespread than previously has been acknowledged,'' said chamber Vice President Richard W. Rahn in releasing the poll of 8,190 responding businesses. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan noted July 12 that credit had become tight and said the central bank would lower short-term interest rates to ease the situation. The federal funds rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans, subsequently dropped from 8.25 per cent to 8 percent. The Fed had kept the rate relatively high for more than a year in an attempt to slow the economy and thus lessen inflationary pressures. Rahn attributed the credit situation to the ``economic slowdown, increased bank regulation and the effects of the thrift-industry bailout.'' Small businesses especially are feeling the impact, he said. Of firms with sales of less than $1 million, 27.4 percent seeking credit reported trouble. Only 19.2 percent of firms with sales between $1 million and $9.9 million reported problems, while just 12.3 percent of businesses with sales of more than $10 million expressed complaints. Hardest hit were real estate firms, with 33.3 percent of those seeking credit having trouble obtaining it. But at least one in four construction, communications and transportation companies and small services-oriented businesses also reported trouble in the survey. Least affected, the poll showed, were businesses in the finance or banking fields. By region, the worst crunch appeared to be in the Northeast where 26.2 percent of the respondents reported having trouble obtaining credit. Trouble also was experienced by 24.6 percent of the businesses in the West, 23.1 percent in the South and 15.6 percent in the Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Appoints Louisiana Democrat To Advisory Commission
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will appoint Samuel B. Nunez Jr., the president of the Louisiana State Senate, to the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, the White House said Wednesday. Nunez, 60, of Chalmette, La., recently won back the Senate presidency from fellow Democrat Allen Bares. Nunez is the immediate past president of the National Conference of State Legislatures. The White House also announced Bush will nominate two new directors of the Federal Housing Finance Board. They are: William C. Perkins, executive director of the Wisconsin Partnership for Housing Development in Madison, Wis., and Marilyn R. Seymann, managing director of Andersen Assetbased services in Phoenix, Ariz. The White House also announced Bush will appoint: _Janis Gabay, the National Teacher of the Year from San Diego, Calif., to the Commission on Presidential Scholars. _William T. Esrey, chairman of United Telecommunications and U.S. Sprint, and Paul G. Stern, chairman of Northern Telecom, Ltd., to the President's National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee. _Charles G. Palm, associate director for library and archives at the Hoover Institution in Stanford, Calif., and Frank E. Vandiver, director of the Mosher Institute for Defense Studies at Texas A&M University, to the National Historical Publications and Records Commission. _Wales H. Madden Jr., an Amarillo, Texas, lawyer, to the Board for International Food and Agricultural Development. Bush also announced the reappointment of D. Warner North, principal director and vice president of Decision Focus Inc., of Los Altos, Calif., to the Nuclear Waste Technical Review Board.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Damage Feared From Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with feds approving use of oil-eating microbes for spill cleanup. SUBS grafs 14-15, `Loy said...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with surface dissipation, details of microbe decision. Picks up 16th graf, `The process...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT3
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials today approved the use of oil-eating microbes to help clean up a 17-mile oil slick in Galveston Bay that has stained beaches and threatened wildlife in delicate marshlands. Crews in Galveston Bay used booms to hold the 500,000-gallon spill in check as the Coast Guard opened an inquiry in Houston today into the cause of Saturday's barge-tanker collision. Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Robert Douville, chief of investigations for the Marine Safety Office at New Orleans, said officials had subpoenaed four tanker crewmen for questioning. Douville said the hearings will take up to three days. Thousands of feet of booms, five skimmers and a vacuum truck were used Tuesday in the cleanup. The vessels were to return at daylight. ``The oil is significantly disappearing and is being picked up,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Dennis Schaefer. Salvage crews had retrieved about 48,400 gallons of the spill by Tuesday night, he said. Heavy black oil was reported on bathing beaches near San Leon. Oil also washed up at Texas City, Bolivar Peninsula and Pelican Island off Galveston, and two sea bird deaths have been blamed on the spill, the Coast Guard said. Environmentalists feared more damage because the oil is thick and unlikely to dissipate in the bay, which is protected from the Gulf of Mexico by barrier islands that contain nesting grounds for birds and other wildlife. ``The worst kind of spill you can have is one behind these barrier islands, which is what we've got,'' said Larry McKinney, director of resource protection for the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. ``With the quantity of the oil reported, the location of the spill and the sheen that is 17 miles long, that's setting us up for a worst-case scenario.'' At least 100 species of birds, including the endangered brown pelican, and at least 75 types of fish inhabit the bay area, McKinney said. The spill occurred after a Greek tanker collided with two barges in the Houston Ship Channel, sinking one barge and damaging the other. Both leaked oil. The double-hull tanker did not lose any of its 29,400 metric tons of jet fuel. Coast Guard Rear Adm. Jim Loy, who flew over the slick Tuesday, said he recommended contractors bring in about five more skimmers. But he added, ``I think we have a pretty good handle on the environmentally sensitive areas.'' The Coast Guard said today that surface oil has dissipated but the crude may have sunk. After a two-hour meeting, a 14-member federal and state team overseeing the cleanup approved using oil-eating microbes on parts of the spill, said Texas General Land Office spokesman Blanton Moore. He expected the microbes to be spread over sensitive marshlands and shallow areas that skimmers can't reach. The organisms convert the oil into a fatty substance fish can eat, and die when the oil runs out. The process was first tested on open waters after the supertanker Mega Borg spilled 3.9 million gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico in June, and state officials had pronounced the experiment a success. ``Our concern is not to introduce something into the water that we're not very sure about,'' Loy said Tuesday. But Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro said the microorganisms used in June already are EPA-approved. ``If there were questions about the side effects of this procedure, they should have been answered at that time,'' he said. The busy Houston Ship Channel closed after the accident but reopened to incoming barge traffic Tuesday. About 100 barges were waiting to enter, and as many as 60 ships were waiting to get in and about the same number were waiting to leave, the Coast Guard said. The disruption costs shippers a total of about $1.5 million a day, said Ted Thorjunssen, president of the West Gulf Maritime Association.

DOC.HEAD: Baker, Shevardnadze Discuss Arms Control, Cooperation
LaserPhoto IRK8
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister dnadze discussed conventional arms control and U.S.-Soviet coopEduard A. Shevareration in a marathon meeting Wednesday, Soviet sources said. But in talks that lasted into the night in a remote fishing lodge, the envoys did not discuss the 12-year-old civil war in Afghanistan, expected to mark the highlight of the two-day talks. There has been speculation of a settlement in the conflict since Baker arrived in Irkutsk Wednesday. Expectations were heightened after a sudden visit by Afghan President Najibullah to Moscow on Sunday. But on Wednesday, a source close to the negotiations said no breakthrough was expected to end the war, which has claimed more than 1.5 million lives and left Afghanistan in ruins. ``Exaggerated expectations were created,'' he said on condition of anonymissed a busy schedule of meetings for the rest of this year. Baker will meet Shevardnadze again when he travels to Moscow Sept. 12 for talks on German unification among the two Germanys and the four World War II allies _ France, England, the United States and the Soviet Union. The two meet in New York Oct. 1-2 during international talks on conventional arms. During a three-hour talk Wednesday morning, Shevardnadze gave Baker a 15-page outline of areas for economic and scientific cooperation, the source said. The outline mentioned capital investment, U.S.-Soviet space projects and joint work on ecology and medical research, the source said. Tass said one space project would be a joint flight to Mars. The document was a response to Baker's July 18 offer at a meeting with Shevardnadze in Paris of U.S. technical advice on the failing Soviet economy. Another Soviet source, quoting a draft of a four-page U.S.-Soviet communique, said that under an economic cooperation package, Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher and leading American businessmen will join Baker in Moscow in September to meet with Soviet counterparts. Resolution of the Afghan conflict appears hung up on the role to be played in Afghanistan by Najibullah, the 43-year-old former security chief who uses only one name. The United States has reportedly softened its demand that Najibullah step down before elections can be held. But the U.S.-backed Afghan resistance wants Najibullah to relinquish power before it comes to the negotiating table. A compromise in which Najibullah would remain president but give up control over his country's military and security forces is being considered, the first Soviet source said. Wednesday's talks occurred against a backdrop of water sports and sightseeing. Baker and Shevardnadze rode a hydrofoil on the Angara River and fished for an hour. Shevardnadze caught a trout but Baker came away empty handed. At one point as the two envoys walked among a crowd of 200 well-wishers, Baker mussed the hair of a sullen 6-year-old Siberian boy and said, ``I love Siberia. I love Siberia.'' ``They don't recognize their own minister but they certainly recognize you, sir,'' Shevardnadze mused to Baker. Shevardnadze and Baker were interviewed as they returned from the fishing lodge tucked into a forest on the banks of the Angara River, to Irkutsk, a tree-lined city filled with log cabins and known as the ``Paris of Siberia.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Militants Surrender in Trinidad, Ending Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Bakr reportedly surrendering, hostages put at 42, all of them out of TV station. Pickup 10th, `Earlier today...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Moslem militants surrendered today and began freeing their 42 hostages, ending a six-day coup attempt that seriously threatened the government and reportedly left at least 20 people dead. The 25 people who had been held hostage since Friday at the government television station left the building one by one, were searched in the middle of the street by soldiers, then taken away on an army bus, state radio said. A short time later, the leader of the coup attempt, Abu Bakr, and about 50 rebels left the building, dropped their weapons in the street, put their hands behind their heads, and surrendered to soldiers, witnesses said. Government spokesman Gregory Shaw said another group of soldiers was heading over to the Parliament building, about a mile away, to take the remaining rebels into custody and evacuate their 17 hostages, who included seven Cabinet ministers and other officials. Shaw said it was his understanding that Bakr and his group of about 100 Moslem extremists had surrendered unconditionally. The hostages initially included the prime minister, Arthur N.R. Robinson, but he was freed on Tuesday after offering to step down, call new elections and grant the rebels amnesty. It was not immediately clear whether the government would fulfill that pledge since it was made while Robinson was held captive. Details of the final negotiations that produced the rebel agreement to surrender and free all their hostages were not immediately available. Earlier today, Bakr had described the coup attempt as a ``small family squabble'' and said that an accord had been reached to end the standoff. Speaking in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. from the Caribbean nation, Bakr had indicated that the hostages would be freed soon. ``The negotiations are over. We already have a signed agreement,'' he told the BBC. ``We are making preparations now for the evacuation of all the people, all the people at the television house and the people who are at the Parliament building.'' At least 20 people were reportedly killed in fighting and looting associated with the coup attempt. The capital was reported quiet today, but a government spokesman said there were explosions overnight. ``It's very calm,'' said the spokesman, Bernard Pantin. He said he did not know the cause of the explosions but said they were not near the Parliament or the television station, where the captives were being held. Bakr had blamed Robinson for widespread poverty in the once oil-rich nation of 1.3 million people near Venezuela. He said in today's interview he was seeking a ``new beginning in Trinidad.'' Bakr's Jamaat al-Muslimeen group, which means the Moslem Group in Arabic, was founded in 1984 and is believed to have 250 to 300 members. It is also believed to have received financing from Libya. The U.S. Ambassador, Charles Gargano, said no sign of popular support surfaced for Bakr's extremist sect. ``This is not a revolution,'' he said. ``It is a hostage situation.'' Although Bakr said in the BBC interview that everyone being held by his followers would be freed, he also denied that the people were in fact hostages. ``We don't have any hostages, sir. We never had any hostages,'' he told the BBC interviewer. ``You'll have to rephrase that question.'' Asked whether the people in question were then free to leave, Bakr responded: ``There's a curfew. They can't walk about in a curfew.'' A 6 p.m.-to-noon curfew remained in effect throughout most of Trinidad following earlier widespread looting. When the interviewer expressed disbelief that only the curfew was stopping the prisoners from leaving, Bakr also mentioned that bus service had been disrupted. He said of the coup attempt, ``It was a small family squabble... I'm saying that emphatically.'' Robinson was allowed Tuesday to leave the besieged Parliament building. It was not clear whether he would continue as prime minister. Fifteen government officials were held hostage in the Parliament building and 25 others in the government TV station. At least nine people were killed when Bakr and his followers took over both buildings on Friday. Robinson, 63, was hospitalized for treatment of a leg wound suffered in the takeover, as well as for exhaustion and glaucoma. The government had said earlier that Robinson was shot in both feet. There was no explanation for the discrepancy. Smart would not discuss the conditions under which Robinson was freed, or say whether his health was a factor. Bakr said in today's interview that Robinson was freed as a ``humanitarian gesture.'' Gargano, interviewed before Robinson's release, said the government remained united and in control. He said Robinson's deputy, Winston Dookeran, and eight other ministers who escaped rebel capture were running Trinidad. Smart said the government continued to enjoy the ``complete loyalty'' of the 1,500-member military and 5,000-member police force. In a joint telephone call Monday night from inside Parliament, Robinson, Bakr's chief negotiator, Bilal Abdullah, and Minister of Justice and National Security Selwyn Richardson all said a settlement had been reached. Richardson said the agreement called for Robinson to resign and for elections to be held within 90 days. But government spokesman Gregory Shaw said there was no agreement: ``These are statements of people being held at gunpoint. People are made to make statements.''

DOC.HEAD: 29 Hurt in Crash When Train Goes Wrong Way
DOC.TEXT: A rush-hour passenger train smashed head-on into a stationary commuter train at a station west of London Wednesday, injuring 29 people. British Rail said a three-car train entering Reading station from Tonbridge at 20 mph was switched to the wrong platform and hit the front of a stationary eight-car commuter train from Reading to London. The driver of the Tonbridge train was in critical condition at Royal Berkshire Hospital with leg, head and back injuries. One passenger with leg injuries was also hospitalized. The others were released after treatment. Investigators said they were puzzled by the crash. Automatic equipment should have prevented a train from running into an occupied platform. They said human error or faults with signals or points were believed to have caused the morning crash at the station, 35 miles from London. The Tonbridge train should have stopped alongside the London-bound train. Both trains were crowded but all injuries were on the Tonbridge train, whose passengers were standing ready to get off and were thrown forward, most suffering bruises and cuts. Bernadette Currie said she had just stood up, preparing to leave the train, when she was ``jolted forward and hit the wood of the sliding door. Some of my teeth were knocked out.'' The Tonbridge driver was trapped by his legs in the crushed cab for more than two hours while firefighters cut him free. He was conscious throughout and talked to his rescuers as he received painkillers and blood transfusions. ``His feet were twisted, so it was impossible to free him immediately. We used hydraulic equipment to bend back the metal, like opening a tin,'' said senior fire officer Lyn Ashfield. ``He had lost a lot of blood, but we kept talking to him to take his mind off the pain,'' he said. Debra Whitehead, 23, a passenger on the Tonbridge train who suffered a sprained neck, said: ``Everyone was thrown forward and we were all just sitting there, wondering what had happened. ``I was in the third carriage from the front, but there was no panic, just confusion,'' she said. British Rail has had two serious crashes in the past two years. Faulty wiring in a signal led to 35 people being killed and more than 100 injured in a three-train crash at Clapham Junction in south London during rush hour on Dec. 12, 1988. Driver error was blamed for a two-train crash in March 1989 near Purley station on London's southern outskirts in which five people died and 94 were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Says Blocking Phone Numbers from Caller ID Would Help Harassers
DOC.TEXT: A woman subjected to two years of obscene phone calls, vandalism and threats from a ``telephone terrorist'' urged a Senate panel Wednesday not to restrict the new Caller I.D. devices that display the phone numbers of incoming calls. Mrs. Stacey Blazer of Olney, Md., said she opposed a bill by Sen. Herbert Kohl, D-Wis., that would require phone companies to offer selective blocking of Caller I.D. for those customers who don't want to reveal their phone numbers. In the case of harassing calls, she said, blocking would ``protect the perpetrator of the crime at the expense of their victims.'' Telephone companies such as Philadelphia-based Bell Atlantic are promoting Caller I.D., which displays incoming numbers on a small video device, as a way to thwart unwanted callers. They cite statistics in New Jersey showing a dramatic decline in the number of obscene phone calls after Caller I.D. began there two years ago. But privacy advocates say callers should not be required to give away their phone numbers to car salesmen, mail order houses and the like whenever they make a phone inquiry. Law enforcement officials and operators of battered women centers say blocking is essential. Six areas of the country now have Caller I.D., and as many as 22 states are debating whether to allow it. California requires blocking, while a Pennsylvania court has outlawed it as a violation of wiretaps laws. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has offered a similar long-distance service to businesses for several years. Wednesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on technology and the law primarily focused on the issue of whose privacy should be paramount: the caller or the called? ``We should not sacrifice everyone's privacy to catch a small minority of phone terrorists,'' Kohl told the hearing. But Mrs. Blazer, who said Caller I.D. worked for her after repeated cries for help to the police did not, was equally adamant: ``My right to privacy is more important than a potential harasser's right to violate my privacy.'' She said Caller I.D. is more effective than services such as Call Trace, which allows a victim of a harassing call, by pushing three numbers on the telephone, to tell phone company computers to record the caller's phone number. Only police can gain access to those numbers, however. ``I wanted to know if he lived next door or if he was one of my husband's business associates,'' Mrs. Blazer said of a man who called her repeatedly, threatened to rape her, banged on her door and windows and vandalized her house. ``Call Trace wouldn't reveal that.'' Phone company wiretaps eventually led to the man's arrest and conviction, she said, but only after repeated delays and red tape. His calls resumed while he was on probation and stopped only when she signed up for Caller I.D. earlier this year. ``If I had Caller I.D. two years ago, I could have prevented all this before it began,'' she said. She agreed with a New Jersey Bell President James G. Cullen, who testified that Caller I.D. would not be as effective if blocking were allowed, particularly for harassing calls. Cullen also said customers prefer Caller I.D. to Call Trace. ``Customers say they want to deal with the situation themselves,'' Cullen said. But Janlori Goldman, an attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union, said it could be dangerous for women to call back an obscene caller and confront him.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Asserts Role on US-Soviet Chemical Pact
DOC.TEXT: Senators warned the State Department's designated legal adviser Wednesday about a looming confrontation with the Bush administration over the parliamentary form of the recent U.S.-Soviet agreement banning chemical weapons. President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev signed the accord at their summit in June. The measure calls for the two countries to destroy most of existing stockpiles and end the production of new weapons. At issue is whether the proposal should be an executive agreement, which the Bush administration wants, or a treaty, which the Senate wants. A treaty must be ratified by the president with the approval of two-thirds of the Senate; an executive agreement such as the one on chemical weapons requires a majority vote in the House and Senate. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-N.Y., said 18 of the 19 members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee ``think it should be a treaty.'' He told Edwin D. Williamson, who has been nominated as the department's legal adviser that ``at a minimum, I would hope to elicit the constitutional basis for the administration's current view that this accord should be an executive agreement _ not a treaty.'' Williamson said he needed to study the issue further because his ``initial impression'' was that the measure should be a treaty. If approved by the Senate, Williamson will succeed Abraham Sofaer. A South Carolina native, Williamson, 50, has spent most of his career with the New York law firm of Sullivan and Cromwell.

DOC.HEAD: Police Start Skimming New Beat Aboard Jet Skis
LaserPhoto BX8
DOC.TEXT: In their ever-widening pursuit of crime, police are patrolling their beats with cars, motorcycles, horses and bicycles. Now add jet skis. The Metropolitan Police on Wednesday showed off their new vehicle _ which looks like a waterbound snowmobile _ for tracking down hoodlums at sea. Police touted the jet skis as unique weapons against crime, allowing officers to nab boaters and other jet skiers who endanger swimmers or break other rules. ``They're interesting and good for morale, but they're also very effective,'' said Kathleen O'Toole, superintendent of the Metropolitan Police. Officer Jim Cullinane said he needed only about five minutes of instruction before he was ready to skim along the water. ``If you've got the touch, you've got the touch,'' he said with a laugh. Cullinane and two other officers were eager to try out their new crafts, which will patrol the Charles River and beaches along the Atlantic Ocean. Under a warm sun, they treated onlookers to a brief water show, making hairpin turns and weaving between other boats in the river. Besides Boston, Florida's Broward County has jet ski police. Broward County began its own jet ski patrols to catch reckless jet ski operators. Los Angeles County police experimented with a jet skis several years ago, but decided they weren't very effective for rescues. Metropolitan Police officers, who monitor waterways around Boston, said their primary targets would be jet ski menaces. But in addition, they would use the department's three craft to catch speeders and drunken boaters, and to help make rescues. The jet ski can make tight turns and skim along waters that would be too shallow for motor boat patrols. It's top speed is 31 mph. Unlike early models, the department's jet skis allow the driver to sit down and can carry more than one person. They are painted blue and white _ like squad cars _ and might get flashing blue lights. Police uniforms have been adapted for the conditions. Jet ski officers will wear dark blue, short-sleeve shirts and shorts, plus orange life jackets. Just like any other officers, they'll carry radios, handcuffs and guns. But Officer Armand Ouellette said the jet ski's novelty would wear off. ``Anything can be fun for 20 minutes,'' he said. ``When you're out there in the 90s and cooking your brains, it ceases to be fun real quick.''

DOC.HEAD: Zhelev Elected First Non-Communist President in Decades
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers on Wednesday elected democratic opposition leader Zhelyu Zhelev as Bulgaria's first non-Communist president in more than four decades. Thousands poured into the streets in a spontaneous celebration. The election of Zhelev, a 55-year-old philosopher turned politician, ended a nearly 4-week-old political standoff after the July 6 resignation of President Petar Mladenov, a member of the ruling Communist party, now known as the Socialists. Mladenov had been popular for steering Bulgaria toward June's free elections, but resigned after it was proved he had urged the use of tanks in December against anti-government demonstrators. Thousands of supporters of Zhelev's opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, celebrated in the streets of Sofia, a UDF stronghold. They chanted: ``Victory!'' ``UDF!'' and ``Zhelyu!'' ``It is a great day today,'' said one supporter, Nadia Mihailova, 55. ``The balance (of power) has been achieved, and hopefully things will quiet down.'' Zhelev, who led the UDF in the June elections that the Socialists won, became president after the 400-seat legislature failed in five previous attempts to elect a new head of state. He is the first non-Communist to gain any leading post in the Balkan nation in more than 40 years. Zhelev was a compromise candidate backed by all parties _ including Socialist leaders _ and won 284 of the 389 votes cast. He ran uncontested after all parties withdrew their initial candidates. Incumbent Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov told the house before the vote that Zhelev's election would mean ``a final rejection of the factual monopoly over power.'' His remarks indicated a commitment to pluralism in the Socialist Party, the only former Communist Party in Eastern Europe to win free elections. The Socialists won 211 seats in the June elections while the UDF took 144. Lukanov had repeatedly said that despite his party's victory in the June elections he did not want to lead a one-party government. Spreading street protests against the Socialists have also made clear that the ruling party's support is dwindling rapidly, necessitating some sort of cooperation with the opposition. Students and intellectuals have staged protests and strikes since the June elections to demand democratic reforms. Before Wednesday's vote, both Zheev and Lukanov indicated that the Socialists and opposition were willing to work together to ease Bulgaria's social tensions and rapidly deepening economic crisis. In his comments before the vote, Zhelev said he wanted to see Bulgaria make a ``peaceful evolution to democracy with the direct participation of the political opposition.'' Immediately following his victory, Zhelev made a surprise move and proposed former Socialist Interior Minister Atanas Semerdzhiev as vice president. Deputies greeted the suggestion with applause and voted overwhelmingly for Semerdzhiev in a show of hands. Only two deputies opposed the choice and seven abstained. Semerdzhiev resigned as Interior Minister last Friday when a furor erupted over the proposed appearance in Parliament of Todor Zhivkov, the Stalinist leader ousted last fall after 35 years in power. The appointment of Semerdzhiev was seen as a move to narrow the widening rift between the Socialists and the opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Mercy Killing Wins Freedom After Five Years
DOC.TEXT: An 81-year-old man convicted in the ``mercy killing'' of his wife will be freed from prison Thursday for humanitarian reasons, Gov. Bob Martinez said Wednesday. Roswell Gilbert, whose case focused national attention on the killing of an ailing loved one, suffers from lung and heart disease and physicians say he could die at any time. ``I think it's in the best interest of all parties concerned.'' said Martinez, a law-and-order Republican who has signed more than 120 death warrants since taking office in 1987 and previously opposed clemency for Gilbert. The retired engineer was the subject of a 1987 television movie that dramatized his decision in 1985 to kill his wife of 51 years, who suffered from Alzheimer's disease and osteoporosis. ``Mr. Gilbert's declining health, and the likelihood that his condition will continue to deteriorate if he remains in prison, leads me to the conclusion that he should be granted clemency,'' Martinez said. Three of the six Cabinet members _ Comptroller Gerald Lewis, Education Commissioner Betty Castor and Attorney General Bob Butterworth _ signed the governor's petition, clearing the way for Gilbert's freedom. ``Oh Lord, it's just such wonderful news,'' said Gilbert's daughter, Martha Moran, in Baltimore. ``It's just wonderful.'' Mrs. Moran said she would return to Florida immediately to help her father resettle, probably back at a Fort Lauderdale condominium where many of his friends reside. ``I think the first thing we're going to do is go out and have a good meal, and then let daddy have a little bourbon and branch water _ which he hasn't had in five-and-a-half years,'' she said. Gilbert was examined in January and a medical report showed he suffered from heart and lung disease and was considered ``at high risk of death at any time,'' because of his age and physical condition. ``Daddy has very bad emphysema and one of the main things I'm going to do is really insist he quit smoking,'' said Mrs. Moran, the Gilberts' only child. Gilbert, who was held at the North Florida Reception Center in Lake Butler, was sentenced to a mandatory minimum prison term of 25 years to life after being convicted of first-degree murder in the March 1985 shooting death of his wife, Emily. The prosecution claimed Gilbert killed his 72-year-old wife because she had become a burden to him. Kelly Hancock, the former prosecutor who put Gilbert behind bars, visited him in prison recently and then called for his early release. His change of heart set off a chain reaction of comment from Cabinet members, followed by Martinez's call for clemency Wednesday. Former Gov. Bob Graham and the Cabinet rejected Gilbert's clemency request in 1985 and Martinez repeated that action as late as January 1987, following the NBC television movie ``Mercy or Murder.'' Gilbert had hoped the movie would gain him support in his bid for clemency. ``I would like to be vindicated,'' he said after watching the movie in prison. ``I'm not the kind of bastard that deserves a life sentence. That's about the same sentence that the most miserable guy in the world would get.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Oil Spill Cookbook, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0586,0549
DOC.HEAD: Help Yourself to Some Alaska Crude Cake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS note at end with address for book. Also moved for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Got a hankering for some Exxon Valdez Halibut? A craving for Beach Crew Chili? If Baked Alaska sounds old-fashioned, perhaps Alaska Crude chocolate cake will satisfy. These and other culinary concoctions were submitted by Exxon Corp. workers, elected officials and others involved in the cleanup of the nation's biggest oil spill. The recipes are collected in ``The Two Billion Dollar Cookbook.'' The title refers to the amount Exxon reported spending to clean up nearly 11 million gallons of crude spilled from the Exxon Valdez in March 1989. A few fanciful names aside, there is little in the cookbook to remind readers it was an oil spill that brought the contributors of the recipes to Prince William Sound. ``We wanted to show some of the good story and the good news of what's happened, with all of those people that got together to work on the cleanup,'' said Kay Harrington, one of four women who put together the cookbook while their Exxon-employed husbands worked on the spill. ``The oil spill was the proverbial lemon, and this was an effort to make some lemonade.'' According to its foreword, the cookbook aims to celebrate ``the richness of friendships and the priceless feeling of accomplishment of a job well done.'' ``But perhaps more importantly,'' it adds, ``our hope is that you will find our book a recipe for healing.'' Healing and humor are welcome in the aftermath of the spill, said Alaska Environmental Commissioner Dennis Kelso, who hadn't seen the cookbook. He cautioned against treating the cleanup as if it were over and done with, or forgetting the damage the spill did. The cookbook, financed by 31 corporations and individuals, including Exxon, went on the shelves of stores in Alaska and Houston last week. Exxon also has the book on sale at its Anchorage offices. The book's pages are sprinkled with upbeat bits of information. It includes photos of a clean Prince William Sound. There are anecdotes about people who met, married or had babies while working on the spill. First lady Barbara Bush sent a recipe for All-American Clam Chowder. Gov. Steve Cowper added one for Buttermilk Pie. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, contributed one for Salmonburgers. Exxon Valdez Halibut, a mix of halibut, mayonnaise, mustard and seasoning ``invented in an Exxon trailer in Valdez,'' was submitted by Mona Cadoret of Lafayette, La. Texas and Cajun cuisine are well represented, reflecting Exxon's Houston roots. The last recipe in the book is for soap. Proceeds from the $16.95 book will be donated to an Anchorage shelter. Kelso said he was sorry he didn't contribute a recipe. ``Blackened redfish comes to mind,'' he said with a laugh. ``I don't begrudge this kind of thing _ there's no reason we can't acknowledge each other's humanity and a sense that ... we each experienced this in a way that's appropriate to acknowledge,'' he said.
To order a cookbook, send $16.95 plus $2.50 postage to: Clean-up Cookbook, P.O. Box 242944, Anchorage, Alaska 99524-2944.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Three Dead as Cargo Ship Founders in Hurricane
DOC.TEXT: Merchant ships plucked 20 sailors from heavy waves Wednesday after their cargo ship began to break up under the battering of Hurricane Bertha 350 miles off Cape Cod. Three crew members died and four were missing. The crew of 27 abandoned the 593-foot Maltese-registered freighter Corazon at 4:20 a.m., 11 hours after reporting the ship was breaking up. Thirty-foot waves whipped by wind gusting to 90 mph had snapped its keel, the equivalent of breaking its back. Soviet, Hong Kong and Norwegian merchant ships steamed to the stricken vessel to rescue crew members crowded in a lifeboat and a life raft. U.S. military aircraft coordinated from above. ``She had fairly calm passage coming across the Atlantic and Bertha just swung right into her,'' said Charles Aitcheson, president of Asca Marine Inc. the ship's New York agent. ``Obviously, they've tried to save as many as they could. They're all out there working hard to do it.'' Authorities did not know if the ship was leaking fuel or how much fuel was aboard. Hurricane Bertha churned on toward Canada's Maritime Provinces carrying 75 mph wind, but was expected to weaken. A swimmer in Florida drowned Tuesday in rough water attributed to the hurricane. The Corazon was carrying more than 25,000 tons of cement bound from Greece to New York, and the load likely contributed to its damage, said Coast Guard Lt. j.g. Rodney Gadsden. ``We know it came apart in heavy seas,'' he said. ``We don't know if it was a structural problem or not. It just happened because of the weather conditions.'' By midmorning the Corazon's bow was submerged and its stern was standing clear of the water 350 miles south-southwest of Cape Cod, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Anthony L. Whitehead. One crew member apparently fell into the water when the crew members boarded the lifeboat and life raft, Whitehead said. That sailor was pulled from the water dead by the Russian trawler Vympel. Four hours after they left their ship, the 13 crew members on the lifeboat were taken aboard the Soviet merchant ship Leonid Leonidov, Whitehead said. But efforts to save the life raft's occupants went less smoothly. The Vympel attempted to rescue what was reported to be 12 sailors aboard the raft, Whitehead said. But the raft was pulled into the trawler's screw propeller and rudder area, and six or seven sailors were pitched into the ocean. The five remaining aboard the life raft were later pulled to safety. Two more life rafts were put out, and three people were seen, apparently in one of them, Gadsden said. More precise accounting was unavailable, but by afternoon the Coast Guard reported 20 sailors recovered alive, three dead and four unaccounted for. One survivor was reported injured. The Hong Kong vessel Nova Europa assisted and the Norwegian vessel Hual Angelita stood by. An Air Force C-130 flew overhead to direct communications, and a Coast Guard C-130 flew in to help. Aitcheson, the ship's agent, said the crew included Greek, Filipino, Polish and Maldivian sailors. He identified its captain as Georgios Tsibirlos, of Chios, Greece. The Corazon, displacing 15,892 gross tons, was built in Japan in 1972 and previously was operated under the Philippine flag as the Dona Corazon II, Aitcheson said. He identified the owner as Good Faith Shipping in Piraeus, Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Outlawed Extremist Group Claims Slaying of Catholic
DOC.TEXT: An outlawed Protestant extremist group claimed responsibility Wednesday for slaying a Roman Catholic man during his son's fifth birthday party. The Ulster Freedom Fighters said in a message to Belfast media that they killed John Judge, a 34-year-old father of three, as he chatted to friends at his garden gate Tuesday night while the party was underway inside his house. The Freedom Fighters claimed Judge was a member of the Irish Republican Army, but the IRA's political wing, Sinn Fein, said he had no connection to the organization or other paramilitary groups. Two gunmen riding in a taxi drove up to Judge's house in the Springfield Road area, a West Belfast Catholic stronghold, opened fire and escaped. The stolen taxi was later found abandoned near the staunchly Protestant Shankill Road area of west Belfast. The killing was the second this year by the Freedom Fighters. The banned group claimed it shot to death another Catholic on July 15 in Lisburn. Judge was the 37th person to die in political and sectarian violence in Northern Ireland this year and the 2,811th since the start of the so-called ``troubles'' in 1969. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic under a socialist government.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE HOUSING ROLL CALL _ 3 TAKES
Plant Owners Will Ask Customers to Pay Accident Costs Until The Year 2014
DOC.TEXT: The owners of the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor will seek to have customers pay costs associated with the 1979 accident until the year 2014, according to plant officials. The unit operated only about four months before it was permanently disabled in the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident on March 31, 1979. Its twin, Unit 1, was unharmed and was given permission to resume operations in 1985. The owners hope to operate the healthy unit until 2014. ``It's wrong to ask our children to pay for a nuclear reactor that only was in operation for four months,'' Eric Epstein, spokesman for Three Mile Island Alert, an anti-nuclear group, said in an interview Wednesday. The costs are the result of the reactor's ``unique, post-accident condition,'' plant officials said in a July 26 report filed with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Because of the accident, the report says it will cost $195.6 million to safely get rid of the damaged unit _ about $70 million more than for a comparable reactor that did not suffer an accident.
