The plant's Pennsylvania owners intend to ask state utility regulators to permit them to start billing customers for the full amount when they make their next rate filings, probably in 1992 or 1993, said Mary Wells, a spokeswoman for General Public Utilities Nuclear, the plant operator. It is standard practice for utilities to ask ratepayers to fund decommissioning, the formal term for mothballing or dismantling a plant at the end of its energy-producing life. But Three Mile Island poses ``a more difficult question,'' Pennsylvania Consumer Advocate Irwin Popowsky said in an interview Wednesday. ``We have not opposed reasonable decommissioning costs for other units on the theory that ratepayers who receive service ought to be accumulating money to decommission it later,'' Popowski said. ``But TMI-2 is unique because it only provided service for a short time. It's certainly going to be an issue,'' he said. Rates for the 426,000 customers of Metropolitan Edison Co., which owns 50 percent of the plant, could increase as much as 4 percent, plant officials said last month. Meanwhile, rates for customers of Pennsylvania Electric Co. and Jersey Central Power & Light Co., which each own 25 percent of both units, could see rates rise 1 percent to 2 percent, the officials said. In the accident, Unit 2 was allowed to lose vital cooling water that normally covers the nuclear fuel rods. Financed partly by ratepayers, the subsequent $1 billion cleanup has focused on removal of fuel from the damaged radioactive core, waste shipment and water decontamination. Plant officials hope to finish the cleanup by the end of 1991, then place Unit 2 in storage for anywhere between 20 years and 60 years while radiation decays inside. The decommissioning money would then be recalled, and the plant could either be dismantled or sealed.

DOC.HEAD: New President a Man of Letters, Not Politics
With AM-Bulgaria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Zhelev pronounced Zh'ell-eff
DOC.TEXT: Zhelyu Zhelev, the new Bulgarian president, was a man of letters rather than politics before last year's Politburo coup that toppled the hard-line Communist leadership. As in other East European countries abandoning Stalinism, Bulgaria's Parliament on Wednesday chose for the presidency an intellectual untainted by a Communist past. Zhelev, an opposition leader, was the first non-Communist to gain a top post in Bulgaria, where the former Communists, now called Socialists, still hold an absolute majority in the Grand National Assembly. But his election to the highest office illustrated the swift and unrelenting decline of the Socialists, who now admit that despite their June election victory they are not strong enough to govern alone. Zhelev, practically unknown in Bulgaria just over a year ago, gained prominence as chairman of the Union of Democratic Forces, the main opposition alliance comprising 16 diverse political parties. He was the only candidate in Wednesday's presidential balloting. The ruling Socialists, the mainstream Agrarians and the Union had withdrawn their candidates in an effort to break a deadlock in Parliament. Last spring, Zhelev led the opposition in talks with the former Communists that forced the ruling party to move toward a multiparty system and Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. While lacking charisma and political experience at the outset, Zhelev became a respected leader and gained considerable popularity in Sofia and other urban centers _ mainly among intellectuals and the country's youth. It was the slightly built Zhelev who stepped into an angry crowd of students and other protesters who had blocked traffic in downtown Sofia to demonstrate against alleged manipulations in the June parliamentary elections. Days earlier, on June 7, Zhelev was the main speaker at a rally of 500,000 Union supporters in downtown Sofia, the biggest such event ever in modern Bulgarian times. Before last year's changes, Zhelev was known only to a small group of intellectuals who managed to get a copy of his book ``Fascism,'' published in 1981. A searching analysis of totalitarianism, the book was soon banned and has become a bestseller only with its re-publication this year. In other East European nations, democratic changes that began last fall are also being led by dissident intellectuals. In Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel rose to the presidency as a dissident playwright who had been jailed and harassed for years. His ideas and plays had won acclaim abroad but were banned at home. Similarly, Hungary's interim president, Arpad Goencz, spent seven years in jail after the 1956 revolution and then was active as a writer and translater of English and French literature. Born March 3, 1935, Zhelev studied philosophy at Sofia University. From 1958-61 he worked in the House of Culture in Veselinovo near Shumen in northern Bulgaria. In 1961-64 he engaged in postgraduate studies but failed to complete them with a dissertation because he had criticized Lenin's theory of matter. He was expelled from the Communist Party in 1964. For the next eight years, Zhelev was either jobless or worked in casual jobs in agriculture in his wife's hometown. Starting in 1972, he worked for two years as a sociologist and joined the Institute of Culture in Sofia in 1975, where he has been active since, except for a period when he was expelled. Also in 1975, Zhelev's thesis was finally accepted and he graduated as a doctor of philosophy.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Accepts Ban on Speaking Fees _ Maybe
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, told its public esteem is ``at the level of used-car salesmen,'' voted 77-23 on Wednesday to bar its members from accepting fees for speeches to special-interest groups, but immediate skepticism was raised as to whether the decision will hold. The vote approved an amendment by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., to a campaign finance overhaul bill. It requires senators to quit giving speeches for profit as of next Jan. 1. But later action by the Senate and a renewed veto threat by the Bush administration regarding the overall bill raised doubts that the honoraria ban will make its way into the books anytime soon. ``This bill clearly will not become law,'' said Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky. He said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu had told him earlier Wednesday that Bush would veto it. The measure's chances also were complicated as the Senate began piling other amendments onto it _ some of them likely to virtually eliminate any chance of two-thirds, veto-proof support for the package. For example, the Senate barely approved, 51-49, New York Sen. Daniel Moynihan's proposal requiring members to forgo unearned income of more than 15 percent of their regular salaries. That would be a hard blow to the Senate's many millionaires, whose stock and interest incomes far exceed their government paychecks. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, one of those millionaires, said ``It looks like a little bit of class warfare going on.'' He said he wouldn't stay in the Senate if the Moynihan provision became law. Also approved was on a 59-41 vote was an amendment by Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., that would prohibit Senate candidates from tapping earmarked funds to help pay for television ads _ until Congress first sets aside $100 million for drug prevention centers. ``I don't know whether this bill is going anywhere,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``Unless there's some changes, that's not going to be possible.'' Senators can now pocket up to $27,337 in outside speaking fees to supplement their annual salary of $98,400. ``When a significant part of our salaries comes from hustling, and that's what it amounts to, we denigrate ourselves,'' said Dodd. ``As public servants, our salaries should come from the public alone.'' Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., said members of the Senate, himself among them, had supplemented their salaries with more than $9 million in honoraria over the past decade. ``The scandals of the past two years have put a black mark on public service and raised public cynicism to an all-time high,'' Byrd said. ``We're about at the level of used car salesmen'' in the public's esteem. The Senate voted last week to denounce Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., for violating several ethics standards, including skirting the limits on honoraria in a book-publishing deal. Six other senators are under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for alleged actions involving savings and loan institutions and Department of Housing and Urban Development programs. The House voted last year to give up honoraria effective Jan. 1, 1991, but also boosted the salaries of its members to $124,000. Reluctant to vote itself the same 25 percent pay boost, the Senate instead retained the opportunity for its members to accept special-interest fees. Republicans, who particularly oppose the campaign bill's provisions for aggregate spending ceilings and government vouchers for buying TV advertising, have lost several party-line votes in their attempts to amend it. Dodd, who reported $15,000 in honoraria income in 1989, called the vote on his amendment significant, regardless of Bush's veto threat, saying it puts the Senate on record for the first time in favor of abolishing honoraria. He said he will add it to other legislation if the campaign finance bill falters. In 1989, senators accepted nearly $3 million in honoraria and kept more than $2.1 million, with the balance donated to charity, according to their financial disclosure forms. Dole, who kept $35,750 in honoraria in 1989, said he agreed with Dodd on the need to eliminate such income but not on the strategy of doing it without a pay raise. ``In January, House members will be getting paid about $22,000 more than senators ... and we could be getting about $22,000 less for years to come,'' he said. Dole said he had considered trying to amend Dodd's measure to include a raise that would return Senate and House salaries to parity, but acknowledged he lacked the votes to win its passage this close to the November election. Dodd's amendment also would limit Senate members' earned outside income to 15 percent of their salaries, a policy that the House also adopted a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Denies Making Any Statements to Detective
DOC.TEXT: A defendant in the so-called Central Park jogger trial testified Wednesday he never admitted to police that he took part in a gang-rape and near-fatal beating. Testifying for the second day, Yusef Salaam, 16, admitted he was in the park April 19, 1989, the night the female jogger was nearly killed. But he said he never saw her. His testimony contradicted that of Detective Thomas McKenna. McKenna last week said he tricked Salaam into admitting he had attacked the jogger and others in the park. McKenna said he made notes of those admissions. Salaam also denied that he saw his two codefendants, Antron McCray, 16, and Raymond Santana, 15, in the park that night, and denied he told McKenna most of the things in his notes. Salaam said he did tell McKenna that, on the day after the rampage through the park, others told him people had been attacked there the night before. Salaam, McCray and Santana are on trial on charges of attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot for allegedly attacking the woman and two male joggers. McCray and Santana admitted taking part in the attack in videotape statements shown to the jury; there is no videotape of Salaam. The defendants are being tried in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders to up to 10 years in prison. The jogger, nearly dead when found and suffering brain injuries, underwent rehabilitation and has returned to Salomon Brothers Inc. where she is a vice president in corporate finance. She still has difficulty walking and does not remember the attack. Three other youths, Steven Lopez and Kevin Richardson, both 15, and Kharey Wise, 17, are to stand trial on the same charges later this year. On Tuesday, Salaam testified that he told detectives that he was 15 almost immediately when they came to his home to pick him up. It is illegal for police to question anyone under 16 without a parent present. Defense attorney Robert Burns says police knowingly questioned Salaam illegally and therefore any alleged incriminating statements by him should be discounted. On cross-examination, Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer suggested Salaam was lying when he said he told police he was 15. She suggested he knew he could be questioned alone if police thought he was 16, and that he thought he could submit to interrogation and return home without his mother finding out. He admitted he knew other teen-agers had been questioned by police about the previous night's events and released, but he denied telling police he was 16 and hoping to be questioned without his mother knowing.

DOC.HEAD: Intellectuals Call for Jailed Student Leader's Release
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Romanian intellectuals appealed Wednesday for the release of jailed student leader Marian Munteanu, and protesters gathered for the second straight day in a downtown square to demand his freedom. The intellectuals' appeal, published in the independent daily Romania Libera, said Munteanu's ``only crime was believing in democracy.'' Meanwhile, President Ion Iliescu issued a statement urging the government ``to propose ways of eliminating tension and confrontation ... and calming the political climate.'' Iliescu, a former high-ranking Communist official who broke with ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, reiterated that he has ``completely disassociated'' himself from Communist ideology. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front won May's multiparty elections. He did not mention Munteanu and dozens of other government opponents who have been jailed since mid-June. Munteanu was one of the primary leaders of a 53-day anti-Communist rally in downtown University Square that blocked the capital's main thoroughfare until it was violently broken up by police in mid-June. Munteanu was badly beaten by pro-government miners who, responding to an appeal for help from Iliescu, rampaged through the capital for several days, beating intellectuals and others deemed government opponents. Munteanu was hospitalized and then detained. The intellectuals' statement charged that Romania continues to be ruled by Communists ``who have abandoned the ideology of Communism but not its methods ... using terror and lies'' and ``hunting down intellectuals who oppose them.'' The statement appealed for international support for the jailed activists. Its signatories included expatriate playwright Eugene Ionesco, honorary Writers' Union President Stefan Augustin Doinas, honorary Romania Libera editor-in-chief Octavian Paler, and other members of the opposition intellectual Group for Social Dialogue. Also Wednesday, several dozen protesters gathered in University Square, where they roped off an area and declared it a ``Neo-Communist Free Zone.'' Opposition activists use the term ``neo-Communist'' to refer to Iliescu and other National Salvation Front members who belonged to the now-disbanded Communist Party. The National Salvation Front emerged during the December revolution that overthrew Ceausescu, a Communist hard-liner. The protesters held a placard demanding the release of Munteanu and other jailed government opponents. Several policemen looked on but did not interfere. On Tuesday, a scuffle broke out between demonstrators and a police officer after police tried to remove the ropes put up by the protesters.

DOC.HEAD: Stockbroker Who Slayed Client To Cover Up Embezzlement Gets 40-year Term
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS final graf to explain how stockbroker linked to crime.
DOC.TEXT: A stockbroker who killed a client he had defrauded and then fabricated clues to throw off police has been sentenced to 40 years in prison. Frank A. Vandever, 36, fatally shot Ronald W. Hiiri in his Stonington home in 1988, then created phony clues suggesting the killing was connected to drugs and sex. Vandever, who pleaded guilty May 25, murdered Hiiri to prevent him from reporting that Vandever had embezzled money from him, the prosecution said. ``I am really and sincerely sorry, your honor,'' Vandever said Tuesday before being sentenced by Superior Court Judge Joseph Koletsky. Four days before the slaying, Vandever was fired from a New Haven brokerage firm after company officials discovered he had taken $43,000 from a woman's account and deposited it in his own savings account, prosecutors said. Vandever had promised to make restitution and assured company officials he had not embezzled money from any other clients. He decided to kill Hiiri because he was worried Hiiri would report that he, too, was missing money, said Assistant State's Attorney Kevin T. Kane. He said Vandever once told a traveling companion he was writing a book on the perfect murder. ``In some ways, this murder could have been perfect,'' Kane said. After shooting Hiiri, first in the back and then at point-blank range in the heart, Vandever left newspapers and books around Hiiri's house to make police believe he was a transvestite or homosexual. Hiiri's wallet showed up in an area of Bridgeport known for drug trafficking. Despite Vandever's efforts, he was immediately a suspect. Hiiri's family knew he was to meet with his stockbroker the day he was killed, and Vandever was videotaped by a suspicious jeweler while trying to buy a ring with Hiiri's credit card.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says `Misunderstanding' With de Klerk Resolved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with government accusing ANC, Communists of `breach of trust.' No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk on Wednesday accused Nelson Mandela's African National Congress of a ``breach of trust'' that has jeopardized black-white talks on ending apartheid. De Klerk met Mandela for three hours in Pretoria and then issued a strongly worded statement criticizing the ANC and its close ally, the South African Communist Party. A dispute over official assertions that militants in both groups are planning for an insurrection has eroded good will developed in recent months between the government and the ANC. Mandela's group is the leading black opposition movement. Earlier Wednesday, Mandela issued a conciliatory statement after the talks with de Klerk. But de Klerk's remarks showed that deep divisions persist over the alliance between the ANC and the Communists. ``Statements and actions by prominent ANC members, as well as by (Communist Party) members ... seriously jeopardize the continuation of discussions aimed at the creation of a climate for negotiation,'' de Klerk said in his statement Wednesday. The president said his meeting with Mandela took place in a ``constructive spirit.'' He said Aug. 6 talks between the government and the ANC on ending white-minority rule would proceed as planned. However, in accusing the ANC and Communists of a ``breach of trust,'' he apparently referred to the recent police allegations that militants from those organizations have been plotting to seize power by force if negotiations break down. De Klerk said Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok would issue statements about ``important information'' obtained by police and the recent arrests of dozens of ANC and Communist Party members. In his earlier remarks Wednesday, Mandela had said, ``I am positive that the talks on the 6th of August will go ahead in good spirit.'' Mandela said he told de Klerk that the ANC and the Communist Party were committed to peaceful negotiations, not violent revolution. He also indicated the two men had cleared up a ``misunderstanding'' about the presence of Communist Party leader Joe Slovo on the ANC negotiating team. After a de Klerk-Mandela meeting last week, the ANC said the government wanted Slovo dropped from the ANC delegation. ``I thought that the state president had demanded that Joe Slovo be excluded from the delegation of the ANC,'' Mandela said. ``The correct position is that the state president was disturbed by evidence placed before him,'' Mandela said in a reference to the police allegations. The statement gave no indication that Slovo would be dropped from the negotiating team. Slovo is one of several Communists who also hold top posts in the ANC. Mandela is not a member of the Communist Party and says the ANC is not a Communist organization, despite the cross-membership. Mandela and Slovo appeared together at a Communist Party rally on Sunday and again denied the existence of a plot to seize power. However, ANC leaders have said that guerrillas will continue to infiltrate the country until a cease-fire is negotiated with the government. The ANC and the government held their first talks in May, three months after de Klerk legalized the group and freed Mandela from a life prison term for plotting against the government. Mandela, deputy president of the ANC, had spent 27 years in prison. The talks Aug. 6 will be aimed at eliminating obstacles to full-scale negotiations on a new constitution to give the black majority a voice in national affairs. Before the ANC enters negotiations, it wants the government to release prisoners convicted of political crimes and allow the return without punishment of about 20,000 South African exiles. Under apartheid, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy and the 30-million black majority has no voice in national affairs. The ANC's guerrilla campaign, launched in 1961, has never posed a serious threat to the government's powerful security forces. The ANC has not carried out any major attacks in recent months.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hits Democrats As Budget Deal Postponed Till September
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 14th graf bgng, `Sen. Lloyd,' with Bentsen saying talks may resume at secluded location
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional budget negotiators appeared to abandon hope Wednesday of reaching a deficit-cutting agreement before fall, setting the stage for election-season finger-pointing over which side is to blame. Republicans suggested Bush would make a political issue of Democratic refusal to offer detailed proposals for tax increases and spending cuts. But House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., countered, ``We didn't pledge that every time the Republicans slit their wrists that we would slit ours.'' He referred to an administration plan _ criticized even by Republicans _ that includes higher taxes on alcohol and a limit on deductibility of state tax payments. White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said Bush, in a meeting with House and Senate Republicans, ``expressed his concerns, frustration ... that the Democrats have not been able to come up with a plan, details, that meet the ones that the Republicans have already put together and are willing to put on the table.'' Bush plans to verbally attack Democrats during Congress' August recess and to veto spending bills he considers too expensive, thus leaving potentially huge automatic spending cuts in place this fall until a budget deal is reached, according to White House officials and Republican lawmakers who met with the president Wednesday. Bush is ``certainly not going to keep his trap shut all during August,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. But Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said Republican plans to bash Democrats for not offering a deficit-cutting plan would backfire. He said the public realizes it is the president's responsibility to offer a budget. ``The Republicans are going to look like a congregation of jackasses,'' Dingell told reporters. With the start of the new fiscal year exactly two months away, the White House adopted a carrot-and-stick approach to the deadlocked, 12-week-old budget talks. Administration officials expressed optimism that the bargaining _ aimed at paring next year's expected $169 billion budget gap _ will succeed after Congress' month-long recess. White House spokesman Popadiuk said that at a morning White House meeting with 150 GOP House and Senate members, Bush ``stated his expectation that the talks will intensify in September.'' And House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Democrats and White House officials have ``an agreement in principle'' to work out a schedule for completing an agreement in September. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said negotiators were considering that when talks resume they would be in seclusion ``where we can work together without interruption.'' One location mentioned was a plantation on Maryland's Eastern Shore, he said. But at the same time, Bush appeared ready to adopt tougher tactics. The Gramm-Rudman law will trigger more than $100 billion in spending cuts on Oct. 1 _ a process known as sequester _ unless a deal emerges. ``The sequester is a reality he will enforce if no agreement is reached,'' Popadiuk said of Bush. Even so, the administration emitted different signals about just how tough Bush planned to be. White House officials initially said Bush was giving Democrats until Friday to make a budget offer, a statement that was echoed by Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the No. 2 House Republican. But shortly afterward, Popadiuk said, ``The president didn't impose any deadlines.'' Republican lawmakers clearly remained angry over the political embarrassment they have faced ever since details of the administration's $54 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases emerged last week. Included in the plan are higher taxes on alcohol and a reduction in the deductibility of state and local income taxes _ both of which have drawn GOP fire. ``You can assume that when the GOP lawmakers go home they won't be shy about the foot-dragging we've seen by the Democrats about finding a credible solution to the budget deficit,'' said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. But Democrats argued that a month of partisan warfare would accomplish little. ``If we want to beat each other around politically, we're not going to come to an agreement, and the public will take it out on both of us,'' said Panetta. Panetta expressed a willingness to give the Republicans a Democratic budget plan as soon as the GOP produced a complete proposal of its own. The Republicans have never formally submitted their plan to Democrats, though details have been described in published reports. But other Democrats expressed no willingness to publicize their own deficit-cutting ideas shortly before the August break. Their fear is that it would make them a target of the same pummeling the GOP plan is now taking. ``I don't think it's generally helpful,'' Foley said of immediately producing a Democratic package. The maneuvering of the negotiators has begun to wear thin on at least some rank-and-file members of Congress. ``I have news for you summiteers, both Republican and Democrat,'' Rep. Robin Tallon, D-S.C., said on the House floor. ``The rest of America thinks you're acting like a bunch of children.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Cosmonauts Launched to Replace Crew in Mir
LaserPhoto MOS13,14
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts soared into space Wednesday on a mission to continue the manufacture of ultra-pure crystals for profit in what has become the centerpiece of the Soviet space program. A Soyuz TM-10 capsule carrying flight commander Gennady Manakov and engineer Gennady Strekalov rose into a hazy sky atop a column of orange and white flames from the Baikonur Space Center in Kazakhstan. The capsule blasted off as scheduled at 1:32 p.m. Watching the launch in the 109-degree heat were two Japanese broadcasters, one of whom will be a paying passenger on a Dec. 2 mission that could bring the Soviet space program an estimated $16 million. On Friday, Manakov and Strekalov will rendezvous with the Mir space station to replace Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin, cosmonauts who have been working in orbit since Feb. 11. During their 4{-month mission, Manakov and Strekalov will continue the work Solovyev and Balandin began: ``growing'' super-pure crystals for use in semiconductors and computer chips. The program is designed to bring profits of more than $40 million. Solovyev and Balandin, who return to Earth on Aug. 9, grew 23 such crystals in the weightlessness of space using the special Kristall module attached to the Mir complex. Each is worth about $1 million, the Tass news agency reported. Producing such crystals and other space manufacturing ``is clearly the centerpiece'' of the Soviet space program, said James Oberg, author of several books on the Soviet space program, in an interview from his Texas home. ``It's the key to their commercialization of space,'' he said. Such importance is given to the crystals, Oberg said, that the past two Soyuz flights to the Mir have had only two cosmonauts aboard so the canister of crystals could ride home in the capsule's empty third seat. Starting in December and continuing into 1992, however, the third seat will be occupied by foreign passengers paying the Soviets hard currency, perhaps as much as $16 million, Oberg said. Sitting in the Soyuz capsule's third seat in December will be either Tokyo Broadcasting System camerawoman Ryoko Kikuchi, 26, or Toyohiro Akiyama, 48, the former Washington bureau chief for the network. The Japanese chosen will spend eight days in space, Tass said. The launch of the seventh main mission to the Mir was not broadcast live on Soviet television, as previous launches have been. A taped report was shown two hours later. Before the cosmonauts got into a bus that took them to the launch pad, Manakov saluted Vladimir Ivanov, chairman of the state commission on spaceflight, and said: ``The crew of the spaceship is ready for the flight.'' ``I wish you a successful flight and happy return to the native land,'' replied Ivanov. When the cosmonauts reached the launch pad, each was kissed on the cheek by an unidentified man wearing a military uniform. In a brief exchange with journalists, Manakov, 40, wisecracked that ``the older one'' _ meaning 49-year-old Strekalov _ would be filling them in on the mission's progress in space. A journalist shouted a traditional Russian colloquial expression for luck before a risky venture: ``Neither feathers nor fluff!'' and a smiling Manakov gave the appropriate response: ``To hell with you!'' Manakov, a test pilot, is making his first space flight. Strekalov is a veteran cosmonaut on his fourth flight, having worked aboard the Salyut space station. Tass said they are expected to make at least two spacewalks, during which they will conduct further unspecified repairs to a hatch on the Kvant-2 module attached to the Mir complex. During a July 17 excursion outside the space station to repair torn thermal insulation on their Soyuz TM-9 capsule, Solovyev and Balandin discovered they could not close a hatch at the end of their space walk. They were, however, able to close it on a subsequent, July 26 space walk.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 11 grafs, committee endorses sanctions bill; edits for transition
DOC.TEXT: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved on Wednesday new restrictions on trade with Iraq, as Democrats on the panel chastised President Bush for not taking such action on his own. The legislation, approved on a voice vote without dissent, calls for an end to the $200 million line of credit Iraq now enjoys through the Export-Import Bank and for U.S. opposition to loans from international institutions like the World Bank. It also would require that any U.S. exporter wishing to sell items to Iraq first prove that they will not be used for any program to develop chemical or biological weapons or ballistic missiles, or enhance Iraq's ability to support terrorism. The bill's author, Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., said the United States must register its disapproval of human rights violations by Iraq and the belligerent rhetoric of its president, Saddam Hussein. Iraq has massed 100,000 troops on its border with Kuwait in a dispute over oil production. ``The lesson of Iraq is clear,'' Berman said. ``You win nothing by appeasing a bully. He merely becomes a bolder and more dangerous bully.'' A day earlier, assistant Secretary of State John Kelly testified before a House subcommittee that the administration is developing new curbs on so-called ``dual use'' exports, goods like computers and aircraft parts that can have either a civilian or military purpose. But Berman said his legislation goes farther because it puts the burden on exporters to show that their products will not be used in weapons programs. ``I regret that the administration has long been unwilling to take a stance and consider sanctions,'' Berman said. And Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the panel's senior Republican, said he hoped the committee action would spur the administration to complete its review of policy toward Iraq and ``recommend a policy we all can support.'' The action came after the near-sale to Iraq last month of industrial furnaces that could be used to make nuclear weapons material. The sale was aborted by the White House at the last minute. Documents obtained by The Associated Press show that officials at the Commerce Department who had previously approved the sale knew that the furnaces had a potential nuclear use. The documents are the minutes of the department's discussions in 1989 with Consarc Corp., the Rancocas, N.J.,-based furnace manufacturer. They show that officials of the company that made the furnaces, Consarc Corp. of Rancocas, N.J., held a meeting on Feb. 22, 1989 with Alan C. Stoddart, a special agent from Commerce's Office of Export Enforcement. ``Mr. Stoddart said the department's main concern is nuclear non-proliferation,'' according to the minutes of the meeting with Consarc's president, Raymond Roberts, and Tina Olnick, a company employee. The minutes continued: ``Mr. Roberts again stated that the customer tells us they will be making titanium castings for making medical prostheses. ``However, the equipment can be used (without modification) on zirconium, for which the principal end use is nuclear.'' In an earlier Feb. 15, 1989, conversation, Roberts told Jeff Tripp of the Commerce Department that ``there is nothing to stop them (the Iraqis) from melting zirconium, the main use of which is cladding material for nuclear fuel.'' Gary Milhollin, executive director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, said the high-performance furnaces such as the ones Iraq sought can be used for a number of purposes, including melting plutonium for bomb cores and titanium for missile nose cones. The Iraqis said the titanium, a lightweight metal, would be used for artificial hip and knee joints for victims of the Persian Gulf war with Iran. On March 15, 1989, Ms. Olnick, Consarc's contract administrator, asked the Commerce Department whether the company needed a ``validated export license'' to ship the furnaces. Such a license is generally needed to export items that would appear to have a direct nuclear capability. In the letter, Ms. Olnick said Consarc did not believe a validated license was necessary but, ``We would appreciate an assessment of the Department of Commerce.'' She added: ``We have informed the customer that we will not proceed with the project until we have received approval to export the equipment in either the form of an assessment that an export license is not required or an approved export license.'' Roberts did not return a telephone call Wednesday to discuss the documents, but he said earlier his company had received permission to ship furnaces to Iraq. Ms. Olnick said she could not talk about the matter. Commerce Department officials have refused to talk about the Consarc case. But after a furnace was seized by the Customs Service on a dock in Philadelphia last month, U.S. officials said Consarc would be required to obtain a validated license. It is unlikely such a license will be granted, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Executive Challenges Club Limits on When Women Can Golf
DOC.TEXT: Marguerite Martin, like a lot of other business executives, has a passion for golf. But she has a problem. She works during the week, and her club, the Longmeadow Country Club, has a rule banning women from the course on weekend mornings. So Ms. Martin filed a complaint with the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination. ``Most country clubs discriminate against women and restrict when they can play,'' Ms. Martin said Wednesday. ``As hard as it is to understand, it's really very simple. To many men, golf isn't a game. It's a disease that doesn't incorporate women.'' Ms. Martin, who launched her own financial management firm after retiring from the insurance business, said she smarted under the Longmeadow Country Club's restrictions for 25 years. She filed the complaint only after trying unsuccessfully for six years to get the club's Board of Governors to ease its restrictions on women. ``As a younger woman you rationalize that making a squawk could hurt your business and back off,'' she said. ``I'm 65. I've lived a good life and gotten though a lot of different types of discrimination. At this time in my life I have to face up to facts. And the fact is that I can't stand this any longer.'' Donald R. Dupre, president of the 350-member club, was on vacation and could not be reached for comment on the complaint, which was filed last month. Two other officers, Vice President John M. Naughton and Secretary Norman J. Van Tassel, declined comment on the action. Ms. Martin suggested that the rules stemmed from the country club's beginnings in 1922 when most women did not work outside the home and could more easily golf on weekdays. ``Most of the women in the Longmeadow Club still fall into that category,'' she said. ``And in truth when you get beyond the hysteria there would probably be only a couple of women who would play on Saturday mornings and it wouldn't bother anybody.'' Alan Cassella, a compliance officer for the discrimination commission, said her complaint was filed under a section of the law covering private organizations that solicit the patronage of the general public. Earlier this year in Hermitage, Pa., protests led officials at the Hickory VFW Golf Course to roll back a rule requiring women to wait until 11 a.m. to tee off.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Chief May Use Local Panels to Cite Obscene Art
DOC.TEXT: Chairman John E. Frohnmayer of the National Endowment for the Arts says he might appoint local panels to help determine whether federally financed works of art violate community anti-obscenity standards. Frohnmayer said the need for such a move had never arisen because an NEA grant had never been denied or challenged under the congressional ban on federal support for works that might be considered obscene. ``If we were required to at some point determine local standards, that's how we would go about it, or that is one of the ways one might go about it,'' he said. The NEA chairman expressed his views during a three-hour deposition taken Tuesday by New York lawyer Floyd Abrams, who is representing the New School for Social Research in a lawsuit against the endowment. A transcript of the 100-page deposition was released Wednesday. The New School is challenging the endowment's requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge they will not use federal funds to create obscene art. The lawsuit charges that the pledge is unconstitutionally vague and violates guarantees of free speech and due process. The New School's application for a $45,000 grant to redesign its main courtyard in New York was approved by the endowment last March. But when informed of the NEA's anti-obscenity restrictions, New School president Jonathan F. Fanton wrote Frohnmayer that the university could not accept the endowment grant ``under a condition that undermines our society's deep commitment to intellectual and artistic freedom.'' Frohnmayer responded in a May 2 letter to Fanton which expressed ``severe questions about the constitutionality of the law.'' Frohnmayer's deposition will be used by Abrams, a noted First Amendment lawyer, when the case is heard before U.S. District Judge Louis Stanton in Manhattan on Aug. 13. The NEA chairman's proposal to appoint local panels to judge whether endowment-supported works might be obscene follows a formula prescribed by the Supreme Court in its landmark 1973 obscenity ruling. The high court said determinations of obscenity must take into account ``contemporary community standards.'' The court said works may be considered obscene if they depict sex in a patently offensive way, appeal to the prurient interest and lack serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. Under questioning by Abrams, Frohnmayer said he might find it necessary to consider ``impaneling a group within a locality in which that grant was going to take place to advise the endowment on community standards.'' But so far, he said, ``we have not been confronted with that issue because ... there has been no grant that has been denied or challenged under this statute.'' He denied that the endowment had rejected any grant application on the grounds that it was ``considered too controversial or troublesome,'' since the anti-obscenity ban was imposed by Congress last October. The NEA was plunged into controversy more than a year ago when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other political and religious conservatives criticized endowment support for exhibitions of controversial works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. At Helms' urging, Congress amended the endowment's current $171 million budget to include a ban on using federal funds for artworks that include ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts, and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific works.''

DOC.HEAD: Scattered Rain, Record Lows
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered over parts of the eastern half of the nation Wednesday, and temperatures settled to record lows south of the Great Lakes. During the afternoon, showers and thunderstorms extended along the Gulf of Mexico coast, across Florida, from Georgia through the lower Mississippi Valley into eastern and southern Oklahoma as well as northern, eastern and southern Texas. Showers were scattered over southeastern Kansas, from north-central New Mexico across central Colorado, and over central South Dakota. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.26 inches at McAlester, Okla.; and 1.23 inches at Atlanta. Rain flooded some low-lying highway crossings in southwestern Texas, the National Weather Service said. Record lows included 51 at Chicago, and 48 at Mansfield, Ohio. Records were tied at Peoria, Ill., at 52, and South Bend, Ind., at 50. Elsewhere, Alamosa, Colo., tied its record low of 39. At the opposite extreme, Salt Lake City reached 102 degrees, tying the record high for the date. Miami hit a record high of 98. The center of Hurricane Bertha was about 185 miles south-southwest of Sable Island, Nova Scotia, moving toward the northeast. Its highest sustained wind speed was near 75 mph. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 58 at Arcata, Calif., to 102 at Gila Bend, Ariz. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 37 at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philippines-Americans
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration suggested Wednesday that murder charges filed in the Philippines against three U.S. agents could have been intended to prevent them from testifying about drug trafficking by Filipino military officials. DEA spokesman Cornelius Dougherty said the agency had been invited to testify before a commission formed by Philippines President Corazon Aquino to investigate allegations of drug trafficking by members of her armed forces. Andrew Fenrich, the head of the DEA's two-man office in the Philippines, had planned to testify until the charges were filed Wednesday, Dougherty said. The charges ``rather effectively put the kibosh on any testimony about the facts concerning the armed forces,'' Dougherty said. ``I'm suggesting there's probably a cause-and-effect situation there,'' he added. Fenrich was one of three DEA agents and 13 Filipino policemen charged Wednesday by the Philippines' military in the July 10 killings of two officers and a soldier during what police said was a shootout during a drug bust last month. According to the National Bureau of Investigation, the soldiers tried to sell $10 million worth of heroin to Needham, who was posing as a buyer. Shooting broke out when the three resisted arrest, the bureau claims. But Brig. Gen. Gerardo Flores, chief of staff of the Philippine Constabulary, said his investigation showed the three were shot in the head at close range. ``We're cooperating with the Philippine government on this situation,'' said Joe Keefe, another DEA spokesman. However, he noted that there are no plans to return the three DEA agents to that country to face the murder charges. The United States and the Philippines do not have an extradition treaty. The DEA is deciding whether to submit testimony to the commission in writing or whether depositions will be taken outside the Philippines and sent to the panel, Dougherty said. Acting DEA Administrator Terrence Burke rejected the allegations of murder, saying in a statement: ``These charges have no merit.'' The Philippines government allows DEA agents to carry firearms, Keefe said, but he added, ``None of the weapons was fired on that day.'' Two DEA agents are normally assigned to the Philippines, but Fenrich and his colleague Jake Fernandez were taken out of the country because of the July 10 events and no agents have been assigned to replace them, Keefe said. The third agent, Philip Needham, was from the DEA's Bangkok office, ``We would like to emphasize that the DEA agents were working at the request of the Philippines government in cooperation with the National Bureau of Investigation,'' Keefe said. The DEA is in the Philippines ``as guests of the host government. We work under the conditions of that government that allows what we can do and can't do,'' Keefe said. The Philippines is considered a trans-shipment point for heroin as well as a new form of methamphetamine called ice, and it is a source country for marijuana, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Staten Island Ferry Fare Increase Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: The price of the best bargain in town doubled Wednesday. The roundtrip fare on the Staten Island ferry jumped to 50 cents. ``It's worth 50 cents. I think it's a romantic ride,'' said Staten Island resident Stanley Harrington, one of the ferry's 75,000 daily commuters. ``This is the best ride ... (of) all the transit operations in New York.'' The half-hour excursion across busy New York Harbor connects Staten Island and the southern tip of Manhattan, passing in front of the Statue of Liberty. It was only the second time the city has raised the fare since taking the ferry over from the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad in 1905 _ when the trip cost five cents each way. In 1975, the fare went up to a quarter for a round trip, paid in Manhattan. The city estimates the fare increase will bring in an extra $2.6 million in revenues. Each round trip costs the city $3.48 per passenger, said Department of Transportation spokesman Joe DePlasco. The cost of ferrying a car remains $1.75 each way. The driver and any passengers each pay the 50-cent round trip fare.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Proposing Easing Amateur Radio License Rules For Handicapped
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday proposed to make it easier for handicapped people to gain advanced amateur radio licenses. The commission, by a 5-0 vote, proposed that examiners be able to exempt mentally or physically impaired individuals who have ``extraordinary difficulty'' in passing high-speed Morse code telegraphy proficiency tests. Currently, amateur licensees must pass a written exam and demonstrate proficiency of five words per minute in Morse code in order to gain a novice or technician's license; 13 wpm for the general or advanced classes; and 20 wpm for the amateur extra class. The FCC proposed that applicants for higher classes could be exempted from the 13 wpm or 20 wpm exams if they have a doctor's certificate stating they cannot pass the telegraphy exams and if they hold a current or renewable novice, technician, general or advanced class operator's license. International radio rules require a proficiency of 5 wpm or more. In other 5-0 votes Wednesday, the FCC: _Proposed establishing standards for conducting comparative renewal proceedings between cellular radio licensees and license challengers when existing lottery-awarded licenses begin to expire in 1993. The commission proposed weighting the process in favor of incumbents in the booming, $3 billion cellular business. _Opened an inquiry into setting standards for the possible introduction of digital audio radio services, which would provide a compact disc quality sound better than today's AM and FM broadcasts. Three applications are pending for such service. _Extended its inquiry into possible changes in rules governing so-called television satellite stations, which rebroadcast to small communities all or most of the programming of a parent station.

DOC.HEAD: Police Block Albanians Seeking Visas at U.S. Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Security forces Wednesday blocked about 90 Albanian refugees who wanted to march on the U.S. Embassy in Paris to demand permission to go to the United States. Carrying personal belongings in plastic bags, the Albanians marched from the military camp at Mourmelon where they have been staying since arriving in France two weeks ago. ``We never had the intention of staying here,'' said one refugee, a 32-year-old who identified himself only as Arden. ``We've already been in France too long. We've asked, in vain, that a representative of the United States come see us,'' he said. ``Now, we're going to Paris.'' The refugees were among 543 Albanians who arrived in France by ferry July 15 after occupying embassies in the Albanian capital of Tirana. Thousands more went to Italy, West Germany and other nations. The refugees who marched Wednesday included about 20 women and a handful of children. They had hoped to walk 12 miles to the town of Chalons-sur-Marne, 90 miles east of Paris, and board a train to the capital. But they were stopped after about four miles by soldiers from the military camp and about 15 police officers. The soldiers passed out mineral water to the refugees under the crushing mid-afternoon sun as Daniel Rouhier, a local official, explained that the Albanians could not expect to emigrate just by marching to the U.S. Embassy off the Champs-Elysees. The refugees eventually boarded military buses and returned to the camp. Rouhier said they will be moved from the camp by Aug. 15 to other shelters around France. About 230 refugees are staying at the Mourmelon camp. ``To my knowledge, none of these particular Albanians has applied for a visa,'' said U.S. Embassy spokesman Paul Kozelka in Paris. ``If they marched up to the gates, I guess we'd hand out application forms.'' He said U.S. officials have received no request through French officials to meet with the Albanians. Washington would likely grant visas to Albanians with immediate family members in the United States or to those who have studied there or worked for the U.S. government, Kozelka said. The refugees who arrived in France last month have been housed at three camps near Paris and two in the southwest. There, they are supposed to learn French, undergo medical tests and adjust to Western life.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Mexican Cult Priestess Given Six-Year Term
DOC.TEXT: The alleged high priestess of a drug-trafficking cult accused of sacrificing 15 people, including a University of Texas student, was sentenced to six years in prison for criminal association, her attorney said Wednesday. Attorney Victor Fernandez Perez Salas said the six-year sentence imposed Tuesday against Sara Aldrete Villareal was the maximum allowed by law. Peres said the defense team would appeal the sentencing by Judge Bernardo Tirado. Miss Aldrete, a former honor student at Texas Southmost College in Brownsville, is one of 10 people still facing charges involving a cult of drug traffickers that alleged sacrificed 15 people near Matamoros, a Mexican city on the U.S. border. Mark Kilroy, 21, of the University of Texas, was among those slain. Authorities began finding bodies in April 1989. Prosecutors claim Miss Aldrete was the high priestess of the cult led by Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo, who allegedly told his followers that human sacrifices would give them immunity from police. Miss Aldrete has admitted knowing Constanzo, but denies all involvement in smuggling, murder or witchcraft. Last month, Tirado dismissed charges against Miss Alderete of homicide, concealment and resisting arrest. The charges were filed in Mexico City. Those charges stemmed from the May 6, 1989, shootout with police in which Constanzo and a bodyguard died. Police said they either committed suicide or were killed by followers as part of a pact to avoid falling into police custody.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Development Councils To Start In Eight States
DOC.TEXT: Rural development councils will be started in eight states this summer as forerunners of a nationwide project to boost development in rural America, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday. The councils will be started in Kansas, Maine, Mississippi, Oregon, South Carolina, South Dakota, Texas and Washington, he said. Existing resources will be used to form the councils, which will have fulltime coordinators, he said. A goal will be to form state-level partnerships between federal and state governments and the private sector. ``The participants will create a long-term strategy for applying federal rural development resources and will carry out joint actions to implement the strategy,'' Yeutter said. Councils will be made up of federal officials representing various departments and agencies that have significant rural development roles. Such agencies would include the Extension Service and the Farmers Home Administration, for example.

DOC.HEAD: Board Rejects Mass Murderer Juan Corona's Third Bid For Parole
DOC.TEXT: Twice-convicted mass murderer Juan Corona's third bid for freedom was rejected Wednesday after he told a parole board he doesn't remember committing 25 brutal machete slayings almost 20 years ago. ``Few crimes in the history of the United States have been as shocking to the public conscience,'' said Ron Koenig, chairman of the state Board of Prison Terms panel, in announcing the decision. A psychological report prepared for the board said Corona, 56, didn't appear to understand the motive for his crimes and ``therefore remains a danger to society.'' The report, said Koenig, indicates Corona ``seems to be living in a world of his own and is extremely dangerous in an unstructured environment.'' Sutter County District Attorney Carl Adams told the panel the report makes clear that ``Mr. Corona is unpredictable and presents an unknown threat if released.'' Corona's lawyer had previously suggested the Corona would use the hearing to take responsibility for the killings for the first time. He was convicted of 25 murder counts for hacking, slashing and clubbing farm laborers to death in 1971 and burying their bodies in Sutter County orchards about 125 miles northeast of San Francisco. Last week, attorney Don Condren told The Associated Press his client might be planning to admit his role in the case. Corona has been criticized at past hearings for declining to speak in his own behalf. Lately, Corona has ``indicated he is going to be willing to talk about it,'' Condren said in an interview from his home, while warning his client still might change his mind. On Wednesday, when asked if he planned to confess, Corona said simply, ``No, I don't remember.'' Koenig asked Corona how it felt ``to be convicted of something you say you did not do.'' ``Very bad,'' Corona said. When the murders occurred, they were the worst mass slaying in U.S. history. John Wayne Gacy Jr., on death row in Illinois, was convicted of more murders than anyone in the nation's history. He was sentenced to death for the murder of 33 young men and boys in 1980. All but one of the corpses had the heads chopped open. A search of Corona's home turned up a machete with an 18-inch blade, a meat cleaver, a double-bladed ax and a wooden club. Corona, a farm labor contractor who preyed on itinerant workers and derelicts, was first convicted in 1973. The conviction was overturned five years later when an appellate court ruled his defense had been inadequate. The second trial, in 1982, also ended in conviction at a cost of $5 million. His defense was based on a denial of his guilt and an attempt to blame the killings on a half-brother, now dead. Corona is serving 25 years to life on each murder count.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Convicted Spy in Israel for Medical Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials warmly greeted the wife of convicted spy Jonathan Pollard as she arrived Wednesday on a 10-week parole from a U.S. prison to seek medical treatment in Israel. Anne Henderson Pollard, wearing a brown checked suit and clutching a bouquet of flowers at Ben Gurion airport, appeared pale and tired as she thanked Israelis who supported her while she was serving 2{ years in a U.S. prison. Authorities told her to maintain a low profile while in Israel. But the plight of the Pollards has touched some Israelis, who have established the Public Committee for the Pollards to work for their release. Committee chairman Amnon Dror said Wednesday, ``We think that a state which endangered a man who had helped them cannot abandon him when he gets caught.'' Deputy Minister Geula Cohen of the right-wing Tehiya Party and Edna Solodar, a legislator from the left-of-center Labor Party, were among those welcoming her. Ms. Pollard, 30, was arrested with her husband Jonathan, a 36-year-old former U.S. Navy analyst, in November 1985 on suspicion of spying for Israel. He was sentenced to life in prison in June 1987 after he pleaded guilty to providing Israel with documents about the military strengths of countries in the Middle East. Ms. Pollard pleaded guilty to conspiracy to receive embezzled government property and being an accessory to possession of national defense doucments. She was sentenced to five years in prison and was released this year. Israeli leaders said the Pollards were part of an unauthorized renegade spy ring and refused to help them, despite their pleas. Jonathan Pollard, who is in solitary confinement in a maximum security federal prison in Marion, Ill. filed for divorce last month citing ``irreconcilable differences.'' Ms. Pollard, who is suffering from a gastrointestinal disorder, said she hoped her marriage would be salvaged. She was taken to Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, where she will receive treatment at no cost. ``I am glad to be here in my natural homeland. I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your emotional support over all these years,'' Ms. Pollard said in a short statement at the airport. ``Our history teaches us to learn from tragedy and to look for a brighter future. I hope the day will come when both my husband and I will be free and back here in Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: Likud Nearly Toppled From Power By Oversight
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli Communist Party nearly toppled Israel's governing coalition Wednesday on a technicality of parliamentary rules. It took an impromptu filibuster and a scurry by hall messengers to save Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing governing coalition. The vote was called unexpectedly by the Communists to protest budget cuts that slashed basic food subsidies. Once the motion was read and the house speaker stood up to begin the vote, Likud legislators realized they were a minority in the room and liable to lose. The 6-week-old coalition commands only a narrow majority in the 120-member Parliament, and many of its supporters were absent. ``They simply didn't notice that a vote was going to be taken so early,'' one parliamentary aide said on condition of anonymity. Hall monitors were sent running to get absent legislators from the Parliament dining rooms. Then, to delay the vote, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai of Likud got up to make an unscheduled speech in defense of his budget, witnesses said. When the vote was taken 10 minutes later, Shamir survived comfortably by a 63 to 48 showing, with seven absent and two abstentions. Shamir's coalition government also easily defeated four other no-confidence motions that came to a vote later Wednesday. Those left-wing motions were to protest the government's handling of a housing shortage fueled by an influx of Soviet immigrants. More than 2,000 Israeli families, many evicted from apartments after rents were raised, have pitched tent camps in parks around the country in the past month. It is the second time Shamir has faced no-confidence measures since his Cabinet was installed on June 11.

DOC.HEAD: Full Schedule of Disability Hearings Restored
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration said Wednesday it has obtained the money needed to permit a full schedule of hearings on disability benefit appeals this fall and has cancelled plans to curtail some of them. The agency said the Office of Management and Budget has agreed to release about $5 million from a contingency fund to pay for all of the approximately 20,000 appeals hearings conducted each month. The hearings are held for people appealing decisions to deny or reduce Social Security disability benefits. The Social Security Administration had said Tuesday it would schedule no new hearings involving expenses for travel or for medical or occupational experts for the rest of the fiscal year, which ends September 30. Gwendolyn S. King, the commissioner of Social Security, said no hearings would have been cancelled. But she said she was ``disturbed at the unnecessary alarm that has been generated among some of the nation's most vulnerable citizens'' because of incorrect reports that all appeals hearings had been suspended. ``Today's action should serve to once again assure the nearly 40 million Americans who receive Social Security benefits that this agency ... will continue to serve the public with great measures of both responsibility and compassion,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Los Angeles
Judge Pounds Final Gavel, Ending Seven-Year McMartin Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with malicious prosecution lawsuit filed. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `The district...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA5
DOC.TEXT: A judge pounded the final gavel in the McMartin preschool case Wednesday, dismissing child molestation charges in the nation's longest, costliest criminal prosecution. Defendant Raymond Buckey promptly filed a multimillion dollar malicious prosecution suit. ``The case of the People vs. Raymond Buckey is hereby dismissed and the defendant is discharged,'' said Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg. ``That completes this case.'' The ruling came after jurors deadlocked Friday in Buckey's retrial on eight charges and the judge declared a mistrial. Later Wednesday, Buckey and his civil attorney summoned reporters to Beverly Hills to annouce the suit against Los Angeles County, the city of Manhattan Beach and a former district attorney. Also named were a therapist and therapy center that elicited damaging testimony from children, and KABC-TV and its reporter Wayne Satz, who carried many early stories about the case. Buckey said he wanted to recoup some of the money his family lost in fighting the marathon case. ``What else can I do?'' asked Buckey. ``Do we just walk out of the criminal system and they're not even going to say they're sorry? Money is something that hopefully can get my family back together.'' The suit, filed in Superior Court in Los Angeles, claims malicious prosecution, conspiracy and defamation, as well as violation of Buckey's civil rights. Buckey's mother, who was a defendant, filed a separate suit in federal court after her acquittal in January. The district attorney's office sought the dismissal of charges, and prosecutor Joseph Martinez said he thought it was ``for the best'' to end the seven-year ordeal that had shattered lives and strained the legal system. ``We can't change the evidence,'' Martinez said. ``There were two juries, objective people who felt there wasn't the evidence to convict.'' The McMartin case consumed seven years of court time and cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million, making it the longest, most expensive criminal court case in U.S. history. ``He's a free man,'' Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, said as he emerged from the last court hearing in the criminal case. ``Please treat my client as not only a free man but an innocent man.'' He stressed that Buckey, like other defendants, was presumed innocent unless convicted, and that Buckey was convicted of nothing. ``This man spent five years in jail, seven years of his life,'' Davis said. ``He is a symbol of the presumption of innocence.'' The attorney likened his client to Rocky Balboa, the boxing hero of the movie ``Rocky.'' ``He's a young man who went through a test and came out a hero at the end,'' he said. ``He slayed his dragon.'' Buckey said the case seemed to last ``a lifetime'' but made him a stronger person. ``I now know how deep I can go into my soul. I've been there and survived. ``I feel scarred by this case and I need to heal,'' Buckey said. He added he now feels in control of his life. ``I no longer have 12 jurors deciding my fate. I'm deciding it.'' Buckey's mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was in court for the dismissal along with his sister, Peggy Ann. Both women were former defendants. ``I still can't believe it,'' said Mrs. Buckey, who was acquitted of all charges against her. ``We've been through seven years of hell and it still hasn't hit me _ it's over.'' The case started with dozens of molestation charges and seven defendants, but only Buckey and his mother ever stood trial. Charges against five other teachers or employees at the Manhattan Beach preschool were dismissed for lack of evidence. When the first trial ended Jan. 18, Buckey's mother was acquitted on all counts and Buckey was acquitted on 40 counts. The jury deadlocked on 13 counts and Buckey was retried on eight. Buckey spent five years in jail, before being released on bail. He took the witness stand at both trials to deny he ever molested any child.

DOC.HEAD: Roseanne Barr's Ratings Drop
DOC.TEXT: Tuesday's rerun of a ``Roseanne'' episode _ the first since Roseanne Barr's screeched version of the national anthem _ had an 11 percent smaller audience than the show did the previous week. An ABC executive blamed the drop of nearly 1.5 million homes more on strong CBS competition than to viewer reaction to the star's national anthem antics at a San Diego Padres game last week. ``I think it has more to do with the CBS movie doing a 22 (audience) share share ... than a backlash against Roseanne,'' Larry Hyams, ABC's director of prime-time audience research, said after the ratings were released Wednesday. The national Nielsen ratings for NBC's competing ``In the Heat of the Night'' also were down from the previous Tuesday, he said. Barr's antics, in which she also grabbed at her crotch and spit on the ground, drew the wrath of baseball fans and President Bush alike. Her Tuesday show averaged a 13.0 rating, down from last Tuesday's 14.6. Still, that was enough for the show to win its half-hour time period against other reruns on second-place CBS and third-place NBC. CBS' repeat of a the second part of its 1987 miniseries, ``Murder Ordained,'' averaged an 11.4 rating against ``Roseanne.'' NBC's ``In the Head of the Night'' had a 9.6. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Barry's Lawyer Admits Mayor Occasionally Used Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, raising 12th graf pvs to 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry has occasionally used cocaine, his lawyer admitted Wednesday during dramatic closing arguments in the mayor's drug and perjury trial. But he argued against conviction, saying prosecutors had not proved Barry used drugs at the specific times charged. The prosecution portrayed a far different Barry, calling him a general in the war on drugs who betrayed the cause and ``was working with the other side.'' The evidence is ``overwhelming'' that Barry relied on friends who brought him cocaine because they wanted city jobs, city contracts and the power that comes with knowing the mayor, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin. Barry's lawyer accused federal authorities of usin the equivalent of an illegal war weapon to catch him in the act of smoking crack cocaine in an FBI operation at a downtown hotel. ``The danger of mustard gas _ which was the sting at the Vista _ is that it cuts at the very fabric of our society,'' said lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy. ``It might be Mr. Barry today, someone else tomorrow.'' ``We do not intend to give you the impression for one moment that there was not occasional drug use by Mr. Barry,'' Mundy said. But he added that ``that's not what the case is about. ... He's being tried for specific instances of alleged misconduct.'' After court adjourned for the day, Mundy said he made the admission to show jurors ``the honesty of the defense, the intelligence of the defense.'' Mundy will continue his closing argument Thursday. Prosecutor Retchin, summarizing six weeks of trial testimony, told the jury that Barry used drugs in ``every quadrant of this city for years'' and wrapped himself in a ``web of deception'' to cover it up, Retchin said the FBI sting operation at the Vista Hotel was necessary in order to expose Barry's drug use. It resulted in the mayor's arrest Jan. 18 after he was videotaped smoking FBI-supplied crack cocaine in a hotel room. ``Some of you might question why there was an undercover operation like this,'' Retchin said to the jury. She told them to ``imagine you were at war'' and ``heard allegations that the general was helping the other side.'' Barry denied he was involved with drugs in grand jury testimony and in public statements, but the sting operation ``breaks the shield of secrecy,'' said Retchin. ``The general was working with the other side, that is what it comes down to,'' she told the jury. Defense attorney Mundy told the jurors, ``I will start right from the beginning by telling you that Mr. Barry used cocaine.'' But he said the government's case was built around imprecise, uncorroborated statements from witnesses persuaded to testify in order to ease their own legal difficulties. ``The defense doesn't carry immunity in its briefcase,'' said Mundy. ``We can't forgive people for things they have done. Only the government has that prerogative, so we're not playing on a level field.'' Retchin recounted testimony from 10 friends and associates of the mayor who said they saw Barry use cocaine some 200 times from 1983 through Jan. 18. Barry sat at the defense table looking pensive as Retchin argued that he should be convicted on all 14 of the criminal charges against him. His wife, Effi, and his mother watched from the first row of spectators. The jurors could look at three oversized prosecution charts displayed in the courtroom, listing occasions, places and times that witnesses said they sold or used drugs with Barry. Barry's web of deception ``began to unravel'' when police investigated the mayor's visits in December 1988 to the hotel room of Barry associate Charles Lewis, said Retchin. Barry and Lewis conspired to conceal their use of crack cocaine in Lewis's hotel room and the mayor then waged ``the ultimate cover-up'' by denying in front of a federal grand jury that he and Lewis had exchanged drugs, she said. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 counts of cocaine possession, three felony charges of lying to the grand jury and one count of conspiracy. Each perjury count carries a maximum five-year prison term. ``Our government cannot work when the chief executive officer charged with enforcing the laws shows utter contempt and disdain for the process and goes into the grand jury and he lies,'' said Retchin. She noted that Barry had told the grand jury, ``I really respect this process. ... This is as important as going to visit the president of the United States.'' When Barry was asked in front of the grand jury whether he had given anything of value to Lewis, the mayor said he hadn't given his friend any cocaine or other drugs. ``Mr. Barry anticipated the question ... Mr. Barry couldn't even keep the lie inside himself _ it had to jump out of him,'' said Retchin. Barry's own security guards, who are city police officers, ``assisted him in his web of protection,'' said Retchin. One guard brought an envelope to Lewis containing money used to buy crack cocaine, said the prosecutor. Another baby-sat the children of ex-model Rasheeda Moore while she went out to buy drugs on Barry's instructions, said Retchin. On a boat ride in the Virgin Islands, another guard ``kept his head down so he didn't have to see the chief law enforcement officer of our city (Barry) using drugs,'' she said. Barry's lawyers had attacked the government's witnesses as being from the ``inner recesses of humanity,'' said Retchin. But ``Mr. Barry is right with them.... It was Mr. Barry who gave us our witness list,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Overwhelm Protesters at Robert Mapplethorpe Opening
LaserPhoto BX10
DOC.TEXT: A controversial exhibit including explicit photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe opened Wednesday as scores of placard-toting supporters and a handful of vastly outnumbered opponents staged competing demonstrations. About 200 supporters, chanting and carrying signs with such messages as ``No Censorship,'' began gathering at the Institute for Contemporary Art around 8:30 a.m. As dozens of patrons lined up to buy tickets, an angry crowd of supporters surrounded one of six protesters opposing the exhibit that helped spark a nationwide debate on freedom of expression. ``These people are trying to force their morality on the rest of us,'' Jim Edgerley of the conservative American Freedom Coalition said as he stood among demonstrators, patrons, police and reporters on te museum steps. While Edgerley spoke, two men deliberately stood in front of him locked in a deep, passionate kiss. ``See, this is the kind of behavior this is promoting,'' Edgerley said. Beside them stood a man who identified himself as Abe Rybeck of the United Fruit Co. theater group, dressed in a black beehive wig, leopard striped tights, red tap shoes, garter and short black camisole dress. Brandishing a fake microphone of tinsel and silver, Rybeck told the crowd, ``Robert Mapplethorpe is exhibiting what is really going on in his community. He is celebrating his life, his friends, his sex.'' Later, the crowd drove Edgerley away by surrounding him and chanting so loud reporters couldn't hear him. Less than an hour after the museum doors opened, an estimated 200 visitors were lined up outside, said museum marketing assistant Denise Spencer. Some held tickets purchased in advance. The small museum allowed just 75 people every half hour to view the 124 photographs taken by Mapplethorpe from 1969 until shortly before he died of AIDS last year in Boston at age 42. Eleanor Bleakie, 70, of Cohasset and her friend, Margaret Mooney, 41, of Chicago were among the first to get a look at the show. ``I'd read a lot about it and I was curious,'' said Bleakie. ``I went to see what was objectionable, but I didn't find it objectionable. I thought it was interesting.'' ``I knew he was a good photographer but I didn't know he was that good,'' said Mooney. ``I wanted to see how his talent measured up against all the hype.'' She said she didn't mind the sexually explicit, homoerotic pictures included in the exhibition. ``They were off to the side so if you didn't want to look at them, you didn't have to,'' she said. They're part of life.'' Public television station WGBH _ which telecast the most explicit photographs on its newscast Tuesday night _ said Wednesday morning it had received 100 calls about the broadcast, most of them supportive. However, several people said they were swearing off public television forever. A coalition of 13 pro-Mapplethorpe groups promised not to demonstrate at the museum on Tuesday, but gay rights groups and individual activists were out in force Wednesday. The demonstrators included about 100 people from the gay rights group ACT-UP and the group Freedom of Expression who walked a picket line across from the museum. Many carried elaborate creations protesting Sen. Jesse Helms, N.C., who has led the fight to restrict federal funds for art he branded obscene. The creations included a twin bed with the faces of Helms and Adolf Hitler nestled on the pillows and a fake coffin labeled ``Casualties of Censorship'' which contained such books as ``Lolita'' by Vladimir Nabokov. Museum Director David Ross stood at the entrance, wearing a button reading ``Fear No Art.'' Ross said he was unafraid of the controversy surrounding the show. The show, which runs through Oct. 4 and is expected to draw at least 50,000 people, is the last of a six-city tour. A Mapplethorpe exhibit scheduled in June 1989 at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was canceled after Helms objected. Helms' protests prompted Congress to limit National Endowment for the Arts grants. Before those limits, the Mapplethorpe tour had received about $30,000 from the NEA, about 10 percent of the cost. A showing in Cincinnati led to obscenity charges against the director of The Contemporary Arts Center, but a federal judge barred police from confiscating photos from the exhibit.

DOC.HEAD: Epidemic Kills 331 People in Nepal
DOC.TEXT: A digestive tract ailment has caused an epidemic in this Himalayan kingdom, killing 331 people in the past six weeks, a Health Ministry spokesman said Wednesday. At least 10,000 people were stricken by gastroenteritis in 24 of the country's 75 districts, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. Gastroenteritis, an inflammation of the stomach and the intestines, is caused by drinking contaminated water. The spokesman said medical teams were traveling through remote areas to treat victims. People were being warned to drink only boiled water, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Surprised by Jogging President
LaserPhoto WX21
DOC.TEXT: Two young women sunbathing alongside the Potomac River didn't bat an eye Wednesday when President Bush and his entourage jogged right by them. Bush appreciatively eyed the women, smiled and apologized, ``You're on national television, ladies. Sorry about that!'' Bikini-clad Dana Habeck, 22, of San Luis Obispo, Calif., and Linda Kreider, 33, of Philadelphia, who wore a one-piece suit, laughed and told reporters they didn't mind the attention. ``It's great,'' said Ms. Kreider. The pair was soaking up the sun at the isolated eastern end of Hain's Point in East Potomac Park on the banks of the Potomac River when Bush came jogging by with Secret Service agents and several running partners, including Rep. Larry Hopkins, R-Ky., and Brit Hume, a White House correspondent for ABC News. The president, wearing shorts and a Houston Police Department T-shirt, got in 2{ miles on a sunny afternoon. Hopkins told reporters later that he had already jogged four miles Wednesday morning when he got the invitation to run with the president. He decided not to pass up the opportunity.
