DOC.HEAD: Germanys Settle Contentious Question of Elections, Fight Over Money
With AM-Price of Peace, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys on Wednesday settled a fight on how to elect a united Parliament but continued squabbling over whether East Germany has enough money to pull its moribund economy into the capitalist arena. West German government spokesman Hans Klein said the opposition Social Democrats agreed to an election plan allowing small East German parties to run on tickets with larger parties with which they are allied. For example, the German Social Union, which is allied with the larger Christian Democrats, could run on the same ticket. This could improve the small parties' chances of winning representation in Parliament, because each ticket will have to win at least 5 percent of the total vote to be represented in the united Parliament. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told reporters late Wednesday that his coalition parties had also approved the plan. The issue at one point threatened to derail the timetable of German unification as parties jockeyed for the most favorable conditions to improve their chances in the all-German election Dec. 2. De Maiziere said he expected the election law to be signed Friday. Meanwhile, East German Finance Minister Walter Romberg said Wednesday his country needs a supplementary budget of $6.25 billion to $7.5 billion plus increased unemployment insurance. More than 250,000 East Germans are unemployed and experts say that number could climb as high as 3 million as companies and factories succumb in the transition to a free market. West Germany has budgeted nearly $15.6 billion this year to cover East Germany's deficit. Manfred Carstens, a top West German Finance Ministry official, criticized East Germany's request for more money as ``unserious and politically dishonest.'' On Tuesday, East German Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt said ``the country is burning'' and called for billions more in West German marks to help prop up the economy. De Maiziere went to Austria on Tuesday to meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl at his vacation retreat and discuss the economic crisis. The mass-circulation Bild newspaper reported Thursday that Kohl pressed de Maiziere to find more savings in his budget.

DOC.HEAD: Business People Complain Mohawk Standoff Threatens Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Local business people complained to Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa on Wednesday that the long standoff between Mohawks and police threatens them with bankruptcy. The Chateauguay Chamber of Commerce sent a letter to Mulroney and Bourassa telling them to get personally involved in a speedy solution to the 3-week-old impasse or face serious problems. Neither leader has taken a public role in dealing with the confrontation that arose from a land dispute, leaving matters in the hands of aides. ``Does it take monster demonstrations, effigy burnings or social unrest to get you to intervene?'' the letter asked. ``If it takes threats to get you to do your job, consider this.'' The letter said businesses and industries in this suburb are on the verge of bankruptcy because of Mohawk barricades blocking highways and the Mercier Bridge connecting the region to Montreal. In Oka, 18 miles northwest of Montreal, a provincial policemen was killed three weeks ago in a police raid on a Mohawk roadblock following a municipal request for police to enforce a court order. Blame has not been established in the death. Mohawks say Oka wants to expand a golf course onto ancestral land. Oka village council scuttled a federal plan to ease tensions when it decided Tuesday night not to sell the federl government part of the disputed property. The land would have become part of a new Mohawk reserve. ``We won't sign until the blockades come down,'' Mayor Jean Ouellette said after the conclusion of a stormy town meeting called to discuss the deal. The federal government offered to pay for land that was slated for the golf course expansion and to pay compensation to the town for economic loss. It earlier bought from a Frenchman land marked for residential development. Ouellette initially recommended that the deal be accepted. Several residents at the meeting objected, however, when told that removal of the barricades would not be part of the deal. ``If we're ready to make a concession by selling the land, why don't (the Mohawks) put down the barricades and the guns?'' said businessman Bernard Boivin, 51, who led the attack on the proposal. Another local man, Guy Dube, added: ``The people from Oka are standing together and saying that to let the natives have the land without any concession on their part is something nobody will agree to.'' In Montreal, a human rights expert said violations have been committed on both sides during the standoff. Jean-Claude Fouque, general secretary of the International Federation of Human Rights, said he won't lay blame in his preliminary report for the United Nations. A final report is expected in a month or two. The federation, based in Paris, is an independent coalition of human rights groups which investigates allegations of human rights abuses. Fouque said Tuesday that the federation is mobilizing a task force of 24 international observers to help end the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Ancient Burial Site with 40,000 Figurines Found in China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD details on new find, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Archeologists have unearthed a 2,000-year-old burial site containing 40,000 pottery figurines in the ancient capital of Xian, said a report seen Wednesday in Beijing. The site is estimated to contain more than five times the number of terracotta figurines found buried with the first Chinese emperor, Qin Shi Huang Di, whose tomb is also in Xian, the Xinmin Evening News of Shanghai reported Tuesday. The discovery of the ancient army of terracotta warriors guarding Qin's tomb was one of the great archaeological finds of modern times. It has turned Xian, in western China, into one of the country's major tourist attractions. The newly discovered burial site dates to the Han dynasty, or between 206 A.D. and 220 B.C. Archaeologists have uncovered 11 pits the past two months, the newspaper said. Each pit measures an average of 13 feet wide, 23 feet deep, and dozens of yards long, the newspaper said. The more than 300 figurines excavated so far are all male, naked and about 24 inches tall, it said. Each was exquisitely crafted with smooth, flowing lines and attention paid to such details as eyes, eyebrows, nose, lips, ears, hairstyle and muscles, it said. Experts believe that bits of silk cloth that were also found at the site indicate the figurines originally were clothed in silk, but their costumes have disintegrated over 2,000 years, the newspaper said. Qin's terracotta army was discovered by peasants from a local commune who were digging a new well to irrigate their parched soil in March 1974 following a winter drought. Hundreds of thousands of foreign tourists visit Xian each year to see the museum built around the pits containing the colorfully dressed, life-size terracotta figures of archers, infantrymen and cavalry, which guard the emperor's tomb, about two miles away. The terracotta warriors have yielded invaluable clues to the dress, weaponry, military organization and physical appearance of the era. Pieced together by experts, the armored warriors and their horses, stand in formation, rank by rank. Each of the sand-colored statues has a different facial expression and hair style. The finds over the years have included bronze and wooden chariots, a variety of weapons, as well as drums and gongs used to give command signals to troops in battle. The museum is about 20 miles east of Xian, now the capital of Shaanxi Province, a city of 2.9 million people, about 660 miles southwest of Beijing. Starting point of the ancient Silk Road to the West, Xian and its environs was the cradle of Chinese civilization under 11 dynasties from the 11 century B.C. to 907 A.D., when the city was the largest in the world with more than 1 million people. Qin unified scattered Chinese kingdoms into a single nation in 221 B.C. and died a year later.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Will Head Nicaraguan Army for Two More Years
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Humberto Ortega, the Sandinista who was to serve only temporarily under Nicaragua's new government, said Wednesday he will remain at his post for at least two more years. However, he pledged loyalty to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and vowed to depoliticize the army. Some conservatives have claimed Mrs. Chamorro's failure to replace the general, brother of former President Daniel Ortega, signals that the U.S.-backed government has entered into a secret power-sharing pact with the leftist Sandinistas. Ortega spoke in Costa Rica the day after he and other Central American officials met here and agreed to make efforts to proportionally equalize the size of their armed forces. Ortega said in the past three months, the Nicaraguan army has already been reduced from 96,000 to 46,000 men. In pledging loyalty to Mrs. Chamorro, Ortega said Wednesday, ``Now that she is supreme head of the army and acts within the frame of the constitution, she will have the support of the military.'' He said he would remain in power to oversee the reduction and professionalization of the armed forces and to make sure it becomes an institution independent of any party. He said he would then enter civilian life, and he ruled out running for president. Supporters of Mrs. Chamorro have been worried about Ortega's position as head of the army. He was appointed to that post in April, when Mrs. Chamorro's government took office after winning popular elections. The new government then reached an accord to end the country's 9-year-old civil war with U.S.-backed Contra rebels. When she named Ortega to lead the army, Mrs. Chamorro said the general, who was the defense minister under the Sandinistas, would serve only temporarily. The Sandinistas are still the largest single party in the country. They control key labor unions and the police, in addition to the army. Sandinista-inspired labor unrest has been one of the new government's biggest problems. Mrs. Chamorro's own forces has been hobbled by defections. Many of her closest advisers, members of the National Opposition Union that carried her to power, have withdrawn from the government.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Romanians Turn to Yoga to Seek Inner Peace
DOC.TEXT: With their outer world beset by economic hardships and political turmoil, several thousand Romanians turned to yoga Wednesday in an effort to seek inner peace. More than 2,000 people gathered in the capital's Polivalenta Hall _ once used for government-organized rallies in support of deposed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu _ for a yoga convention. The gathering was organized by a group of yoga specialists from different European countries. Ceausescu, ousted in December's revolution, banned yoga in the early 1980s after a group of prominent intellectuals held a ``transcendental meeting'' at the Institute of Psychiatry. Participants were later demoted from their posts and the institute was closed down. As Oriental music played in the background and the scent of burning incense filled the air, Romanians of all ages kicked off their shoes and sought inspiration through yoga. Antonio Nazare, a French assistant to the Indian guru Shri Mataji, exhorted the crowd to ``regain their inner peace,'' instructing them to reach out with their hands a huge framed photograph of the Shri ``to absorb her energy.'' ``I'm asking you to experience the peace of the self ... here where comfort is more difficult to attain than in other places in the world,'' Nazare said. Most of those attending the yoga meeting said they wanted to seek refuge from the tension and confusion that have gripped Romania since December's bloody revolution. ``I am happy to discover that I can find peace and calm in the general political pandemonium with yoga,'' said 31-year-old engineer Sandu Bidan. ``I can also find liberty.'' Romania is suffering a severe economic crisis, marked by shortages of many basic consumer goods. Political tensions have been on the rise since June when the government of President Ion Iliescu broke up a demonstration by anti-Communist activists and jailed dozens of opponents. Nazare said he expected even more people to attend a second Bucharest yoga meeting scheduled for Thursday. He also announced that Shri Mataji planned to visit Romania in October. Mataji has been touring Eastern Europe, and recently appeared before 15,000 people in Bulgaria, Nazare said.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Fire Threatens Greek Island, Delphi
DOC.TEXT: A major forest fire raged out of control for a third day on the island of Evvoia off eastern Greece on Wednesday, and a brush fire threatened the ancient sanctuary at Delphi in central Greece, officials said. No casualties or evacuations were reported. The Evvoia fire has burned more than 10,000 acres of pine forest and olive groves, forestry officials estimated. ``It has destroyed our most beautiful forest and will stop soon when it has nothing left to burn,'' said a police officer contacted in Khalkis, the regional capital of Evvoia. Strong winds fanned the blaze, he said. A forestry department communique said other major fires were burning near the towns of Navpaktos, Thebes, Kastoria, Krestaina and Ioannina. A police official contacted at Amfissa near Delphi said a brush fire reached within 325 feet of the marble antiquities Wednesday before wind drove the flames in another direction. He said the fire was still out of control on the cliffs above the sanctuary. Both police officers spoke on condition of anonymity. Delphi, near Mount Parnassus, was the seat of the most famous and powerful oracle of ancient Greece. The prophecies were pronounced in a temple dedicated to the god Apollo that was built in the 6th century B.C. It is the most famous ancient site in Greece after the Acropolis in Athens. Last week a fire near Olympia, the sanctuary to Zeus that played host to the first Olympic Games in the eighth century B.C., destroyed a pine forest and killed two firefighters. Wildfires have also raged across the tourist islands of Samos, Chios and Zakynthos in recent days as Greece experiences its driest year in 100 years.

DOC.HEAD: Princess Anne Nominated for Nobel Peace Prize by Zambian Leader
DOC.TEXT: President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia said Wednesday he has nominated Princess Anne for the Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of her work on behalf of helpless children around the world. The 39-year-old daughter of Queen Elizabeth II has traveled to 26 countries in Asia, Africa, Latin America and the Middle East since she became president of the Save the Children Fund 20 years ago. ``She loves people,'' Kaunda said in a BBC interview. ``She has extended that love to working for helpless children in many parts of the world. That is love in action.'' Nicholas Hinton of Save the Children told the BBC the princess was ``universally admired for her ability to get messages across'' and to cut through bureaucratic red tape in countries where the charity operates.

DOC.HEAD: Two Mauled by Bear in Surprise Encounter on Trail
DOC.TEXT: Two hikers were mauled by a bear they encountered on a trail in the dark, officials said. The couple, both summer workers for a park concessionnaire, were in stable condition at Columbus Hospital in Great Falls recovering from bite wounds and lacerations Wednesday. Rangers were trying to track down the bear. The attack took place Tuesday night, as Matt Alonzo, 23, of New Orleans, and Diana McCrory, 22, of Dyersburg, Tenn., were returning from a hike on the Iceberg-Ptarmigan Lake Trail and were about a mile from a motel, said park spokeswoman Amy Vanderbilt. They weren't wearing bells _ sometimes carried by hikers in the park to deter the park's many bears _ Ms. Vanderbilt said. When they were attacked, they fell to the ground and played dead to discourage the bear. Rangers couldn't tell from tracks if the it was a black bear or a grizzly. They hoped to find the bear and determine if it had previous run-ins with people, Ms. Vanderbilt said. Indications were the animal wasn't what rangers call a ``bad bear,'' prone to attack. ``It appears to be a surprise encounter, with a natural reaction by the bear,'' she said. Vanderbilt said it was unlikely any action would be taken against the bear unless the animal has a history of problems, or if it gets into trouble in the future. It was the first bear attack this year in the park. Alonzo suffered bites and lacerations the length of his right leg and bites on his upper right arm, Ms. Vanderbilt said. Ms McCrory's injuries included bite wounds to her upper right arm and arm pit, her right chest and right side, as well as her right leg and hip, the spokeswoman said. Both work for Glacier Park Inc., the lodging concessionaire in Glacier Park, and work at Glacier Park Lodge in East Glacier. Neither McCrory nor Alonzo wanted to talk about the ordeal Wednesday, said the spokeswoman for Columbus Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush, Regulators Still Disagree on Key Points of S&L Case
With AM-S&L Bailout, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil continues to disagree with regulators on key points in his savings and loan case, in which he has been accused of conflict of interest, documents released Wednesday show. Bush, 35, was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver-based thrift which failed in December 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. In the two documents, made public by the Office of Thrift Supervision, Bush and the regulators said they disagreed on a number of significant points. The key point of contention is whether Bush adequately disclosed to Silverado his business relationships with Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters, two big borrowers from the thrift. On Monday, the OTS released a document setting out the areas of agreement between Bush and the regulators. All of the documents contain information that was previously made public. They have been submitted to Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson as part of the proceeding in the Bush case. Bush has been ordered to appear at a public hearing on Sept. 25 in Denver before Davidson, who will then make a recommendation to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. In addition to the OTS case, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing a negligence lawsuit against Bush and other Silverado directors. Bush's attorneys and the OTS each submitted one of the two latest documents, called statements of contested facts. In his seven-page paper, Bush contends that before he joined the Silverado board, he disclosed his relationships with Good and Walters to former Silverado chairman Michael Wise, other Silverado managers, the board of directors and the thrift's attorneys. Good and Walters invested millions of dollars in Bush's oil partnership, JNB Exploration Co., which drilled a number of dry holes in Wyoming over two years and failed to become profitable. As a director, Bush voted to approve some loans by Silverado to Good and Walters but did not vote on others. Bush also asserts in his document that he made no agreement to abstain from votes involving loans to Good or Walters. In its nine-page submission, the OTS says ``there is no evidence'' that a letter prepared by Wise about Bush's business dealings with the two men was actually sent. The letter was addressed to Silverado's preferred shareholders and was accompanied by a cover memo to the directors, the OTS notes. The document alleges that Bush breached his duty to Silverado shareholders when he voted to approve certain loans to Good and Walters. Five of those loans resulted in a combined loss to Silverado of at least $46 million, the OTS says. ``Generally accepted standards of prudent operation require the disclosure of a thrift director's relationships with major customers of the institution when further transactions are under consideration,'' the agency's document says.

DOC.HEAD: Kids Of Migrant Farm Families Plan For College
LaserPhoto PGS2
DOC.TEXT: A generation ago, the children of migrant farm workers rarely finished high school. Now, many are part of an education program aimed at getting them to college. ``We saw some of these kids that are talented, they have the desire, but college for them is another planet,'' sai Paula Stoup, a research specialist with the state's Migrant Education Program. Thirty-two migrant students gathered for four days of workshops at Allegheny College in northwestern Pennsylvania this week to discuss career goals, brush up on their writing and computer skills and improve their study habits. The program reaches about 6,000 migrant students in about 800 schools across the state, said director Manuel Recio. It helps children who switch from school to school as their parents travel looking for work in the agriculture and fishing industries. The students receive tutoring to help them catch up and can get help with language problems and cultural differences, he said. Marilyn Agosto, 16, attended the program last year and returned this year to help other students. For the past four years, she has lived in Toughkenamon, a town about 20 miles west of Philadelphia. But before that, she moved 14 times because her mother works in health care for migrants. ``You get in a school and stay there a couple months and then you move to another school,'' she said. ``You get behind and your grades drop. It's hard to get caught up.'' When the program began in the 1960s, more than 95 percent of migrant students dropped out of high school, Recio said. Now, about 60 percent fail to graduate. ``That's still very high, but we never would have thought so many of them would get near to college,'' he said. State lawmakers heard from migrant students during an education hearing Wednesday at the college to discuss increasing the program's budget. ``When my father was growing up, he had no hope in life. He was on his own and there was no one to push him on to do anything,'' said Sandra Ramos, 16, from Toughkenamon. ``When I started four months ago to talk about college it shocked my family.''

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say Gene May Increase Risk Of Lung Cancer
DOC.TEXT: A gene that may be carried by one out of 10 people could make them more susceptible to lung cancer, according to a study published Wednesday. ``There's only a suggestion that this gene exists,'' said Joan Bailey-Wilson. ``If it does and a person with this gene smoked, the risk of getting lung cancer would be increased tremendously. ``It doesn't mean a person with this gene would automatically get lung cancer,'' Bailey-Wilson said. ``It would mean they are much more susceptible to environmental factors.'' The scientists at Louisiana State University Medical Center in New Orleans have yet to confirm the gene's existence, but their survey of 4,357 people strongly supported their theory the gene exists, Bailey-Wilson said. ``It's not a wild theory or a guess pulled out of the air,'' said the associate professor of biometry and genetics. ``At this point, it's an educated hunch.'' The findings were published in Wednesday's Journal of the National Cancer Institute. The LSU research team was investigating why Louisiana's lung-cancer death rates are among the highest in the nation and why lung cancer appears to cluster in some families. The findings don't lessen the role environmental factors, such as smoking, are believed to play, Bailey-Wilson said. ``Lifestyle is still a major factor,'' she said. ``If the gene is found, it would still mean that 80 percent of the people who get lung cancer do so because of environmental factors.'' The study predicts that most people who get cancer, whether they have the gene or not, are smokers, Bailey-Wilson said. ``Gene carriers are more susceptible, but it doesn't say at all that those who are carriers will get it, or all of those who aren't won't get it,'' she said. Among the people interviewed who had lung cancer by the age of 50, 22 percent appeared to carry the gene, Bailey-Wilson said. The figure dropped to 10 percent among people who developed lung cancer before age 70, she said, but by that time other cancer causers would have had more time to play a part. Once further research tracks down the gene to its spot on the chromosomes that determine heredity and determines how it works, scientists should be able to develop tests to determine who carries it, said Robert C. Elston, a professor of biometry and genetics who took part in the study. If the research pans out, physicians would be able to identify people at extremely high risk of developing lung cancer, advise them and monitor them more closely, Bailey-Wilson said. Success could also lead to more information on cancers and treating them, she said. Positive identification of the gene is still years away, she said. The researchers are seeking federal funding to continue their work. The scientists in 1976 began going over autopsies and death certificates in 10 south Louisiana parishes to find lung-cancer victims. They then interviewed the 337 families of victims, and found patterns of lung cancer, said Dr. Henry Rothschild, professor of medicine. Such clusters of cancer ``could be explained on the basis of a gene being passed down,'' Elston said. The scientists have not gone beyond Louisiana to determine how widespread the gene might be, but there is no reason to think the figures would not be about the same nationally, Bailey-Wilson said. Louisiana has a lung-cancer rate 25 percent rate higher than the rest of the United States, according to the Louisiana Cancer and Lung Trust Fund. About 3,000 cases of lung cancer will be diagnosed in Louisiana this year, and 2,700 Louisianians will die of it, the American Cancer Society estimates. Nationally, about 157,000 cases will be diagnosed in 1990, and about 142,000 Americans will die. Lung cancer is the top killer among men and women, the organization says, with only a 5 percent survival rate.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Bertha Menaces Canada, Kills Six Aboard Ship
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Bertha and its 75-mph winds swirled north off the East Coast and Canada's Maritime Provinces on Wednesday, breaking apart a freighter and fraying the nerves of coastal residents. Six people were killed aboard the Maltese-registered freighter that foundered off Cape Cod early in the day. The storm also killed a swimmer Tuesday when it churned up seas while passing Florida. At least six people were injured Wedesday in Nova Scotia during the high seas, though the hurricane skirted the mainland. Earlier in the day, forecasters had predicted it would hit here with full force. At 6 p.m. EDT, the National Weather Service in Miami said the storm was about 60 miles southwest of Sable Island, a narrow sandspit about 130 miles east of Halifax. The storm was racing northeast at 16 mph and expected to weaken. Nova Scotians awoke Wednesday morning expecting the worst but saw only the usual gray skies with some rain and light breezes. At sea, though, Bertha was deadly. A crew of 27 abandoned the 593-foot Maltese-registered freighter Corazon early Wednesday 11 hours after reporting the ship was breaking up. Thirty-foot seas whipped by winds gusting to 90 mph had snapped its keel. Merchant ships plucked 21 sailors from the heavy seas, but six crewmen were killed, according to Lt. Cmdr. Paul Milligan, a U.S. Coast Guard spokesman. The Corazon was carrying 22,989 metric tons of cement bound from Greece to New York, and the load likely contributed to its damage, said Coast Guard Lt. j.g. Rodney Gadsden.

DOC.HEAD: Father Given Five Life Terms in Drownings of his Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to restore time element, CLARIFY that judge believed man guilty, but of lesser charge than first-degree murder.
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murdering his four children by driving the family station wagon into a river was sentenced to life in prison Wednesday by a judge who suggested he might have preferred conviction on lesser charges. Lawrence DeLisle was convicted by a jury of four counts of first-degree murder and one count of attempted murder, the last because his wife, Suzanne, also was in the car. Wayne County Circuit Judge Robert Colombo Jr. said he had no choice but to impose five life terms, to be served concurrently. He said the evidence proved beyond doubt the act was premeditated, but suggested he would have preferred conviction of lesser charges. ``I don't know if the defendant is guilty of the crimes of which he was convicted,'' the judge said. The jury could have convicted DeLisle of second-degree murder, negligent homicide or involuntary manslaughter. Witnesses testified DeLisle had complained that his family was a financial burden and once, several years ago, left the house with a candle burning by a leaky gas dryer. Frank Eaman, DeLisle's court-appointed lawyer, said he would seek a new trial and, if that motion was rejected, would ask the Michigan Court of Appeals to overturn the convictions. DeLisle was accused of deliberately driving his station wagon into the Detroit River on Aug 3, a989. Supported by testimony from his wife, DeLisle claimed a leg cramp and a faulty accelerator left him unable to control the car as it raced down a dead-end street and through a barricade at the river's edge. Jurors deliberated three days before convicting DeLisle on June 21 of four counts of first-degree murder and one of attempted murder. DeLisle read a brief statement again proclaiming his innocence. ``A father's job is to protect his children, and I failed,'' he told Colombo. ``I panicked. I froze. That is my guilt, not murder.'' Suzanne DeLisle told Colombo she believed her husband was innocent. As the survivor of an attempted murder, she was allowed to address the judge under Michigan's victims'-rights law. ``The police weren't there. I was,'' said Mrs. DeLisle, who along with her husband was rescued by passing boaters after their car plunged into the river. ``I know Larry is innocent. ... We will be together again.'' Judge Colombo said he questioned his earlier rulings denying a change of venue in the highly publicized case. The jury ``may have been subconsciously influenced by what they already knew about the case through the media,'' he said. Deputies returned DeLisle to the Wayne County Jail, where he would stay until being transferred, probably Thursday, to the State Prison of Southern Michigan near Jackson, sheriff's spokeswoman Nancy Mouradian said. Mrs. DeLisle, confronted outside the Frank Murphy Hall of Justice by a swarm of reporters and photographers, shouted ``Leave me alone! Enough is enough!'' as two companions led her to a waiting car. Eaman told reporters he would ask for a new trial within six weeks. He said he was surprised by the candor expressed by Colombo before the sentencing and was encouraged by the doubts raised by the judge. ``I don't think this case is over by a long shot,'' Eaman said. Wayne County Prosecutor John O'Hair said he couldn't fault Colombo for expressing anxiety over the case. But he also said that most key rulings on evidence and the jury-screening process were heavily weighted in DeLisle's favor. ``From all reports I've had on the trial, I believe the record made in the case is virtually unimpeachable,'' O'Hair said. ``I believe we have had as fair a trial as is possible in the criminal justice system.'' The children, Bryan, 8; Melissa, 4; Kathryn, 2; and Emily, 8 months, drowned as the family station wagon sank in 27 feet of water.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Officials Urge Regulation of Marketing of Baby Formulas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12 grafs for 9-17 pvs bgng `In the' to ADD Carnation statement and background on company's marketing of infant formula, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. conference to promote breast-feeding denounced on Wednesday the practice of distributing baby formula free to new mothers, particularly those in developing nations. The conference urged closer regulation of the marketing of baby formula to encourage breast-feeding, which is considered a key to lowering infant mortality. Doctors said even mothers who have tested positive for the AIDS virus should breast-feed. ``Attainment of the goal demands ... vigorously defending against a bottle-feeding culture,'' said a declaration on the third and final day of the conference. The conference was led by the World Health Organization and UNICEF. Mother's milk helps boost a baby's immunity and eliminates the need to use possibly contaminated water to prepare formula or other food. U.N. officials estimate that 4 million to 5 million children could be saved each year if they had been breast-fed. Many deaths are caused by severe diarrhea infections. An assistant director-general of WHO, Hu Ching-Li, decried the situation in some poor countries in which companies provide baby formula free to new mothers who are capable of breast-feeding. After beginning to bottle-feed her child in the hospital or clinic, the mother continues to do so after going home but often does not have the money to buy the proper formula, Hu said. Such marketing violates a marketing code adopted by WHO in 1979. U.N. officials say only a few countries adhere to the code. UNICEF's executive director, James P. Grant, said he hopes more nations will pledge to adopt the code when their leaders attend the World Summit for Children at the United Nations in New York in September. Two formula makers _ Carnation Co., a subsidiary of Nestle; and Gerber, which is producing a formula with Bristol-Myers _ have marketed their products directly to the public despite the objections of the Academy, which represents 39,000 pediatricians. However, a spokesman said Carnation's marketing campaign, which involved a few weeks of ``general consumer ads'' in the United States, had been discontinued about 18 months ago. He said the company did not consider that campaign to be direct marketing, because the company was not identified in publicity promoting the use of infant formula. ``We do not now nor have we direct-marketed,'' said Dick Curd, a spokesman at Carnation headquarters in Los Angeles. Nestle has been the target of a U.S. consumer boycott for a decade because of its marketing of infant formulas in developing nations. American Home Products, another formula-maker marketing in developing nations, also is being boycotted, said Howard Bozich, executive director of Action for Corporate Accountability, which monitors infant-formula abuses. Eighteen other companies, some from Western Europe and Japan, also sell formula in poor nations in violation of the WHO code, he said. The boycott against Nestle ended after the company agreed in 1984 to follow U.N. marketing guidelines. But it was renewed in 1988, when consumer activists accused Nestle of skirting the intent of the guidelines by encouraging some new mothers in developing countries to use formula, even if they could breast-feed. The company denied that charge. WHO officials said the benefits of breast-feeding are so great that even mothers who tested positive during pregnancy for the HIV virus should nurse their children. Hu, a Chinese physician, said the recommendation was based on research in many countries, including those where there is a ``very high prevalence of AIDS.'' When pressed, he declined to elaborate, saying the research included unpublished studies. There have been cases of mothers apparently transmitting the HIV virus, which causes AIDS, to children through breast milk, but it is rare and has not been used as a reason to discourage breast-feeding. A study in June 1989 in the New England Journal of Medicine presented circumstantial evidence that breast-feeding may increase the AIDS risk for newborns. The study, directed by Dr. Stephane Blanche of Necker Hospital in Paris, found that among infected mothers, AIDS infections were found in five of six infants who were breast-fed, compared with 25 of 99 who were not. It cautioned that further studies are necessary ``before infants at risk in developing countries are deprived of the advantages of breast-feeding.'' In the United States, breast-feeding has declined about 1 percent a year the past decade, said Dr. Antoinette Eaton, vice president of the American Academy of Pediatrics. She said statistics show less than half of all mothers are still nursing their babies one month after birth.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Colorado Springs
British Prime Minister Visits Colorado
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Thatcher's arrival in Aspen. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `During her...
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher ran into soggy, London-like weather when she arrived at this mountain resort Wednesday to address an international symposium. Mrs. Thatcher, coatless in a driving wind and chilly rain, hurried from her Colorado Air National Guard twin-jet to a waiting four-wheel drive vehicle. She did not pause to wave at the small crowd but did shake hands briefly with a group of visiting dignataries, including U.S. Ambassador to Britain, Henry F. Catto, and Aspen Mayor Bill Stirling, among others. The prime minister came to Colorado to begin a combined business-pleasure trip during which she is scheduled to give a speech at the Aspen Institute. She arrived in the country at Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs and changed planes for the hop to this Rocky Mountain ski resort. She was greeted in Colorado Springs by Gov. Roy Romer and Gen. Donald Kutyna, head of the U.S. Space Command and North American Aerospace Defense Command. Kutyna's wife, Lucy, gave the prime minister roses when she stepped from the plane onto a red carpet. During her flight to Colorado Springs, Thatcher told reporters she was cutting short her planned 10-day visit by three days to attend the funeral of Ian Gow, the conservative member of Parliament killed by a car bomb on Monday. Gow's funeral is Aug. 8. In Aspen, Thatcher will be joined Thursday by President George Bush in a celebration of the 40th anniversary of the Aspen Institute. Bush is scheduled to open the symposium with a keynote address Thursday. The two heads of state also will meet Thursday to discuss issues. It will be their fourth meeting in three months. The institute, founded by Chicago industrialist Walter Paepcke in 1950, is designed to help global leaders focus on critical issues. The theme for its 40th anniversary gathering is: ``Renewal: Leadership and Values for the 21st Century.'' The symposium begins Thursday and runs through Sunday, when Thatcher will give her closing address and receive the Statesman Award. Nearly 1,000 people are expected to participate in the institute's seminars, which will range from health care to the environment. The Statesman Award recognizes outstanding contributions by world leaders. The two previous recipients were Jean Monnet, who spearheaded European economic integration, and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. This is Thatcher's first trip to Colorado, and she plans to squeeze in visits to the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder and the Strategic Defense Initiative National Test Facility and NORAD in Colorado Springs on Friday. Thatcher, 64, also will take time to visit with her son, Mark, 36, and his wife, Diane, and her grandson, Michael.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Prepares Speech to Defend Defense Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf to UPDATE with Bush planning to call for 25 percent reduction in U.S. armed forces.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush prepared Wednesday to defend his 1991 defense budget as House Democrats savored the cuts they inflicted on the B-2 bomber program and the Strategic Defense Initiative. ``I was out running at six this morning just because I was exhilarated,'' Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., told reporters a few hours after the House Armed Services Committee cut $24 billion from the $307 billion the president had requested for defense spending in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The administration began lobbying Senate Republicans to restore the cuts as the White House said Bush would speak Thursday on ``how he perceives the U.S. defense budget.'' The president is expected to call for a 25 percent reduction in military forces by the mid 1990s but wants to maintain support for the B-2 and the Strategic Defense Initiative, according to administration and Pentagon sources. ``The president wants a rational build-down,'' one source said. Bush was to make his remarks Thursday in a speech in Aspen, Colo. On Tuesday, the House Armed Services Committee voted to halt production of the B-2 stealth bomber at the 15 planes under construction, not the 75 Bush had asked for. At nearly $865 million each, it is the costliest airplane ever built. The committee, on a bipartisan vote of 40-12, also stripped nearly $2 billion from Bush's request of $4.7 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars; cut military personnel by 129,500; and scaled back on two nuclear missile programs. The vote left Democrats on the panel with a heady feeling. ``There was an image that we never met a weapons system we didn't like and that we would fund anything that they would bring over'' from the Pentagon, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said. Bush, meanwhile, went on the offensive. Spokesman Roman Popadiuk said the president will speak Thursday in Aspen, Colo., where he will be meeting with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Bush ``will address how he perceives the U.S. defense budget and U.S. force structure in meeting the changing demands,'' Popadiuk said. The speech, to be delivered at the Aspen Institute, will deal with ``defense aspects of U.S. foreign policy,'' the spokesman said. Meanwhile, the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on military construction approved an $8 billion spending bill for fiscal 1991 that slashes $210 million from Bush's request for $420 million for the NATO Infrastructure Fund. The panel, following the lead of the House on Monday and the House Armed Services Committee on Tuesday, also prohibited the use of U.S. money from the fund for building a new base at Crotone, Italy, for the 401st Tactical Wing unless authorized by Congress. The wing of 72 F-16 jet fighters must leave their current base in Torrejon de Ardoz, Spain. Acknowledging the House tradition of wholesale cuts in the defense budget, the administration looked to the Senate to salvage its major weapons programs. The Senate has approved a higher Pentagon budget target for the new fiscal year _ $289 billion as compared to the House's $283 billion. The chamber moved late Wednesday to bring to the floor the bill that emerged from its Armed Services Committee. The Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Michael Dugan, told a television interviewer, ``I think that thoughtful men and women ... will come to the conclusion that if you want peace, you have to prepare for war.'' He predicted that Congress will not stop the B-2 program at the 15 planes. Support for the plane is higher in the Senate than in the House. One staunch backer is the Armed Services chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. In anticipation of Senate action, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met with the chamber's Republicans on Tuesday. At the same time, a July 26 letter from Cheney began circulating on Capitol Hill. In the letter, to the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, John Warner of Virginia, the secretary said the Senate bill ``provides substantial resources for the B-2 stealth bomber, Trident ballistic missile submarine, small intercontinental ballistic missile and peacekeeper-rail garrison programs.'' His comments amounted to an endorsement of the committee's decision to slash $1.6 billion the administration had sought to move the MX missile arsenal from silos to rail cars. The panel left intact the $548 million the Pentagon had requested for research and development on the multiple-warhead MX missile as well as $202 million for the single-warhead Midgetman missile. In its bill, the House panel eliminated all of the request for the MX and Midgetman missiles and, instead, set up a $610 million strategic pot for the two weapons. The panel also called on Bush to decide in 90 days which missile he wants. At the same time, Cheney noted the ``major ... shortcomings'' in the Senate bill, including a $1 billion cut in Bush's request for SDI, elimination of all funds for the MILSTAR program of communications in the event of a nuclear war and cuts in the Navy's A-12 aircraft. ``I urge the Senate to amend the bill to remove these concerns, so that the final bill advances substantially the national interest,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Cult Leader Convicted on All 15 Counts
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader's wife was convicted Wednesday of participating in the 1989 ritual slayings of a family of five. It was the first verdict in the case. A Common Pleas Court jury found Alice Lundgren, 39, guilty of five counts of kidnapping and five counts each of complicity and conspiracy to commit aggravated murder after three days of deliberations. Mrs. Lundgren, who could draw a life sentence, stood calmly beside her attorney, Joseph Gibson, as the verdict was read. She said nothing, frowning slightly as a deputy sheriff led her away. ``No one was prepared for that verdict,'' Gibson said. He said he would appeal the decision. Assistant Lake County Prosecutor Karen Lawson said the verdict in this city about 30 miles northeast of Cleveland would set the tone for the trials of other cult members charged in the case. ``I don't believe Alice Lundgren's testimony was credible,'' Ms. Lawson said. ``She hedged. She split hairs. She lied.'' Eight people remain to be tried, including Mrs. Lundgren's 40-year-old husband, Jeffrey, and their son, Damon, 19. Four others have pleaded guilty to charges in the case. Lundgren was defrocked in 1988 as a lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Kirtland for inappropriate conduct. He formed his own splinter sect, whose members lived commune-style with the Lundgrens on a farm. Judge Paul Mitrovich did not set a sentencing date for Mrs. Lundgren. Mrs. Lundgren was among 13 cult members from Kirtland who were arrested around the country last January in the April 17, 1989, shootings of Dennis Avery, his wife Cheryl and their three daughters of nearby Madison Township. Their bodies were found buried under a barn on a Kirtland farm about 30 miles east of Cleveland where the group lived. All five were bound with duct tape, gagged and shot, then dumped in a common grave. Authorities said the Averys also belonged to the group, but were not considered as steadfast in its beliefs as the others. During Mrs. Lundgren's trial, three of the cult members who pleaded guilty testified against Mrs. Lundgren. They said she'd known her husband had targeted the Averys for death as a spirit-cleansing ritual before treks in West Virginia and Missouri in search of God. One cult member, Deborah Olivarez, testified that Mrs. Lundgren portrayed her husband to others as a prophet who must be obeyed. Mrs. Lundgren testified that she'd heard of a plan by her husband to sacrifice some cult members but that she disregarded it ``because he'd come up with these wild-haired plans all the time and he didn't carry through.'' She said she wasn't at the farm during the killings _ she had been told by her husband to take her three other children shopping _ and that she was told about the slayings afterward by other cult members. Mrs. Lundgren also said her husband sometimes hit her and threatened her with a gun when she argued with him. She said testified that she was afraid of her husband, who based his ideas on his interpretation of Scriptures. Jeffrey Lundgren faces trial Aug. 13 on five counts of aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. If convicted, he could get the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Reverses Ruling that Husband's OK Needed for Name Change
DOC.TEXT: A judge's ruling that forbade a woman from changing her last name without her husband's permission has been overturned. However, the Superior Court decision stopped short of barring the probate judge who issued the original ruling from doing so in the future. ``The reversal ... is not surprising,'' said Steve Brown, executive director of Rhode Island's American Civil Liberties Union. Superior Court Judge Antonio Almeida ``has simply recognized the very basic, if obvious, principle that women are no longer the chattel of their husbands.'' ``I'm happy in one way, but I'm uphappy, because if another woman goes into his courtroom ... it's possible that he could do this again,'' Lucille Ann Riccitelli said Wednesday. Riccitelli, 41, decided to resume using her maiden name when her father died suddenly with no sons. Her sister uses a hyphenated name, she said. She changed the name on her driver's license, Social Security card and a bank account. But Fleet National Bank refused to change the name on the bank account Riccitelli held jointly with her mother without a court document substantiating the name change, she said. When Probate Court Judge Anthony B. Sciarretta learned Riccitelli was married, he told her to get her husband's consent. She refused and he denied the name-change petition. In March, Riccitelli, represented by an ACLU attorney, appealed the ruling and also asked that Sciarretta be forbidden from requiring a husband's permission in any future cases. Almeida, in a brief opinion written Friday and released Wednesday, formally changed Riccitelli's name. ``Under common law, individuals have a right to change their name provided they do so with a nonfraudulent purpose,'' Almeida wrote. ``Since no fraudulent purpose exists on the part of the appellant, the Probate Court's denial of said petition was in error and is hereby reversed.'' He denied the motion preventing Sciarretta from requiring a husband's consent in the future. ``We are disappointed the judge did not go further,'' Brown said. ``However, I am hopeful that this will prompt Judge Sciarretta to rethink his anachronistic ways. Otherwise, we will find ourselves back in court seeking future remedies.'' Sciarretta could not be reached for comment Wednesday. He was not at his home or office. He said previously that he has ``a firm policy when there are family situations.'' He said he feels spousal consent is needed ``if there is to be any integrity in the family unit.'' Riccitelli said the experience, in which she was made to feel ``like a little girl,'' has made her more aware of discrimination against women. ``It's a form of harassment that happened that opened my eyes in some ways,'' she said. ``I am really definitely more aware of things like that and I am willing to stand up for things much more easily.'' Riccitelli said she has started volunteering at the Women's Center of Rhode Island, a shelter for abused women and their children.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Campaign Reforms, Honoraria Ban
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, warned that its public esteem had fallen to ``the level of used car dealers,'' voted Wednesday to hobble the money chase for campaign funds and to ban outside speaking fees. Democrats overrode longstanding Republican objections to limiting how much candidates can spend to win office to pass by a 59-40 vote, largely along party lines, the first wholesale revamping of election laws since the Watergate era 16 years ago. ``The public is rapidly losing confidence in the federal election process,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``It is clear we have gotten to the point that the worst alternative is to do nothing.'' South Carolina Sen. Ernest Hollings, who maintains a constitutional amendment is needed to address campaign reform, was the only Democrat to vote against the bill. Five Republicans _ Sens. John McCain of Arizona, James Jeffords of Vermont, William Cohen of Maine, David Durenberger of Minnesota and Larry Pressler of South Dakota _ supported the bill. Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., absent with a heart ailment, did not vote.

Immediate skepticism was raised as to whether the campaign reforms or the accompanying elimination of honoraria that now allows senators to keep thousands of dollars in speaking fees each year will clear several remaining hurdles, including the renewed promise of a veto by President Bush. ``This bill clearly will not become law,'' said Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky. McConnell said he was told by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu earlier Wednedsday that Bush would veto it. ``It will be vetoed, there's no doubt about it,'' added Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla. By a 77-23 vote earlier Wednesday, the Senate had voted to include in the bill Sen. Christopher Dodd's amendment to ban pocketing of honoraria after Jan. 1, 1990 and limit any other outside earned income to 15 percent of Senate salaries. The House voted a similar ban for its members last year. ``When a significant part of our salaries comes from hustling, and that's what it amounts to, we denigrate ourselves,'' said Dodd, D-Conn. ``As public servants, our salaries should come from the public alone.'' In addition to the spending caps, the reforms in the bill would abolish union, corporate and trade association political action committees that accounted for one-fourth of the $185 million spent on Senate elections in 1988. House leaders said they hoped to vote Friday, before lawmakers begin a five-week vacation, on campaign finance reforms. But they acknowledged that it might not happen because of widespread discord among Democrats over its measures. Unlike their party colleagues in the Senate, House Democrasts rejected calls to ban PACs, which have overwhelmingly favored them over Republicans in recent elections. Many also have voiced opposition that the proposed $550,000 spending cap for House races is to low to cover both primary and general election challenges. The Senate bill would establish population-based spending caps ranging from just under $2 million for Senate candidates in the smallest states up to nearly $10 million for the largest, California. Republicans called it a ``partisan charade'' to prevent Republican challengers from raising enough money to overcome Democratic incumbents' name recognition advantage and deny the GOP a chance to gain control of Congress. ``In my view the die is cast on this bill,'' said Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, expressing only scant optimism ``that maybe something will come out of all this. Unless there's some changes, that's not going to be possible.'' The bill would represent the first major change in election laws since congress passed the 1974 Federal Election Campaign Act in response to the Watergate scandal and the resignation of President Nixon because of it. That law established both a taxpayer checkoff public financing mechanism and voluntary spending ceilings for presidential elections. It also set spending ceilings on congressional races but they were overturned two years later by the Supreme Court as unconstitutional. The Senate bill would close loopholes in the 1974 law that allowed millionaires to make contributions in blocks of $100,000 through unregulated state party organizations to the campaigns of both Bush and Democrat Michael Dukakis in the last presidential election. Republicans, after losing party-line votes to stop the practice, said it still allows unions to spend millions of dollars of their members' dues on voter registration and turnout, 90 percent of it on behalf of Democrats. ``This campaign reform bill only reforms Republicans,'' complained Dole. ``We like reform but we don't want all of it _ it's got to be shared.''

The measure's chances also were complicated as the Senate began piling other amendments onto it _ some of them likely to virtually eliminate any chance of two-thirds, veto-proof support. For example, after voting to give up the $27,337 in honoraria they can now pocket, the Senate barely approved, 51-49, New York Sen. Daniel Moynihan's proposal requiring members to forgo unearned income of more than 15 percent of their regular salaries. That would be a hard blow to the Senate's many millionaires, whose stock and interest incomes far exceed their government paychecks and had little problem voting to ban honoraria. Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., said members of the Senate, himself among them, had supplemented their salaries with more than $9 million in honoraria over the past decade. ``The scandals of the past two years have put a black mark on public service and raised public cynicism to an all-time high,'' Byrd said. ``We're about at the level of used car salesmen'' in the public's esteem. The Senate voted last week to denounce Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., for violating several ethics standards, including skirting the limits on honoraria in a book-publishing deal. The House vote last year to give up its members' honoraria also boosted their salaries to $124,000. Reluctant to vote itself the same 25 percent pay boost, the Senate instead retained the opportunity for its members to accept special-interest fees. In 1989, senators accepted nearly $3 million in honoraria and kept more than $2.1 million, with the balance donated to charity, according to their financial disclosure forms.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
Kuwait Claims Iraqi Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi and Kuwait troops have clashed at the border of their two countries, the Kuwait embassy said Wednesday night. Faleh Bader, director of the ambassador's office, said, ``We confirm there is an offensive at Kuwait border and we have no comment.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects County's Redistricting Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday rejected the county's plan to redraw voting districts, calling it illogical and insensitive to minorities. The ruling was issued by U.S. District Judge David Kenyon, who previously ruled that the layout of districts for the Board of Supervisors improperly deprived Hispanics of political power in the nation's most populous county. Kenyon ruled the Board of Supervisors' conservative majority failed to redraw district boundaries. He said the plan constitutes ``a nonsensical distortion of existing supervisorial districts, a calloused interpretation of the Voting Rights Act, and is insensitive to the needs of Hispanic and black residents.'' The judge set a hearing for Thursday to consider alternative plans proposed by civil rights groups and the U.S. Justice Department, the winners in a voting rights case against the county. Kenyon ruled June 7 the supervisors violated the federal Voting Rights Act by conspiring in 1981 to draw district lines that preserved their incumbencies while diluting Hispanic voting strength. The lawsuit, filed in August 1988, accused the supervisors of deliberately spreading the county's Hispanic population across several districts when they changed voting boundaries after the 1980 federal census. Though Hispanics make up an estimated 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million residents, the five-member board has not had an elected Hispanic member in 115 years. The board's conservatives responded to the ruling by drafting a plan that created a Hispanic majority in one of the liberal board member's districts, while also preserving the conservative majority. It was this plan that Kenyon rejected Wednesday. Attorney Marc Rosenbaum of the American Civil Liberties Union, one of the plaintiffs, said the judge's ruling sends a strong message to governments that think they can gerrymander away minority political clout. ``Their day is over,'' said Rosenbaum. ``But ... those governmental bodies that respect the law, adhere to the Constitution and to the rights of minorities ... have nothing to fear.'' The next redistricting plans, to be submitted by the ACLU, the government and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, are aimed at creating a Hispanic majority district but without an incumbent. The plans could greatly increase Hispanic political clout and overturn the conservative majority, with possibly profound implications on future funding for such areas as health and social services programs. Conservative Supervisor Mike Antonovich denounced the judge's decision and vowed to fight it on appeal. Antonovich said the plaintiffs were simply trying to use the courts to upset the board's ideological complexion. ``They're doing that outside of the electoral process,'' he said. In defense of the current district boundaries, Antonovich pointed to the June election. Sarah Flores, a Hispanic backed by conservative supervisors, got the most votes for a seat opened by outgoing conservative Supervisor Peter Schabarum and forced a runoff with Superior Court Judge Gregory O'Brien. But plaintiffs have rejected Antonovich's reasoning, saying the ethnicity of a supervisor is not as important as who elects the supervisor. Kenyon's decisions have put the outcome of the election in doubt.

DOC.HEAD: Unclad `Doonesbury' Character Becomes Controversial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents of 4th graf may offend some readers.
DOC.TEXT: Some editors are taking a close look at a ``Doonesbury'' comic strip due out next week in which a character clad in nothing but rope utters provocative language. ``Frankly, it didn't offend me, but I'm thinking of all the people out there,'' said Jim Hughes, executive editor of the Baton Rouge Morning Advocate and State Times. The strip by G.B. Trudeau features the character J.J. giving her rendition of ``performance art'' with a bucket over her head and nothing but rope covering her privates. She speaks in fragmented sentences laced with words with sexual connotations such as ``lubricate'' and ``hot juices,'' but doesn't make any direct reference to sex acts. ``The way I read it, it's an attempt to show the lengths that the art community will go to thumb their noses at government grants,'' said Jack Morrissey, an associate editor at Universal Press Syndicate. The Kansas City area-based company distributes the ``Doonesbury'' strip to about 1,000 newspapers. Trudeau appeared to be referring to controversy over National Endowment of the Arts funding. Some conservative politicians have tried to block government money going to artwork they consider obscene, and several performance artists have lost their grants. Morrissey said several editors had called with questions about taste and the reason behind releasing the strip. But no paper indicated that it would pull the comic next week, he said. Hughes said he had his staff call other papers around the country Wednesday to see whether they would run the strip, which papers received this week and is scheduled for release from Aug. 6 to Aug. 11. Hughes said his paper had yet to make a decision. Three of the papers contacted by Hughes' staff _ The Kansas City Star, The Los Angeles Times and The Philadelphia Inquirer _ said they examined the strip closely and decided to run it without alteration. ``If you held it out, the Doonesbury people would get mad. And if you run it, I imagine some other people will get mad,'' said Joe McGuff, vice president and editor of the Star. ``I just take that as a given.'' Bob Duffy, vice president of Universal Press, said newspapers could choose to withhold the strip. But he strongly discouraged editors from altering it for reasons of taste, as papers have done to Trudeau's comics in the past. ``We'd rather have them drop the strip than alter it,'' he said. ``That's always been our position, but you can't police 1,000 newspapers.''

DOC.TEXT: U.S. factory productivity lagged behind all but one of the world's major industrial countries last year, and analysts blame the poor showing largely on the nation's weak savings and investment rate that in turn holds down plant investment. A Labor Department survey on the 11 richest industrial countries is a worrisome sign that Americans' standard of living won't increase dramatically any time soon, private economists said Tuesday. In addition, they said, it shows that the nation's economic clout may be slipping, compared with such nations as Japan and West Germany. ``It isn't the worst thing in the world if someone else is richer than you, but since power tends to go with wealth, this hurts our standing on the power curve,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago.

Outnumbered Republicans are complaining that it is only their traditional sources of money being singled out for ``reform'' in a Senate campaign finance bill. The furor erupted Tuesday after Democrats beat back efforts to weaken unions' influence in elections. ``All of the bipartisanship has completely broken down,'' Sen. John McClain, R-Ariz., said after losing a 49-49 tie vote on his measure to make candidates turn surpluses in their campaign accounts over to the government instead of keeping them for use in future elections. Meanwhile, Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said he would attempt to amend the bill today to ban senators from accepting up to $27,100 a year in speaking fees ``honoraria'' to supplement their current $98,200 salaries.

The Commerce Department approved the sale of industrial furnaces to Iraq even though the manufacturer told U.S. officials the items could be used to produce nuclear weapons material, documents show. The White House intervened to block the sale of the furnaces this month, effectively reversing the Commerce Department's earlier decision. The action came as Congress passed sanctions against Iraq and the administration weighed whether to restore Iraq to a list of countries that support terrorism. U.S. officials believe that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is seeking to develop nuclear weapons technology. A senior State Department official said Tuesday the United States is placing new restrictions on exports of items to Iraq that could be used for the Middle Eastern country's development of missiles or chemical and biological weapons.

Gene therapy, a new medical magic bullet in the war on cancer, diabetes and many inherited disorders, could be used on patients for the first time this fall. A federal panel approved the use of gene therapy for two disorders on Tuesday and a National Institutes of Health scientist said that if the technique works, it gives medicine a powerful new way to cure the incurable. ``This is the first step in what probably will be a revolution in medicine over the next two decades,'' said Dr. W. French Anderson, an NIH researcher. A proposal by Anderson to use gene therapy to treat an inherited immune system disorder and one by Dr. Steven Rosenberg to treat a lethal skin cancer were approved by the Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee at NIH.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: a version of this story also moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to pressure from civil rights groups and corporate sponsors of this month's Professional Golfers' Association championship, the host country club has agreed to admit black members. Shoal Creek Country Club announced Tuesday that an insurance company president is its first black member. It said more blacks are under consideration. The action halted plans by the NAACP and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference to protest the tournament Aug. 9-12. Six companies, including IBM and Spalding, had decided not to run TV commercials during the championship because Shoal Creek had no blacks. An NBC-owned TV station in Los Angeles had said it would not air highlights of the tournament.

DOC.HEAD: Modern Lombard League Seeks Autonomy from Rome
DOC.TEXT: Winds of independence, blown from the north by an 800-year-old ghost incarnate, are giving Rome a few shivers. Northern politicians have revived the Lombard League, a 12th century alliance of autonomy-loving cities that fought the oppression of the Holy Roman Empire. They want to remove Lombardy, the most productive part of Italy, from the grasp of a slow-moving, tax-eating, notoriously inefficient central government. Rome was stunned this spring by the league's strong showing in local elections. It became the second-ranked party in the region, behind Premier Giulio Andreotti's Christian Democrats. Part of the Lombard League's popularity stems from northern resentment of Rome for sending workers from the underdeveloped south for the past 40 years to deliver their mail, teach their children and police their streets. Northerners have disdained some of those jobs, particularly police work, because of the low pay and high risk. Others jobs, such as teaching, are based on national competitions the northerners claim are weighted in favor of people from the south. In addition, many bureaucratic posts are political appointments, and northerners say southerners get most of them. The league wants to end a virtual open-door policy that is bringing a tide of poor immigrants to Italy. Most of the latest arrivals are poor, from North Africa and Asia. On a wall of the league headquarters, in a working-class district of Milan, is a poster showing a plump chicken whose golden eggs tumble into a basket held by a fat farmer's wife. As the league sees it, the chicken is productive Lombardy and the peasant woman a parasitic south. Lombard League newspapers denounce Rome for, they say, using money from the north for wasteful development programs in the south. Hundreds of millions of dollars were poured into construction projects in the Naples area after the 1980 earthquake there, for example, but thousands of people made homeless by the disaster still live in makeshift housing. Sen. Umberto Bossi said in an interview the party wants Italy to become a federalist state with the central government's role limited to defense, foreign policy, taxes and some judicial matters. Bossi, league president and its only member of Parliament, looks to Switzerland, Lombardy's neighbor across the Alps, as a model. Many Lombards say they identify more with the rest of Europe than with Italy, whose international image often is that of the south. Soccer may well be country's strongest bond, but north-south bitterness emerged even during the World Cup competition Italy hosted this summer. Argentine soccer star Diego Maradona, who plays for Naples during the regular season, was booed for trying to get his fans to root for Argentina when it played the Italian national team in Naples. He was accused of exploiting north-south hatreds. ``I never said that the Neapolitans should root for Argentina,'' he said later. ``I just made a few observations ... like the banners in Verona,'' when Naples played there, ``that said `Wash yourselves' and `Welcome to Italy'.'' Charges that the League is racist make some northerners cautious in expressing sympathy for the party. Bossi rejects the racist label. ``I didn't vote for the league, but some of my friends did,'' said Claudio Tarini on the train ride home to Milan from Rome, where he had spent two days dealing with the bureaucracy to obtain the necessary permits for a business trip to Nigeria. While racism undoubtedly motivated some to vote for the league, Tarini said, public disgust with Rome was the principal reason for the election success. As a newspaper columnist wrote in describing the average citizen's entanglements with clerks and paperwork to meet ordinary requirements of daily life: ``Will I have to vote for the league to get a driver's license?'' The column appeared in La Stampa, a national daily based in Turin, capital of the Piedmont, which borders Lombardy and has its own regional party. Bossi says the League will begin collecting signatures in September to force a referendum on a law that allowed tens of thousands of Third World immigrants to stay in Italy. After his election to the Senate in 1987, Bossi sponsored a bill that stopped the practice of sending convicted Mafiosi from the south to internal exile in northern towns.

DOC.HEAD: Queens Miracle Claim Keeps Drawing Crowds After 20 Years
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: At a park that was twice the World's Fair grounds, amid softball games and bicycles, under the vapor trails of thundering airliners, hundreds convene each week to seek the Virgin Mary. They are certain she is here, in Flushing Meadows Park. They have assembled for 20 years _ since June 18, 1970, when Veronica Lueken, a housewife and mother of five, first said she saw Mary at a church in Bayside, Queens. The Roman Catholic Church is not convinced. But believers insist they are witnesses to a continuing miracle. ``It increases our faith,'' said Kathy Anderson, a Long Island mother of four who attends with her husband, a computer consultant. ``We truly believe that Jesus and the blessed mother are here. This is the most important Marian shrine of our day.'' Linda Bonas, 30, a Brooklyn teacher, looked around at the 500 or so worshippers reciting the rosary on a recent Sunday and said: ``If everything was happy and was doing well around the world, you wouldn't have too many people here. Most of them realize there's something missing.'' Mrs. Lueken claims the apparitions tell her that unless we mend our sinning ways, the world will be destroyed by comets, earthquakes, World War III and other disasters. But she rarely attends services. She has had heart and gallbladder surgery and suffers from high blood pressure, back pain and ringing in the ears. Her followers call her a ``victim soul,'' one who suffers in exchange for blessings. Word of her first vision at St. Robert Bellarmine Roman Catholic Church spread quickly. In 1975, she was barred from holding vigils there _ the crowds were too big. Police offered to let them meet at Flushing Meadows, where the Vatican pavilion stood during the 1964-65 World's Fair. Pope Paul VI had blessed the site, marked by a stone wall on a grassy field. Mrs. Lueken says the visions moved there from the church. It seems an unlikely place for a miracle, amid soccer and softball games, joggers and bicyclists. Traffic drones from nearby expressways and jets roar overhead to and from La Guardia Airport, sometimes drowning out the prayers. Worshippers bring a statue of the Madonna each week and adorn it with roses. The flowers, believed blessed by the Virgin during services, are then given to the crowd. Frank DeRosa, spokesman for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, which oversees Queens, said ``no credibility can be given to the claims of apparitions at the site of the vigils. The diocese does not believe that anything of an incredible or miraculous nature is happening there. We discourage people from coming to attend the vigils.'' Michael Mangan, director of Our Lady of the Roses, Mary Help of Mothers _ the official name for Mrs. Lueken's followers _ says the diocese's failure to certify the miracle is ``par for the course when it comes to the church and their involvement and assessment of apparitions.'' He said the group's name came to Mrs. Lueken in a message from Mary. ``Roses, as Our Lady explained, is nature's purest flower, a symbol of perfection,'' said Mangan. ``Mary, help of mothers, is because many mothers are worried about their children today.'' The group claims 60,000 believers worldwide. On a recent Sunday, Peter Livsack, 63, came on a chartered bus from Philadelphia. Like many others, he brought a Polaroid camera and snapped pictures of the Madonna he said would become ``miraculous photos.'' Livsack says he often notices squiggles, shadows and patches of light on the pictures when he gets home. He believes these are messages from God resembling doves, initials and faces of saints. ``See the mouth, see the eye, right in the branches of the trees?'' he asks. Many of the messages Mrs. Lueken receives are predictions of doom _ ``God's punishment for man's rejection of him,'' Mangan says. ``Civilization has always been punished or ended when the moral decadence and sins has reached its peak.'' But he added: ``The Virgin Mary, like a true mother, has love for her children and she's coming to warn us to mend our ways and turn back to pray the holy rosary and practice the Roman Catholic faith.'' Mangan, one of 15 full-time employees, says bills are paid ``through unsolicited donations.'' Requests for money are never made at the services and are not common in the group's literature. ``Our Lady just gives enough to provide for her work,'' he said. The organization describes its history and Mrs. Lueken's messages in booklets, videotapes, radio and cable television shows aired around the country, and even in advertisements on the subway. ``We're using the latest technology and modern means to propagate this message,'' said Mangan. ``Anything to inform these desperate souls out there.''

DOC.TEXT: Retired United Methodist Bishop James K. Matthews, 77, says returning to the job as an active bishop ``is a little like swimming and riding a bicycle _ once you learn, you don't forget.'' Matthews, who had headed church areas in Boston and Washington for 30 years before retiring in 1980, made the comment after he was recalled to head a new Albany, N.Y., area until a permanent bishop is elected in 1992.

Christian and Moslem leaders have made a joint appeal that the war be ended between rebels and government troops in Ethiopia, that they allow movement of emergency aid to famine victims and that negotiations begin toward a settlement.

George D. Karcazes of Orthodox Christian Laity commended the meeting for urging acceptance of married priests as bishops and referring other proposals to a task force.

Delayed in arriving for a crusade until midway through it because of recuperation from a rib operation, evangelist Billy Graham commented, ``I am recovering from 50 years of preaching, I suppose.'' A spokesman says Graham, who underwent surgery in April to remove a portion of a rib, took the pulpit six weeks ahead of his doctor's recommendation for the final three days of the crusade. It had been led earlier by an associate.
Roman Catholics in the world total 906 million, up 13 million from the year before, reports the Vatican Statistical Yearbook. Their proportion of world population held steady at 18 percent.

A Richmond Circuit Court jury has awarded $1.56 million to four children of a former Southern Baptist missionary couple in a lawsuit against the denomination's foreign missions board. The lawsuit by the children's mother contended that board officials, on learning that her husband, G. Thomas Wade Jr., was sexually abusing their oldest daughter, did not inform Mrs. Wade of the abuse so she could stop it. The abuse continued, and also involved two other daughters, the suit contended. The couple also has a son. A psychiatrist testified about psychological damage to the children and treatment needed. The jury allocated the award among the children. The board seeks to overturn the verdict.
