DOC.HEAD: Governors See GOP Plan as Adding to Tax Woes
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It used to be an article of Republican faith: the more taxing and spending that can be shifted out of Washington to local and state governments, the better. That tenet now seems subject to revision to fit the federal deficit crunch. As governors and local officials see it, the new version shifts spending all right, but then proposes tax changes that would undercut their ability to raise their own revenues. At the long, lagging negotiations on an elusive deal to trim the $169 projected budget deficit, Republicans produced a plan that included a new ceiling on federal tax deductions for state and local income taxes. It also would sharply increase the federal tax on beer and wine, as part of a package of $54 billion in spending cuts and revenue increases. The federal tax deduction for state income taxes would be limited to $10,000 a year, and most of the estimated $3 billion it would produce would come from taxpayers making $100,000 a year or more. So some congressional Republicans said the plan the administration floated _ but never really disclosed _ should satisfy Democrats who insist that upper income Americans pay most of the tax cost of deficit control. It didn't. And it ran head-on into the opposition of governors of both political parties, in Mobile, Ala., for their annual conference, which ended Tuesday after raising the volume of their usually scattered protests. The governors already are facing tax woes of their own; 36 states are electing governors this year and where incumbents are in jeopardy, it's usually over increased taxes. State taxes generally have increased during the past decade, under a conservative Republican administration that has trimmed federal aid. That worked in boom times, but it is a worsening problem in a slowing economy. Democratic governors circulated a letter demanding that President Bush drop the tax idea. They said it would impose a double tax in the states that have done the most to deal with their own financial problems, and would make it tougher for the states to increase their own revenues. There are income taxes in 44 states, and local income taxes are levied in 11 of them. Along with the impact, governors feared the precedent. Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, a Republican usually allied with the administration, said the idea of a deduction limit was ominous. Once that ceiling was in place, lowering it would be a tempting way to come up with future federal tax increases. About one-third of all the itemized deductions on federal tax returns are for state and local income taxes. Deductions for state sales taxes were phased out as part of the 1986 tax overhaul. Bush has not acknowledged administration authorship of the tax plan; the refrain at the White House is that everything is still on the table. That's what John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, told the governors on Sunday. He also said the proposal wasn't what the president would prefer. But it was put together by Bush's budget director, and it appears that the president would prefer it to a straight increase in the federal income tax rate for the wealthiest taxpayers. Under current law, middle and upper income taxpayers pay 33 percent; on family incomes over about $186,000, the rate dips back to 28 percent. Despite that White House wariness, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, said, ``We've laid out a specific plan and we're still waiting to hear from the Democrats.'' But the Democrats were in no hurry to talk taxes. They always wanted the Republicans to go first. And congressional Republicans, looking toward the Nov. 6 elections, complained they were taking a beating.

DOC.HEAD: Corpus Christi Becoming Focus of Anti-Abortion Activism
DOC.TEXT: In just nine months, the Roman Catholic bishop has excommunicated two abortion clinic employees, the sheriff has prayed on the sidewalk while police pulled his wife and other anti-abortion protesters from a clinic doorway, and petitioners succeeded in forcing a vote on a city charter amendment that would declare human life begins at conception. ``The Holy Spirit is doing something in Corpus Christi,'' says Rex Moses, the man inspiring much of the anti-abortion activity. ``I think it's happening because God has picked Corpus Christi as a beachhead.'' His opponents say it's Moses, not God, who picked Corpus Christi, which is Latin for ``body of Christ.'' ``I think Rex Moses targeted the city,'' said Amanda Stukenberg, president of South Texans for Choice, an abortion rights group. ``I think the name itself helped make it a battleground.'' Moses might agree. ``All names are significant,'' he said, noting that reporters often ask him if Moses really is his name ``because it all seems to improbable.'' ``God matched this person with that name,'' he said. It was in November that Moses, 35, brought his anti-abortion crusade from Austin to this Gulf Coast city of nearly 300,000, which is predominantly Catholic and Hispanic. Moses said he formed Body of Christ Rescue after losing the support of religious leaders in Austin. He was convicted three times there of criminal trespassing for blocking access to women's services clinics with his Austin Rescue group. Moses has appealed a year's worth of jail sentences, but said he expects he'll eventually have to serve the time. He asserts that trespassing is not illegal if the trespasser is trying to save the unborn from ``imminent harm.'' One of Moses' first actions upon arriving in Corpus Christi was a ``rescue.'' Twelve people were arrested for trying to keep patients and staff out of one of the city's two clinics, where a total of about 3,000 abortions were performed last year. But Moses wasn't arrested then, nor in the other 18 local clinic blockades in which he has participated. And police have arrested only a handful of his protesters. Police Chief Henry Garrett said only those who assault police officers or force their way into the clinics will be taken into custody. Mass arrests would only give the protesters more publicity, he said. The police chief said he does not foresee having to arrest Sheriff Jim Hickey or Hickey's wife, Jan, two staunch Moses allies. Hickey surprised visitors to the sheriff's department earlier this year with Moses posters featuring a photograph of a decapitated fetus and the caption, ``Legal Abortion Kills Baby Boy.'' Hickey won't send deputies to help police clear access to the clinics, saying, ``I would be aiding in murder of babies if I did.'' The Catholic sheriff credits Moses with inspiring him and others in the city to get more involved in the anti-abortion movement. Tracy Cassidy, chairwoman of the Human Family Committee, which sponsored the petition drive to force the vote next Jan. 19 on the city charter amendment, is another Moses ally. She said she knows adding a preamble to the charter would have no legal weight, but ``we will be making a statement as a community that we respect human life in all stages.'' The declaration states, in part, that ``Human life begins at conception and extends to the moment of natural death.'' South Texans for Choice will fight it. ``Statements about one's philosophies or religious beliefs do not belong in the city charter,'' Ms. Stukenberg said. Moses helped promote ``a religious coalition that is directing its congregations how to vote on a secular political document,'' she said. Rachel Vargas, one of the Corpus Christi residents excommunicated by Bishop Rene Gracida, also blames Moses for the stepped-up anti-abortion activism. Ms. Vargas links her excommunication to a statement she gave last December during a Moses-organized ``rescue,'' when she told a local Catholic newspaper that she was a ``pro-choice Catholic.'' She said she believes more contraception would reduce the number of abortions and that ``God breathes life into a baby at the moment of birth.'' Moses and many of his followers oppose all forms of artificial birth control. Gracida ``certainly had to make an example out of me, since I publicly stated that I am a pro-choice Catholic,'' said Ms. Vargas, who cried during an interview six weeks after her June excommunication, which deprives her of church sacraments, including Communion. ``Someone had to be a scapegoat,'' she said. Dr. Eduardo Aquino, an obstetrician, also received an excommunication decree from the bishop earlier this year. Elva Bustamante, director of the New Women's clinic where Aquino performs abortions twice a week, has received two warning letters from the bishop, but no final decree. She sent the bishop a letter last month telling him she would not quit her job, as he had demanded. Church law states that those participating in abortions automatically excommunicate themselves, with or without an official decree from a bishop. Moses devoted his life to the anti-abortion cause shortly after converting from what he calls ``fundamentalist quasi-Pentecostal'' beliefs to Catholicism in 1988. He gave away most of his possessions, he said, quit his $200,000-a-year job designing pension plans, and sold his share of the company for $1. He got rid of his assets in anticipation of the lawsuits he believed would follow his protests, he said. He now owes more than $1 million in judgments to an Austin clinic and an Austin police officer injured while trying to lift a 300-pound protester. He said he, his wife and their four children survive on occasional cash and food donations, and his office space and duplex are leased from former City Councilman Cliff Zarsky, a longtime abortion foe. Moses contends his activities here have left the city with far fewer doctors willing to perform abortions, and Ms. Vargas also believes that many local prominent pro-choice figures now are afraid to speak out. But not all members of the religious community, even those opposed to abortion, support his tactics, Moses concedes. They cite the biblical instruction to obey the laws of the land. ``The guy who wrote that was in jail when he wrote that,'' Moses responds, referring to Apostle Paul. ``If a lot of people agreed with what I am doing, I wouldn't have to be doing it.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Photographer Goes Down Memory Lane
DOC.TEXT: Philip Jones Griffiths, a photographer who spent three years covering the Vietnam War, took a trip down memory lane last year. But he did it the hard way _ on remnants of the Ho Chi Minh trail. When he first saw what once had been North Vietnam's famous, much-bombed main supply route south, he suffered a bit of photographer's regret: ``I suppose what I was thinking is that I should have been here 20 years ago. The photographer's instinct is to say, `I've been cheated. I should have been here.' '' His ``Ho Chi Minh Trail'' expedition, filmed for the BBC's ``Great Journeys'' series bought by 61 public TV stations, will start airing later this month _ Aug. 11 here and from Aug. 13 to 16 in other cities. The Ho Chi Minh trail was far more than a trail. It was a network of trails, dirt roads and river crossings, mostly covered by jungle, that stretched south for 200 to 300 miles into Laos, Cambodia and South Vietnam. It was heavily bombed by U.S. warplanes and periodically infiltrated by U.S. Army Special Forces troops, but few Western journalists ever traveled it during the war. No doubt puzzled, officials in Hanoi last year gave Griffiths and his camera crew permission to film what it looks like now _ at least those portions still passable in the Soviet-made jeep they loaned him, along with a guide. As you'd expect, it was tough trip, says the 54-year-old photographer. Large chunks of the once-bustling trail have been reclaimed by the jungle, ``and once you stop upkeeping a road like that it disappears very quickly. So our biggest task was actually finding it.'' ``Occasionally, you'd find what looked like a hopeful bit of road. But after half a mile, there would be so many old bomb craters that no vehicle on earth could traverse them. They were too close together.'' Griffiths got to travel only the trail's Vietnam side. His attempt to follow it through Laos, starting at what once was a major wartime entry point called the Mu Gia Pass, was blocked by guards. It wasn't just because the trail was washed out, he says. ``The Laotians wouldn't let us go in. They try to maintain a little independence from the Vietnamese, so they were anxious that it wouldn't seem they were being ordered to let us in.'' But he doubts that the trail network through Laos exists anymore, although he concedes ``there's no real way of finding out'' without Laotian permission. The Welsh-born Griffiths, whose documentary is liberally filled with North Vietnamese wartime footage of the trail, only got as far as Vietnam's Central Highlands before his expedition ended. The reason: the continuing war in Cambodia in which soldiers who include the Khmer Rouge are fighting those of the Vietnam-backed government. ``We couldn't get too close to the border at times, because when you start coming around the edge of Cambodia, the Vietnamese began getting worried about the Khmer Rouge,'' he says. Griffiths took a philosophical attitude about the possibility that the Cambodian communist forces might have crossed the border and mined parts of the road on which he was able to travel. ``My feeling is that the bits the Vietnamese kept in repair were pretty well-traveled, and if the Khmer Rouge had ever booby-trapped them, they certainly weren't going to tell me about it,'' he says. The early part of his tour took him through what once was the so-called demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam, then past two famous battlefields _ Khe Sanh and the A Shau Valley. He spent one night in the latter, which in May 1969 was the scene of the bloody, controversial battle for what U.S. troops called Hamburger Hill. ``There's sort of a people's committee building on the valley floor right opposite Hamburger Hill,'' Griffiths says. ``You sit on the balcony in the evening, and you look at Hamburger Hill. ``It just looks so peaceful and green now. That's one of the disappointing things about old battlefields. They don't look like old battlefields.''

DOC.HEAD: Social Security Harvest Sometimes Better Than Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: In much of rural America, a boost in monthly Social Security checks is more important than an increase in soybean prices or a few new jobs at the local broom factory. ``Transfer payments, such as Social Security, are a large and growing source of income in non-metro areas,'' says a report by the Agriculture Department. ``From 1969 to 1987, transfers grew from 11.6 percent to 18.7 percent of non-metro income.'' Transfer payments also include retirement and disability benefits, medical benefits, welfare, food stamps, unemployment insurance, veterans' benefits and various other benefits. ``Such transfers have a stabilizing effect on rural economies,'' the report said. ``Recipients continue to receive income from the programs, even when employment and earnings fall during recessions.'' In 1987, when transfer payments made up 18.7 percent or $18.70 of every $100 in rural income, the urban rate was only 13.7 percent. The report was written by Robert A. Hoppe and Linda M. Ghelfi of the department's Economic Research Service and was included in a recent issue of Rural Development Perspectives magazine. Big development programs to boost business and industrial enterprises have had a lot of attention over the years. Federal grants, loan guarantees and similar aid are staple fare when Congress talks about rural development. A financially healthy agricultural sector also is looked upon as one way of enhancing the rural economy. While all of these are important, the study by Hoppe and Ghelfi shows that Social Security and the other transfer payments are making a valuable imprint of their own. Since 1969, the report said, wider eligibility and increased payment levels occurred in a number of programs. In 1973, for example, Medicare began to cover disabled people under the Social Security and railroad retirement programs. Food stamps existed in less than half the nation's 3,000 counties in 1969. By July 1974, all counties were required to offer them to low-income families. ``Finally, people 65 and older are a growing proportion of the total population, particularly in non-metro areas,'' the report said. The report said 475 rural counties have a ``high share'' of their incomes from transfer payments. Those range from 12.3 percent in Clay County, Ill., to 25.8 percent in McDowell County, W.Va. High-share counties were said to be concentrated in: _Appalachia, including West Virginia, Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee. _Ozark-Ouachita area of Missouri, Arkansas and Oklahoma. _Other scattered areas of the South. _Upper Great Lakes region of northern Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota. _Various areas scattered throughout the West. ``These counties are highly dependent upon retirement and disability income because earnings per job are generally low or because elderly residents constitute a high proportion of total population,'' the report said. In 1986, for example, earnings per job averaged $13,668 in the high-share counties, compared with $15,188 in all the non-metro counties. Not only do transfer payments help buffer against the effects of recession on local economies, the elderly and welfare recipients tend to spend their money at home. ``This spending provides local retailers with a stable consumer base that helps them survive recessions when the newly unemployed reduce their purchases,'' the report said. ``Some rural development specialists even advocate attracting older (people) because retirees can bring large amounts of transfer income with them and tend to spend their income locally.'' There are practical limits to all this, however. Building a local economy on Social Security checks and other benefits can have some pitfalls. ``Local business and government leaders in areas heavily dependent on transfers should try to keep abreast of proposed program changes that could alter transfer payments,'' the report said. ``Retirement and disability programs, in particular, should be monitored closely.'' The analysis said a continued commitment by society to support Social Security will be especially important, since it alone pays about three-quarters of all retirement and disability benefits. ``Relying on the transfer income of the elderly, then, can be a viable short-run development strategy,'' the report said. ``But in the long-run, the transfer income of the elderly may not be a rural development panacea.''

DOC.HEAD: Problems at Nuclear Weapons Plant Numerous, Costly
DOC.TEXT: Rocky Flats makes plutonium triggers for nuclear warheads. But for years, it also has produced nightmares. There have been breaches of security. There have been radiation leaks. Alarms meant to warn of impending nuclear accidents have failed to work. For now, plutonium production has been halted at the plant, which is 16 miles west of Denver, and one study says it will take five years and $150 million to fix only the more pressing of Rocky Flats' problems. Critics say it could take billions of dollars and 20 years to completely clean up hazardous residues. ``I think people should be concerned that we're operating safely,'' said Phil Warner, the plant's new general manager. ``This plant is no more dangerous than any other large manufacturing operation, but the materials are dangerous stuff unless you do a good job. ``People ought to make sure we're doing a good job,'' he said. ``I would.'' Federal officials ordered the halt in plutonium processing last November after being shocked by the unsafe conditions they found. EG&G Inc. was named the new manager of the government-owned plant at the beginning of the year, and its executives say things were even worse than they expected. Among the most serious problems cited: _ Many alarms do not work, and wiring of the system was not documented properly. The alarm system is tied to the public address system, which often does not work. The problem is so serious that in the event of a runaway nuclear reaction, the proper emergency teams might not be alerted. _ Crucial equipment, especially pipes and holding tanks, is more than 30 years old, and workers fear gaskets will leak when production resumes. Dams are being built inside the plant to contain any leaks. _ Glove boxes in which the warhead triggers are fabricated have cracked glass that could release plutonium into the air. Other glove boxes lack drains for water. If water builds up over a few inches, it could cause an uncontrolled fission reaction; the resulting flash of radiation would kill anyone within 15 feet instantly and injure people up to 70 feet away. _ Monitoring devices have failed, allowing plutonium to be tracked from the plant on workers' shoes. Decontamination teams had to trace workers' routes off the grounds, including into Denver, to determine where they tracked the toxic metal. Other problems included the lack of a single on-site environmental executive and the need for paving a parking lot, apparently to reduce wind-blown dust that potentially could carry radioactivity off the grounds. In addition, investigators said soil, groundwater and a sewage treatment plant are contaminated with hazardous waste. Residents of the area fear contaminated water has seeped into their groundwater supplies. Then this summer, federal investigators found they could breach part of the security system intended to prevent theft of highly radioactive plutonium. The government suspended the handling of all radioactive materials, although officials said other security measures prevented any plutonium being smuggled off the grounds. In late July, the Department of Energy announced the $150 million price tag for the partial cleanup at the 130-building complex in the foothills of the Rockies. Officials said it will be at least several months before EG&G can meet conditions for resuming plutonium production. The plant, which was hit by near disastrous fires in 1957 and 1969 and blamed for radioactive contamination outside the site because of improper dumping, is the nation's sole producer of plutonium triggers. Without the triggers, the deployment of missile submarines and land-based missiles could be affected, because warheads have to be replaced periodically. Executives, government officials and plant workers say the problems of the facility, which opened in 1951, are serious. However, they say EG&G and Energy Secretary James Watkins are serious about cleaning them up. Dave Simonson, deputy plant manager for the Energy Department, says 60 percent of the production problems should be fixed by the end of the year and the rest within five years. Critics say they welcome EG&G as manager, but they are withholding judgment on its promises to devote more effort to safety. ``We've had these changes of heart repeatedly. I take it with a grain of salt,'' said Dr. Edward A. Martell, a scientist specializing in cell radiation damage at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. Rockwell International Corp., which operated the plant from 1975 through last year, defends its stewardship. Jeff Charney, a Rockwell spokesman, blamed the federal government for not providing enough money to deal with the problems. But Rep. David Skaggs, D-Colo., who represents the district in which Rocky Flats is located, said more than 100 safety problems were identified before plutonium processing was halted, including some so serious they had ``a potential for causing a severe injury or fatality, potentially fatal occupational illness or loss of the facility.'' Safety inspectors called in by the federal government said the plant had been lucky no major nuclear accident occurred. ``It's pretty sad when we're reduced to relying on luck while running a major nuclear facility,'' Skaggs said. Gov. Roy Romer, who often had a stormy relationship with the plant over safety and nuclear waste storage, praises EG&G, but says the plant should be moved from the populous Denver region. ``I have to believe there is no way you can allow something to exist on the metropolitan borders that will endanger its citizens,'' he said. Warner thinks the plant will be here 20 to 30 years more and says the important thing is to get it working safely. EG&G launched an extensive effort to retrain all 5,990 employees at the plant. Gary Francis, director of performance based training, said many of the workers handling plutonium didn't even know what they were working with. ``What we found was a variety of training,'' he said. ``We had to go back to some of the basics, to give them an understanding of radiation and the principles involved, a lot of basic things they were not presented. They were taught what, but not why.'' Ted Tegler, who helped clean up after a 1969 fire that nearly resulted in a runaway nuclear reaction and whose body now is contaminated with 13 percent of the lifetime allowable dose of plutonium, said production often took precedence over safety at the plant. But the attitude of managers has changed, he said, and workers are pleased. ``They're taking a strong line on safety. They want to know about problems,'' he said. ``Before, people were harassed and labeled a troublemaker, but that has changed significantly.'' As a result, employees flooded a hot line set up for workers' safety complaints, alerting officials to the vast array of problems. ``When EG&G moved in, we weren't pleased with what we saw. Minor levels of contamination were accepted as routine,'' said Joe Majestic, director of health and safety at the plant. That has all changed, he said: ``If we find contamination from a routine survey above the level allowed for free access by anyone to that area, we now report that as an occurrence, and we work to find it and fix it. ``We need to learn from our past and do a better job in the future,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Flats Makes Triggers for Nuclear Warheads
With BC-Rocky Flats, b0583
DOC.TEXT: The products of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant are euphemistically called ``triggers'' or ``pits.'' But actually, they're the components for softball-size atomic bombs used to jump-start the fusion reaction in a nuclear warhead. Rocky Flats' triggers go into the 25,000 nuclear warheads in the United States' arsenal. The warheads, which must be replaced periodically because plutonium decays, are assembled at the Pantex nuclear weapons plant in Amarillo, Texas. Some of the plutonium used at Rocky Flats comes from aging nuclear warheads. Other plutonium comes from nuclear reactors. At Rocky Flats, high amounts of electricity or acid baths are used to melt or separate the plutonium from other elements. The metal is packaged into disks, which then are machined and formed into balls that become the heart of a nuclear weapon. The actual shape of the trigger is a secret, because some geometric shapes produce better explosions than others. The triggers are shipped to Texas, where Pantex workers attach high-speed explosives designed to detonate instantaneously, causing an inward blast. Without simultaneous detonation, the plutonium would simply explode, scattering radiation but causing no atomic reaction. The plutonium and explosives are placed near a core of hydrogen. In an atomic explosion, the plutonium undergoes fission, its atoms splitting in a chain reaction that creates extremely high temperatures which ignite a source of neturons, such as plutonium-beryllium. The neutron source then sets off a combination of deuterium and tritium, fusing hydrogen and setting off a reaction similar to that which powers the sun. The power of a hydrogen warhead is measured in megatons _ the explosive force of a million tons of TNT. The most modern U.S. missiles carry several warheads of about a quarter to a half megaton each, and some B-52 bombs range up to 9 megatons. By contrast, the total power of the bombs dropped on Germany during World War II totaled 1.3 megatons.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Flats Trying To Determine Extent of Damage From Fires ^With BC-Rocky Flats, b0583
DOC.TEXT: Since it opened in 1951, the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant has been the scene of two major fires that allowed radioactivity to escape into the surrounding region. No one knows how much, but officials say they don't think the contamination was serious. The most recent fire was on Mother's Day in 1969. It began in a glove box, used to handle highly radioactive plutonium, and quickly spread to plutonium in other boxes. Firefighters contained the blaze, but damage totaled $70 million. The building in which it occurred is ``contaminated to infinity,'' meaning radiation levels inside the building could not be calculated. Contamination outside the building was small, officials say, but the threat of widespread contamination was immense. Federal investigators concluded that only the heroic efforts of the firefighters prevented a complete loss of the building and its contents, and a major release of plutonium into the environment, with the city of Denver only 16 miles away. The investigation found heat detectors had been mistakenly insulated during remodeling and did not detect the fire until it was out of control. A similar problem had occurred 12 years earlier, when plant workers covered up heat detectors because they were frustrated by too many false alarms. According to a report compiled by plant managers, that fire, on Sept. 11, 1957, began in molds used to make plutonium detonators. An explosion blew out 620 air filters, allowing a cloud of radioactive waste to escape and drift toward Denver. The report said the radiation released was minimal, although no determination ever was made on how much plutonium was missing. Officials say documentation on both fires is skimpy, and they have no idea how much radiation was released. The plant's new manager, EG&G Inc., has set up teams to study records and try to determine how much radioactive material escaped.

This time, the volley is directed at the park superintendent, an Indian woman who wants to present a more accurate view of what happened on June 25, 1876.

uperintendent.
``I don't think she was qualified, and she was ill-prepared. I think she is way in over her head'' _ Bill Wells, Custer enthusiast.

DOC.SECOND: BC-Personal File-Pis he convened a hearing of the House Ways and Means human
DOC.TEXT: resources committee. The Downey-Stark proposal would cost more than $5 billion over five years and would provide extra unemployment and health benefits to about 200,000 workers _ far fewer, Downey noted, than the number expected to be displaced. ``I think it's inadequate. It should cover more people,'' Downey said. ``But we don't have the votes.'' Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., called the measure to ``a domestic Marshall plan,'' akin to the post-war European reconstruction program financed by the United States. Republicans, even some from states that would benefit from the proposal, immediately criticized the legislation as unfair to unemployed workers who lose their jobs for reasons unrelated to federal policy but who are no less needy. Republican Rep. Rod Chandler, whose home state of Washington faces job losses due to the new spotted owl policy, called the legislation an ``ill-conceived, hastily slapped together proposal'' that would burden the Medicaid system with the extra health benefits. ``It leaves out those who have lost their jobs due to other causes,'' Chandler said. ``Are they not worthy too?'' Republicans on the subcommittee also made clear their concern that the program would drain scarce federal revenue. Downey and Stark proposed financing the measure through continuance of a 0.2 percent federal unemployment tax which is due to expire this year. The Bush administration also piled on, saying that existing programs already provide adequate job retraining and jobless benefits. Labor Department administrator James Van Erden said the Bush administration ``believes that singling out certain groups of workers for special treatment based on the cause of their dislocation is inequitable and inappropriate.'' Despite the GOP criticism, the idea of helping workers hurt by government policies has gained considerable support on Capitol Hill since last March when the Senate narrowly rejected a proposal by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va. Byrd's plan would have provided hefty unemployment benefits to coal miners laid off if tougher clean air standards led to reduced coal burning. Since then, new and increasingly elaborate measures have been proposed to provide extra jobless benefits but to a larger pool of workers than West Virginia's coal miners. ``The Byrd amendment was a much bigger entitlement and a much smaller population _ which was the problem,'' said William Cunningham, a lobbyist for the AFL-CIO and a supporter of the Downey-Stark proposal. ``This is not geographic. ``It is actually governmental actions that are causing these job dislocations. The number of regions involved have to be taken into account.'' Sens. Joseph Lieberman and Christopher Dodd, both Connecticut Democrats, proposed legislation last week that would cost about $1 billion a year and would include a provision ensuring that laid-off defense workers get at least a substantial fraction of their former salaries while unemployed. A separate House proposal designed to ease the burden of defense cuts would cost an estimated $200 million a year.

Sales of new homes surged 8 percent in June, the sharpest increase since November, the government said. Many analysts said the government report indicates the sluggish housing industry has bottomed out. The Commerce Department said Tuesday new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 581,000 units after posting a revised 2.3 percent gain in May. May sales first were reported last month to have risen just 0.4 percent, the first advance in five months. Despite the increase in June, new homes sales for the first six months of 1990 have fallen 9.7 percent below sales of the first half of 1989 when they totaled 340,000 units.

Chrysler Corp.'s second-quarter earnings dropped 47.2 percent compared with last year as incentives absorbed a huge chunk of profits, the automaker said. The results Tuesday, when combined with earnings reported last week by General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., showed profits for the Big Three tumbled 42.2 percent in the April-June quarter from last year.

A prestigious Dutch retailer announced it is buying FAO Schwarz, a venerable old American toy store chain known to generations of shoppers as the ultimate place to browse for playthings. The U.S. subsidiary of NV Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer (KBB) said Tuesday it will acquire the 17 stores operated by FAO Schwarz as well as its catalog business for an unannounced price. Officials disclosed few details of the deal with FAO Schwarz's present owners, an investment group that includes the chain's two highest ranking executives.

The House voted overwhelmingly to toughen criminal penalties for rip-offs by savings and loan officials and to create a special prosecutor and a national commission on the thrift industry scandal. The legislation was brought hastily to the full House so lawmakers could vote tough on S&L crime before they recess for the summer at week's end. It passed Tuesday 424-4. The bill would increase the maximum prison terms _ up to life in prison for the worst offenders _ and boost fines that could be levied against individuals and institutions convicted of savings and loan crimes.

Federal investigators spread blame for the Exxon Valdez oil spill far beyond the captain, accusing Exxon Corp. of operating tankers with reduced crews and too little rest and criticizing the Coast Guard for not cracking down. The National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday also criticized Capt. Joseph Hazelwood for leaving his third mate at the helm before the ship ran aground and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989.

UAL Corp. stock plunged amid speculation that reluctant lenders may force UAL employees to seek an extension of the Aug. 9 deadline for financing their $4.38 billion buyout of the airline company. The union-led employee group also might have to ask UAL's board and stockholders to accept less than the currently proposed $201 per share, analysts said. UAL tumbled $16.87{ to $140 a share Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, extending Monday's $6.12{-a-share drop as new reports circulated that banks might be balking at lending money for the proposed purchase of United Airlines' parent company.

The fund insuring Americans' $2.5 trillion in commercial bank deposits is under considerable stress and could suffer its third consecutive loss this year, a top regulator said. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said Tuesday ``it would not be unreasonable'' to predict a $2 billion loss, reducing the fund to around $11 billion. It lost $851 million in 1989 and $4.24 billion in 1988 as bank failures soared to post-Depresssion highs.

Fiat Group, Italy's largest industrial company, and Ford Motor Co. formed a joint venture to merge their agricultural subsidiaries into a new company controlled by Fiat. The move Tuesday further's Ford's goal of ridding its non-automotive operations. Last week, Ford announced it was entering final negotiations with the Loral Corp. of New York over the sale of Ford Aerospace Corp.

Interco Inc., the manufacturing firm that nearly destroyed itself by using junk bonds to fend off a hostile takeover attempt, apparently has solved its nagging debt woes and avoided bankruptcy court protection. The company, which owns Converse and Florsheim footwear companies along with furniture manufacturers Lane Co. and Broyhill Industries, announced a basic restructuring agreement with its creditors Tuesday.

Wall Street turned in a mixed performance Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 12.13 at 2,905.20 after fluctuating throughout the session and plunging nearly 39 points in the last half-hour of trading. The dollar extended its steep descent against major foreign currencies. Treasury bond prices were mixed. Platinum futures prices surged more than $10 an ounce; other precious metals were mixed; energy futures rose; livestock and meat futures advanced; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Growth, as in the Economy, Is Not a Dirty Word
Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: As the Federal Reserve's anti-inflation policy slows the economy to a crawl, even a standstill and maybe a reversal, the questions are becoming more numerous. Why, for example, do supporters of the Fed's go-slow policy believe that growth beyond 2.5 percent a year is inflationary, when it averaged nearly 4 percent a year with only 2.5 percent inflation in the 1950s and 1960s? And when, more recently, Japan's economy has consistently grown by 4.5 percent to 5 percent a year without severe inflationary side effects? Why do they believe that inflation threatens when the factory operating rate approaches 84 percent of capacity, when that was the norm in that same 20- year period? Why shouldn't growth be seen as the solution to economic problems, rather than a creator of them? Doesn't experience show that sustained growth would reduce indebtedness at all levels, raise exports, increase income? John Wright has been among those questioners, not just of recent policy, but of the Fed's policies over many years. He has written and lectured on the subject and has personally carried his views directly to the Fed officials. Growth, he says, is not a dirty word. ``This nation's policy makers need to realize that growth is not only good, it is also inherently non-inflationary,'' he says, adding but one qualification: ``So long as a reasonable share of it can be and is reinvested at reasonable capital costs in productive capacity.'' That is, so long as we the producers don't become just greedy consumers and eat up everything we grow but instead, like good potato farmers, put away some of the crop to continue seeding the farm. Wright is the founder of Wright Investors' Service, a Bridgeport, Conn., firm operating internationally in money management, financial advice and corporate and financial information. In an address prepared for the American Banker and Bond Buyer publications, Wright stated that again and again in the 1970s and '80s the Fed misread the causes of inflation, and then tried remedies that badly damaged the economy. Inflation during those years was largely ``cost-push,'' Wright said. It was ``imported'' inflation; price-factors such as OPEC oil were its cause. But the Fed, he said, misread it as domestic ``demand-pull'' inflation. The latter inflation, caused by demand that exceeded the economy's capacity to produce, is correctible by restricting the domestic money supply. The Fed did that _ for an inflation that simply didn't exist. The result of these restrictions, said Wright, were soaring interest rates and reduced production, which further exacerbated rising product costs. ``During this period, the Federal Reserve Board's failure to recognize the non-inflationary growth potential of the U.S. economy caused three significant recessions in the space of the 10 years 1973-1982,'' he stated. And with this result: ``The lost national income and foregone federal tax revenues which resulted produced the $100 billion federal budget deficits which have plagued the U.S. annually since 1982.'' Wright's message to the Fed: Please recognize that recession, not inflation, is the greater risk to the U.S. economy. Ease monetary policy. Do so quickly and significantly, breaking with the too-little-too-late Fed tradition. ``My prescription for the ailing U.S. economy is much lower interest rates,'' Wright said. Lower rates, he said, would spur growth, particularly for capital investments in plants and equipment. The Fed fears lower rates would spur inflationary demand. Wright says they underestimate the economy's potential. Increased investment, he reminds the Fed, could mean expanded supply as well as expanded demand. The production-consumption balance could be maintained, and inflation restrained. The economy could grow, jobs could be created, exports spurred, the balance of payments improved, tax revenues enhanced and debts repaid.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Slump Hits Hard, But Long-Term Effects Will Vary
DOC.TEXT: The computer industry's shift away from mid-sized machines to more powerful and popular small machines has led to dismal financial reports from computer companies here and cost thousands of jobs, analysts say. Nationally, computer sales have been in a slump, and the downturn has particularly damaged sales of companies that make mid-size computers. Massachusetts has suffered heavily by the new industry trends, especially several large manufacturers that focused on mid-size computers. Each company has tried to make adjustments, but the news of the last week reflects how difficult this transition can be. _Digital Equipment Corp. announced its first-ever quarterly loss last Wednesday and said it plans to cut up to 6,000 jobs in addition to a previous cutback of 3,000. _Data General Corp. reported its fifth consecutive quarterly loss Thursday. The company already has cut its workforce from a high of 18,000 employees several years ago to 11,710. A company spokesman said more reductions cannot be ruled out, although there are no such immediate plans. _Wang Laboratories Inc., which has been bleeding red ink for months, announced another losing quarter on Monday and said it expects to cut about 1,000 jobs. Overall, the company will have cut its payroll by more than 8,000 jobs since July 1, 1989, when Wang employed more than 28,000 people. Overall, Massachusetts has lost more than 23,000 high-tech manufacturing jobs since May 1988, according to state figures. As of May 1990, there were 215,300 high-tech jobs. Marc Schulman, a stock analyst at UBS Phillips & Drew, said the underlying cause of each company's trouble is the same _ the shift away from mid-size computers. ``But the position of the various companies is quite different,'' he said. For example, Digital has a strong presence as the world's second largest computer company, and has come out with many new products to be more consistent with the market. But Wang, which has slashed its costs and does not have as strong a presence, needs to boost its revenues, analysts said. ``Once you get behind the eight ball, it's hard to get out in front of it,'' Schulman said of Wang's future, adding that the company needs to find new markets. Wang is betting part of its future on image processing, a system allowing computers to store the actual images of documents. This technology can be used, for example, by insurance companies that want to keep copies of police reports on record. ``We view it as an emerging technology,'' said Frank Ryan, a Wang spokesman. ``We would hope it would explode, but I'm not sure it will. In actuality it will build.'' Wang officials believe they have ``turned the corner,'' and hope to show profits in the new fiscal year that began July 1. At Data General, officials have moved aggressively to shrink the company and market products to conform with industry standards _ a growing segment of the computer industry, said spokesman Ray Thomas. ``In a world of standards, you can achieve differentiation by being most attuned to the standards ... by being the most standard among standards,'' Thomas said. ``We believe we've taken the right steps toward structuring the company for the long term,'' he said. Digital has had a multi-faceted strategy, with a big push on making products that link together computers from other companies. ``All of our product lines have been refreshed,'' said Mark Steinkrauss, a Digital spokesman. Yet aside from adapting to changes within the computer market, companies must also contend with a soft national economy, which has made customers more apprehensive about making expensive purchases, Steinkrauss said. Eventually, the result of this transformation should be further consolidation within the industry, he said. ``Invariably, as there is growth, it attracts more players,'' he said. ``But demand is satisfied, and then a shakeout occurs.''

DOC.HEAD: In the Fight for Convention Business, the Unconventional Rules
DOC.TEXT: Watch people play in the sand. Get your picture taken with Minnie Mouse. Knock the eight ball into the pocket with a billiards champ. In the frantic competition to lure convention business, the pitches are anything but conventional. Everything from a 9-ton sand castle to women in harem costumes from the Trump Taj Mahal are on display through today at the 70th annual meeting of the American Society of Association Executives, the people who decide where associations hold their annual meetings. At stake is $30 billion a year in business. Hundreds of convention bureaus, hotels, airlines and tourist attractions from around the world are wooing the meeting planners at Chicago's McCormick Place. San Diego's exhibit drew a small crowd of executives who watched two people mold 9 tons of sand into a huge castle, with a koala bear and elephant sculpted on one side to represent the San Diego Zoo. The exhibit succeeds at what seems to be the main point of many of the exhibits _ keeping a captive audience. ``We have people coming back four, five and six times to see how the sand sculpture is progressing. It's a real draw,'' said Kelly Nelson, national sales manager for the San Diego Convention and Visitors Bureau. At the Miami exhibit, meeting planners were drawn by eels and rays and colorful fish in two huge aquariums. The fish tanks were set amid lush tropical greenery and posh furniture in a small building set up within the convention center. A tuxedo-clad piano player performed in a corner while executives relaxed on couches or wandered to the fish tanks. The building alone cost $180,000, said Merret Stierheim, president of the Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau. ``It is not an inexpensive sales method,'' Stierheim said. But given that visitors spend $5.7 billion in Miami each year, he said, ``This is worth it.'' A few rows over, the lobby of a Hilton Hotel was partly recreated in a two-story exhibit complete with two curved staircases. A uniformed maid rushed out periodically to wipe fingerprints off the brass handrails. ``We wanted to make a statement,'' said Bob Moore, senior vice president of sales at Hilton Hotels Corp., which has been toting the $125,000 display around the country for four years. The Milwaukee Convention and Visitors Bureau lured executives with the chance to challenge Steve Mizerak, Billiard Hall of Fame member and former world pocket billiards champion. Crowds gathered as one executive after another challenged Mizerak and lost, only to be replaced by another. ``Then, while the customers are waiting, we start talking to them,'' said Dave Nolan, Milwaukee bureau president. Many meeting planners said they decided their convention sites before seeing the exhibits. And few of the exhibitors were sure how many gawkers would actually sign up for a meeting. But that didn't cool the warmth of their welcomes. Executives visiting the Birmingham, England, booth were invited to sit down for tea and scones. At the Walt Disney Co. exhibit, convention-goers stopped and smiled for souvenir pictures with Minnie and Mickey Mouse. And there were smiles, too, at the Pittsburgh booth, as meeting planners were handed 2-ounce bottles of Heinz Ketchup. Debra Smucker, national sales director for the Greater Pittsburgh Convention and Visitors Bureau, said she touts the city's compact downtown and central location. But first she warms up her audience with gifts of ketchup and tiny, green pickle-shaped pins bearing the logo of Pittsburgh-based H.J. Heinz Co. ``Its a good opportunity to stop people as they go by,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Change Pigs' Diet, Reduce Saturated Fat Ratio in Meat
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say they have taken another step toward ``designer pigs'' for health-conscious consumers by creating lean pork with less saturated fat than today's cuts. The key is the diet of hogs, who are fed whole soybeans cooked in a special processor known as an extruder, said scientists at the University of Illinois and the Harlan E. Moore Heart Research Foundation. The unusual feed ingredient produced pork with a significantly higher ratio of polyunsaturated to saturated fat: a 50 percent improvement in pork chops and a 100 percent improvement in bacon. ``We can produce healthier pork and do it in an economical way,'' said Dennis Leszczynski, a dietician and food scientist at the heart foundation in Champaign. ``And there are no important differences in animal performance, meat taste, texture, processing or storage.'' Peter Bechtel, a University of Illinois meat scientist who worked with Leszczynski on the project, prepared a report on the findings for today's meeting of the American Society of Animal Science in Ames, Iowa. ``Pigs are like humans. We're all a product of the kind of fat we eat,'' Bechtel said. ``So, we change the ratio of polyunsaturated fat in the pork by altering the fat that goes in the hogs.'' Because the final product may cost more to produce, the researchers said, farmers must sell processors and consumers on the health value of their new pork to justify a higher price. Leszczynski said farmers have had few incentives to deliver a leaner hog to market. The price often has been based only on live weight. Bechtel said some processors now are paying a premium to farmers who deliver lean pigs. ``The key is testing the market to see how much the consumer is willing to pay for healthier pork,'' said Leszczynski. The American Heart Association says the ratio of polyunsaturated fat to saturated fat should be 1-to-1, said Leszczynski. He said feeding extruded soybeans improved the ratio from .28-to-1 to .43-to-1 in pork chops and from .25-to-1 to .50-to-1 in bacon. Though the pork ration improved, it still is not the .83-to-1 ratio found in a lean chicken breast. ``We're getting closer,'' Leszczynski said. ``The challenge now is to see how much higher we can go without adversely affecting the meat quality or the economics.'' The study involved 160 pigs. Some had a diet that included 20 percent extruded soubeans for the six weeks before slaughter. Conventional hog rations contain corn and soybean meal. The scientists substituted the extruded whole soybeans for the meal in an effort to retain soy oil which is relatively high in polyunsaturated fat. Research at the International Soybean Program at the University of Illinois has shown that extrusion not only leaves the oil in the final product but that it also destroys the natural digestive inhibitors in soybeans. Bechtel said most Illinois farmers already have soybeans. An extruder could cost about $8,000 and could be shared by a group of farmers. ``Why couldn't a farmer take his soybeans, have a little extruder and feed them directly to his pigs instead of selling the beans to a processor and buying back the meal?'' Bechtel said. ``Producing this kind of pork is an economic possibility.'' Some pork producers already deliver leaner animals to market by selecting breeds with less fat and by slaughtering them before they get too heavy. That process has created pork cuts that are 97 percent lean. Bechtel said his project indicated the composition of the remaining fat could be improved. ``Now we're talking about custom-made pork _ designer pigs,'' he said. ``They won't all be alike anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Spreads Out Blame For Biggest Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts grafs 1-4. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials insist that the Exxon Valdez captain was drunk at the time of the Alaskan oil spill. They also blame his third mate, the company that hired them, the Coast Guard and port authorities for the disaster. Despite Capt. Joseph Hazelwood's acquittal by an Alaskan jury and the Coast Guard's dismissal last week of drunkenness charges against him, the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday that his drinking was part of the probable cause of the nation's worst oil spill. Board members said the Coast Guard needs to develop a more efficient system to monitor and control boat traffic in critical areas. ``One of the lessons of this accident is that if we had a good vessel traffic system, it probably would not have happened,'' said board member Jim Burnett. ``The same or worse results are possible in one of our other ports. I think it's a tragedy that we've had this wholesale neglect of the vessel traffic system.'' But the board also cited Exxon Corp. for failing to provide its biggest oil tanker with ``a fit master and a rested and sufficient crew.'' And it said third mate Gregory Cousins failed to properly maneuver the vessel after he was left at the helm, the Coast Guard failed to control traffic in the ice-clogged sound and the state of Alaska failed to provide an effective pilot's service to guide ships out of the sound. The board voted 4-0 to adopt the five-part probable cause and a long list of conclusions and recommendations resulting from the March 29, 1989, spill of 11 million gallons into Prince William Sound. ``The probable cause reflects the decision of the board that in addition to the alcohol impairment of the ship's master, there are safety issues of equal importance,'' said Burnett. Board Chairman James Kolstad said the NTSB hopes its report, which included 36 safety recommendations, will help prevent future spills. The board's analyses carry no force of law and, by statute, cannot be used in court cases. But they often serves as guidelines for congressional, administrative and private action. Hazelwood's lawyer, Thomas Russo, said the safety board members acted ``like they dropped off the moon'' in again accusing Hazelwood of being drunk. Twenty-one witnesses at Hazelwood's trial testified that he was sober, Russo said, and authorities botched the blood tests showing alcohol in his system more than 10 hours after the accident. ``Their conclusions are not founded in the evidence,'' Russo said. The board said eyewitnesses, medical tests and an unusual study of Hazelwood's speech indicated he was drunk when the ship ran aground. Medical investigator Merritt Birky said calculations based on blood tests of Hazelwood show that he would have had a blood alcohol content of .2 percent at the time of the grounding, which is five times the legal intoxication level under Coast Guard rules. Birky said he believes Hazelwood's alcohol level shows he probably was drinking on board, which is against Exxon rules. Hazelwood denies drinking on board, although he has admitted drinking prior to boarding the vessel. He is appealing a conviction in Alaska of one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil for which he was fined $50,000 and ordered to spend 1,000 hours cleaning Alaskan beaches. Last week, the Coast Guard dismissed charges of drunkenness and misconduct against Hazelwood but suspended his license as a ship's master for nine months after he pleaded no contest to breaking rules involving drinking alcohol prior to duty and leaving the bridge. ``This is the largest and costliest accident the safety board has ever investigated,'' Kolstad said in opening the meeting. He said $2 billion had been spent cleaning up the spill. Investigators also raised concerns about Hazelwood's attempts to move the vessel off the reef as it was spilling oil, saying it could have caused greater problems. ``He was going into an unknown area where he couldn't have known whether it would remain upright or capsize,'' said chief investigator William Woody.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainment Giant Unveils Plans for Ocean Theme Park
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co. has unveiled its master plan for a 350-acre, $2-billion oceanside resort and theme park in Long Beach with everything from five luxury hotels to the world's biggest aquarium. The Port Disney resort would also lure travelers to a pair of transportation relics owned by the entertainment giant _ the Queen Mary and the Spruce Goose museum pieces. Burbank-based Disney wants to build another theme park either in Long Beach or adjacent to Disneyland in Anaheim. ``Disney is committed to building a second major theme park in Southern California,'' Alan Epstein, vice president of Disney Development Co., said Tuesday. The 70-page preliminary plan was submitted to Long Beach officials in compliance with existing agreements. There are also discussions with the city of Anaheim and a location decision isn't expected until next year. Epstein said a final decision will be ``based on community support, government approvals, public sector participation, and theme park and resort economics.'' Some Long Beach residents expressed unhappiness over the proposal, citing transportation woes and the potential for overbearing political and economic clout on the part of Disney. They also object to spending taxpayer dollars to help Disney. ``Why in the world would we want to give money to a company that has more money than they know what to do with?'' said Karen Pilcher, president of the Rose Park Neighborhood Group. But city officials say Long Beach needs the money Disney will bring. ``The residents should take an active part, and I applaud their concern. But we should be careful to keep our eye on the bull's-eye,'' said Councilman Wallace Edgerton. ``To solve problems like crime, traffic or the needs of the poor, it takes money. And that's the bottom line: Disney will bring money to this city.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were higher at midday Wednesday on London's Stock Exchange, helped by gains in oil shares. Much of the gains could be attributed to the oil sector, which has been active amid the increasing tension on the border between Iraq and Kuwait, dealers said. The market was generally quiet, however, with little news to spark interest, traders said. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 13.3 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,339.5. Volume came to 237.8 million shares at midday, compared with 176.7 million shares at the same time Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Housing Markets Hinder People On the Move
DOC.TEXT: In these days of sluggish real estate markets, the always-dicey process of selling one home and buying another can be especially hard on one's peace of mind. Even under the best of circumstances this kind of deal takes fast footwork, a bit like trying to step from one moving boat to the other without falling into the water. Now, thanks to gluts in many local markets around the country, it may be easier than ever to get stuck with two properties and two mortgage commitments _the new one you just acquired and the old one you can't unload. The risk is compounded by the tax laws, which let you defer capital gains tax on any profit from your old home only if you reinvest the money in your new place within a specified time. The rule, as summed up by the accounting firm of Ernst & Young in the 1990 Arthur Young Tax Guide: ``You must buy, or build, and live in another house within two years before or two years after the date of sale of your old home to postpone the tax.'' As they are wont to do in such matters, the authorities have construed this language strictly, rejecting virtually all pleas for exceptions no matter how good the excuse. Was construction of the new home unavoidably delayed by fire, bad weather, zoning dispute or other circumstance beyond your control? Sorry. ``What is more, the house must be substantially complete when you move in,'' points out the Personal Tax Adviser published by another big accounting firm, Price Waterhouse. ``You cannot pitch a tent on the foundation and claim you occupy your new home.'' In view of this, Price Waterhouse recommends, ``include a clause in your construction contract that calls for your contractor to pay any taxes you owe if construction is delayed beyond the 24-month limit.'' On the other hand, if the new house is bought and occupied but the old one won't sell, it may be hard to find anybody to take the tax burden off your shoulders. As Deloitte & Touche accountants put it in a current report on the subject: ``in a slow real estate market a timing problem may develop.'' One way to try to forestall this problem is to get a solid buyer signed up for the old home before you commit yourself to buy a new one, if it's possible to manage the sequence that way. If you can't follow that script, the experts say you still may have a couple of fallback positions when an old home goes begging for buyers. Maybe, suggests Deloitte & Touche, you can sell it to a friendly but separate entity such as an incorporated business you own or an employer that is transferring you. ``The sale must be bona fide and entered into on an arm's-length basis,'' the firm cautions. Alternatively, suppose you must rent your old house for a while until you sell it, in order to keep your cash flow from running dry. Have you converted the home into a rental property that isn't eligible for tax deferral when you sell it? No, you may still get the break, the experts say, as long as you meet the other requirements. Says Price Waterhouse: ``The courts have ruled that temporarily renting out your old house because of a depressed real estate market will not prevent you from deferring your gain.''

DOC.HEAD: More Manufacturers Selling Their Own Stuff, So Who Needs Department Stores?
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Vacationers bound for summer getaways will notice something has happened to out-of-the-way tourist spots. Many have become miniature shopping meccas catering to devoted bargain seekers. Clusters of shops carrying discounted designer duds have sprouted up all over the country. More manufacturers whose wares are normally peddled by mainstream retailers are striking out on their own. Outlet complexes are thriving in areas frequented by tourists, who have the time to browse for good buys. Busloads of pricewise shoppers regularly pour in. Elsewhere, outlets grouped near major thoroughfares are catching the attention of passers-by. The trend has ominous implications for traditional retailing. It won't run all regular stores out of business. But it does mean more competition in a saturated industry already fraught with fierce battling for market share. Sales at outlets are growing faster than general retail revenues, although they still account for a small portion of retailing. Outlets generated nearly $6 billion in sales last year, according to Value Retail News, a Clearwater, Fla.-based publication that tracks the industry. By contrast, a single retailer, industry biggie Sears, Roebuck and Co., alone had 1989 sales of over $30 billion. ``People like the excitement of shopping in a factory outlet. They like the prices,'' says Lynn Ellsworth, president of Company Stores Development Corp., a Brentwood, Tenn.-based builder of outlet malls and a pioneer in the field. Manufacturers have several incentives to sell directly to consumers. It allows them to control the process of getting rid of leftovers rather than risk problems that can crop up when they unload merchandise on liquidators. Close-out chains and off-price merchants _ which absorb excess apparel and sell it at discount _ often compete for customers with nearby department stores and other regular retailers. Manufacturers usually make sure their own outlets are far away from major shopping hubs so they don't jeopardize sales of their labels selling at full-price stores or upset relations with retailers, their primary customers. ``We purposely stay away from traditional retailers,'' notes Benard Holtzman, president of apparel designer Harve Benard Ltd. Clothing companies, accessory makers and others that go into retailing must tred carefully. The last thing they want is for outlet customers to return home gloating to their local retailer about the great deal they got. Women's apparel powerhouse Liz Claiborne Inc. has located its 22 outlet stores 45 minutes to an hour away from regular retailers selling its label. Ritzy Ralph Lauren's lines are sold at discount outlets deliberately situated 90 miles to 120 miles away from places where the Polo collection is sold in full-price, company-owned boutiques and department stores. Nevertheless, the issue is so touchy that manufacturers don't exactly go out of their way to publicize their involvement in the outlet business. Some even disguise their name, meaning customers can't tell who owns an outlet. Pricy Izod-Lacoste sportswear is sold at outlets called Fashion Flair, for instance. Irked by the trend, the National Shoe Retailers Association recently adopted a resolution expressing disapproval of the proliferation of company-owned factory outlets. Independent shoe retailers are up in arms because, they say, manufacturers are bypassing them in channeling merchandise to outlets. Association President Bill Boettge said the group believes independent shoe sellers are being treated unfairly. He said the group isn't trying to start a national boycott but some association members are refusing to carry merchandise of manufacturers that operate their own outlets. From a manufacturer's point of view, it makes good business sense to look for new channels of distribution. Upheaval in the retail industry, intensifed by the bankruptcy filings of big name chains, including the parent companies of Bloomingdale's, The Bon Marche, Lazarus and others, has made manufacturers nervous about depending on department stores to market merchandise. No longer mere havens for fashion has-beens, manufacturers increasingly use their factory outlets to showcase merchandise. Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. reportedly does half its business in its own outlets, marketing Van Heusen Shirts and shoes from its G.H. Bass & Co. division. Commercial developers say projects involving outlets tend to get financial backing more easily in these tight money days than construction of traditional retail centers. Although lenders have tightened up their practices after the savings and loan debacle, they're still willing to support sound deals. Conventional retailers may be on the ropes but factory outlets look like they're on stable ground, according to Richard Echikson, chairman of Millburn, N.J.-based Retail Consultants Inc., which helps clients assess potential retail investments. ``There is an increasing interest in the financial community and development community in true factory outlet malls,'' says Echikson. With financial backing, an increasing number of outlets has gone upscale, offering entertainment and other amenities. The Woodbury Common in Central Valley, N.Y., for instance, recreates a village setting. Malls are growing bigger, too. Benderson Development Co., out of Buffalo, N.Y., plans to open what it claims will be the world's largest manufacturers' outlet mall late next year in downtown Niagara Falls. Not all outlets are in the middle of nowhere or even near prime tourist attractions. Many outlets have been moving closer to metropolitan areas as more manufacturers get into the act. According to Value Retail News, the number of outlet chains has mushroomed, and last year more were opened than ever before in a single year. By the middle of this year, there were about 350 chains in operation, up from 264 at the start of 1989. The popularity is expected to continue as consumers save more of their incomes than they did during the free-spending '80s. Aging baby boomers are keen on bargains now that they are tucking away spare dollars for their tots' educations. Charles Bloom, chairman of the Chelsea Group, a New Jersey-based developer, owner and operator of factory outlet shopping centers, says the concept complements traditional retailing and will never supplant it. ``Without retail, there is no wholesale,'' he notes. ``You couldn't buy a bargain if it wasn't selling for a higher price somewhere else.''

DOC.HEAD: Pistner Hopes His Turnaround Techniques Work at Ames
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: They call him ``Mr. Turnaround,'' a wonderboy who rescues sinking retailers, then moves on to the next hopeless case. But as the new chief executive officer of Ames Department Stores Inc., Stephen L. Pistner faces his most formidable challenge yet: leading the nation's fourth largest retailer out of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. If he pulls it off, his reward could amount to a tidy $9 million _ $1.5 million a year in salary for three years, plus incentives worth $4.5 million. Pistner (pronounced pize-ner), a man known as much for his robust ego as for his retail savvy, says he's worth every penny. ``I know that I'm highly paid and I know people can't really relate to that, but for those of us who can save a $5 billion company, for those stockholders and banks, this is a bargain,'' said the 58-year-old Pistner, his voice and face becoming animated. Pistner already has engineered remarkable recoveries at both Target Stores and Montgomery Ward & Co., analysts said. There's also the McCrory Corp. of New York, operator of a large chain of variety stores, where he's credited with interjecting new merchandising ideas into an already successful formula. Pistner's taste for adventure extends to off-hour hobbies like flying, sailing and white-water canoeing. His more refined interests include collecting art, ancient glass and antique cars. He took the helm at Ames April 30, five days after the retailer, listing $1.4 billion in liabilities and cut off by its major suppliers, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws. Much of the chain's troubles have been blamed on its $778 million acquisition of 392 Zayre stores in 1988. Pistner's first three months on the job have shown a true-to-form Pistner doing what he does best: mercilessly shedding unprofitable operations and replacing top managers with new blood. He is now in the process of closing 221 stores _ about one-third of the chain's 679 stores _ a move that will cut 18,000 workers and streamline the now-rambling Ames into a Northeast corridor chain. Pistner pioneered the concept of ``power departments'' _ stores within stores that specialize in specific kinds of merchandise, like clothing or major appliances. For all of his salesmanship finesse, Pistner also has a reputation for a brash, impersonal management style that has alienated both top brass and sales clerks. At Ames, he already has named a ``chairman's shopper'' to rove around Ames stores incognito and snitch on employees who are not treating customers well. ``He's in a hurry. He doesn't have time or much tolerance for ignorance,'' said Norman McMillan, a Chicago retail consultant who worked with Pistner at both Target and Montgomery Ward. Another consultant who has known Pistner for years said, ``His attitude is, if you're not with him, you're against him, and he'll trample right over you.'' Pistner's roots in retailing go back to 1953, when he started as a salesman in St. Paul, Minn., for a small electronics company. He worked his way up and eventually bought the company. In 1970, Pistner sold the business to Dayton-Hudson Corp., the Minneapolis-based retailer. Three years later, Dayton-Hudson picked Pistner to take over the helm at its Target stores, which had been a big money-loser for years. Under Pistner, Target's profits soared within a few years as the chain became the first so-called ``upscale discounter,'' stores with well-known brand names and trendy interior designs to compete with department stores. Target is now the nation's third-largest discounter, after K mart and Wal-Mart. After his success with the Target chain, Pistner was named president and chief operating officer of Dayton-Hudson in 1977. He left four years later to take on another daunting task _ rescuing Montgomery Ward, a struggling unit of Mobil Oil Corp. Mobil had lost about $600 million on the retailer in its 10 years as owner. Under Pistner, Montgomery Ward closed 50 stores, upgraded the quality of the remaining 375 outlets, and focused on its more-successful products. Within two years, Mobil turned a $40 million profit, its first since 1979. Pistner left Montgomery Ward in 1985 to become chairman of McCrory. He left the company in 1988 for undisclosed reasons. Some analysts say he and owner Meshulam Riklis _ both forceful men with powerful egos _ were unable to work together well. Pistner has never tackled a company in bankruptcy proceedings and some analysts give him only a 50-50 chance of saving Ames. ``He's highly regarded in the field, but the question is, is the situation so far gone that it would be impossible for any human being to fix this scrambled egg?'' said Alan Millstein, a New York publisher of a monthly newsletter for retailers. Pistner doesn't share such doubts. ``I have rebuilt, reconstructed and redefined almost every retail business,'' he said. ``When there's a problem, I know how to repair it.''

DOC.HEAD: Computer Giant Forming New Company for Low-Tech Businesses; Job Cuts Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines previous files, ADDS 1 new graf to include stock price after 4th graf pvs `IBM spokesman ...' Picks up pvs 5th graf `The new ...
DOC.TEXT: Computer giant IBM today said it will form a new subsidiary for its U.S. typewriter, keyboard and some printer businesses and intends the buyout firm Clayton & Dubilier Inc. to become the unit's majority owner. An announcement released from the Armonk, N.Y. headquarters of International Business Machines Corp. said a plan is being studied to include the remainder of its worldwide information products business in the alliance with Clayton & Dubilier. The announcement didn't contain any financial details of the planned arrangements with Clayton & Dubilier. Published reports have estimated that a buyout of the IBM businesses could cost about $2.5 billion. IBM spokesman Glenn Rossman said negotiations on a final agreement are expected to conclude by the end of the year. Until then, no information will be disclosed on how much Clayton & Dubilier will pay IBM or what size stake it will acquire, he said. Wall Street took the announcement in stride because there has been widespread publicity about IBM's possible intention to reconfigure itself. IBM stock gained 12{ cents to $111.87{ in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The new U.S. company, made up mainly of IBM's information products business operations in Lexington, Ky., and Boulder, Colo., is expected to reduce the current work force by 1,200. By the end of the year, the company will have 3,500 to 4,000 employees, IBM said. IBM Vice President Marvin L. Mann will become the chief executive officer of the new company. Mann said making the information products operation a stand-alone business will enable it to concentrate its resources on expanding sales. ``We intend to increase our investment on advertising and promotion, greatly improve our dealer support programs and incorporate a sales force with information products as its only priority,'' he said. Steps are being taken to assure that employees are treated fairly, he said. Clayton & Dubilier Chairman Martin H. Dubilier said: ``Our intention would be to build on IBM's reputation for quality and performance, while developing more aggressive long-term growth strategies for new business.'' Clayton & Dubilier has had experience in businesses at the low end of technology. Since the firm was formed in 1978, it has made 15 acquisitions with combined sales of $7.5 billion. The New York-based buyout firm has made it a policy to avoid unfriendly maneuvers, preferring to work in partnership with the management of the businesses it acquires. IBM said it will maintain an equity holding in the new company. The corporation will continue to market selected printer products made by the new company under the IBM name and will provide service for all printers. The new company will provide typewriters, intermediate and personal printers and supplies with the IBM logo through authorized dealers and other channels in the United States. The work force reductions envisioned for the new company will be accomplished through a program of voluntary resignation and early retirement. Eligible employees in Lexington will be offered the opportunity to resign, retire or begin a five-year pre-retirement leave with incentive payments, IBM said. Rossman said the program will be consistent with IBM's long-standing policies regarding work force reduction. The formation of the new company is part of IBM's strategy to sharpen its focus to concentrate on its computer and software business. IBM Chairman John F. Akers said the action ``further advances IBM's transformation'' and puts the information products division into a better position to grow in the future. ``The new company will enable us to reduce overhead and more efficiently allocate our resources to strengthen both the subsidiary and IBM as a whole,'' Akers said.
