DOC.HEAD: Mahlmann Quits Stotler
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Mahlmann resigning from Stotler, conforming editing changes; Picks up 11th graf: Meanwhile, the ...
DOC.TEXT: Karsten Mahlmann, chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today he has resigned as head of a financially battered commodities firm that operates a subsidiary accused of violating the Commodity Exchange Act. In a letter to members of the Board of Trade, Mahlmann said his resignation as chairman of Stotler Group and Stotler and Co. was effective at noon Tuesday. Mahlmann said he has no plans to step down as chairman of the Board of Trade. In the letter, he said he ``simply was not a party to the financial decisions (at Stotler) which are now being scrutinized by the exchange and the regulators.'' ``I have had no day-to-day management responsibilities (at Stotler) since early 1988, and my position at Stotler was constantly eroded,'' Mahlmann said. Mahlmann said had he been aware of Stotler's recent financial decisions, ``I would not have condoned them, and I would have taken action to reverse them.'' He said he remains Stotler Group's largest shareholder. His resignation comes a day after federal regulators filed a civil complaint accusing a Stotler subsidiary of violating the Commodity Exchange Act. Filed in U.S. District Court by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the complaint names Stotler Funds Inc., a commodity pool operator owned by Stotler Group. Stotler and Co., a futures brokerage and the group's principal subsidiary, has withdrawn from the futures business because of shaky finances. In its complaint, the government said Stotler Funds improperly used pools of clients' money which had been set up for investing in commodity futures contracts. The CFTC said Stotler Funds instead used about 80 percent of one pool's assets _ about $4.55 million _ to invest in Stotler Group. In addition, Stotler Funds lent $1 million from another pool to its parent company. Stotler Funds' use of pool assets in this way ``operated as a fraud or deceit on clients or participants ... in violation of the Commodity Exchange Act,'' the regulators contended. The complaint seeks a court order to stop these practices and the appointment of a temporary equity receiver. The Chicago Tribune reported that hundreds of investors in the pools _ called Compass and Advanced Portfolio Management _ were notified Monday in a letter from Stotler that the holding company had defaulted on the two deals and that henceforth, the two pools no longer would do business with the parent. In a letter from Thomas Kolter, Stotler Group's general counsel, participants in APM and Compass also were told that because of the defaults, the investors wouldn't be allowed to redeem their shares in the pools for the time being, the Tribune reported. Mahlmann and Stotler officials did not return telephone calls today. Meanwhile, the Board of Trade announced that its board of directors had voted to give Mahlmann a vote of confidence as chairman of the exchange despite the problems with his futures brokerage. ``In recognition of his commitment to the Board of Trade, the Board of Directors fully and unanimously expressed its confidence in Karsten Mahlmann as Chairman,'' the exchange said in a statement outlining action take at a special meeting Monday. It said the special session was called so that the board could be briefed by the exchange's Business Conduct Committee, which has been reviewing the situation with Stotler.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Remain Unchanged in June
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 new grafs after 3rd graf pvs, But while ... to include construction spending. Picks up 4th graf pvs, If the ...
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge was unchanged in June, the Commerce Department reported today, suggesting sluggish growth _ but no recession _ for the remainder of the year. The Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, had risen a revised 0.7 percent in May, not quite as strong as the 0.8 percent gain first reported last month. But while the index did not advance in June, it escaped a decline. In the past, three consecutive declines sometimes _ but not always _ have signaled a forthcoming recession. In another economic report, the government said today that construction spending was flat in June after two consecutive monthly declines. The report pointed to further evidence of weakness in the building industry. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $447.5 billion. If the economy continues to grow through November, it will reach its eighth year of expansion following the last recession. It already is in the longest peacetime expansion in U.S. history, but has slowed noticeably in recent quarters. In advance of today's report, a consensus of economists had expected a 0.2 percent gain in June. Only four of the forward-looking components were positive. They were an increase in the price of raw materials, higher stock prices, an increase in building permits and slower business delivery times. On the other hand, six were negative: a drop in manufacturers' unfilled orders, a smaller amount of orders for consumer goods, a decline in the money supply, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence, a decrease in orders for new plants and equipment and an increase in weekly unemployment claims. One indicator, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 146.0 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and up 1.4 percent from its level a year ago. The index was unchanged in January and then fell twice and rose twice in subsequent months. Many economists contend that such a choppy performance is characteristic of continuing economic weakness. The Commerce Department reported last Friday that the gross national product, which measures the nation's total output of goods and services, inched ahead 1.2 percent at an annual rate in the second quarter. It revised economic growth from January through March down to 1.7 percent from 1.9 percent and said the GNP edged up a barely perceptible 0.3 percent annual rate in the last quarter of 1989. That was far below the 1.1 percent previous estimate. In fact, the department said growth in all of 1989 rose just 2.5 percent, the weakest performance since a decline of 2.5 percent in the recession year of 1982. ``The economy is as close to recession as possible without formally being in one,'' economists at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets wrote in their current Weekly Economic & Financial Commentary following the GNP report. Virtually every segment of the GNP showed weakness in the second quarter, including consumer spending, which has fueled much of the nearly eight years of economic expansion since the 1981-82 recession. But Commerce reported on Monday that personal consumption, which accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, rose 1.0 percent in June after being flat in May and showing weak growth in earlier months. This led some analysts to say consumers were continuing to keep the economy out of recession, usually defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth. DRI-McGraw Hill, a Massachusetts forecasting firm, said in its current summary that ``consumers shifted to a lower gear this winter _ but not into reverse.'' Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist for Fuji Securities Inc., noted in the current issue of the securities dealer's Perspectives that the leading index ``has slipped at the modest pace of 0.1 percent per month since early 1989. ``Its performance foreshadows further sluggish economic growth, but it does not portend recession,'' he wrote. The Bush administration revised its GNP forecast last week to 2 percent growth for the year. This would require growth to accelerate to a 2.9 percent rate in the last half of 1990 _ a feat some analysts doubt will occur. ``Economic growth has been less than 2 percent for five consecutive quarters,'' the Merrill Lynch economists noted. ``Our forecast calls for three more quarters of GNP growth under 2 percent.''

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Up Sharply In Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. said Wednesday its earnings rose nearly fivefold in the second quarter from results that were depressed by a large restructuring charge a year ago. The photographic giant earned $384 million, or $1.19 per share, for the second quarter, compared with $77 million, or 24 cents per share, in the same quarter last year. The 1989 results were reduced by $227 million due to restructuring costs. The company said excluding the charge, its profit was up 26 percent from $304 million, or 94 cents per share, in 1989. It was the first quarterly earnings increase for the company since 1988. Sales for the quarter were up 2 percent to $4.87 billion from $4.77 billion in 1989. The 1989 results were restated to reflect Kodak's conversion from a 13-week to a 12-month calendar, effective Jan. 1. ``Despite the sluggish U.S. economy, revenues continued at high levels and prices held firm overall,'' Kodak Chairman and Chief Executive Kay R. Whitmore said. ``Costs are being carefully controlled, especially in photosensitive manufacturing. In addition, we saw somewhat sooner than expected the benefits of actions initiated in 1989 to sharpen our focus on value-adding parts of the business.'' As part of the restructuring, Kodak sold or consolidated about 20 businesses and eliminated 7,500 jobs worldwide, most through voluntary separation and attrition. Whitmore said operations ran ahead of predictions for the quarter and half year. ``Barring unexpected developments in the general economy or dramatic changes in currency valuations, we look forward to continued recovery in Kodak earnings and to a strong second-half performance,'' he said. Industry analyst Brenda Landry of Morgan Stanley in New York said, the results were better than Wall Street had expected. Landry said she was revising her estimate for Kodak's 1990 earnings to $3.95 per share from $3.75. ``The numbers came in nearly 20 percent better on the bottom line than we forecast,'' said David Nelson of Shearson Lehman Hutton. ``We believe that the fundamentals look better and the margins will be higher throughout the course of the year.'' Earnings rose in the imaging, information and health segments of the company and dropped in the chemicals segment. Whitmore said the chemicals earnings were ``considerably better than expected.'' Earnings for the first half of 1990 were $583 million, or $1.80 per share, up from $289 million, or 89 cents per share, after restructing costs. Without the restructuring charge, first-half earnings last year were $516 million, or $1.59 per share. First-half revenue edged up to $8.983 billion from $8.977 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. A strong cash market for soybeans continued to lend strength to near-term soybean futures, analysts said. Reports of record cold temperatures overnight in the eastern Midwest also supported soybeans. But forecasts for a warm-up in the region prompted light selling in the corn market amid perceptions that higher temperatures will speed up corn crop development, which is lagging behind the normal pace. Trading activity is expected to grow more cautious in advance of the Agriculture Department's Aug. 9 crop report, which will include corn and soybean production estimates. DOC.HEAD: Congress Seeks Ways to Help Defense Cut, Clean Air, Spotted Owl Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 10 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony; picks up 8th graf pvs., The measure ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government should give special help to workers who lost their jobs because of policies on clean air, protecting the spotted owl and cutting defense, lawmakers said today. ``As important as it is to reduce defense expenditures and to increase our drive to protect the natural environment, it is also important that we make every effort not to do so at the expense of American workers and their families,'' said Rep. Pete Stark, D-Calif. Stark, who spoke before the House Ways and Means human resources subcommittee, is cosponsor with Rep. Thomas Downey, D.-N.Y., of a proposal to provide cash benefits to workers who lost their jobs due to new environmental or military spending policies. The Bush administration opposes the legislation, saying that unemployment benefits should be the same for everyone. ``It is unnecessary, would duplicate existing adjustment programs, and would be inequitable in its treatment of workers,'' said James Van Erden, a Labor Department official. The legislation is only the latest in a deepening pile of proposals to help workers displaced by government actions, and the ideas are gaining supporters from across the country. ``What we need is a bold new initiative on the level of a domestic Marshall Plan for American workers and industries in transition,'' Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., told the subcommittee. ``Whether it is a timber community in western Washington state, a coal mining community in the hills of West Virginia, or a town or city located near a military base or defense facility,'' Adams said, ``the federal response should adequately reflect the degree of federal responsibility for the change being inflicted on local jobs and local workers.'' Adams' comments came in response to one of the broadest of several proposals designed to cushion the blow of federal policy changes on workers. The Downey-Stark proposal would provide cash and health insurance benefits to workers displaced because of military base closings, defense procurement cuts, changes in the Clean Air Act or enforcement of the Endangered Species Act. The measure would affect everyone from decommissioned military officers to B-2 bomber technicians and from coal miners to loggers. Estimates are that the so-called Downey-Stark amendment could cost more than $5 billion over five years. Sens. Joseph Lieberman and Christopher Dodd, both Connecticut Democrats, proposed legislation last week that would cost about $1 billion a year and would include a provision ensuring that laid-off defense workers get at least a substantial fraction of their former salaries while unemployed. A House proposal designed to ease the burden of defense cuts would cost an estimated $200 million a year. The political momentum of such bills has increased considerably since March when the Senate narrowly rejected a proposal by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va. That plan would have provided hefty unemployment benefits to coal miners laid off due to declining demand for coal amid rising factory emission requirements. The Byrd bill would have benefited a narrow pocket of workers _ largely in West Virginia. But now, with new measures to protect timber country inhabited by the rare spotted owl, and with defense spending declining under congressional pressure, the number of workers affected by federal action and the regions involved have grown dramatically. ``The Byrd amendment was a much bigger entitlement and a much smaller population _ which was the problem,'' said William Cunningham, a lobbyist for the AFL-CIO. ``This is not geographic. ``It is actually governmental actions that are causing these job dislocations. The number of regions involved have to be taken into account.''

DOC.BYLINE: Advertisers Catching on as Baby Boomers Mature? ^By KARIN MILLER
DOC.TEXT: That Americans are aging should have marketers racing to attract a huge maturing generation, but they're slow to catch on, an author said. ``You've got young creators and they're working from their own value systems,'' said David Wolfe who wrote ``Serving the Ageless Market: Strategies for Selling to the Fifty-Plus Market.'' ions recorded by Ray Charles, Placido Domingo, Elvis Presley, Merle Haggard, Lawrence Welk, the Supremes, Frank Sinatra and about 100 others. And it's not just on radio stations, but every time the song is performed at trade shows, in shopping malls, on elevators and even on airplanes, Preston said. Back when BMI was formed in 1939, ASCAP had a virtual monopoly on song publishing. Broadcasters angered with the royalty rates demanded by ASCAP and the limited number of licensed composers they could play on the air started the company, Eliot described in his book. The new company had an open-door policy for all sorts of musicians that were essentially ignored by ASCAP, including country music, rhythm and blues and, eventually, rock 'n' roll, Preston said. ``They just became a house organ, a scab union in order to gain representation for what ASCAP considered the garbage of the pile,'' Eliot said. ``It turned out to be the cream of the crop.'' BMI signed artists who weren't part of the traditional Tin Pan Alley, such as Leadbelly, Woody Guthrie and Hank Williams in the early years. When rock 'n' roll started, it gave BMI access to a goldmine of hits from Chuck Berry, the Everly Brothers, B.B. King, the Beatles and the Rolling Stones. By the late 1950s, BMI was jokingly referred to in the industry as Big Money Incorporated, Eliot said in ``Rockonomics.'' Today, the two companies compete on almost an even keel, Eliot said. BMI, because it's still more willing to take a chance on unknown artists, still has an advantage in rock and pop music, while ASCAP has the lead in such areas as Broadway and television, he said. ``They've become more conservative, they've become less embattled,'' he said of the two companies. ``They realize there's room at the table for both plates. It's better to exist without a cold war.'' Preston said the constant advance of new technology keeps BMI royalty hunters busy. For instance, the use of music as a motivational tool at trade shows and corporate meetings is a lucrative part of the business that was hardly thought of a decade ago. The increased use of ``sampling'' old riffs in new songs, particularly by rap artists, presents a fascinating new challenge for the publishing companies, Eliot said. In some cases, older artists whose work is being appropriated don't appreciate what the new musicians have done, he said. It's still an open question that may have to be decided by courts. Former members of the '60s rock band the Turtles were furious with rappers De La Soul for using part of their music without permission. MC Hammer recently cut Rick James in on part of the royalties for ``U Can't Touch This,'' which borrows the melody from James' hit, ``Superfreak.'' BMI has planned several events to celebrate its anniversary, including giving a special achievement award to Michael Jackson. But one anniversary commemoration may make music fans envious. The company has produced a three-CD set of some of its best music, including the pop charts and television themes. It's virtually an encyclopedic look at what's been popular for the last 50 years, from the Tommy Dorsey band's ``Opus No. 1'' to the Miami Sound Machine's ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You.'' Don't look for it in stores, however _ the company is just distributing it to people in the industry, politicians and the media. ``I've had so many calls from people asking if they could buy it somewhere,'' she said. ``But it's not for sale.''

DOC.HEAD: UAL Stock Plunges As Confidence in Buyout Wanes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``Stock prices ... at $140.'' to UPDATE with stock down late this morning; pick up 4th graf, ``The United,
DOC.TEXT: The stong headwind from would-be lenders confronting the employee-led group trying to buy United Airlines' parent for $4.38 billion is apparently blowing away investors' confidence in the deal. The price of UAL Corp. stock tumbled more than 13 percent on the New York Stock Exchange in the two days since reports surfaced that banks were balking at lending money for the buyout. Stock prices retreated $6.12{ a share Monday and $16.87{ Tuesday, closing at $140. They had tumbled another $8.50 by late morning today, to $131.50. The United Employee Acquisition Corp., the group formed to accomplish the buyout, said Tuesday night that it was still trying to work out the financing. But the group's statement lacked any expression of hope of success. ``While there remain a number of significant issues to be resolved,'' the statement said, ``we expect to continue to work toward solutions.'' It said the employees also are ``continuing discussions with airframe and engine suppliers and with institutions interested in sale-leaseback transactions.'' With an Aug. 9 deadline for arranging its financing, the employee group could be forced to ask UAL directors for an extension and may have to lower its offer, analysts said. Stephen Dexter, an industry analyst with Kemper Financial Services Inc., said he believes it is highly likely the deadline would be extended. Dexter also said the employee group might have to lower its offer to get banks to lend. The employees need to borrow about $4 billion to complete the deal as proposed. ``The very best odds you can give this deal at this point is 50-50, and that's being pretty generous,'' he said. An earlier proposed $6.75 billion buyout of UAL by the company's pilots, management and British Airways PLC collapsed last October for lack of bank financing. The employee group has asked UAL's aircraft and engine suppliers, including Boeing Co. and General Electric Co., to invest in the proposed deal. The group said Monday it was close to getting help from its suppliers, but the banks reportedly are unhappy that no agreement has been reached. The trade publication American Banker said Tuesday that Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp. representatives did not attend a meeting Friday on possible bank financing. The newspaper also quoted unidentified sources as saying Citicorp had withdrawn for the time being from a bank group negotiating with the employees over financing. The article followed reports Monday from various sources that Chemical Banking Corp. had withdrawn temporarily as a possible lender. The banks and the employee group refused to comment on the report. Chemical, Citicorp and Chase were among five banks that expressed interest early in July in becoming lead lenders for the buyout. The other banks in the group are Bankers Trust New York Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe-Cinema Sold to French Industrial Group
DOC.TEXT: A French industrial group, Chargeurs SA, on Wednesday purchased Pathe-Cinema SA, the film company which Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti tried in vain to buy earlier this year. The acquisition, costing an estimated 1 billion francs, or $180 million, was announced in two stages. First, French stock exchange officials announced that Chargeurs had bought 52.3 percent of Pathe-Cinema for 517 million francs, or $93 million, from four companies within the Rivaud investment group. Later, Parretti's Pathe France Holding, which owned 46.5 percent of Pathe-Cinema, announced it also was selling its shares to Chargeurs. The sale price was not disclosed, but was believed to at the same price per share as the transaction with Rivaud. Trading in Pathe-Cinema shares was suspended following the transaction with Rivaud. There was no indication when trading would resume. The was no immediate indication whether the sale of Pathe-Cinema would affect Parretti's efforts to buy MGM-United Artists in the United States. The Chargeurs deal follows Economics Minister Pierre Beregovoy's decision in June to block Parretti's acquisition of Pathe, saying it ``would be of a nature to disrupt public order.'' Specifically, Beregovoy questioned the source of Parretti's funds, which were linked to a Swiss company, Sasea. If this were the case, he argued, Parretti's group should have sought prior approval from the French government because Switzerland isn't a member of the European Community. The case was viewed as an example of the government's desire to keep a French cultural asset in French hands. Parretti's Pathe France Holding complained that French authorities wanted to combat foreign ownership even though such an attitude contradicted their avowed support for increased economic integration in Western Europe. Pathe-Cinema owns about 150 movie theaters in France and is one of Western Europe's major film distributors. Chargeurs, a diversified industrial group, already had interests in film production and distribution.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Slight Drop in Second-Quarter Income
DOC.TEXT: The Travelers Corp. reported Wednesday a slight drop in second-quarter net income, citing competition that has limited its ability to raise prices, regulatory pressures and disappointing returns on real estate investments. For the quarter ended June 30, the insurance giant reported net income of $102 million, or 98 cents per share, compared to $114 million, or $1.10 per share, for the same period a year ago. Total revenues for the second quarter were $3 billion, down from $3.2 billion a year ago. Net investment income was $892 million, compared to $887 million a year ago. Premiums were $1.9 billion, compared to $2 billion last year. For the first six months of 1990, net income was $193 million, or $1.85 per share, compared to $212 million, or $2.06 per share, for the first half of 1989. Total revenues for the first six months of this year were $6.2 billion, compared to $6.3 billion a year ago. Premiums for the first six months were $4 billion, the same as last year. Net investment income for the first six months was $1.8 billion, also the same as last year. ``Commercial lines profits improved overall as a result of higher realized capital gains in this year's second quarter,'' said Edward H. Budd, chairman and chief executive officer. ``However, very competitive market conditions continue to limit price increases needed to keep pace with loss cost increases.'' The Travelers recently announced that it was withdrawing from personal lines of auto and homeowners insurance in nine states because of regulatory and pricing pressures.

DOC.HEAD: Spending on Construction Unchanged from May to June
With AM-Economy
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending, which had fallen for two straight months, was flat in June, the government reported Wednesday. The Commerce Department said spending on residential, non-residential and government projects totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $447.5 billion after dropping 1.9 percent in April and 0.3 percent in May. The April and May declines were not as severe as first reported. The April figure was revised from 2.2 percent while the May number improved slightly from 0.4 percent. Residential spending was down 2.2 percent for the second consecutive month, to $196.1 billion at an annual rate in June. Single-family building was off 3.5 percent following a 4.0 percent drop in May. Spending on apartment projects was unchanged after rising 1.5 percent the previous month. Some analysts said they expect a slight pickup in residential building but suggested other areas of the construction industry would remain sluggish. David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said residential spending still was feeling the effects of higher mortgage rates earlier this year. The rates, he said, caused sales to drop and builders to put off projects until inventories fell. The average 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage, which had been in the double digits for most of the year, dropped to the 9.98 percent level by last Friday. And the Commerce Department reported on Tuesday that new home sales had jumped 8 percent in June, their second straight increase after five months of declines. Non-residential spending surged 3.9 percent to $107.1 billion at an annual rate, paced by a huge 10.2 percent gain in construction of office buildings. The non-residential segment had fallen 0.9 percent in the previous month. Both Berson and Darryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., expressed surprise at the spending on office buildings and suggested the pace could not be sustained because of widespread vacancies throughout much of the nation. The Federal Reserve estimated earlier this year that the national vacancy rate of downtown office buildings was 16 percent. The often-volatile government sector was off 0.1 percent to $108.4 billion following a 3.8 percent advance in May. ``Given the fiscal situation, we expect this to trend down over the second half of the year,'' Berson said.

DOC.HEAD: Fort Howard Chief Executive Resigns
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Paul J. Schierl, who has battled illness since arranging a management-led buyout of Fort Howard Corp. two years ago, resigned Wednesday as the paper giant's chief executive after 16 years. Donald DeMuse, president of the Green Bay-based company since 1984, was named to succeed Schierl as chief executive. DeMuse will also continue as president, the company said. DeMuse was not available for interviews Wednesday but said in a prepared statement that Schierl was ``the driving force behind the considerable success that Fort Howard Corp. has enjoyed for many years.'' ``His contribution to building the value of the company has been immense. Everyone at Fort Howard will miss him,'' he said. Schierl, who was named chief executive in 1974, led the company through unprecendented growth through the 1980s. Fort Howard's sales grew from $296 million in 1978 to more than $1.7 billion in 1987. In 1988 he led a $3.7 billion management takeover of the company and later orchestrated a partial sale of Fort Howard's profitable paper cup division to a Massachusetts firm, which moved the operations to Chicago. Although the paper cup division sale reduced the company's sales nearly in half, Fort Howard has shown continued growth while concentrating its manufacturing on tissue paper products. Its sales in fiscal 1989 exceeded $1 billion for the first time since the takeover and sale of the paper cup division, company spokesman Clifford A. Bowers said. The 55-year-old Schierl had a heart attack in April 1988 and another one last March. He suffered a stroke while recovering from double bypass surgery in April and has been recovering since he was released from the hospital, the company said. Schierl had met with Fort Howard officials and visited the plant since returning to his suburban Green Bay home from the Cleveland hospital where his surgery was performed, but had not returned to work, company officials said. DeMuse, who joined Fort Howard 23 years ago, was instrumental in the 1988 buyout along with Kathleen J. Hempel, the company's first vice president. Under the buyout, New York-based Morgan Stanley & Co. became the company's majority owner and appointed four members to the Fort Howard board of directors. The company statement said Schierl will continue as a consultant to Morgan Stanley, working on projects unrelated to Fort Howard. Schierl also will remain a member of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago and will be chairman of the Fort Howard Foundation, a charitable arm of the company. Fort Howard employs 6,000 workers at its three plants in Wisconsin, Georgia and Oklahoma.

DOC.HEAD: Media Giant Forms Sports Marketing Company
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. said Wednesday it has formed a new company to coordinate and expand its involvement in sports marketing. Time Warner Sports will be headed by Seth G. Abraham, who the company said helped build sports programming for its pay TV service, Home Box Office. Time Warner said the new sports company will coordinate and broaden the sports rights agreements currently held by the parent company's magazine, cable, pay television, home video, licensing and book groups. The $11 billion media and entertainment giant estimated its sports-related activities generate more than $750 million a year in revenue. Time Warner publishes Sports Illustrated and SI for Kids magazines, carries sports events on its HBO cable channel and on HBO Video cassettes, and licenses sports properties. Additionally, Time Warner said its new sports company would develop new sports businesses across the corporation by acquiring sports rights and building on the company's products and sports relationships. It is expected the new company will explore new businesses such as developing syndicated TV programming, regional networks and pay-per-view ventures, talent management and the creation of sports events. Asked if the new company was created to buy a sports franchise such as a major league baseball team, Abraham said that was not part of the company's immediate plans although he would not rule it out over the longer term. He said its mission was to create a corporate sports strategy that would take advantage of the sports ventures which various Time Warner divisions pursue on their own. Abraham cited the company's current affilation with heavyweight boxer Mike Tyson as an example of the possibilities he will pursue. HBO owns the rights to cover several Tyson boxing matches. In the future, Abraham said Time Warner Sports may seek to sign Tyson for publishing, pay-per-view TV and home video deals as well as to cover his fights on HBO. In a statement, the Time Warner co-chief executives, Steven J. Ross and Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., said Time Warner Sports will play ``a major role in the corporation's strategy of globalization, because sport is a universal form of entertainment.'' Abraham, 42, joined HBO in 1978 as director of sports operations. He most recently had overseeen sports, scheduling, promotion, talent relations and public realtions for HBO and its sister pay TV network Cinemax.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Airline Revenue Helps Narrow Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp. on Wednesday reported a net loss of $49 million for the second quarter, about half the size of last year's $101 million second-quarter shortfall from continuing operations. The New York-based holding company for Pan American World Airways attributed the narrower deficit mainly to sharply higher airline revenue. Pam Am's loss for the three months ended June 30 declined to 33 cents a share from 69 cents a share a year earlier. Total corporate revenue rose 12.2 percent to $1.02 billion from $909.4 million in 1989's second quarter. The corporation had an operating loss of $8.6 million for the second quarter, down from $49.6 million in the second quarter of last year. ``We are encouraged by our second-quarter results, not only by the substantial improvement over last year, but by the improving trends we recorded during the quarter,'' said Thomas G. Plaskett, Pan Am chairman and chief executive officer. Revenue from scheduled air passenger services grew 16.7 percent to $830.8 million from $711.9 million. ``Pan Am reported the highest scheduled passenger revenues ever recorded by the airline in the second quarter, and in the month of June, we showed our first net profit in any month since August of 1988,'' Plaskett said. For the first half of the year, Pan Am had a net loss of $239.7 million or $1.61 a share, smaller than $255.9 million or $1.76 a share through the first two quarters of 1989. The corporation's operating loss amounted to $158.6 million in the first half, down from $178.3 million a year earlier. Operating revenue rose 13.6 percent in the first half to $1.87 billion from $1.64 billion.

The stock market recorded some spotty losses today as investors studied new signs of sluggishness in business activity. The Commerce Department reported that the index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in June, rather than posting the small increase many analysts had been expecting. Separately, a monthly report from the National Association of Purchasing Management showed a marked dropoff in its measure of activity in the manufacturing sector of the economy. Those developments reinforced expectations in the financial world that business growth was likely to remain meager at best in the near future. In that environment, hopes have flagged on Wall Street for any impending improvement in corporate earnings. But at the same time, interest rates have moved lower of late. In today's credit market activity, prices of long-term government bonds rose about $5 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.35 percent-8.37 percent range.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Tumble Amid Slack Demand; Favorable Weather
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as the market's focus returned to bearish factors such as slack export demand and favorable U.S. growing weather. The wheat market led the way down on indications that foreign demand remains weak. Soybean futures also fell steeply, erasing the modest gains posted in the two previous sessions. Strength in the cash soybean market, which recently provided support to futures, continued on Wednesday. But that indicator of domestic demand was overshadowed by a lack of export interest. ``I'm not saying there's no demand, but there's not enough to hold beans at $6 or so,'' said Gerald Zusel, manager of floor operations at the exchange for Balfour Maclaine Corp. Weather forecasts projected a continuation of beneficial conditions for corn and soybean development in the Midwest. At the close, wheat futures were 3 cents to 7{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.81\ a bushel; corn was 4{ cents to 5{ cents lower with September at $2.55{ a bushel; oats were 5{ cents to 6} cents lower with September at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 9 cents to 15 cents lower with August at $5.84 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Two Quebec Paper Mills Still Struck
DOC.TEXT: Workers at two paper mills in Quebec remained on strike Wednesday with no signs that the walkouts would end soon. About 1,200 workers walked off the job Saturday at Quebec and Ontario Paper Co. in Baie-Comeau, Que., while 420 workers struck Thursday at James MacLaren Industries in Masson, Que., after the companies rejected a union request for 20 percent more vacation pay and a reduction in work hours. The two companies belong to the four-member Eastern Canada Newsprint Group, which has bargained jointly for more than three decades but has become splintered lately. The two other companies in the 3,300-employee group _ Daishowa Paper Mfg. Co. Ltd. in Quebec City and Domtar Inc. in Dolbeau _ have accepted the demands of locals of the Canadian Paperworkers Union. However, MacLaren has said it wants to bargain separately with its workers, while the union has said it will only bargain with the company as part of the group, MacLaren spokesman Normand Chenail said. The unions are striking over local issues. Central bargaining by the group was expected to begin later this month on the basis of a model settlement reached by the union with another company, Stone-Consolidated Inc. The agreement, which won only 56.4 percent approval from 2,300 Stone workers in eastern Quebec, calls for annual wage increases of 5.5 per cent over three years. I return, the union agreed to let mills operate on two holidays and allow repairmen perform a variety of tasks on night shifts. Many workers were angry that the contract broke little new ground in areas including job security and overtime. The two strike-bound companies and the union said they will pay close attention to what happens during negotiations involving 4,000 workers at the larger Canadian Pacific Ltd., which begin this week. Neither MacLaren, which produces 180,000 tons of newsprint annually, nor Quebec and Ontario Paper, which produces 450,000 tons annually, said they have any stockpiles. Both companies supply American newspapers, but it was not immediately known what publications might be affected by the walkout.
