DOC.HEAD: Insurance Company, Mutual Fund Announce Purchase
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co. said Wednesday it will jointly acquire Oppenheimer Management Corp. from British & Commonwealth Holdings PLC for approximately $150 million. MassMutual, the nation's 11th largest life insurance company, said it and senior management of Oppenheimer plan to acquire the New York-based Oppenheimer, which is one of the nation's biggest mutual fund companies. The purchase is subject to approval of the mutual funds' independent directors and the funds' shareholders, said Joseph Mondy, MassMutual spokesman. Under the proposed agreement, Oppenheimer Management would continue to operate independently and retain key management. The change of ownership would not affect shareholders' investments in mutual funds managed by Oppenheimer Management, MassMutual said in a prepared statement. The proposed acquisition will further MassMutual's venture into mutual funds, which the company introduced in 1988 with the MassMutual Integrity Funds, Mondy said. ``What we're buying are funds with a long and well-known track record. Because of that we want to keep it as a separate entity,'' he said. Both companies also are looking to increase their involvement overseas, he said. MassMutual was established in 1851. Its 1989 gain before dividends reached $612 million, a 12 percent increase over 1988. Dividends for 1989 totaling $489 million were distributed to about 1.6 million policyholders. Oppenheimer manages more than 50 mutual funds with assets of more than $14 billion and more than 1.2 million shareholder accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Transamerica Reports Dip In Profits, Cites Lower Capital Gains
DOC.TEXT: Transamerica Corp. on Wednesday reported a 5 percent drop in second-quarter profits, attributing the dip to an expected lower level in capital gains. Transamerica reported net income of $86.5 million or $1.08 per share for the three-month period that ended June 30, compared to $91.2 million or $1.15 per share for the same period of 1989. Revenues for the second quarter were $1.67 billion, down slightly from $1.69 billion in 1989. But the financial services company also said strong performances in its life insurance, consumer lending and real estate service businesses boosted income from operations 11 percent during the first half of the year. Earnings for the first six months of the year declined 3 percent, from $162 million or $2.04 a share in the 1989 period to $156.8 million or $1.96 a share. Revenues for the six months that ended June 30, 1990 were $3.3 billion, up slightly from $3.28 billion for the same period last year. Last year's first-half results included $30 million, or 40 cents per share, in investment gains, one-third of it from the sale of warrants in the divestiture of Budget Rent a Car, Transamerica said.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Surge
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices rallied Wednesday amid buying inspired by reports of political tension in the Middle East. Trading was hectic on the New York Mercantile Exchange, especially after the near-month crude contract swept past $21 a barrel. The contract for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, settled at $21.54 per 42-gallon barrel, up 85 cents on the day and bringing its gain over the past two sessions to $1.33. Contracts for delivery during October through December also advanced strongly. Refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc followed the crude lead and settled sharply higher. Unleaded gasoline for September delivery climbed 1.81 cents to 64.27 cents a gallon, more than making up for Tuesday's loss of 0.28 cent. Later contracts also posted significant gains. The September home heating oil contract, which added 0.18 cent on Wednesday, soared 2.84 cents to 61.19 a gallon. The October, November and December contracts jumped ahead, too. Meanwhile, in natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.402 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.411 on Wednesday. The later contracts were mixed. Energy analysts said unconfirmed reports of Iraqi troop movements within Kuwaiti territory encouraged buyers. James Steel of Refco Inc. said traders have been speculating that Iraq might seize certain Kuwaiti oilfields because it disagrees that the fields should be under Kuwait's ownership. Steel said indications that some influential OPEC members are taking steps to abide by a new oil production agreement also supported prices. The output-cutting accord reached by the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at a meeting last week in Geneva has lifted oil prices on world markets in recent days. Other bullish supply and demand factors lent a positive tone to the energy market. A report that South Korea's crude oil imports rose 19 percent in the first six months of the year from 1989's first half suggested that Asian demand may be stronger than previously thought, Steel said. A moderately bearish weekly report from the American Petroleum Institute released late Tuesday after the market closed appeared to be largely ignored by traders. It showed virtually unchanged refinery runs.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Forming New Company for Low-Tech Product Lines; Job Cuts Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs `Wall Street ...' with closing stock price.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Acting to free resources to focus on its main high- technology businesses, IBM on Wednesday announced it will place its typewriter, keyboard and certain printer operations into a new company in which it will retain a minority interest. A firm specializing in buyouts, Clayton & Dubilier Inc., will acquire the majority stake in the new firm. Executives of International Business Machines Corp. and Clayton & Dubilier said in interviews that negotiations on a final agreement are expected to conclude by the end of the year. Until then, they said, no information will be disclosed on how much Clayton & Dubilier will pay IBM or what size stake it will acquire. Industry analysts have estimated that the businesses would be worth $2.5 billion to $3 billion. The preliminary agreement calls for the new company to include the U.S. portions of IBM's Information Products business. Eventually, the rest of the worldwide operation will be melded into the alliance with Clayton & Dubilier, said IBM Vice President Marvin L. Mann, who will become the company's chief executive officer. Mann said in an interview that the company's businesses, made up largely of IBM facilities in Lexington, Ky., and Boulder, Colo., will do better on their own than they would remaining within IBM. ``Under IBM, this business has not had the highest of priorities,'' he said. ``IBM is less in the business of selling products and more in the business of selling solutions and total systems.'' Traditional typewriters have been elbowed out of offices by fancier machines capable of a broader range of functions, noted Barbara Otto, spokeswoman for the Cleveland-based group 9 to 5, National Association of Working Women. But Mann said there still is money to be made in typewriters. Supplying products like typing elements for the vast number of IBM Selectric and other machines already in offices is lucrative. ``The typewriter business is not a growing business but it's a profitable business and it's still quite a substantial business in size,'' he said. And the new company will go beyond typewriters. It will manufacture and supply keyboards for IBM and other companies' workstations. It will develop and market intermediate and personal printers and supplies. Mann said the printer and keyboard business is expanding rapidly. The IBM offspring would rank within the top 200 of the Fortune 500 list of the country's largest corporations based on annual revenue, Mann said. Wall Street took the announcement in stride because there has been widespread publicity about IBM's intention to reconfigure itself. IBM stock added 12{ cents closing at $111.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Steps are being taken to assure that employees are treated fairly, Mann said. The new company is expected to reduce its work force by 1,200, with 3,500 to 4,000 employees by the end of the year. Including operations outside the United States, the company would have 5,000 employees. The anticipated job cuts will be accomplished through a program of voluntary resignation and early retirement. Eligible employees in Lexington will be offered the opportunity to resign, retire or begin a five-year pre-retirement leave with incentive payments. IBM said the program will be consistent with its long-standing ``full employment policy'' of no layoffs. Since the mid-1980s when growth in the computer industry began to slow, IBM has pared its payroll through plant consolidations and voluntary early retirements. The buyout firm figuring in IBM's plans has had experience in lower-end technology businesses. Since it was formed in 1978, Clayton & Dubelier has acquired 15 businesses with combined sales of $7.5 billion. The New York-based firm has made it a practice to avoid unfriendly maneuvers, preferring to work in partnership with the management of the businesses it acquires. Chairman Martin H. Dubilier said substantial investments will be made in the IBM company to broaden its product line, bolster marketing efforts and strengthen the distribution network. IBM will maintain an equity holding in the new company for an indefinite period of time, said James J. Forese, IBM vice president of finance. He said the deal will not have a material impact on IBM's earnings. Forese said the new company will continue to use the IBM logo for about three to five years before gradually making a transition to its own. In seven to 10 years, its products will carry a new logo. Formation of the new subsidiary is a key element of IBM's strategy to stay on the cutting edge of the computer and software industry, the company said. ``It will fundamentally let us focus on our core business,'' Forese said. ``When we looked at what's on our plate from a competitive standpoint, we thought the information services business would be better off on its own.''

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Announces Financing Plans
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury tentatively plans to borrow a quarterly record $32.25 billion from the public next week in a series of debt auctions to replenish the government's coffers, it announced Wednesday. But Undersecretary Robert Glauber emphasized the auction would be contingent upon congressional assurance that it would enact legislation by Monday raising the federal debt limit above the current $3.12 trillion ceiling. ``We are offering $32.25 billion of notes and bonds to refund $20.0 billion of privately held notes maturing on Aug. 15 and to raise approximately $12.25 billion of cash,'' Glauber said. The $32.25 billion would surpass the previous record of $30.5 billion in notes and bonds sold last May. Glauber said the auctions next week would include: _$11.50 billion in three-year notes in minimum denominations of $5,000 to be sold on Tuesday. _$10.50 billion in 10-year notes in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be auctioned on Wednesday, and, _$10.25 billion in 30-year bonds in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be offered on Thursday. Also on Thursday, the Treasury will auction $10 billion in 36-day cash management bills in minimum denominations of $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar regained some ground in foreign exchange Wednesday, but traders warned that the U.S. currency remained weak. Gold prices also moved higher. Analysts said the dollar's advance appeared to be a technical correction as traders took profits on foreign currencies that have surged higher against the dollar during the past week. The dollar has fallen sharply amid increasing signs that the U.S. economy is weakening and amid speculation that the Federal Reserve will be forced to lower interest rates to stimulate business activity. The dollar is supported by higher rates, so a move by the Fed to push rates down would also bring the U.S. currency lower. Further evidence of an economic slowdown came Wednesday from the monthly index issued by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which fell to 47.4 in July from 51.1 in June. The decline indicated a slowing of the manufacturing sector. Analysts said currencies with higher interest rates _ especially those in Europe _ remain strong against the dollar, and they are not expected to decline in the near future. The dollar recovered some ground against the British pound Wednesday. Sterling fell to $1.8552 in New York from $1.8635 late Tuesday. In earlier London trading, one British pound cost $1.8550, down from $1.8595 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.58885 West German marks, up from 1.58555; 1.3540 Swiss francs, up from 1.34475; 5.3240 French francs, up from 5.3195; 1,162.75 Italian lire, up from 1,162.00; and 1.15275 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15165. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5920 West German marks, up from 1.5875; 1.3555 Swiss francs, up from 1.3475; 5.3355 French francs, up from 5.3210; 1.7935 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7880; 1,164.75 Italian lire, up from 1,162.00, and 1.1530 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1523. The dollar also rose to 147.30 Japanese yen in New York from 145.835 on Tuesday. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar fell to 146.65 yen from 147.50 Tuesday, and in London it was quoted at 147.20 yen. Gold rose in New York, closing at $373.30 a troy ounce, up $3.30 from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $373.50, also up $3.30 from Tuesday. In London earlier, gold was quoted at a late bid of $374.30 per troy ounce, up from $372.05 late Tuesday. Zurich's market was closed for a holiday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $2.04 to close at $371.46 per ounce. Silver picked up 3.5 cents to close at $4.822 on the Commodity Exchange. Silver traded in London at a bid of $4.82 a troy ounce, up 3 cents from late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Push for Aid to Workers Hit by Defense Cuts, Environmental Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, deleting duplicated time element and recasting slightly. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats proposed a $5 billion program Wednesday to help workers who lose their jobs because of defense cuts or environmental rules designed to clean the air and protect the spotted owl. Touching off an immediate and heated debate with Republicans and Bush administration officials, Reps. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., and Pete Stark, D-Calif., unveiled legislation to provide extra unemployment and health benefits to families affected by the policy changes. The proposal is specifically aimed at defense workers, including military people, laid off because of Pentagon spending cuts, along with loggers idled by the effort to preserve the spotted owl and its forest habitat, and coal miners left above ground by tougher clean-air laws. ``We owe it to them to provide the assistance they need,'' said Downey as he convened a hearing of the House Ways and Means human resources committee. The Downey-Stark proposal would cost more than $5 billion over five years and would provide extra unemployment and health benefits to about 200,000 workers _ far fewer, Downey noted, than the number expected to be displaced. ``I think it's inadequate. It should cover more people,'' Downey said. ``But we don't have the votes.'' Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., called the measure to ``a domestic Marshall plan,'' akin to the post-war European reconstruction program financed by the United States. Republicans, even some from states that would benefit from the proposal, immediately criticized the legislation as unfair to unemployed workers who lose their jobs for reasons unrelated to federal policy but who are no less needy. Republican Rep. Rod Chandler, whose home state of Washington faces job losses due to the new spotted owl policy, called the legislation an ``ill-conceived, hastily slapped together proposal'' that would burden the Medicaid system with the extra health benefits. ``It leaves out those who have lost their jobs due to other causes,'' Chandler said. ``Are they not worthy too?'' Republicans on the subcommittee also made clear their concern that the program would drain scarce federal revenue. Downey and Stark proposed financing the measure through continuance of a 0.2 percent federal unemployment tax which is due to expire this year. The Bush administration also piled on, saying that existing programs already provide adequate job retraining and jobless benefits. Labor Department administrator James Van Erden said the Bush administration ``believes that singling out certain groups of workers for special treatment based on the cause of their dislocation is inequitable and inappropriate.'' Despite the GOP criticism, the idea of helping workers hurt by government policies has gained considerable support on Capitol Hill since last March when the Senate narrowly rejected a proposal by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va. Byrd's plan would have provided hefty unemployment benefits to coal miners laid off if tougher clean air standards led to reduced coal burning. Since then, new and increasingly elaborate measures have been proposed to provide extra jobless benefits but to a larger pool of workers than West Virginia's coal miners. ``The Byrd amendment was a much bigger entitlement and a much smaller population _ which was the problem,'' said William Cunningham, a lobbyist for the AFL-CIO and a supporter of the Downey-Stark proposal. ``This is not geographic. ``It is actually governmental actions that are causing these job dislocations. The number of regions involved have to be taken into account.'' Sens. Joseph Lieberman and Christopher Dodd, both Connecticut Democrats, proposed legislation last week that would cost about $1 billion a year and would include a provision ensuring that laid-off defense workers get at least a substantial fraction of their former salaries while unemployed. A separate House proposal designed to ease the burden of defense cuts would cost an estimated $200 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: National Steel Corp. Reports Sharp Drop in Earnings
DOC.TEXT: National Steel Corp. said Wednesday its second-quarter earnings plunged 66 percent because of large numbers of equipment overhauls. The country's fifth largest steel maker reported profits of $13.1 million, compared with $32.4 million for the second period of 1989. Sales for the quarter ended June 30 were $655.9 million, compared with $674 million in the year-ago period, the company said. Kokichi Hagiwara, the company's chairman and chief executive, said the equipment shutdowns were required to modernize and maintain key steel finishing facilities. ``These planned outages kept us from fully capitalizing on the improving business climate,'' Hagiwara said in a statement. Ronald Doerr, National Steel's president, repeated earlier projections that the company's markets will continue to improve during the second half of the year. ``We are experiencing strengthened demand in the automotive, can, pipe and tube markets,'' Doerr said in a statement. ``Some softness still exists in the construction market, but this condition should improve as the year progresses.'' National Steel is not publicly traded. It operates as a joint venture owned equally by National Intergroup Inc. and NKK Corp. of Japan. Net income in the first half of 1990 was $8.9 million, down 79 percent from income of $42.2 million in the 1989 period.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Stock Down Again; Signs of Stability
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. stock continued dropping Wednesday as investors showed more skepticism that a $4.38 billion employee-led buyout would succeed. UAL, which fell a total of $23 on Monday and Tuesday, finished down another $4 at $136 a share Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock traded at $131 a share at one point during the session. The stock has dropped in the wake of reports that banks were balking at loaning money for the $201 a share buyout offer, with an Aug. 9 deadline approaching the employee group to arrange financing. Several airline analysts said they expected the stock price to stay in the $130 to $140 range until there was concrete information that the deal had fallen through, that financing had been arranged or that the acquisition group had requested an extension of the deadline. ``Once it seems to find a bottom, the price will bounce back somewhat,'' said Robert Decker, an analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago. ``There's always investors willing to step up to the plate and pick it up at what appears to be'' a low price that will rise. The acquisition group stated Tuesday that it was trying to secure financing, but gave no indication of how the process was going. Officials for the group did not immediately return a telephone call on Wednesday. Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Corp. and Chemical Banking Corp. _ members of a group that had expressed interest in being the lead bank lenders for the deal _ reportedly have balked at providing money because of concerns that the buyout relies too heavily on debt. The other banks in the group are Bankers Trust New York Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp. The banks and the employee group have refused to comment on the report. Spokespeople for Citibank and Bankers Trust again refused to comment on Wednesday, while the other banks did not immediately return telephone calls. Several analysts said it appeared the acquisition group would not be able to meet the Aug. 9 deadline, given the apparent reluctance of banks and concerns about the use of leveraged buyouts. ``The timing is not right,'' said Mark Daugherty, an analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. ``They're trying to jam something through that the market is not ready to let through.'' A proposed $6.75 billion buyout of UAL by the company's pilots, management and British Airways PLC collapsed last October when banks refused to finance the deal.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to CORRECT change and close on Dow industrials. UPDATES with closing prices, advances and declines throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Worries about economic growth in general and the banking industry in particular combined to push stock prices lower in an erratic session Wednesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 5.94 to 2,899.26. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 733 up, 777 down and 524 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 176.81 million shares, against 173.81 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 216.03 million shares. The Commerce Department reported that the index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in June, rather than posting the small increase many analysts had been expecting. Separately, a monthly report from the National Association of Purchasing Management showed a marked dropoff in its measure of activity in the manufacturing sector of the economy. Those developments reinforced expectations in the financial world that business growth was likely to remain meager at best in the near future. In that environment, hopes have flagged on Wall Street for any impending improvement in corporate earnings. But at the same time, interest rates have moved lower of late. In today's credit market activity, prices of long-term government bonds rose about $5 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to the 8.35 percent-8.37 percent range. Bank stocks were broadly lower, depressed by worries cited in a Wall Street Journal article about continuing pressures on profits in the industry. Citicorp fell } to 19]; Chemical Banking 1 to 22; Manufacturers Hanover 1 to 29{; J.P. Morgan ~ to 37[, and BankAmerica } to 24. By contrast, Eastman Kodak was a standout gainer, jumping 4\ to 42] and ranking as the most active Big Board stock. The company reported second-quarter earnings of $1.19 a share, up from 24 cents in the corresponding period last year. UAL tumbled 4[ to 135~ after taking a 16~-point drop Tuesday, amid reports that at least three banks have withdrawn temporarily from financing plans for a proposed buyout of the airline holding company. Energy stocks, still responding to signs of upward pressure on oil prices, continued to dominate the list of new 52-week highs. British Petroleum rose 1\ to 75}; Exxon \ to 52[; Schlumberger 1[ to 66{; Hallibuton } to 55|, and Atlantic Richfield 1[ to 130{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $6.57 billion, or 0.19 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .22 to 194.38. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell .76 to 419.84, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down .63 at 355.52. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 2.33 to 435.91. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 353.30, down .30.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Tensions Boost Oil, Gold Futures
DOC.TEXT: Reports of heightened tensions in the two-week-old dispute between Iraq and Kuwait helped boost gold and petroleum futures prices Wednesday as fears of a crude-oil supply disruption swept through the trading pits. On other commodity markets, copper futures soared; grains and soybeans were sharply lower; and livestock and meat futures also fell. In a non-trading development, Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann resigned amid federal allegations of wrongdoing at the trading firm he headed. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 32 cents to 85 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September up 85 cents at $21.54 a barrel; wholesale heating oil was 1.85 cents to 2.84 cents higher with September at 61.19 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline was 1.81 cents to 2 cents higher with September at 64.27 cents a gallon. Energy analysts said unconfirmed reports of Iraqi troop movements within Kuwaiti territory encouraged buyers. James Steel of Refco Inc. said traders have been speculating that Iraq might seize certain Kuwaiti oilfields because it disagrees that the fields should be under Kuwait's ownership. Steel said indications that some influential OPEC members are taking steps to abide by a new oil production agreement also supported prices. Gold and silver futures also rose on the Iraq-Kuwait news, reflecting not only the inflationary effects of higher oil prices but also the tendency among investors to seek the safety of precious metals during times of international conflict. Peter Cardillo, director of commodity research at Jesup, Josephthal & Co., said gold also benefitted from strength in the bond market Wednesday. ``Higher bond prices means lower interest rates. Lower interest rates in turn are positive for the precious metals,'' he said. Gold futures settled $3.30 to $3.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with August at $373.30 a troy ounce; silver was 3.2 cents to 3.5 cents higher with August at $4.822 a troy ounce. Copper futures surged on the Commodity Exchange on buying that some analysts linked to tight supplies of scrap copper. But others said the move was not justified by market fundamentals and the copper market is due for a downward correction. Copper settled 2.6 cents to 4.25 cents higher with August at $1.292 a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade as the market's focus returned to bearish factors such as slack export demand and favorable U.S. growing weather. The wheat market led the way down on indications that foreign demand remains weak, despite the Agriculture Department's announcement of a sale of nearly 248,000 metric tons to China at subsidized prices. Weather forecasts projected a continuation of beneficial conditions for corn and soybean development in the Midwest. After the close, the National Weather Service issued a forecast for mild temperatures and normal precipitation in the region during the latter half of next week. Wheat futures settled 4 cents to 7{ cents lower with September at $2.81\ a bushel; corn was 4} cents to 6 cents lower with September at $2.55{ a bushel; oats were 5} cents to 6} cents lower with September at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 9 cents to 15 cents lower with August at $5.85 a bushel. The Board of Trade's announcement of Mahlmann's resignation followed by one day the filing of a civil complaint in U.S. District Court by federal regulators alleging fraudulent use by Mahlmann's company, Stotler Group Inc., of $5.6 million in customer funds. Mahlmann, who also has resigned from Stotler, said he played no part in the allegedly improper transactions. Livestock and meat futures tumbled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with weaker cash cattle markets, large hog slaughter numbers and expectations of weaker demand in the weeks ahead. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .80 cent lower with August at 77.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent to .80 cent lower with August at 89.47 cents a pound; live hogs were .42 cent to 1.17 cents lower with August at 60.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower across the board with August at 49.22 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Report Shows Manufacturing Economy Weakening
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The association's... to CORRECT index to 47.4 percent to 47.7 percent; PICKS UP 6th graf, `The index...
DOC.TEXT: In another sign of sluggishness in the nation's economy, businesses in July slashed orders for manufactured goods and reduced inventories, the National Association of Purchasing Management said Wednesday. It was the first drop in the group's measurement of the manufacturing sector in three months and gave further weight to a belief the nation's economy may be slipping into a recession. A measurement of activity by chief purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies tumbled in July to its lowest rate since January, in its sharpest monthly decline since January 1984. ``It reflects a weakening manufacturing sector, so the cutting edge is getting dull,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities International Inc. ``Businessmen are going to become even more cautious.'' The association's Purchasing Managers Index fell to 47.4 percent in July from 51.1 percent the previous month, ending three months of increases. A reading below 50 indicates the manufacturing economy generally is declining. The index, a composite of survey results on order levels, prices, inventory and other areas, had been below 50 for 11 straight months. It averaged 48.8 percent in the first seven months of 1990. July's reading was the lowest since 45.2 percent in January. The decline was the sharpest since the index fell about nine percentage points in early 1984, economists said. Orders from manufacturers tumbled to 46.2 percent from 54.9 percent in June. The rate was the lowest since January ``and will undoubtedly weaken, if not decrease the recent modest growth in production,'' the association said. The group's production index was above 50 for the sixth straight month, but fell to 52.1 percent from 53.9 percent. It was the lowest level in five months. Inventories declined for the 20th straight month, at a pace sharper than the previous month. The group's inventories index fell to 39.3 percent from 42.9 percent in June as purchasers cut the volume of July orders and used existing inventories. ``The sharp decline in new orders apparently caused purchasers to reduce the quantity of purchases and work off existing inventories,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee. ``The weakness of new orders in July now casts a shadow over the previous expectations for continued growth in the economy in the third quarter,'' he said. Bond prices, which improve on news of economic softening, surged after the report was issued. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond finished up more than $6.50 per $1,000 in face value, with its yield tumbling to 8.35 percent from 8.41 percent late Tuesday. Some economists play down the significance of the purchasing managers report because manufacturing accounts for only about 20 percent of economic activity. But others said manufacturing is a leading indicator of overall business activity, and that even the service sector has shown signs of weakness. ``I think it's telling us the economy is weak again and businesses are making an effort to reduce inventories,'' said Robert Chandross, chief economist with Lloyds Bank PLC in New York. In other segments, the report said export orders increased while imports declined for the third consecutive month. Prices for manufacturing products, which include metals, textiles, sulfur, lumber and fuels, held steady, indicating no movement in inflation. Employment decreased for the 17th straight month, at a slightly lesser rate than in June.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS six grafs with House looking into Stotler, background on Mahlmann, O'Connor; NO PICKUP
DOC.HEAD: CBOT Chief Quits Stotler
DOC.TEXT: Karsten Mahlmann resigned Wednesday as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest commodity futures exchange, amid charges of wrongdoing at the trading company he headed. Mahlmann, who is midway through an unprecedented fourth term as the CBOT's chief, said he was stepping down ``in the overwhelming interest of the Board of Trade and because of my deep love and respect for the institution,'' according to a statement issued by the exchange's board of directors. The board said it regretfully accepted the resignation, which was effective immediately, ``in respect for his wishes and out of the respect and love he has for the Board of Trade.'' The board said it had elected CBOT Vice Chairman William F. O'Connor to serve the remainder of Mahlmann's one-year term, which ends Dec. 31. Earlier Wednesday, Mahlmann announced his resignation as head of Stotler Group Inc., a beleaguered commodities firm that operates a subsidiary accused of violating the Commodity Exchange Act. Mahlmann stressed in that announcement his ``non-involvement in the day-to-day affairs'' of Stotler Group and its affiliates. ``I have had no day-to-day management responsibilities since early 1988, and my position at Stotler was constantly eroded,'' Mahlmann said. ``I simply was not a party to the financial decisions which are now being scrutinized by the exchange and the regulators,'' Mahlmann said. Mahlmann's resignation comes a day after federal regulators filed a civil complaint in U.S. District Court against a Stotler subsidiary, Stotler Funds Inc., a commodity pool operator owned by Stotler Group. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission alleges that Stotler Funds improperly used pools of clients' money that had been set up for investing in commodity futures contracts. Stotler Funds instead used about 80 percent of one pool's assets _ about $4.55 million _ to invest in Stotler Group, the government said. Stotler Funds also lent $1 million from another pool to its parent company. The complaint seeks a court order to stop these practices and seeks the appointment of a temporary equity receiver. The complaint comes on the heels of other problems for Stotler Group. Last week, it announced that its principal subsidiary, the Stotler and Co. futures brokerage firm, would be shut down after failing to meet minimum capital requirements. Mahlmann, who said he remains Stotler Group's largest shareholder, said had he been aware of Stotler's recent financial decisions, ``I would not have condoned them, and I would have taken action to reverse them.'' Mahlmann and other Stotler officials did not return phone calls Wednesday for further comment. Mahlmann was serving his fourth one-year term as chairman. His term would have expired in January. Some CBOT members believed Stotler's woes had damaged his leadership abilities at the exchange, and they called for him to resign, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division at Chicago-based Gerald Inc., an exchange member. Frazier said the members' concern was that the Stotler predicament had hurt Mahlmann's ability to lead the CBOT's battle over regulation of the futures industry. The exchange wants the CFTC to maintain control over stock-index futures, but the Bush adminstration is seeking to transfer that authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees the stock market. Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., said Wednesday the House Energy and Commerce Committee would look ``into the facts and circumstances surrounding the recent collapse of Stotler & Co.'' Dingell, the committee's chairman said ``these events raise serious questions about the adequacy of regulation and oversight in the futures industry.'' Dingell's comments came in a letter to the heads of the SEC and the CFTC. Mahlmann began working as a runner at the exchange in 1957, shortly after graduation from high school in his native Germany. He became a member of the CBOT in 1963, after work in its cash grains department had earned him the nickname ``Cash.'' He became director of the exchange in 1983, vice chairman in 1986, and was first elected chairman in 1987. He beat Leslie Rosenthal, a former CBOT chairman, in a close election in January. O'Connor has been a member of the CBT since 1955, and is a partner in O'Connor and Co., which he founded in 1957. Elected CBOT vice chairman in 1990, O'Connor is also vice chairman of the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange, an affiliate of the CBOT.

DOC.HEAD: Violence in Trinidad Concerns Caribbean Tourist Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 16 `He said' to make it `Sweeney said...' Picks up 17th pvs, `The major...' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Trinidad, moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Caribbean tourism industry watched developments in Trinidad carefully this week, aware that violence on one island can hurt business throughout the region. ``I hope they get this resolved quickly. The longer it goes on, the worse it will look to the traveling public,'' said Clive Banfield, Delta Air Lines marketing manager. The Caribbean Tourism Organization has sent telegrams to travel agencies saying other Caribbean countries were safe. Barbara LeBlanc, a writer for the daily San Juan Star newspaper, observed that even the hint of danger drives away tourists looking for a ``fantasy'' island. ``The international tourist's knowledge of democracy is awfully small. There is very little doubt that problems like this hurt the region,'' said John Bell, executive vice president of the Caribbean Hotel Association. Bell said it was fortunate the Moslem uprising and looting in Trinidad happened during the summer slow period. The prime winter season is five months away. Hotelier Jag Mehta, manager of San Juan's Radisson Normandie Hotel, said Puerto Rico will escape the fallout from the negative publicity and could benefit from tourists looking for safer places to visit. ``It's too far from us. Fortunately, The New York Times and other newspapers showed maps. So people know where the problem was,'' he said. Airports were closed Friday evening on the twin islands of Trinidad and Tobago and did not re-open until Sunday, and then only during daylight hours. Some airlines canceled flights to the islands until conditions returned to normal. Trinidad's 22-hour curfew, 6 p.m. to 12 noon daily, tied up traffic between the Piarco international airport and Tobago's Crown Point airport, said Noel Sweeney, director of the Trinidad and Tobago Tourism Development Authority. Interviewed by telephone, Sweeney said a flight was leaving Wednesday with about 100 tourists who were stranded on Tobago after their vacations ended. Dallas Vonortengren of Kawana Travel in New York said the disruptions in flight schedules made it difficult to get tourists out of the area. ``The situation is much too unstable to advise travelers to go there,'' she said. The violence is likely to set back Trinidad and Tobago's efforts to develop tourism, particularly on the island of Tobago. The country's economy, dominated by the oil industry, is in a slump because of low world oil prices. The government has earmarked increased tourism as one new source of employment and foreign exchange earnings. Sweeney said 218,000 people visited Trinidad and Tobago in 1989, including about 29,000 cruise ship visitors. The major tourist attraction in Trinidad is the annual Carnival, which the Caribbean Islands Handbook says some consider ``safer, more welcoming to visitors and artistically more stimulating than its nearest rival in Rio de Janeiro.'' Neighboring Tobago has a world famous reef, Buccoo Reef, known for its spectacular fish, diving and clear warm waters.
